description:
Simply put: go here, bring your friends, you're going to have an amazing experience. Phillip, one of the owners of Olea, happened to be our waiter and from start to finish was kind, funny, informative, and beyond helpful. 

We decided to go to Olea because THEY TAKE RESERVATIONS which is so important on a Sunday brunch in SF. No wait for our table and we got to sit outside in the beautiful sunlit weather. 

Here's what we had around the table: chillaquiles, cazuela, custard toast, pork belly sandwich, huevos rancheros. We all sampled and tasted the foods at the table and everything was so amazing. Personally, I would recommend the cazuela because it was amazing and a great brunch option after a rough night. 

Phillip was so incredibly helpful and his restaurant is so cozy and welcoming and warm. He told us a bit of his story and a bit about SF and it was such a great time for all of us. This place is worth a trip no matter what your plans! We'll definitely be back on our next trip to the city. 5/5 location, 5/5 food, 5/5 service!
author: Cory S.

description:
Olea is such a cute restaurant located in Nob Hill (also very adorable area in SF). We were planning to stop by at a different restaurant across the street from Olea but the line was so long at that location we decided to try Olea instead (so happy we did). Brunch was absolutely amazing that I'm still talking about it (especially the French toast). 

Highlighting the challah custard toast with cinnamon sugar and strawberries. The challah bread was served warm, it was so soft and moist. The custard within the bread was phenomenal (probably the best French toast I've ever had) which deserves a 5 star rating!
author: Angeline L.

description:
We came here this past Saturday, Oct 6, for brunch coz the place across from it had a line of people waiting. And we were all glad we did!!!

The Pork Belly Sandwich caught my attention on the menu. The pork belly itself was lightly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside (the way I like it). It was topped with jalapeño cabbage slaw which gave the sandwich a little  kick. I complemented it with their version of the michelada.

Then we shared the Olea's Challah Custard Toast with strawberries, which served as our dessert. Their take of the French toast is by far the best I've ever had! 

I am so delighted that we stumbled upon this gem!
author: Bo A.

description: Wasn't too impressed. Met a friend here for brunch. Menu looked decent. I had the huevos rancheros which were a disappointment. Too much tomato and it was super saucy, didn't seem like a proper breakfast. Mimosa was good but how do you mess that up, price was okay.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Delicious brunch spot that's only open on weekends! It's a small little restaurant with Mexican style brunch foods. Found it with a friend and it was a delightful surprise.

We both ordered the chilaquiles - it came with slow roasted pork and was so delicious. The portion looked small but I was very full afterwards. The one downside is - I wanted to customize my eggs (to over easy instead of scrambled) but it wasn't possible since it would slow down the kitchen line. Oh well - still happy with the meal!

I think it's unique that Olea is only open Sat/Sun. There wasn't a wait for 2 - though there were larger parties waiting to be seated when we arrived around 10:30-11. Come in 2s for fast service! 

It's also a place that tries to get you in and out pretty fast, I felt rushed to pay and leave after the meal. Still a nice small find.
author: Jacqueline D.

description:
We came here in a whim for brunch and were delighted not only with the incredible selection of fresh, beautifully cooked options (try the chilaquiles!), but also the Owner Phillip's friendly and warm demeanor. He was so welcoming and fun to chat with. Definitely made the experience for us!
I will say that this is a slow food restaurant - if the weather is nice, take your time to enjoy a sunny, leisurely meal on the patio. Such a delight!
author: Christopher R.

description:
Small Portions.....lacking flavor....friendly staff though.....but overall we wish we would just waited longer in line at MyMy. We paid twice as much and left hungry. I'm sure they use great ingredients, but it was not made evident in the menu wording. Another place with a San Francisco pricing scale that leave you underwhelmed. Btw we live half a block away, and we are willing to spend for good food, but a prefectly diced vegetable doesn't always equal a great dish.

The only option for coffee is a $7.00 (French press). $15.95 Small Omelet with tiny salad (no toast).

In response to the owner. 
It is still not clear to me what the points of "quality" are in your in your ingredients...Are there particular farms you work with in certain seasons, maybe a olive oil with unique qualities or maybe a local or imported cheeses you like to use? Your answer was caddy, unhelpful and shows your lack concern for your guests. Why is your Asparagus Omelet 16.00, why? Because it's not even Asparagus season maybe, lame. Confetti diced tomatoes, dumb? Hand picked baby greens, I doubt it. Quality is defined in a number of ways...you're still leave me underwhelmed and unimpressed. What a shame!
author: Adam L.

description:
Neat trick: THEY TAKE BRUNCH RESERVATIONS. Color me impressed (with myself) as the husband I were seated outside promptly with a view of the line - which moved quickly for a brunch line in SF- but still!

Love the large French press coffee - a coffee-brewing method beloved by me but rather passé in this age of pour-over nonsense. I ordered the chilaquiles, the husband the huevos rancheros. I have never seen him inhale a meal so quickly.  Both of us loved the black beans (order a side if your entrees don't come with!) The chilaquiles were still crisp though adequately sauced - my only complaint is that I wished the pork had been served on its own rather than scrambled into my eggs. A request I might have made if I had known.

We'll be back. I want to try those corn cakes! Stellar brunch in SF that takes reservations. Wowee.
author: Archana P.

description:
Got the french toast here. That's it. Had one job, and I accomplished it. 

The french toast is like none I've ever had before. It was so soft on the inside, very easy to cut. When you bit into it, you can really taste the egginess. Most french toasts that I have you really taste the egg on the outside of the toast. Not sure how they made it, the inside also had some stretchiness (maybe cheese + egg?). I'm still thinking about how it's made as it was so unique. My best guess is they use a syringe as to inject the egg whites because the insides were truly amazing. 

If you're ok with nothing savory, getting a full serving is probably better than half serving (3 pieces vs 2) because you don't want to come here and feel like you haven't gotten your french toast fill. However, eating 1.5/2 + sharing a savory dish is probably a good balance.

Also got here at like 1:30 on a Saturday for a party size of 2, no wait :D
author: Victor D.

description:
Get the challah French toast, empanadas, and sweet corn cakes!!

Cute little establishment. Workers could be a little more friendly but I think it was just really busy that day.
author: Diana L.

description: The food was amazing! Little wait time. Great service. Super clean as well! Why the low stars? The gentleman (we think he's the owner) that greeted us had terrible bedside manner. Then he wanted the front door propped open and it was freezing. Grabbed our cards when we were paying and pretty much told us we didn't put the cards in the jar correctly. Our experience was ok, we were so cold!
author: Tiffany R.

description:
Food: 3 stars
Service: 1 star

The food is decent. Started off with a French press coffee, which was marred by the coffee being too finely ground, resulting in heavy silt at the bottom of my mug. 

The host was unnecessarilly curt as I informed him of my reservation.The one star is shared between the curt host and absent-minded server, who was polite but messed up our order twice. 

Also, the passive aggressive sign by the door reads in all CAPS is a red herring for unhappy and overwhelmed staff.

Overall, the service was awful.
author: Lily W.

description:
Food was decent, service blows. 

Line was too long at MyMys so we figured we'd try something new.

No reservations chill out by the fire hydrant, but we lucked out and only had a 15 minute wait.

Ordered the sweet corn cakes with two eggs and a mixed green salad. My sister ordered the bacon omlete​ with a mixed green salad. 

Both meals were good, salads aren't drenched in dressing like side salads normally are, the green 'spicy' sauce under the corn cakes are not spicy at all, but overall everything was cooked well and tasted good. Wished the corn cakes had more crunch to them...

Server on the other hand took our order and just never returned. Ended up having to flag other people down to get extras and even the bill. I love it when you're just chilling looking around for your server for the bill as the huge line of people waiting just stare you done. C'mon guy, turn the table already.

One thing you'll see on their menu is that all staff split tips. Servers, bussers, kitchen staff, etc... I like that they put that up front but I feel that allows for others to drop the ball (aka our server) and let others earn their tip. My thoughts tho (former server).
author: Mandi W.

description:
I haven't had brunch in San Francisco in almost, well forever really. I couldn't afford it back then. Now having broken my piggy bank after years of savings, I could venture out into Nob Hill for some breakfast places!

Olea was actually a random find - we were waiting around the area and found ourselves in a predicament - breakfast hunger. Lo and behold, the outdoor seating of Olea beckoned us and we found ourselves in the lovely seating of the outdoors. 

Fantastic service. They were incredibly diligent in making sure we had a blast eating at their place, and they made sure we had enough for my friend (who drank literally a gallon of water). Attention to detail was everything, and they were there for that. 

The French Toast, as you may know, is one of their highlights. I was amazed as such delectable item that found its way into my mouth, and with the combination of custard coated in cinnamon sugar, it was simply a 5/5 off the bat. We almost fought each other to finish the last bite, which I am happy to say I won. Get this for sure if you're by yourself or don't have a stomach like a cow (or me...)

The Breakfast sandwich along with the omelette also made for a great combination - it's hard to venture away from a place that simply makes great breakfast food. And don't forget to get the French Press coffee - you'll want it to keep awake after a food coma inducing meal! 

While we didn't have to wait in line for brunch, I'm definitely heading back here to engage in another series of breakfast and brunch in San Francisco. Friendly, amiable and outdoor seating makes Olea a great choice to jumpstart your weekend adventures!
author: Chris S.

description:
We were initially walking to a different restaurant and saw this on the sidewalk and decided to stop.  BEST DECISION EVER.  I will be gawking and dreaming about the Challah Custard Toast, Korintji Cinnamon Sugar, Strawberries french toast that we had here until I can, maybe, go back one day! 
Absolutely to die for!!
author: Nikki L.

description:
I was happy to see that Olea takes reservations (so rare for brunch!) which was a big pro, plus I had heard great things about their french toast, so I chose this spot for a brunch date with my sister. 

Even with a rez you do have to wait in a bit of a line (with others who have reservations), but we were seated within a few minutes. We chose to sit outside since the weather was sunny and beautiful but honestly it quickly got way too hot since there are no umbrellas or shade, so you may want to opt to sit inside! 

My sister ordered the chicken empanadas with 2 over-easy eggs, and I got the cazuela (baked eggs with pork in a tomato sauce), which reminded me of a shakshuka. We also shared a half order of the french toast (which was already huge, so I can only imagine how large the full order is!). Everything was tasty although the empanadas are a bit small (looked about the size of dumplings), but I wasn't wow-ed. French toast was yummy but didn't blow my mind. 

Service was friendly but not attentive, they did not proactively re-fill our water, and we had to ask to get it refilled. 

I think I still prefer Mymy which is located right across the street, although they do have a longer wait, so it's a toss-up of whether you are willing to wait for your brunch!
author: Vivian L.

description:
Yummy breakfast - went with a group of 5 on Saturday morning. We didn't have a reservation so we had to wait in line for about 40 minutes. We were originally going to go to Mymy across the street, but the line was longer so we jumped ship for Olea. Turns out, Mymy doesn't take reservations and Olea does, so the line actually went much faster over at Mymy, as people with reservations took what would otherwise have been our tables. 

We sat outside and were very cold as a result, but that's not the restaurant's fault. The food was very good, they had a lot to choose from and was good quality. Their drinks were a little underwhelming as they only have a wine/beer license but my Grapefruit Mimosa was tasty nonetheless. If you're after a Bloody Mary, I hope you're into Sake because that's what they sub vodka for to make them. Mymy offers pitchers of Mimosas so if Mimosas are more important for brunch, go across the street. I have food envy all the time, but restaurant envy is a first for me!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Olea has SF menu price tags not justified by either the portion size or quality. 

Decided to come here with my friend because there wasn't a huge wait to be seated. 

Good iced coffee. I love that they have the Coronado sugar cubes.

Food itself is just ok and nothing special. Maybe it's because I had an omelette but it was super basic and not even a stellar omelette.

UPDATE: Regarding the snarky comment, i meant to write Turbinado sugar cubes but i'll leave it unedited since I own up to it. Good job on your $4 box of sugar and why don't you instead focus on improving how you cook eggs. I live so close by but am never ever tempted to go in again and would rather wait an hour in line across the street instead (and i despise typical SF waits). Down another star.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
One Sunday morning, my deathly hungover friend croaked, "I need potatoes."

We were parked outside of Brenda's and in her ill state, she was in no mood to even consider the absurdly long wait for a table. I pulled out my phone and texted a few friends who were familiar with Lower Nob Hill, asking for potato-friendly brunch recommendations. Shortly after the first text rolled in, we drove toward a tiny hipster restaurant and quickly found parking on the same block. Unfortunately, potatoes were noticeably absent from this menu and we walked out feeling especially dejected because we had put over an hour on the meter. We would have to continue our elusive search for potatoes on foot.

I don't remember how we found Olea. But there were open tables and more importantly, potatoes. (Along with excellent brunch food.)

All was well.
author: Amy C.

description:
Overall the experience was great! Adorable restaurant, it was a beautiful day and we got to sit outside. Upon arrival there were a bunch of empty tables but the hostess made us start a line outside and wait to be seated.

There was an older gentleman (who I believe may have been the owner?), he was really nice. The other servers weren't that nice, they weren't rude either but a smile wouldn't hurt anyone. Either way, drinks were brought out promptly, same with the food. They forgot our side dish but it wasn't a big deal. Food was really good, fresh and flavorsome, they have this amazing home made chili paste oh man it was so good! The oj is fresh squeezed, perfectly used in our mimosas
author: Taleen K.

description: I came back to Olea for brunch and I have to say it's a cozy, wonderful place to spend a weekend afternoon.  The food is on point and that challah french toast is the stuff dreams are made of!
author: Julie L.

description:
AMAZING AMBIENCE AND FOOD, will return for brunch over and over again!

Best French toast in the city (and maybe beyond).

Great coffee/espresso.

Perfect mimosa with tasty fresh squeezed juice.

Very yummy huevos rancheros (but not as good as French toast).

Great service and not too long of a wait on weekends. Reservations are accepted!

Loved the outdoor seating.
author: Kimia M.

description:
The service was awful- rude owner and staff. I would never come here again.

I was meeting a friend for brunch and got to the restaurant before her. I told the waiter seating people that my friend was on her way but that I would like a table for two. The restaurant had a few empty tables and no wait so I got seated right away and ordered a $6 latte to sip on while waiting. 

My friend's Lyft driver got lost and she ended up arriving 20-30 minutes later (how was I supposed to know?). A guy that I'd never spoken to before (I assume he's the owner?) came up to my table, got in my face and said "you told someone that your friend is parking right?" I apologized for my friend, explained that I told the waiter that my friend was on her way, and told him that her driver lost but he just gave me a dirty look and accused me of lying. Other tables turned to stare at the altercation- super uncomfortable. 

It's not my fault that my friend's driver got lost and if they had a policy of not seating until everyone arrived then I would have waited. I felt like I was accused of lying and was berated in public when I didn't do anything wrong. 

Either have a policy of not seating until everyone is there or don't berate paying customers if their friends run late.
author: Dasol S.

description:
Stopped by this place after a workout and was surprised that there was no line, since it was a beautiful day at prime brunch time.  We got a table outside and service was fine.  The food and coffee left a lot to be desired though.  We ordered the french press coffee, but the coffee had no flavor, which was surprising given that coffee in SF is generally really tasty.  For our entrees, we ordered the omelette and the huevos rancheros.  The huevos rancheros had very little flavor and I had to add a ton of salt to my food, which is something I rarely have to do.  My friend said the omelette was also lacking in flavor.  The bacon was the one standout item (thick-cut and flavorful). 

I'd say the food is good enough to eat if you're really hungry and want to stay in the area, but I personally wouldn't return given the plethora of solid brunch options in the city.
author: Arthi N.

description: My favorite French toast ever. This place is great! No wait, awesome service and did I mention the French Toast is amazing. It's got great texture, lots of good flavor, and a good amount. Highly recommend it.
author: Vinayak P.

description: I hate the idea of folks giving Yelp ratings based on service, but this was a miserable experience, so I am making an exception to do so. The other week, I made a reservation for brunch and selected indoor seating, because OpenTable gives you the option. I then waited more than forty minutes for my table this morning. At the 35 minute mark, when I asked about the table, the owner snapped at me that he has a sixty person restaurant and everyone wants to sit inside. If you take reservations and give the option of selecting inside vs. outside, at least honor those who took the time to indicate where they wanted to be seated. The food is good here but not worth the attitude. They then usher you through your meal so that they can turn the table quickly. I ended up waiting longer for my reservation than I was seated "enjoying" my meal.
author: Katherine N.

description: My boyfriend and I were seated almost instantly for brunch (on a Saturday!) which really impressed me considering how crowded it already was. I really enjoyed the offering of a French press and freshly squeezed juice. Friendly service, but our waiter was obviously very busy as we were only able to order one thing at a time; a few minutes apart. I had the omelette which was full of fresh veggies, but I do wish I had the chance to ask for some hot sauce. Great outdoor seating area for watching all the tourists leaning out of the cable car with their selfie sticks. Stay safe out there!
author: Caitlin S.

description: Great breakfast and easy to find. Everything was really good and friendly service. We sat outside while the weather was great. The coffee was delicious and the eggs were cooked perfectly. I would recommend this place.
author: Ramiro S.

description: Had a great breakfast after a nice walk from the top of Nob Hill! We each ordered a different breakfast: chilaqules, omelette, and scrambled egg sandwich. All were excellent! The restaurant manager was very personable and attentive. Would definitely return for another visit!
author: Joyce G.

description:
This place was alright. It's a nice restaurant tucked in an unassuming but relatively classy spot on the basement floor of a Nob Hill building. While the cuisine was healthy, unique, and all made in house, the portions were small and the quality of the ingredients as well as flavor were lacking given the $40-50 per person cost.

To start I ordered the mushroom soup and had the gnocchi as my entree. Both were small portioned and honestly OK tasting. The best part of the restaurant is the free bread they give in the beginning but they will only give you one because they are "handmade."

Lastly I'd say the clientele made the ambiance classy, but the interior itself was very ordinary. Service was good but would have been better if they could give more portions or provide a pay option for the bread.
author: Amy G.

description: Wanted to go to another place across the street but the line was way too long. Ended up going here where there was no line and so glad we did. Service is really good and the food is delicious. I had the huevos rancheros but it wasn't as filling as I would have liked it to be and was still a little hungry afterwards. Sat at a small table outside which wasn't the most comfortable but the sun was out so it was still nice.
author: Jo S.

description:
I liked my Cazuela! It had great flavor and just the right amount of heat to spice it up.

The place is pretty small but it has its own cute ambience to it. A bit noisy too but my friend and I were on the side so not too bad.

I really enjoyed the Cazuela and once I finished the entire bowl it was still steaming a bit because the dish was so hot. I liked the pork, tomato sauce, and eggs all in a bowl like a stew. It was perfect since it was a bit windy and chilly that day.
Unfortunately my friend did not have a dish prepared half as good as mine. Hers lacked seasoning, color in presentation, and the chicken was dry. It was the Migas Con Huevos had yellow squash, eggs, salsa, chicken, and I don't know what else.It was sad looking and sad tasting unfortunately.

The avocado toast looked good and seemed like a popular dish but I don't know if I want to ay about $16 for the toast and a side salad that comes with it.

If I do come back, it'll be for the Cazuela!
author: Laura Y.

description:
The French toast was total bomb!!! The small size (which has 2 pieces) would have been sufficient for a person, we got the large size (with 3 pieces) and finishing up the last few bites was a challenge to our stomachs but not to our palettes. 

The mexican style eggs - huevos rancheros - was quite good too. 

We went at 9 am and they was no crowd. We were the first to get there..
author: Sharanya A.

description:
TLDR - Simple brunch spot with no wait. Solid food, but not worth a special visit

My friend and I were looking for a quick brunch spot after getting our butts kicked at Core40, and Olea and Mymy were the closest options, right at the same intersection as the studio. Between the two, the menus looked pretty similar, but we opted for Olea and its lack of wait.

Pretty small restaurant and honestly pretty easily missed. I've walked by it multiple times on the way to my workouts without a second glance. Most of the seating is inside, but if the weather happens to be one of those rare sunny days in SF, there's some seating outside to enjoy the sun and warmth. 

Menu was pretty short and simple, primarily with egg-centered dishes, and everything looked healthy. The food was solid and not too expensive (not by SF standards anyway), but given the its simplicity, I'd probably only return if it was the only convenient option.

* MIGAS CON HUEVO ($13.75) - 3.5/5
[chicken sausage, spinach, zucchini, salsa]
Good scramble in the sense that there certainly wasn't anything bad about it. Fluffy eggs, savory sausage, tender veggies and slight kick from the salsa. But did it impress me? Not really. Simple ingredients and easy to replicate at home to be perfectly honest, even for someone who can't really cook.
author: Jessie L.

description: Skip this place unless you enjoy waiting in line for an hour (no list to put your name on either) to be served chilaquiles that's mostly chicken skin (see photo) and coffee that doesn't come with mugs. Our waitress was very nice though and they gave us a discount for the chicken skin incident.
author: Farah W.

description:
Olea is one of my favorite brunch spots in the neighborhood. The food is consistently delicious, and the owner is always excited to see us. My boyfriend ate breakfast by himself here once, so maybe it's exciting to see that he doesn't always eat alone :)

If you can only order one thing here, get the challah french toast, which consists of challah bread dipped in custard and topped with cinnamon sugar and strawberries. I typically only eat savory breakfast foods, but I'll make an exception for Olea's challah french toast, which is, dare I say, the best I've had in the city.

The kitchen uses fresh, seasonal ingredients, so the menu does change sometimes, but they typically have my favorites:

- Cazuela (baked eggs, meat & sauces change but I've had both ground beef and chicken, as well as red and green sauces)
- Migas Con Huevos (scrambled eggs with squash, I love a couple of variations of this more than others)
- Sweet Corn Cakes with Eggs & Plantains (so many delicious things packed on one plate)

If you're feeling extra hungry, get a side of crispy bacon or french fries. For drinks, you can't go wrong with the fresh squeezed orange juice or french press coffee.

Olea also offers outdoor seating, perfect for sunny days, or if you have a dog.

Yes, you will have to literally stand in a line instead of putting your name down on a list. It looks like they take reservations for brunch now, so the line could be avoided. You can also just arrive early to beat the crowd.
author: Grace C.

description:
Excellent.  Waits in line for about 10 min. Max.

Ordered Huevos Rancheros which came to the table hot and saucy.  Delicious and perfectly cooked.  A side of chicken sausage is a must.

Speaking of must my hubby absolutely fell in LOVE with his dish.  Cazuela!  2 eggs baked w/spicy tomato sauce, ground pork, bacon, tortilla chips and parm.  He said it was absolutely the best thing on the menu.  Take that to heart as he is really picky.

Excellent French press coffee and a great lively vibe here.

Will come again when visiting the Nob Hill neighborhood
author: Susan C.

description:
If you love french toast, you must order it at Olea. Made with challah dipped in custard with cinnamon sugar, it's heavenly. Just the right amount of fluffiness and sugar. 

Sometimes when I find my perfect order, it's hard for me to venture away from it, but I've tried some of their avocado toast and scrambled eggs; it seems like you just can't go wrong!

Located a block away from Polk street, it's not as packed as some of the other popular spots and the food is superb. There's still usually a line though so I'd suggest getting there about about 20 to 30 minutes before you'd like to be seated. It quite packed inside, but cozy with outside tables available as well. On a sunny Sunday morning, it's a great place to be.
author: Shira W.

description: Came here since Mymys across the street had a long line. We sat outside and ordered the BLT with fries and avocado focaccia. Overall the food was pretty basic and overpriced. Was super disappointed. The service was also slow, our glasses of water were empty almost the entire meal. We had to ask for water a few times but it was forgotten about so we had to go into the restaurant and find a someone for water.
author: Mika O.

description:
I've heard about the "rivalry" between Olea and Mymy and finally can say I've eaten at both.  I wasn't that impressed with Mymy (though love their other restaurant Griddle Fresh), but still thought it was a little more well rounded than Olea.  

Our waiter was friendly but the wait for an order of French Toast and a scramble is just way too long.  We got there on Sunday afternoon around 1:10-1:15 and they close at 2.  No wait for a table luckily.  They just didn't seem to be as efficient in the kitchen, granted I know that the kitchen is small, but one should not have to wait over a half hour for these two fairly simple breakfast dishes.  The staff was busy but did not seem very attentive.  I ended up switching my husband my migas con huevos for his French Toast.  The custard French Toast was amazing with just the right amount of sweetness and apples garnishing the rustic bread.  My eggs were pretty much a scramble with some pork tenderloin some salsa and veggies.  It was a small portion and was just lacking seasoning.  Though hubby thought the scramble was alright.  

I heard their dinner is really good, but not sure if they crank it out faster or if it is also just less crowded in general.  I think if I were to get Olea again, it would be the French Toast to go.  4 stars for that deliciousness but - 2 stars for slow service and the bland migas con huevos.
author: Cat C.

description:
Call ahead and make resos, this spot is super popular on weekends. The challah custard French toast is absolutely worth the morning wait, I recommend sharing as a half order is two huge thick slices.

Great outdoor seating for people watching and very quick and friendly service.
author: Angela L.

description: Average food, average atmosphere. They badly need new furniture and new servers. My server had a stick so far up his keister that he was choking on the wood. The atmosphere was as grey as San Francisco's mornings. No tip for you.
author: Daniel H.

description: Limited menu (good) in a very noisy room for its size. Service attentive, food good too. Corn cake, egg, salad concoction I had with some home frys.
author: Henry K.

description:
Probably my favorite brunch spot in the city. They have a pretty fixed menu, but have new and different omelettes every week. I usually get the BLT sandwich, but all the food is killer. Good variety on the menu so everyone can find something they like. 

The overall vibe inside is relaxed and fun. They play great music (usually along the Disclosure line) and the staff is always friendly.
author: Hannah Y.

description:
Very meh experience. Came on a Sun around noon, only 1 group waiting by the fire hydrant in front of us. We had wanted to go to mymy across the street but the line was ridiculously long so we decided to give Olea a try. We were quickly seated inside. Unfortunately, the service leaves a lot to be desired. 1) My friend wanted to sub out her salad for toast (or fruit which they don't have) but was told that wasn't an option and she could just pay for a slice of toast on the side. 2) We were seated directly in line of the front door which they decided to leave open on a pretty windy day to accommodate the servers needing access to customers seated at the tables outside (which I understand). We asked whether they could close the door a bit as we were freezing and we were flat out told no. After we pushed a bit, he finally conceded and closed the door a few inches. 3) If you just want drip black coffee, good luck because you'll be forced to order expensive french press coffee. 

Our food came quickly. I had ordered the veg omelette - it was ok but nothing spectacular. The service and attitude really killed it for me.
author: Yin H.

description: Had brunch here today!  Challah french toast was amazing!  French press coffee and perfectly cooked bacon side made the whole meal perfect.
author: Steven K.

description:
Downgrading to 1 star. Yelp is a place to freely and openly give your honest opinions without being ridiculed by the owner. Please see below for his/her sarcastic remark and I'm not the only one they have replied to. Stunned that this business is ok with this. Here's a subsequent message I received - 


Olea R.
Owner
One week ago
Block & Report Owner
We are and I am sure you are just as wonderful in whatever it is you do.  How about I come by your place of work and review you on Yelp?
author: Aria S.

description:
The best brunch I've had in SF to date. 

And there was no wait with a ton of open tables inside and out on the Saturday we went, which never hurts. 

I got the avocado toast, roomie got the corn cakes, and we split challah custard french toast, despite my hatred for custard.

My avocado toast was a real panty melter. I'd def order that again in a heartbeat. I tried a bite of the corn cakes my roomie got and while they were good, they just didn't hold a candle to my avocado toast. 

The challah custard French toast was outstanding. We only got a half order but had we gotten a full, it wouldn't have been a stretch for me to eat finish since I ate pretty much the entire half order on my own anyway. 

Service was great- they kept referring to items that were on the table as being, 'by the gentleman', and I kept getting really confused since we were the end table and the only person sitting by me was a 20-something girl at the next table over. Legit took 3 turns of our server referencing 'the gentleman' before it dawned on me that he was talking about my roommate. LOL. Hardly. Like, farthest thing from that, but what a thoughtful gesture on their part to assume.
author: Candice G.

description: Brunch in SF is always so crazy...it's normal for waiting for 45 minutes to an hour...so it seems.  You always see lots of people out especially when the sun is out. It's a great feeling to see that. We waited for about 45 minutes before having a seat. We had a french press coffee for 2, Cazuela and Huevos. The food itself was awesome. I loved the Cazuela with baked eggs. It was definitely a heavier brunch, but I loved all of it. I had a chance to try the Huevos too with the beans. YUM! Service was attentive and friendly. They were quite busy, but the crowd died down, a little after we left.
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description: I am really glad we went to Olea for brunch instead of standing in line at various well known breakfast places in the area. The Green Cazuela was nothing I have had before. It was really really good !! The best french toast ever!! They take reservations at Open Table and the owner was also very nice.
author: Jonie A.

description:
Hmm, I'm a little confused by the 4 and 5 star reviews here! My party wasn't impressed with the service or our food-- I ordered the huevo rancheros which were average at best. I'm not sure if I'll be giving Olea another chance.

EDIT: Check out the rude comment from the owner below! That tends to be a pattern if you read other low reviews.
author: Nicole W.

description:
The owner and wait staff are always RUDE RUDE RUDE and the service is slow. The gentleman who seats people in glasses is especially rude and arrogant. To top it off, the food is mediocre as well. 

In addition, Yelp is advising that Olea's food safety inspection was in the BOTTOM 5% OF ALL SAN FRANCISCO. With so many good restaurants to choose from in SF, why take the chance? STAY AWAY. Go to Mymy, Crepe House, or Sweet Maple instead.
author: Kevin B.

description:
The Mr. and I were in San Francisco for a long weekend over the Easter holiday. We enjoy Sunday brunch on a regular basis, so I looked at several San Francisco options for this meal. I chose Olea because of it close proximity to our hotel, its price point, and its menu. 

This particular morning was rainy and cold, so we arrived wet, hungry, and a tad late for our reservation. Luckily they saved our table for us, because the restaurant was packed. Olea is a small, but cute place. Our waiter was attentive and took good care of us. 


We ordered the French Press coffee first and studied the menu. The Challah Custard Toast was calling my name, but I was trying to be 'good' and chose the bacon omelet while the Mr. ordered Huevos Rancheros. He enjoyed his and mine was 'okay' but truthfully I couldn't stop thinking about that toast. I think we shocked our waiter by adding it to our order mid meal. The Mr. likes to eat, so we decided to split the large order. Yes. We were being piggy. I have absolutely NO regrets. The Challah Custard Toast was everything I hoped it would be. Served with strawberries and a little pitcher of warm syrup it really hit the spot. 

Three breakfasts later, we left full, happy, and ready to hit the rainy streets of San Francisco!
author: Kym T.

description: The Fairmont hotel said to check this place out. It was in walking distance from the hotel. What a awesome place, it's in the basement of a building very quaint atmosphere. Food was on point! I had the chilaquiles! If you like hot and spicy things this is your dish!
author: Josh G.

description: Fantastic brunch! We had the Cazuela which was a very impressive dish with slow roasted beef, spicy tomato puree broth, two perfectly cooked eggs, parmesan cheese and a few crisp tortilla strips...truly unique and soooo delicious! Great almond milk latte as well. Lovely location right on California street across from trader joe's with friendly, prompt service.
author: D M.

description:
A great corner spot in Nob Hill. We had a party of 4 and came about noon on Sunday to find a line on the corner. Typical for small places like this that I've been to in the city. Our wait wasn't too bad, but it did seem like they were a little understaffed, between tending to the tables inside and keeping the line moving outside.  

We sat outside and it was really nice. Our server was friendly and attentive and quick, which I really appreciated. 

I ordered the corn cake & egg entree, which was served with fried plantains, avocado tomatillo salsa, and a veggie hash. Everything was amazing! The flavors were terrific and the corn cakes were perfectly cooked. But the veggie hash was to die for! I'd actually call it diced veggies, because there was no hash, but whatever it was amazing. Acorn squash, potatoes, peppers, onions - perfectly cooked and flavored. So, so good. 

My husband had the challah custard french toast (the only sweet brunch item) and he thought it was fantastic. I had a couple bites and really enjoyed it - thick bread, crunchy exterior, soft on the inside. 

Fresh OJ was tart and sweet and pulpy and amazing.
author: Elise H.

description:
Popped in for a Saturday brunch with 2 pals a little after 10:15 am. The wait was very mild and the host was more than accommodating. Like most busy brunch places, Olea will not seat your table until the entire party has arrived.

We ordered a Bloody Mary, OJ, and a cappuccino. Regular drip coffee is not available. Coffee comes  as either a form of an espresso drink or via French press.  

Our table ordered the famous French toast as a starter. Wow!! It was excellent. The brioche base had an inner creamy inside that I've never experienced with French toast before. The sliced strawberries that covered the dish were a nice finishing touch.

For my main meal I feasted on the corn cakes with eggs and squash. This dish was excellent except the  blackened squash was slightly burnt. 

I will certainly be back to enjoy another brunch and perhaps lunch or dinner here!
author: Andrea H.

description: I had high hopes for this brunch spot in Nob Hill. There's always a healthy line so I decided to check it out with a few of my gfs. Ultimately, I was very underwhelmed. Organic lemonade was not freshly squeezed. The chilaquiles were very spicy, too spicy. There was no regular sour cream to balance out the spiciness. We asked and they only had Chipotle cream available. I ordered a cazuela, which tasted like chili with an egg in the middle. It was not terrible, but not good either. I'm glad I tried it out but I will not be coming back. Service was attentive but the food did take a while to make it to the table. We also thought it was overpriced for what we ordered.
author: Jezzica B.

description:
Olea is one of SF's hot spots for brunch. 

The restaurant is not very big and there is always a line on the sidewalk, but the wait is worth it. 

Even though I only came here twice, I already have my favorite (which I will order forever): the Olea's Challah Custard Toast, a.k.a. french toast. This is undoubtedly the best french toast I have ever had.  You must try it! It's sweet, very moist, dense, and extremely yummy. Paired with strawberries (and my personal order of a side of extra crispy bacon) it is just perfection. 

The only downside of this place is the wait time. Even though it is worth it, it is rather annoying. So, if you are willing to wait, you should definitely try Olea's brunch for yourself.
author: Andréia S.

description:
WOW, I'm literally laughing at how ridiculous this is, but I'm updating my Yelp review because  apparently I need to "get attention on Yelp"...the owner of Olea is crazy/rude/unprofessional. Below is his private message to my first comment:

"Then please don't come to my restaurant, it seems like all you want to do is rant and get attention on Yelp.  Do us both a favor and move on."


We went here because the line at My Mys was ridiculously long and there was no wait at Olea. I've been here before, but prefer not to because the owner and wait staff are always rude and the service is slow.
author: Liz D.

description:
My friends and I had the misfortune of choosing this place on Sunday for Brunch. Let me save you the trouble: AVOID this establishment

Many others have already pointed out issues with this place, including having poor safety standards, but what my friends and I experienced specifically was:

1. As many people have already pointed out in the reviews, *Extremely rude* and arrogant "owner"/waiter who seemed to take every chance to talk down to patrons. Owner ("Philip") was rude to my friend and started lecturing him, at one point even dropping that "I run a successful business..." fool please, we're in San Francisco, I run a business that makes yours look like a lemonade stand, do not try to pull that kind of weak, showboating behavior here. By the way as an entrepreneur: Shame on you Philip.

Another tip, BUSINESS 101: DO NOT lecture your paying customers. And learn some manners. SF is a small city - I will be recommending to everyone I know to avoid this establishment. If you're reading this, you should too.

2. Very mediocre yet overpriced food

I've never had such a bad experience in the city and such an unpleasant manager/owner/waiter who doesn't know how to treat customers. This business deserves to fail because it's owner is a rude and extremely unpleasant person, and I certainly look forward to seeing it shut down in the future.

If you want to see first-hand how rude and arrogant the owner is, just look at the responses he has posted to people who have left reviews in the past calling out his rudeness. Would you want to patronize and give money to someone like this? I am honestly shocked these guys are even still in business. It's no wonder MyMy across the street has so much more business than this restaurant that this sad excuse of a business owner has.
author: Dan A.

description:
I find the owners response to his Yelp reviews hilarious.

Moved close by and always saw the cute outdoor seating so obv had to stop by.

What we ordered
1. French press small $6 serves 2
2. Huevo rancheros 
3. I forgot the name but it had eggs and lamb sausage
4. Fresh squeezed OJ

The brunch food isn't your classic American brunch menu of eggs Benedict etc so if that's what you're expecting then I would probably go elsewhere. 

Overall food is okay. The OJ and coffee was pretty great. I thought the prices were a bit high. The host was a bit sassy. Had fomo that I didn't order the avocado toast.
author: Joy M.

description:
The review is only for french toast.
Best french toast in SF! Love this more than the one in kitchen story.
So soft and yummy inside!
author: Aldora Z.

description: Super delicious food. Line can be long so expect a wait. Order the French toasty- superb!
author: Jimi B.

description:
Although the food was ultimately OK tasting, there were a bunch of issues, per below.
 
1.  We ordered the corn cakes, and only 5 minutes later did the manager come back to tell us they had run out of them.
2.  I specifically asked if the black beans had any dairy, and was told no.  The order arrived with cheese on it.
3.  We went out of our way to confirm that the breakfast potatoes were done "on the grill," not deep-fried.  They were deep-fried when they arrived.
4.  The ketchup bottle had disgusting black mold-looking stuff around the top of the bottle.
5.  The manager was smarmy and self-serving.  (Less of a disaster than the other things, but still not OK.)
 
One and done.  Especially because this place clearly looked like a second choice to the place right across the street, which had a long line whereas Olea was very easy to walk right into.
author: D. V.

description: Amazing Americano....smooth, bold, and well made. The french toast ranks in my top 5 of all time...creamy fluffy and evenly cooked.  This is no plain french toast - this is custard inside with browned outside wonderfulness. The corn cakes and papas fritas were amazing as well. Worth the wait on weekends!  We will be back!
author: Shariq H.

description: Go for the French toast if for nothing else. Loved the English waiter, very friendly but overall menu wasn't great.
author: Holly M.

description: This place is definitely a great choice if you're looking for a delicious big brunch. The challah French roast was fantastic, not too sweet like many places. They had a half size which was much more manageable. Girlfriend got corn cakes and scrambled eggs. I think the best thing about this place is that it has a different menu every week, which makes it fun to keep coming back to have new dishes. Also, they design their menu around what food they can get that will be fresh!
author: Tom R.

description: fantastic OJ. french toast is good (this is a photo of a "half" order). corn cakes meh
author: Tiffany Z.

description:
First, check my Yelp distribution... I'm not a consistently annoyed customer, in fact I think I generally give 4-5* reviews. Now, take this review as a warning to avoid OLEA.

My Sunday morning at Olea was really the worst. Doing my best to keep this brief, here's a few reasons why you should also steer clear of Olea:

--- manager/HOST/owner incredibly rude, treats customers as though they're not paying to be there (ex: YELLING at people in line, PATRONIZING me when i asked about usual wait)
--- the host is so RUDE that he's worth AVOIDING the entire restaurant for but it gets worse....
--- food was really BLAND and sub-par for what you're paying (boyfriend's meal was boiling when he received it, so he couldn't eat it for 20 minutes)
--- wait staff is really INATTENTIVE: never refilled glasses, didn't look in our direction after 20 minutes of trying to get the check

Not only am I Yelping about this, but I shared this experience with several of my friends and neighbors because of how disappointed I was with Olea. It was really a bummer to spend $50 on a brunch that put me in a bad mood!


*AVOID Olea, VISIT MyMy Instead*
author: Kerry G.

description:
I am not sure whether that was me or Olea, who was having a bad day but I really did not enjoy my experience there.

First flag came when they said they do not have decaf coffee so did not order coffee. Sorry, I am not going to trigger a panic attack so that I can have coffee here. Then I ordered a mimosa, which was served in a plastic water cup (uploaded its photo). Maybe it will sound snobby but if you are going to serve your mimosa like that, I think you should let your customer know about this when they give the order. 

Although, food was decent, I will probably stick to Mymy next door.
author: Gokhan T.

description: Solid brunch place with a great location and ample outdoor seating. The service was fantastic and the food was delicious. I had an egg white omelet with roasted Brussel sprouts, sweet potatoes, Carmalized onions, and goat cheese. I am not usually a fan of goat cheese but it worked very well with the sweetness of the potatoes. The drinks were good and strong. Mimosa was tasty and the Bloody Mary was very spicy. Would definitely come back here!
author: Lisa D.

description:
Brunch review -- always order the Cazuela! So delicious during foggy San Francisco mornings. 

Avocado toast is also yummy but way overpriced at $15. You could buy some avocados at trader joes down the street and make it yourself. 

Boyfriend's pulled pork tacos were good too. Someone knows how to cook meat! However they were a little soggy because the serving of pork wasn't drained well. 

French press coffee is meh. Get fancy coffee at Contraband across the street instead.
author: Martina M.

description:
Hands down my favorite brunch place in SF--and this is saying a lot given that my runners up are trendy Foreign Cinema, roof deck purveying El Techo, and line down the block even on weekdays Zazie. 

So what makes Olea so special? It's simple: the food. It's delicious. Period. I've been coming here for the past 6.5 years. I've been eating french toast for, oh, probably 31 of the past 33 years. And I've never had a ore delicious french toast ever. Then we can talk about the egg sandwich made with acme bread and the perfect combo of vine-ripened tomatoes, cheddar cheese, and perfectly cooked bacon. Or the seasonal and constantly changing omelette options. Or french press coffee. You get the idea. 

And, ok, this is going to sound so cheesy, but the place is so obviously cared for with love by the owner who is there every single day and is the first to enthusiastically describe any number of today's specials. MyMy Coffee across the street has a bigger following and I just don't get it. 

Olea is also incredible for dinner. The same great quality. The same great service. Not so standard SF pricing. It's one of the few places left in the city where you can get an amazing meal without spending a fortune and without waiting in an ungodly line. 

In sum: run, don't walk.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
As a vegetarian I appreciate the Olea. The food served here is very good and plated nicely. As an example the goat cheese tart looked great and tasted smooth but not overpowering.   The slightly tart beet sauce complimented the creaminess of the cheese with a consistency of a salmon pate.

The restaurant is perfectly charming.  Intimate and quite enjoyable.   I've met some nice people here at neighboring tables.  

The service has always been impeccable.   On a recent visit the waiter could not have been more attentive refilling our water as well as checking on our satisfaction.  We had a few brief but engaging conversations and learned he was the owner.  It's easy to see he has passion and pride in his business.  

Make sure to order the dessert as the bread pudding is incredible.  I'll definitely return and enjoy the quality provided by this neighborhood restaurant.  Enjoy.
author: D S.

description:
I had a great lunch time at this cozy place. I sat outside on the street watching the cable car go by along with the rest of the world and had a couple of beers along with one of the French press coffees (I needed a little caffeine boost). 

The service was very friendly and overall a pleasant experience. I didn't have food because I was still full from breakfast but the menu looked great for brunch and the other people seemed to be enjoying their food! 

It was a nice spot. I would definitely go back to try out their menu.
author: Mike T.

description:
Olea has the cozy feel of a European bistro, housed in the bottom floor of a charming older building. Seems like a real neighborhood joint, slightly off the beaten restaurant path. 

The menu boasts healthy-ish California cuisine and farm-fresh ingredients -- a lovely spot for a mellow brunch or romantic dinner. The offerings are limited, but almost everything on the menu is alluring. I had a delicious soft scramble with spinach, mushrooms, squash, eggplant, special sauce & sesame seeds (creative!) and my date had a baked egg dish with Mexican sauces & tortilla chips. Hearty & healthy grub, nice presentation, and gracious & attentive staff made this a really soothing start to the day. They really deliver on their "upscale, yet casual" mission statement. 

Olea is a local treasure for Nob Hill residents, or those seeking a hype-free SF dining spot.
author: Nique F.

description:
My friend and I picked this place to have a quick dinner before going to the Haunted House at the nearby Haas Lilienthal house. It was really charming and cozy! I was warmly greeted by a man who appeared to be the owner and we were allowed to sit at a comfortable 4-top in the corner, even though we were only a party of two. The place was surprisingly slow at 7:30 p.m. but picked up in the next hour. I had made reservations through Open Table, but wouldn't have needed them. Apparently, this place is crowded for brunch, but remains a hidden secret for dinner. 

We had a nice glass of wine and yummy bread with dipping oil to start. It's a limited menu (no appetizers), but the dishes they have are inviting. My friend had the scallops and I had the pappardelle pasta w/lamb meatballs. Both were amazing with great presentation! Portions were decent, service was excellent. Olea's menu uses Niman Ranch meats and wild caught seafood, and fresh organic produce from local farms whenever possible. Everything tasted fresh and healthy, with wonderful flavors.

Olea was a pleasant surprise and I would recommend highly for a dinner restaurant in Nob Hill. I'm sure their brunch is wonderful too, and I'll have to try it the next time I'm in the city on a weekend morning.
author: Wendy N.

description:
Would give zero stars if I could. Really? Waste my time. So disgusted with the service here and food. 

Order was taken first and 5 tables came after us and they all got their food no more then 10min.  Server did not even acknowledge or came by to check on us for over an hr until we ask where our food was. When ask about our food, server did not apologize for the food but simply pass by and said yeah it's coming. No refills on water.  Being in the restaurant industry, service should be valuable.  I truly believe they have forgotten our order, it happens. What's unforgivable is not acknowledging their customers after walking pass our table over 5 plus times to count the least. 

I will give them credit for the press coffee, very smooth and done right. The mimosa was so sad, it was prepared on a regularly ugly cup and barely have any orange flavor to it given that it was suppose to be fresh squeeze orange juice.  Omelette was not greasy but very dry. Cazuela chicken was nothing special. Bacon was on the dry hard side. Perhaps because we asked for our food after an hour, maybe they just put it together super fast I don't know and I'm very disappointed. 

I seriously hope the owner read this review and work on their rude service. Sorry but I  will never come back again.
author: Shamoo S.

description:
Walkable, outdoor seating, pups are welcome, tasty viddles! 

Every time we visit we bring our puppy and enjoy our new fav breakfast spot. The lines aren't too long. They're very organized, and friendly. They seat you quickly. The menu is small and the dishes are made exquisitely. Every time I can expect the same quality. French toast is amazing and the breakfast sandwich is great too.
author: Socal I.

description:
Decent brunch, but a tad expensive and the menu is limited. Usually when I go out I can't decide what to order because there are too many tempting options, but at Olea nothing really jumped at me from the menu. And everything is like $15-$17.

Love that they have fresh squeezed juice, but I drink it so fast that I can't really justify paying so much for it. 

The service is great and the staff is really nice.
author: Sara M.

description:
For brunch, Olea deserves five stars. I really couldn't think of anything that could've been better about our meal or the experience.

We waited less than half an hour at 11am on a Sunday, which is very reasonable for the city. 

The food though. Oh my. If you haven't heard already, the challah bread french toast is amazing. It's a fluffy, cinnamon sugary, puffy goodness. Slightly damp in the center, but not too soggy, it's like a warm and fresh donut + churro. Since the french toast is basically like a dessert, I'd recommend a half order of this (or sharing a full order) and trying one of their other dishes as a main course.

The seasonal omelette with garlic, corn, mozzarella and collard greens was amazing. It was a pretty delicate and thin omelette, which just left me wanting more. The egg was very evenly cooked -- not too browned, just a nice soft texture that paired well with the filings. 

The cazuela was really good as well. A sightly spicy pork broth, all baked in a dish. It also came with two eggs that were perfectly cooked. Grilled french toast on the side was very complementary for soaking up the saucy yumminess. The yolks weren't runny, but they were still slightly soft and orange on the inside. Left me wanting more. Again.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I came here with a friend on a windy Saturday morning. When we arrived, it was packed!

And sure enough..... the food is AMAZING and lived up to the hype! 

I'm vegan and this is what I ordered:

Avocado & toast, with mixed greens, extra virgin olive oil & sea salt, pimento flakes. 

SO simple, yet SO good. I was very happy with this dish, and I loved how generous they were with the avocado!

I'm definitely coming back here just to eat this!!!
author: Shalini P.

description:
A solid brunch spot, and for its quality and reasonable, price, a pretty reasonable wait. Glad I came, and it was worth biking across the city from the Mission!

THE WAIT: No reservations, no call-aheads (as per usual on SF). But there's no list even once you arrive; you stand in line outside the restaurant. You do have to brave the direct sunlight (bring sunblock or a sunhat!), but it moved pretty fast, and the guy managing the line (who reminded me of Tim Gunn, in both looks and demeanor) was efficient and checked often. It would've been about a 30-minute wait for a group of three around 12 noon, but our 3rd was late so we grabbed coffee at Contraband. When our 3rd got there around 1pm, we'd popped back into line for only about 15 minutes.

THE SERVICE: Great, efficient. Our server even got me a couple extra free slices of toast to finish off the stew in my Cazuela.

BRUNCH
* Cazuela (2 baked eggs, ground beef, bacon, fire roasted roma tomato, red bell & pasilla pepper stew, tortilla chips, pamesan cheese. $13.75) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/olea-san-francisco?select=tJoWFCTS0sNRSbLFVHYuFg#20tOHZ65BODG75Ct41P-ZQ
Yelp reviewers seemed to love this so I had to get it. I loved the crunch from the chips, softened slightly by the stew, the intense spicy flavors, the hearty meat. However, the soup was more watery than I expected so it wasn't as hearty as I expected.

* Enchiladas (filled w/ shrimp, cotija cheese, carmelized leeks, poblano cream sauce, fresh salsa, black beans. $14.25) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/olea-san-francisco?select=tJoWFCTS0sNRSbLFVHYuFg#dm68z_VGkztAiv2a4Jzfjw
I was surprised to like this so much! I'm usually not much impressed by enchiladas, but I didn't realize this would be shrimp (my bf ordered this) and I found the meat to be really crunchy and fresh. The black beans were cooked just right, and the sauce was tasty.

Brunch menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/olea-san-francisco?select=tJoWFCTS0sNRSbLFVHYuFg#tJoWFCTS0sNRSbLFVHYuFg
author: Ziyan C.

description: The French Toast is definitely the breakfast item to get here. Was a little bummed they didn't have a side of fruit I could order in addition to my meal but I would still go back!
author: Run.It.Off V.

description:
I definitely recommend this place for brunch.

Based off of other reviews, the wait time can be a little long because the place is so small. We took those words of wisdom and arrived a half hour before they opened. At first, we were like, "This is crazy.... why did we come so early?" After about ten minutes of being there, we were more like, "Woah, I'm so glad that we came early." This is definitely a popular place and the line does stretch down the block pretty early on.

They don't do any sort of reservations and it's first-come, first-served. Before you're seated, your entire party must be there to ensure that a seat isn't going to waste. I completely understand the concept since every chair is prime real estate. With that being said, if you're an introvert and have to have your bubble of space, just know that they will seat people at the same table as you if there are seats available. Some may find that awkward, but that never bothers me.

I was already smitten when I sat down to see they had a full espresso bar as well as French pressed coffee. Of course I had to order both an Americano and the pressed versions to try out both methods, but my favorite was the pressed option. The Americano was good, but the carafe of coffee that was presented to me was nice and hot, smooth and made with a great bold, dark roast. It was about $5, and if I hadn't ordered the espresso drink, I just might have ordered another pitcher of the black goodness.

For food, I went with the ever so popular Olea's Challah Custard Toast. A full order got you two huge pieces of soft bread that had been dipped in egg and custard and grilled to a nice golden brown perfection. On top comes some delicious strawberries and once I poured on the maple syrup I was doneso. It's probably some of the best French Toast that I've ever put in my mouth.

We also split the scrambled eggs on an Acme rustic roll and it too was delicious. The bread is nice and hard on the outside and soft inside like a piece of ciabatta filled with a generous amount of eggs, bacon, tomatoes, and cheese that's served with a small side of greens.

Service was great and I loved how the owner came around to each table to converse with his customers. It was super busy, but he made sure to talk to everyone, clear tables, refill drinks, and give checks when his servers were helping other people. We never felt neglected.

I'll definitely keep this place on my radar the next time I'm in SF, I'll have to explore their dinner options at some point, too!
author: Ryan C.

description:
I waited for about 45 minutes with two of my friends to have brunch here and if I'm waiting that long ...the food better knock my socks off, which it did not. I almost wish I had just sucked it up and waited the extra hour to get a table across the street at Mymy, but we were also pressed for time. 

My overall experience with what I ordered/experienced/ambience/etc. is getting a two star rating. HOWEVER, I did try my friend's Challah French Toast which was off the hook (no one says that anymore...I don't know why I said that). So if I was reviewing just that dish alone, I would say four stars. The bread was thick and fluffy and randomly moist in the middle...it was just great.  

That was probably the only redeeming thing of my whole experience here. I also tried the kale/butternut squash omelette (which came with a pathetic salad on the side) and the Cazuela. Both the dishes were just mediocre and nothing stood out in terms of taste. It's not that they tasted bad, they were just boring, which makes this place not "line-worthy". The service was also kind of sleepy and slow and it always took just a bit too long to flag someone down.
author: Renu A.

description: This tiny breakfast joint is very french chic.  The prices are high, but at least the portions are large.  The French Toast is a must try.  I got the pork tacos and fries, both were tasty.  I'm surprised a breakfast joint like this can make such perfect fries.  I'm definitely a fan and will try to return soon!
author: Soo Jin M.

description: We showed up on a Saturday, super surprised to see that there was no wait. I then preceded to eat the driest, most flavorless omelette of my life ... My brunch partner got the same tasteless omelette, so it is possible that other things on the menu are better. The service was fine, but I will most definitely not be coming back.
author: Claire K.

description: Pet friendly!!! They were very willing to accommodate my Siberian husky with a nice spot outside. This place has fantastic food, a great location and outdoor seating to soak up that beautiful SF sunshine. The staff is super friendly, very accommodating and they seem to really enjoy what they do.
author: Tim E.

description: Legit Brunch. Made & served with love. Superb choices & coffees. Why are you in line across the street?
author: Susan C.

description:
With a line so long at Olea, I expected a really good brunch/lunch spot. I came here on a Sunday around lunchtime and the line was about a good 35 minute wait. My party and I waited with our big umbrellas in hand in the rain. We were finally seated and the menu is very limited. Usually, places with limited menus will focus on the quality of the food and excel. However, I was quite disappointed to be honest. The majority of my party ordered the cazuela which they enjoyed. I tried it and it was good.

I ordered the braised pork shoulder sandwich with fries. The pork shoulder sandwich looked  very good and I was excited to bite into it. However, the pork was chewy and dry. Usually meats that are braised have a soft texture with juices oozing out. This wasn't the case. At nearly $13 for the sandwich and fries, it didn't really meet my expectations in terms of price and quality. When it came time to pay for the bill, it took a very long time to receive our check then which was at least 20 mins and then again to get our cards back. With a limited menu, I expected them to excel at every dish on the menu. For me, it just didn't do it for me.
author: Danster L.

description: My coworker always recommends this place to all of our customers so I had to try it for myself. I came to this place with high expectations and I was blown away. Our server was the owner, and he was brilliant. The food was to die for. Everything from the bread to the dessert was amazing. Their menu changes all the time, so that's something to considered before coming into the restaurant.
author: Genesis G.

description:
Unfortunately, what could have been a decent brunch was ruined by less than stellar service and atmosphere. First of all, on a lovely day in SF the room was incredibly hot and stuffy, which was unpleasant. Then upon asking for water, we were brought half-filled cups of warm tap water. We then had to ask for ice and more water which seemed to irritate the waiter. Food was mediocre; $15 for a (not large) breakfast sandwich with 10 leaves of lettuce (supposed to be a "salad?") on the side. 

All in all, there was a lot of potential here, but we will probably not be returning after this experience.
author: Abby B.

description:
I'm sadly knocking 2 stars off this place.  I visited the restaurant again today and was pleasantly surprised that they had started outdoor seating meaning (hopefully) we would be seated faster.  This was true; however, it seems as if they did not increase their wait staff.  Instead of a quaint brunch with friendly servers, it seemed as if they were overworked, and running around.  The table to the left had to ask multiple times for their check.  We did not get cream/milk with our coffee (and I mean for 8 bucks, really...) or syrup with our french toast.  The saddest part was when we realized that they changed our favorite dish - the Cazuela.  Instead of a special dish, it seemed rather plain in appearance and in flavor (its usually kind of green).  The waiter replied that sometimes they change the ingredients and was not sure when the other dish would be back.  

So anyways, still a decent spot, BUT i'm not sure it's worth the wait in line, over-worked servers, a-OK service just for slightly above average brunch.
author: Aly A.

description: My partner and I go to Olea every weekend. We love the brunch and service... so much better and better for you than mymy across the street. Their menu is great for all preferences. We didn't know they were open for dinner until recently and it was fantastic, best steak I'd had in a while :)
author: Tanya H.

description:
Leisurely ambiance. Fresh, flavorful plates worth the starving wait between the line out the door and the slow-food service. Really friendly service. Recommend the Avo toast and the scrambled egg sandwich. The eggs are perfect, and I will be returning with friends. 

Also, was impressed by their assorted selection of nice breads. Challah for French toast, a levain for the avocado toast and a crunchy baguette for the scrambled egg sandwich. 

The mixed greens that accompany many of the plates were to die for. Great for brunch if you feel like waiting. The noise is a little overwhelming, but there are seating options both in and outside.
author: Julia-Rose K.

description:
Well, the wait almost made me take a star away, then I ate. Delicious!!! I had the Pork Shoulder sandwich, but my companions had the Cazuela Eggs and Migas con Huevo. I suggest all three. The Sake bloody was excellent, the Mimosas were standard. 

Once seated the service was impeccable, and all was well worth the wait, especially on a sunny day off.
author: Greg F.

description: Decided to eat here when the place across the street was too busy. Great decision. I had some of the best French press coffee I've ever had and some delicious huevos rancheros.
author: Carl E.

description: Overrated. Food was mediocre tasting (for brunch at least), service was ok. A couple things that were dumb: We were served water that was hot (steaming, because it had been sitting in the sun). I told the waiter and his response was jokingly "well maybe because it's been sitting in the sun!" Like what the hell, if you knew this, why would you serve it? To fix the problem he brought ice to pour into our cups, which was a little messy. Not the way I would go about it. Food was stupidly priced for how average and kind of bland it tasted. $15 for avocado toast? We got the smoked salmon toast and avocado toast, both tasted like things we could make at home. And apparently yelp says they received a poor health score.
author: L T.

description:
Nothing beats brunch after a night of drinking! 

At around 10:45am the wait was about 30 minutes. 

What we ordered:

Challah Custard French Toast: YUM! I got the full order which was probably too much but the bf helped me finish it. The toast is light and the cinnamon is delicious! The texture of the custard was on point. It have the toast a fluffy almost squishy feeling and I was smiling with every bite. 

Cazuela: Perfect comfort food for a hangover. The tomato sauce had lots of spices and flavor. I probably would prefer a slightly thicker tomato sauce. I liked the baked egg in the dish. A fried egg would probably go well, too.

Iced Coffee: I didn't care for the coffee prepared this way. I get what Candice H. means when she says it has a sour flavor. Te latte didn't have the same flavor, though. 

The food took quite a while to come out but was worth it. Service was friendly. :) 

I wouldn't definitely come back!
author: Lena H.

description:
Came here for brunch with the hubby and waited about 20 minutes for a table as the restaurant is small.

We both ordered the Challah Custard French Toast as the other items on the menu were too heavy.  The French toast is topped with Korintji cinnamon sugar and strawberries.  It was tasty and very light even though there's custard.  The husband felt the custard gave the French toast an undercooked marshmallow texture which he didn't like.  

We also ordered the large Blue Bottle French pressed coffee that tasted sour. Not sure if it was the blend or something was wrong. We both didn't care for it.
author: Candice H.

description:
Excellent service, a cute little patio and a delicious brunch menu. A variety of egg and meat-based dishes, there's something for everyone. Our table had the huevos rancheros and the pork tacos with a side of beans, both very tasty.

This is a great choice for people in severe nut and shellfish allergies like myself. The staff are careful and knowledgable, and the menu is pretty small / there was no shellfish on it anyway when I was there.
author: Kate H.

description:
As you approach the intersection of California and Larkin street, you are greeted by quite a scene - hoards of people gathered around two restaurants across the street. Of course it's a Sunday morning, and San Francisco brunch beckons. The question is, which line to pick? 

Since I've been to Mymy (which asks you to put your name down), my friend and I decide to check out Olea. Do not be deterred by the long line, it moves pretty quickly! We waited for about 20 minutes for a table for 2.

The menu had tons of choices, which were appealing, but my friend and I both decided we wanted the Migas con Huevos. Scrambled eggs with tortilla chips, with a side of salsa, that sounded like just what we wanted to fill our eager stomachs. While the eggs were well scrambled, the whole dish lacked flavor and left me wanting more. The two small pieces of bread, while perfectly sized to scoop the eggs on, were slightly too hard. I was disappointed, especially since I had my expectations pegged high upon seeing the line and the other yelp reviews. Perhaps I will come back to try something else - but perhaps not, seeing how there are many other places in the city left to explore.
author: Julia N.

description: This one is just another ordinary brunch spot in the city. Not sure if its worth the wait.
author: Ellie D.

description:
Great spot for brunch! We came here with a group of 6 and waited about 45 minutes in line. They do let you know that they might split bigger parties into 2 tables. 

The juice at Olea is super fresh, but the michelada and Bloody Mary were okay and a bit too spicy. The coffee was good not great. I didn't order the French press of Blue Bottle because it looked like too much coffee. 

I ordered the huevos rancheros, which were really good! The plate had a lot of food, with homemade tortillas and great chicken sausage on the side. The plate was a little too drippy for me, there wasn't enough tortilla or something to pick everything up. I did love the flavor overall. 

I would come here again but definitely have some better places to go. We waited a long time for our food but the service was great.
author: Lauren G.

description:
Randomly came here one weekend for Brunch. There were three other couples in front of me and the bff. We waited about an hour unbeknownst to us until we were seated. While standing in the sun and starved we tried to figure out what to order. Majority of people on yelp recommended the baked egg dish and french toast. That's exactly what we ordered, we split it and did not regret one bite. 

The baked egg dish was phenomenal. It was delicious and unique. It consisted of this umami-laden broth with ground pork, jalopenos, some veggies and two baked eggs. DELICIOUS! I wanted to lick the thing it was so good. I would return just for this, not sure if I would wait an hour for it though (there's not much I'd wait an hour for).

The french toast was also really good. Not too sweet. Had the right amount of mixture soaked into the bread so it wasn't dried. 

I'm curious how dinner is at Olea and I'll have to find out one day.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I guess with SF brunch places, the first thing people want to hear is how long the wait is. Well I got here at 12:30 on a Saturday and the wait was 5 minutes. AND it's opposite the street to Mymy (phenomenal btw), where the wait is substantially longer.

I got the Custard French Toast and a large glass of Orange Juice. The OJ was exceptional, just to my liking. Fresh, sweet and full of pulp. The French Toast on the other hand was good, but not great. The OJ definitely carried the team in this instance though.

If you want a decent place that doesn't have as long as a wait as some of the staple SF brunch spots then definitely check Olea out!!
author: Ray H.

description:
Oh, how I love brunch!  It is too early to beat the line and when you're there during peak hours, the wait can be horrendous!  That is why you sleep in and wait until the last hour to get in because it is a win win situation on not having to wake up early and not having to wait in line for a whole hour or so!  That is exactly what I did coming here!

Their brunch food is spot on!  You must get their Cazuela!  The presentation looks great and the entree tasted like a light chili stew!  Yum, for a late brunch meal!

Their custard strawberry French toast sprinkled with and surrounded by cinnamon, reminded me a bit like a churro!  I tended to have a high expectation on this dish because the description of it, sounded scrumptious.  However, it was disappointing in a way that I imagined custard filled toast.  It was just buttered up instead.

Their French pressed coffee is clean and strong.  No need for sugar or milk to corrupt the natural flavor of the coffee.

Service was good and the decor is like a communal kind of table setting.  

They serve American cuisine for dinner as well.

It is a small, mellow corner restaurant to enjoy a dining setting, surely!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
JQ and I came here for brunch on a weekday, only to find out that they weren't serving brunch that day :( So we settled for lunch, which was pretty good. The venue is quite small, located on the corner of California and Larkin. You walk down some stairs into the restaurant (so you can see the feet of people walking by if you're next to the windows). It was really quiet when we were there since there was only one other couple. Since it was not busy, we had no issues with service. I think we were actually served by the owner, who seemed like a nice guy. He would check up on us to make sure we were happy with the food and whatnot. They also have one small bathroom for customers to use.

We got two of their sandwiches and split them:
-- Braised Beef Short Rib Sandwich: With Arugula, Served with Mixed Greens
