The beef was really tender and qutie delicious. I'm not a big fan of salads so I stuck with my fries, but JQ said the salad was refreshing and pretty good.
-- Pork Shoulder Sandwich: With Apple Cider Slaw, Served with French Fries
While this sandwich was not bad, we both definitely preferred the short rib sandwich. The cider slaw was just meh. But of course I enjoyed the fries.

I wish I could have tried the brunch here but oh well :/
author: Esther K.

description: I'll keep this short and sweet, because all you really need to know is this: come for brunch, order the Challah custard French toast, and live happily ever after.
author: Liz F.

description:
Very cute brunch place in Nob Hill. The coffee is very good. I'm not sure I'm a fan of the Bloody Mary. They were really thick, a bit warm and not served over ice.

However, saved by the delicious custard toast, better than French toast and one of the best meals I've had lately.

The avocado toast was excellent. Artisan olive oil, red pepper flakes and thinly sliced avocado.

Will definitely eat here again
author: Sarah S.

description:
Worst Heavos Rancheros I've ever had. (I don't understand other people's reviews with all this flavor and delicious food, it was bland AF and trust me I enjoy my food and flavors)

Smallest portions I've had at a brunch place EVER (Ordered more tortillas, they brought out 1)

Absolute WORST Manager/Owner/Host maybe even human being? ever? it's up for debate - Pretentious, rude, judgmental 

I would ABSOLUTELY recommend going to a liquor store to have a better dining experience than going to this unimaginably terrible restaurant. 

- Shawn
author: Shawn W.

description:
World's most pretentious waitstaff; good food.

We waited a half hour outside in the cold to be seated here. The couple behind us did not want to be seated at a "communal table", but the manager of the restaurant informed them that it would be an additional half-hour wait.

Five minutes after sitting down, two tables opened up.

We had observed that the table we were seated at was adjacent to an open window, and it was cold. We hadn't yet warmed up from standing outside.

When we requested that the window be closed, the waitress and the host came by together as a team to inform us that they could not close the window more than an additional half-inch, since they need to keep the room ventilated.

We asked the waitstaff if we could move to one of the tables that opened up.

The host said that he first had to see who else was waiting outside for a table. He returned and said that he could not move us, because there was a larger party waiting.

The party that was waiting to be seated was five people---the exact capacity of the table that this other couple and we were seated at.

The manager informed us that we would need to ask the couple that we were sitting with if they were also willing to move. They said yes. In front of him. The host then repeated to us in a condescending tone that he does not move seated guests, and that we would have to ask the couple next to us if they were willing to move. Again, we asked them in front of him, and again, they said yes.

When the food finally came, we asked for a single slice of bread to help mop up the sauce. The waitress said she could not bring us a slice of bread. We would have to order four slices of toast from the menu.

The staff never came by to check how we were doing during the course of the meal.

The food here is good. It's overpriced, but it's good. It's prepared nicely.

The manager should not be in his role as a manager. Nobody wants to visit a restaurant where they're given a hard time for making a reasonable request to feel comfortable.

And now I'm getting harassed by the manager for this review. Classy way to handle your business.
author: Ian M.

description:
Edited :

It is a cute spot for a small brunch for 2 or a couple of friends. It is a bit small so I don't recommend bringing your kids.  The host didn't want us to bring our stroller inside and said to leave it outside.  Really?  We told him that it can fold itself and wouldn't take much room. We finally were able to get seated after a 20 minute wait-with the stroller.  Not really kid friendly here, I guess! 
The food was just not good for my taste... 
I had the corncakes with fried eggs and veggie mash.  Sorry but I hardly ate it. Hubby had some beef sandwich. ..

Conclusion: we didn't finish our plates....I personally didn't like my plate but the people on the next table loved it! It's all about taste and preferences,  I suppose.
author: Deb M.

description:
I have to say, this a somewhat different place with dinner menu we found on a rather eclectic side. The ambience is very small & cozy, and it seemed a bit pricey (at least, whatever we chose to order). The service was very courteous & we liked the actual food that we had ordered.

Will we come back here very often? I don't think so. But that's mostly because we don't live very close-by & it's somewhat out of the way for us. Even if we did live nearby, we think it would be a great place to visit, perhaps twice a year with friends (during summer time & Holidays season).
author: Sharmila B.

description: Loved this place!  Was roaming in the area looking for somewhere for breakfast on a Saturday.  There was a line, but the management got through the line SO quickly. We were seated outside, and our waitress couldn't have been nicer or more helpful and checked on us regularly. I had the bacon omlette (YUM) and a couple of glasses of perfect orange juice.  Would happily return!
author: Erin D.

description:
********
Just reading your response now lol. Your pathetic lies and immature response says everything about your piss poor attitude and service. We never rearranged a single seat or table. We were told by one of your staff it's first come first serve at the patio and sat on a table of 4. The table had 4 empty glasses. Nice attempt to make us sound like hooligans, little do you know about us. Maybe what you didn't really like was my people's colour. "OYE" lol 
*********

Last weekend, four of us plus our two dogs came to Olea for brunch. There was a small line up outside. We stood in line and the host happened to be asking how many ppl. We said 4 and will sit outside since we have dogs. Waitress said ok, its first come first serve outside so whenever one opens but we don't know the wait time. All the other customers ahead of us were waiting to be seated inside as it was drizzling (we heard them say inside and my wife personally asked everyone to verify they are not waiting for outside seating). A table of 4 eventually opened up on the patio. It hand empty glasses (no dishes at that point). Since we were next in outside seating we grabbed it (per the instructions to grab when one becomes available). Shortly after a waiter or buss boy came to grab the empty glasses from our table. We actually helped him collect the glasses and placed them on his tray. He started saying "you should check with host before sitting", asked us to move b/c he was cleaning and how it's "common curtesy to wait to be seated". Seriously? Didn't even ask if we check w/hottest  already, he was lecturing us in a rude aggressive manner. He clearly did not want us there for some reason so we simply gathered ourselves and went across the street where we've always had wonderful food and experience. It was silly of us to think "let's try something new". Olea requested to remove my first review for lack of details, hope this paints the picture of our experience and our sincere apologies that we didn't meet your specific criteria. Thank you!
author: Aziz S.

description: I've had the BLTA on a few occasions, you can never go wrong with that! And of course the custard French toast - mm so delicious. The wait is also reasonable, typically less than 10m for a seat, much more reasonable than Mymy's across the street. There is also a lot more seating, so it's good for larger groups, too.
author: Elisa L.

description:
I don't normally leave review but mom enjoyed it so much that she insisted I leave one :)

The food was excellent and they were so nice and accommodating with all of my dietary restrictions. We had the quinoa, pork loin and bavette steak and the gelato and sorbetto for dessert. 
Would recommend all of these! Steak was cooked perfectly and the carrot purée was delicious
author: Alex S.

description: Worst spot ever! Owner or the man with glasses who seats you is rude and asks for a "must tip!" lol go sell yourself dude!!! Lol don't recommend this spot at all...
author: Leah A.

description: My usual but the most special breakfast lunch place. I don't know if any other place makes French toast this good. Lines might be killing but worthy waiting with a good company of people. Too bad it's open only on weekdays
author: Edward M.

description: This place is so yummy for brunch! We lucked out and didn't need to wait too long, though it seems like the wait can be obscene sometimes. Service was fast, portions were substantial, and it was a nice romantic weekend brunch spot overall.
author: Jen H.

description: One of my fave places. I always get the corn cakes, which are super satisfying and the perfect way to eat eggs over easy. I also always sneak a bite of french toast from whomever happens to order it! It's custardy and sweet and served with some sort of fresh fruit. I've also loved the avocado toast and cazuela...but always go back to the corn cakes :)
author: Felicia B.

description: Lovely cosy neighborhood spot. We had dinner on a weekday and enjoyed the food and attentive service. While the menu is not extensive, one can find something to their liking. We had a salad and soup to start with, both fresh and flavorful, followed by trout and pasta entrees, which were cooked to perfection, and ended the meal with a slice of  cheesecake. Wonderful experience and we look forward to dining at Olea again.
author: EG P.

description:
Came here for breakfast this morning and ordered the full size french toast, all i can say is wow. It was Challah with custard filling and covered in cinnamon sugar, topped with strawberries. The food was absolutely delicious, was the perfect amount of sweet. The full size was two of these bad boys, but with the extreme fluffiness from the custard, it was very filling. We also ordered a large french press coffee for the four of us, only was enough for three full cups. The coffee was pretty regular, nothing special, but can't say it was bad.

When me and my three friends arrived, we walked right in without a line. Service was pretty good and quick. However, towards the end, It started to get a little packed and people were waiting for tables and the waiters/waitresses seemed to be eyeing us and getting a bit pushy so we would leave and give up the table. We were basically still finishing up our meal when we noticed this attitude.

Have to say that the pricing was a little high as well. If I remember correctly the french toast was around $14.75 and the large french press was $8.75. In my opinion, that's pretty steep for breakfast. On the bright side, they were giving 3% off of the check if you pay with cash, so this was pretty nice to have.

In conclusion, enjoyed the food, service was great until the very end, prices were a bit high, but would recommend.
author: Steven P.

description: This cute restaurant is the perfect weekend breakfast spot in Nob Hill. The owner himself  greeted us and got us seated right away. He recommend the French press, delicious bold coffee! All of the staff is super friendly, we chatted with the owner quite a bit. Great guy! I ordered the avocado toast and my BF got the huevos rancheros added bacon. BF pro tip take some of the avo from the girlfriends toast and use as a nice topper. If I lived in SF this would be my go-to spot. Still dreaming about that avo toast...
author: Kaitlin B.

description: Lovely cazuela: you are so delicious. Hot, tangy, filling but not too heavy. The perfect breakfast for a chilly SF morning. Mine had shredded chicken and a tomatillo sauce, with egg and some sliced mushrooms (?), but yes it all worked. It was wonderful. We also tried the challah french toast which was a good addition for some sweetness. Hell, not some sweetness a LOT of sweetness but it was soft, fluffy and worth getting. The avocado toast needed a sprinkle of salt to really shine. And it had to be eaten all together to taste good: egg, perfectly ripe and delicious tomato, and the salad. At first it seemed bland but as you ate everything the flavors melded together and it is a light addition to a meal. On our second visit (yeah they earned two out of our five SF breakfasts!) we had the huevos rancheros, and the corn cakes with vegetable hash. Both were done nicely. My sweetie loved the vegetable hash. I felt the corn cakes would have been better if warmer. I liked the sauce with my huevos, but huevos always leaves me a little hungry...I should have added something more filling. Still, their mexican sauces are seasoned well, and everything was fantastic overall. A french press coffee was good and strong, and I loved my cappuccino on the 2nd visit. Service was extremely friendly and they recognized us as well. I will miss you beautiful cazuela until I can return again.
author: Stephen K.

description:
The last time we were in San Francisco, Matt P found a great spot for us to have brunch.  It was a toss up between Olea and the breakfast café next door.  We finally went with Olea, because they seated us first.

I ordered the scrambled eggs with tortilla chips and ham (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/14OmmSWHfM717iZo5jePtg?select=QSrkSoZseaBTEjHZIzNDgg#xq42YwnRcyaUEWX7fvK-Pg)  I don't remember the exact name, but I'm positive it wasn't the flat omlette or the cazuela.  It was so good, that Matt P and Robert H decided to copy my order, and order the same thing.

The other party in our group ordered the slowly braised marinated pulled pork sandwich with green cabbage, cilantro and yellow carrot slaw and a side of roasted new potatoes.  Between the two, our dish was definitely better.  The scrambled eggs kind of reminded me of a different way of making chilaquiles.  IT's not as good as chilaquiles, but it did have more eggs.  I liked it, and the amount was a good size... enough to leave me full.

Since this place was pretty small, we sat at a long community table with two or three other groups.  It was a fun experience. I didn't get to try their famous coffee, but I'm not really a coffee drinker.  You will have to wait for Matt P's review for that.
author: Emily S.

description: Lucky enough to find this place by chance on our last day in San Francisco. Will be back every time we visited. Delicious food cooked to perfection. Loved it!
author: Rob S.

description:
After my friends helped me move I brought them here for brunch! They don't take reservations but luckily the wait wasn't very long. The inside was small and very cute.

I had the challah bread french toast (13.75) and fresh squeezed orange juice (3.75), and both were good. If you like this French toast I highly recommend checking out The Front Porch in bernal heights -- they have similar French toast sticks that are crispy on the outside!!

This place is fancier than Mymy across the street, so it would be nicer for a first date. Half the menu is Latin-inspired breakfast, which isn't what I go usually go for, so I had trouble picking what to eat. But if that's your jam, this place is great!
author: Cynthia W.

description:
I was super excited to try this place!! Whenever I walk by the inside looks cute, clean and put together.  I looked up the yelp review once upon a time and saw the four stars so didn't even think twice. 

My friend and I ordered the french toast, pork shoulder sandwich, omelette & latte.

Service:
The female server that helped us was polite and gracious. Super nice, very pleasant. The male server ( not the owner ) was a bit absent service wise (must be specific, don't want to mislead the owner) , but nonetheless helped when I asked or water or for ketchup.

Food:
Took about 20 min for the food to come out. Place was quiet (came in at 11am) but felt that the wait for the food was just a bit long.

Simple plating, both my friend who's a cook at 1760 (so he knows his tastebuds and has credibility food wise!! ) and I agreed that the food needed seasoning. 

I thought that since I love salty food I was just the only one, but he agreed as well. We tried to eat the omelette and sandwich without salt and pepper but just couldn't do it! Had to get an extra ketchup because the food needed it. (also they only give you a tiny bit of ketchup with a good amount of fries..after reading other reviews, maybe it's because they're trying to save.....)  However the fries were very very salty, luckily I love salty fries, but for someone/my friend that isn't a salt addict like me, it was too salty for him. Very crispy though :) 

French Toast was nice, custardy in the middle, not too heavy. Sweet enough, but paired great with maple syrup. 

Latte- friend said was not bad, but not amazing. 

****All in all the food was alright. For a $15 dollar sandwich (including tip) I would have expected a little bit more. And my friend who had the omelette enjoyed his omelette much more after some salt & pepper. 

Thumbs up for the male server that asked for my ID since he saw on my card to " SEE ID" so that made me smile, what he lacked in service he made up with reading what was on the back of my credit card :)

Luckily I didn't experience the wrath of the owner even though  he was there...He gave us our french toast and told us that the rest of the food would be coming... I'm glad I didn't make him mad! Probably won't be back, from my experience/meal here & other reviews it seems as though there are many rules to follow.
author: Selina W.

description:
This place is just...weird.  There are often lines waiting for a table and I really do not understand why.  I have been here twice and neither occasion was very good.  It is not a pleasant environment to have a meal in, and the meals themselves are mediocre.  

The place is staffed primarily by stuffy white folks who seem to take no pleasure in being there.  I have seen them be especially rude to families with smaller children.  Their attitude does nothing to help the lackluster food taste any better.  Portion sizes are small, and it's kind of hit or miss whether you'll like it enough to finish it.  I'm pretty tolerant, but really, this place just makes you feel like you'd rather not be there.  

Just head to MyMy across the street for a more relaxed atmosphere and better food.
author: Lars T.

description: The dinner at Olea was hands-down one of the best meals I've had in months. This unassuming little place packs a big punch. I had the steak and my friend had the pasta. I would recommend this place to anyone, and will be going back.
author: James H.

description:
Challah! That's why we waited 45 minutes for a spot. Challah custard toast with cinnamon sugar toppped with fresh strawberries. No worries if you're thinking it's going to be super sweet. It's not! But the promise of that French toast goodness in a terrific presentation delivers! $11.50

We also shared their Soft scrambled eggs on acme bread rustic roll with tomato slices and bacon, with a side of salad. $10.50. Add $1.75 if you want cheese.

Freshly squeezed orange juice completes the meal. $ 3.50.

Awesome host. They deliver this customer service that makes you feel it's ok to wait 45 minutes for their food. It was a warm day in the city. Water was offered for waiting customers. 

But once you order food comes out in average time- a bit faster actually!

Olea won't sit you if your party is not complete. They would also ask you if you prefer a private table or if you don't mind a communal one. DO NOT forget to sign your name as soon as you get to Olea. 

A fan of the Challah! Wooohooo!
author: Janet D.

description:
Olea is arguably the best restaurant in Nob Hill, which says a lot given the vibrancy of the neighborhood. Absolutely amazing for brunch and quite solid for dinner -- it's rare to find any restaurant that can do both so skillfully.

Brunch: Expect a line (typically 15-30 minute wait). Definitely worth it. They serve blue bottle coffee here (recommendation: get it french press). Best french toast  in city. Cazuela is served in a hot skillet and is absolutely a must try if you've never had this dish before. The Migas Con Huevo is a little heartier than the Cazuela and also fantastic. The Scrambled Egg Sandwich is arguably the most substantial savory item as it's fairly large and comes with a large salad too. 

Service is nice and friendly. I only wish they cleared tables faster and kept the line moving faster.

Dinner: It's definitely an intimate setting as people haven't figured out this place is great for dinner. Service is very attentive and friendly. I was recommended the pork chop which I tried and it was surprisingly moist and well cooked. It was very substantial in portion and the accompanying root veggies were delicious. They were great at suggesting accompanying wines by the glass. The scallops were great too as an entree if you're looking for something lighter.
author: Victor W.

description: Enjoyed a lovely birthday dinner for my mother. The service was excellent! I had the Pappardelle Pasta with Lamb Meatballs and it was amazing! The ingredients were all very fresh. The meatballs really made the dish for me, they were perfectly cooked and juicy. I would definitely reccomend this place to anyone!!
author: Chanel A.

description:
Olea is not your average Sunday brunch serving up some new ways of dishing out your... dishes.

The challah custard toast is amazing.  This isn't your typical "french" toast meal, but instead a Jewish tradition mixed with the ever-so-expected real maple syrup.  The menu does change frequently - almost on a weekly basis, always serving up the freshest of fresh.

Located on the corner of California and Larkin,  Olea is easily missed.  If it weren't for the several groups usually waiting outside to clue you in on what's happening downstairs.  This quiet little restaurant seems homely with lamps and small country-ish tables adoring it's inner walls.  Make sure to bring a sweater, don't be afraid to wait a bit, and check out their ever-changing menu.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Arrived at this adorable neighborhood spot to find that they seat as first come first serve, and you have to wait in line outside the restaurant. On a busy day, that would really suck but somehow we were lucky enough to be seated within 10 minutes. 

- Challah custard toast - whoaaaa so good. Not too sweet yet still super decadent. Definitely try this even if you aren't big on sweets for breakfast
- Omelet - I don't love omelets, so I thought this was just ok. It was pretty cheesy. 
- Huevos rancheros - Loved how fresh this dish was, especially compared to other huevos rancheros. It was a bit bland though and could've used some hot sauce.
- Poached eggs with polenta cakes - My favorite dish by far, with a delicious tangy green sauce. If they have this on the menu, make sure you order it.

If it's not too busy, this is an excellent spot for brunch. Highly recommend!
author: Amy Y.

description: I recently had brunch at Olea. I ordered the Huevos Rancheros and thought it was good, not great. It seemed as if they were trying to make up the lack of flavor by drenching it in spicy sauces. I would like to mention that if i ever do go back i plan on ordering the french toast, as many previous yelpers stated, it is great (i tried a piece from my friend). Also interestingly, if you plan on ordering coffee they serve it in a french press and it tasted good although im no coffee connoisseur. One last note, it may have been that we went on mothers day, but the price seemed alittle high, also they charge 3% less if you pay cash.
author: Matthew H.

description: Unpleasant experience. Disclaimer: I did not eat anything here and I'm sure the food is wonderful. However, the service my party encountered was unsatisfactory. I was meeting 4 other people for brunch. The first person to arrive asked for an estimate of time for a party of 5. Oddly, the host denied us even an idea of the wait time even after we asked several times. While waiting, we overheard a couple asking to stand inside because it was too cold outside. "Welcome to San Francisco" he said, denying their request. It seemed as though he didn't even want their business. At this point we were very turned off and decided to leave. We went across the street to a resteraunt called Mymy where the service is delightful and the food is delicious. As I write this review, I am drinking the freshest orange juice next to a wonderful heat lamp looking at the shivering crowd across the street.
author: Christa B.

description: This is a good place to go once to get it off your list of restaurant recommendations. The food is overpriced and in my opinion not worth it. It's typical breakfast food. I had the Huevos Rancheros and it looked unappetizing. It was slightly cold which made it less enjoyable. The one thing that was absolutely fabulous was the Challah toast. That's a no brainer if you decide to visit this place. The staff is very attentive, and the ambiance is relaxed.
author: Leila H.

description: Amazing food and excellent service. Three of the four of us had the filet and all of us found that ours was perfectly prepared to our liking. Cute neighborhood gem with a wonderful ambiance! 5 stars all the way!
author: Lindsey M.

description: They don't have a list to put your name down on. They ask you to line up at the fire hydrant and wait until a table is ready for you.  What are we? Dogs??  No one to tell you roughly how long the wait is either.  But since so many people are sheep nowadays I guess this business will continue to remain busy.
author: David S.

description:
Decided to try this place for brunch this last Sunday and I will say the experience was filled with both good and bad. 
I always like to start with the bad news first...
1st off, I HATE when I have to wait in line and not be able to put my name down at a restaurant. Along with that, Olea's owner is the host and he does NOT allow outside food or drink. No seriously, he will force you to chug your coffee or juice that you went out and got because you were forced to wait in line. The two women who were sitting next to us somehow got the coffee by the Drink Nazi himself, and made for an awkward situation as he said he doesn't allow outside drinks and needs her to chug it now or give it to him. 
Weird right?
Now for the good news...the inside and the beverages. I liked the music (upbeat, loud), the fresh squeezed oj or grapfruit juice(mimosas), the french pressed coffee (self-pressed by you at your table), and the polite servers.

So the food...I ordered the scrambled egg sandwich with tomato, bacon, and cheddar served on an Acme rustic roll w/ a side of greens...overall: 3/5
Why? I like a fried egg not a scrambled egg...always makes for a more bland sandwich. My favorite part was the bread...
My girlfriend ordered the Cazuela...a renowned and beautiful dish of theirs (Baked Eggs with Pork, Bacon, Garbanzo Beans, Spinach, Parmesan Cheese, Tomato Sauce)
overall : 3.5/5 
Why? It is okay but for $13.75 'the juice is not worth the squeeze... ' It is a flavorful broth with a few eggs cooked in that my girlfriend said is nothign she would go back for. 
Lastly, we gave into the hype and split the French Toast that the Yelp reviews were ranting about. I thought it was pretty tasty and gave it a 3/5 my girlfriend would've joined the hype and given it a 4/5 claiming "it was just perfect. "

Overall...Olea's brunch gets a 3.7/5 and I wilI : MAYBE go back
Why? Because though I hate waiting in line,  I did enjoy the music and beverages, and the food was good but, nothing to die for.
author: Naveed B.

description:
I love their French Toast. I really do.

Their custard toast is a little bit more special than your typical pan fried eggy bread. 

First, the texture was perfect. The toast was fluffy on the touch, slightly crispy on the outside and really bouncy in the center. The egg custard was cooked through and there was not a hint of sogginess. 

Secondly, maple syrup and the strawberry topping were completely addictive. It wasn't too sugary nor thick. It was tasty till the very last bite.

Lastly, it just looked beautiful. I love the plating and presentation. How could it not be a wonderful day waking up to a breakfast/brunch like this?

Cazuela and other items on the menu were good but I would come here just for the french toast.
author: Mona W.

description:
I've had a 3.5-4 year relationship with Olea. 

It started long distance; I came in for business one week and a friend invited me to come try it out. Ended up having the Challah custard French toast with a large French press of blue bottle.

All that time and maybe three dozen visits since (I live much closer now, in the bay), I've only ever ordered the toast. It's the best French toast I've ever had.

Like all relationships, there's been growth. Management changed, a mini-Cooper drove into the side of the building, closing it for a few months... You know, typical relationship stuff.

I enjoy the current owner, Phillip. He's straight forward and takes the business seriously. He reminds me a bit of Tim Gunn. Despite ownership changing hands, the quality of the food and service remains high. It's still a fabulous location (and the building is probably more structurally reinforced now following the compact German car's uninvited half-entrance).

Few rules: you line up outside and will only be seated when you're all there. It's a small place, and even though they have outdoor seating now, the wait for 4+ during peak brunch hours can easily run over 30 min. No outside food or drinks.

Look, I can't tell you how the eggs are here, or whether the dinner menu is good. I see other people ordering not-French Toast and I get brain hurt. I'm sure that food is all terrific, because their ingredients and the overall menu are all excellent. Still, Olea is a challah custard French toast factory as far as I'm concerned. The only needed improvements are an automated ramp that brings endless toast out, and a chair and table positioned right in front of it so I can sit there with my mouth open and gorge.

If a sweet breakfast sounds good to you, and if you're a fan of French toast, I personally think this is the tastiest option in the city. Certainly the best toast I've ever had.

Dolla' make you challah, folks.
author: Aram J.

description:
Rude man "served" us. Couldn't have been made to feel more unwelcome in this restaurant if he had tried. I don't really understand because usually in San Francisco wait staff are so welcoming and friendly.

The food itself was good, but being treated the way we were ruined the experience for me.

I see in the comments that I am not the first to have experienced this at Olea, I wish I had read the reviews before going to this restaurant.

With so many fine places in San Francisco, I just wouldn't bother with Olea, the food isn't good enough to justify being made to feel like you are bothering the staff by being there.
author: Chris S.

description:
Find of the month for sure. I think the best way to describe it is a vegetarian restaurant that serves meat. The dishes veritably ooze freshness, wholesomeness and healthiness, and they're damn tasty too. Add a cozy basement location in (or at least near) the city's best neighborhood and what more do you want?

Well, I think the pork chop could have been juicier and arranged on a more exciting bed than brown rice and peas. But it was still tasty and didn't do anything to erase my memory of the frisee salad with mussels I had as a starter. That was absolutely stunning - the best salad I've had this year.

My Girlfriend's meal consisted of the flat bread (flattest bread I've ever had and among the tastiest) with ricotta, pears and greens and a Mexican beef stew. Both of those were positively delicious. And the chocolate pot de creme for dessert was awesome as well.

Our waiter was a delight as well, so all in all this was a hit and we'll be going back for sure, not only for more dinners but for brunch as well. My only regret is that I didn't even know about this place sooner.
author: Oscar C.

description: On the corner of California and Larkin, walk down a few stairs into the pleasant abode of Olea Restaurant, a small cozy place with only a few tables, where the engaging owner, Philip, or friendly server, Julia greets you. The feel is very European as you look up at the sidewalk from the site situated below street level. The simple curated menu features three starters-two salads and a bowl of mussels, and a handful of entrees. We shared the mussels and sopped up the delicious garlic and wine broth with sourdough. The duck was perfectly executed and melted in my mouth. My husband reported that the pork chop was overcooked and dry, the quinoa salad, although quite a small portion for the price, pleased my daughter. There are no sides offered, although they kindly brought a bowl of mash potatoes when requested. For dessert we had the tres leche cake, but it failed to satisfy. Other desserts included tiramasu and gelato.  We were told that the regular chef was on vacation, yet we found that the sous chef did a satisfactory job of executing the menu. Corkage is a very reasonable $15, and Philip was keen on providing fresh stemware with each vintage. The owners have opened a restaurant in Oakland on Grand near Lake Merritt called Kitchen 388 where they are serving Southern comfort food. Sounds like another place to check out. Our family enjoyed the meal and the homey ambiance. Make sure to make a reservation as capacity is very limited.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Some unique brunch options on the menu! Prices are pretty standard, restaurant itself is really cute and the outside seating is great for people watching. The service is fantastic! Try the huevos rancheros.
author: Sonia K.

description:
One of my favorite brunch places in San Francisco - nestled in a residential part of Nob Hill. 

I've had the casuela, the migas and also the challah custard french toast - uniformly delicious and served quickly. I also like the french press coffee (but beware they don't have decaf). 

Seating is tight because this place is small (some say "charming") - but I've only come with 1-2 other people so it's never been an issue for me.

Easy to get to by cable car or bus, parking's not so easy, but that's SF for you. Definitely try and get here before they open on the weekends, because they don't take reservations and the line builds up fast.

Highly recommended - go here!
author: Joshua B.

description: When I have a sweet brunch craving...Olea is it!  I go for the Challah French Toast with cinnamon sugar and strawberries.  To die for and currently #1 in my books for french toast in SF thus far.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Olea, I wanna French your toast!

Um, I don't exactly know what that means, but all I know is it's THAT good.

It's really nothing fancy, no ricotta stuffed bread, no creme fraiche topping, etc.  Just plain old Challah toast topped with cinnamon sugar and the freshest strawberries.  The toast itself is very custard-like -- its fluffiness play nicely with the fine grittiness of the cinnamon sugar topping. Just superb.

My cousin had their omelette with peas, mushrooms topped with vibrant tomato sauce and it was perfect as well. Olea uses cage free eggs from a farm in Aptos. Their menu goes through seasonal changes to reflect the freshest ingredients from local farms. 

For you caffeine addicts, you'd be glad to know that they serve Blue Bottle coffee, French pressed style, meaning more cups of joe than you can handle! 

This charming neighborhood resto is not big on space,so come early to avoid the mad Sunday rush.
author: Janice C.

description:
I used to live right around the corner from here but it took me over 5 years to finally eat here.  I was a little apprehensive because there was always a line outside but when we went a few weekends ago, there was no line.  And our experience was amazing.  Our waiter was very friendly and let us know that order was just enough when we were thinking about getting more.  We got the custard toast for our son but ended up eating most of it ourselves.  We also got the granola (delicious) along with the Cazuela.  

Great spot with great service and amazing food.  I'll make sure it's not another 5 years until I come back.
author: Blake B.

description: This place was just what we needed!  Brunch spot in the City without the crazy wait.  Portions were just right and the dishes were not the norm, but should be.  Recommend the Migas Con Huevos and the baked Strata!  The people were welcoming and service was awesome!
author: Nino M.

description:
YAY, I have found my go to brunch place!

Service is friendly and efficient
Food is delicious! 

French toast was wonderfully rich but also light and fluffy.
Huevos Rancheros was marvelous.  Be sure to add some of their house made hot sauce.  Truly divine!  The smokey richness with a good balance of rich flavor and spice.
author: Lev E.

description:
This restaurant has delicious food and the menu is thoroughly thought out. So many amazing flavors!!! 

The service was INCREDIBLE!! We were well taken care of and on top of the normal service, my boyfriend got a nose bleed halfway through dinner and the owner of the restaurant came out with a first aid kit to help us. He made us feel so comfortable and helped us in any way he could!! It was so nice and went above and beyond great service.  

I am happy to know I have a family feel restaurant in my neighborhood that has terrific food too!!
author: Shannon C.

description: Nice service & Sunday brunch. Quaint, cozy brunch corner in the city. Not a ton of seating but its charm is in its small size and cozy feel. We got sat at a communal table which is a charming idea. Corn cakes with veggie hash and fried eggs are a great veggie option. It's sweet and filling. Came with tasty avocado slices. French press coffee was a nice compliment, and it was fun to share this pot with another.
author: Kristen C.

description:
I'll start by emphasizing that dinnertime is when these 5 stars really shine.

One evening, I was stopped by two kindly Welsh women asking for directions to a seafood spot on Hyde that their hotel had recommended. In the midst of explaining where to go, we mentioned that we were going to Olea, so they decided to check out the menu and wound up trying it out. As they left, they approached our table, and one woman said to us "I'm sorry to bother you, but I just wanted to let you know that that was by far the best meal I've had since we've been on holiday, thank you so much for pointing it out." 

If that's not enough to sell you, I'll elaborate.

Olea is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. 
How can I make such a bold claim, you ask? There are a number of reasons.
- Genuine and welcoming owner
- Attentive but not overly-pushy staff
- Gorgeous, fresh, high-quality food; literally everything on the menu is delicious
- Warm, inviting atmosphere
- Excellent wine selection and a skillful recommendation from the owner himself
 
Olea's brunch is delicious (especially the french press coffee and the french toast), but the atmosphere is close and busy, and you don't get the full experience like you do in the evenings.

In the evenings, you'll be greeted by the owner or one of the equally kind and generous staff. As you sit, sipping a tastefully recommended glass of wine, you'll notice passersby drawn into the warm glow, peeking over the candlelit windowsills. You'll look over the menu and feel equally impressed and overwhelmed, as everything sounds so good - and I'll tell you, everything really is so good. Allergies aside, you really can't go wrong with a single dish on the menu. It varies with the season, as they only use fresh, high-quality ingredients, so if you're eyeing something but afraid to branch out, just do it; it might not be available next time you're in. 

The pork tenderloin is incredible, and seems to be more of a staple among the rotating, ever-delightful assortment of fresh fish, lamb meatballs, risotto, short rib, white wine mussels, the list goes on. 

The staff are hospitable and attentive, but observant and respectful of the guests' space;
you won't feel like you're being rushed to free up your table. The owner is one of the most genuine people I've met in the service industry. My boyfriend and I were lucky enough to become regulars at this wonderful spot, and he always greeted us like old friends. He seems simply delighted to be doing what he's doing, and it shows through his calm, charismatic demeanor, and the wonderful atmosphere of his restaurant.

TL;DR - Nothing but good things to say about an evening at Olea.
author: Amy J.

description:
My favorite breakfast spot in San Francisco!  I live right around the corner and will be moving and will dream about Olea!  The food is always fresh and locally sourced.  They have amazing baked egg dishes and omelets always with new vegetables and ingredients.  The French toast is to die for! The dinner is remarkable here as well.  In the evening they light candles and Olea has a romantic spark to it.

Such a neighborhood gem!  The owner is a great guy and I cannot say enough good things about Olea and the exceptional quality of food.  This is not a greasy spoon diner breakfast--this is SF cuisine and Bay Area farm fresh at its finest!

Downside: people are starting to realize what a gem this place is and the line can get LONG for weekend brunch.  Go early.  Trust me, it is worth the wait. If you can have breakfast on Friday there is never a wait and you can enjoy Olea and visit with the owner who is awesome!
author: Shannon B.

description:
Sweet little spot I found from yelp. And man did it deliver.

Went on a Sunday and it had a line, but it moved fast and we were sat quickly by the owner.

Started off with some amazing spicy bloody marys the vegetables used for garnish were pickled in house, perfect consistency and spice.

Then my friend and I shared the custard french toast with strawberries and the cazuela (egg, pork, bacon, tomatillo sauce, beans, parmesean cheese, served with toasted bread). 

Both of them were amazing! Clearly quality ingredients. The French toast even topped bill's cafe Parisian French toast (for San Jose yelpers).

The staff was very friendly and the manager came and chatted with us a couple of times.

Overall a perfect Sunday brunch.
author: Adriana I.

description:
Olea's Custard Challah French Toast with Korintiji Cinnamon Sugar and Strawberries--get it.

Reason to Get Up (+'s):

+ FRENCH TOAST - full order please. You know others will want a bite. I'll put on my Sunday best to down the custard confection that doesn't weigh me down like a loaded sponge.

+ Blue Bottle French Press Coffee - umm, yeah it's something like $5.25 I think to have someone else crush the beans and put it in Bodum. For some reason it tastes freaking good though when someone else gets it ready for you.

+ CAZUELA is another signature dish. It's like a soupy mix of eggs, garbanzo beans, spice, spinach and tomato sauce. Great I think if it's a cold foggy day but not when the sun is actually shining in SF.

+ SETTING is cozy. Perhaps seating for 25-30. Tables set far enough where I can have a private conversation.

+ SERVICE was great. Water refilled regularly and seated promptly.

+ MIMOSAS with OJ or grapefruit juice. Joy.


Reason to stay in my PJs(-'s):
- When Challah French Toast gets pulled from the menu.

TIP: French Toast and BB Coffee. Echo.
author: Yiven C.

description:
Simply wonderful. Everything was great. 

Food and service gets 5 stars.
My only issue was with how cramped the place is. Next time I'll probably sit outside and avoid the somewhat claustrophobic inside tables. 

Parents came to visit and we went here on Saturday. The wait was better than average (about 10mins), and the speed of service was really exceptional for a busy Saturday. Our server was very attentive and I liked the fact that the 'host/manager' was also supporting table service, which made everything run a lot smoother. 

I highly recommend the challah french toast (whoa!) and all of their egg dishes are really thoughtfully prepared. Grapefruit mimosa was nice and the french press blue bottle coffee was a nice touch too.
author: Nina N.

description:
Best french toast EVEEEEEER!!

This place is so cute and cozy. And I love that they get their ingredients from local farmers as often as possible. 

And did I mention they have the most bomb french toast I've ever had??

Came here for a late brunch on Sunday. The hubby and I got there around 1PM, but there was still a wait! We waited about half an hour, but it really didn't seem that long. The owner/manager was super nice and kept acknowledging us and letting us know where we were on the list. 

First, we started off with a large french press coffee to share. By the way, they serve the oh-so-delicious Blue Bottle Coffee. They have a few espresso drinks as well if you're not into black coffee. 

The hubby ordered the migas huevos - scramble with beef, pork and tortilla chips topped off with a delicious sauce with great aroma and spices. I love the extra crunch from the tortilla chips, but it also came with some crostini on the side. Yum! And definitely ask for some hot sauce. They make it themselves with whatever ingredients are in season!

The winning dish of the day was their amaaaaazing french toast! They call it custard toast on their menu and that's exactly what feels and tastes like. Because they use challah bread, it just soaks up whatever cream sauce they dip it in. The bread looks dry, but it's so creamy and soft on the inside. There's no overpowering egg taste like traditional french toast and it's just the right sweetness! It's so good that you don't even need to eat it with syrup! The sprinkle of cinnamon sugar around it is enough! But definitely try it with a little syrup, too!

By the way, get the side of bacon with it. Just do it. You won't regret it.

Love this place! This is how brunch should be! Simple, locally sourced and delicious!
author: Daisy T.

description:
I love the fact that this place is so friendly and casual, and has such great food! I ordered the Migas Con Huevo and devoured it. Definitely not a large dish, but a good amount of food. We also ordered a Custard Toast for the table and it was fantastic. Beyond fantastic, actually. 

Enjoy!
author: Ami D.

description:
Two words sum up this place: cozy and cute. My friend and I were actually planning on going somewhere else that was closed, so we walked back here. No reservation on a Friday night, and the host managed to seat us at a big table that we ended up sharing with 3 other parties. No complaints here -- we didn't have to wait at all!

We shared the pan seared coho salmon with lentils and avocado relish, as well as the pappardelle pasta with veal meatballs, spinach and parmesan cheese. The second dish was the clear winner -- the veal meatballs melted on the tongue and the noodles were cooked perfectly. The salmon, on the other hand, was WAY too salty. I love salmon, lentils and avocado, so it shouldn't have been hard for me to love this dish, but it was.

Another thing -- the fork that came out with the pasta was piping-hot. As in, I tried picking it up and burned my fingers. This was probably a one-time mistake but, geez. Not a very pleasant thing to happen to you when you're out at dinner!

Definitely would've given Olea 4 stars otherwise, if it hadn't been for the burn. And I still do want to come back for the brunch, which seems to be getting rave reviews from you Yelpers.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I take the California cable car often and when I saw the red sign outside that Olea started having brunch on Fridays, I made a note to self, next time I had a Friday off or if I was working from home, I'd make a brunch stop (Saturday brunch is way crazy, major waiting list, it must be good, right?).  So today was my opportunity!  I was starved to say the least and wanted a REAL breakfast.  

I had Olea's challah custard toast with korintji cinnamon sugar topped with sliced poached pears with real maple syrup + a side of bacon + a small fresh-squeezed orange juice.  I took the first bite of toast - mmm!  It was crispy cooked just right with the cinnamon and maple syrup - yummy!  The bacon was a perfect accompaniment and the fresh oj was scrumptious - loooooooved it!  Service was nice and let me chow down uninterrupted - when I'm hungry, I'm kind of head down and concentrating.  ;)

Brunch is brunch, but Olea does is RIGHT!  Thank you, and I will be back - I want to try dinner too!!
author: Maile N.

description:
This is such a quaint restaurant. I felt like I was dining at home. For a Friday night, it was surprisingly empty. I was able to get reservations on Open Table on the same day. I had the quinoa and ribs and both were absolutely flavorful. The meat fell off the ribs easily. The quinoa had bits of avocado and chick peas. For dessert, I tried the petite four sampler including a raspberry macaroon with a creamy chocolate filling, brownie, lemon tart, and lemon sorbet. 

The service was great. The waiter was attentive and friendly. I don't understand why this place was so empty. Although the dinner menu was a bit limited, the dishes were very flavorful. I'll definitely come back for dinner and hopefully for brunch.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Saturday morning (well actually 1 PM) brunch.  The place was about half full, I imagine most people were already in and gone by the time I finally rolled out of bed and could get myself down the block for food.  Very nice service, attentive without being pushy.  I had the migas, which were very well made, very tasty and quite nice.  Very much recommend.  If it's a nice day, grab one of the tables outside in the sun.
author: Bill M.

description:
French Toast again - never disappoints!  Light, soft, and crispy. Also, their bacon is so crispy perfect 

The cazuela changes there, so yummy but wish the eggs were runny (my only reason not to give you five stars). 

Service is friendly, efficient, but not rushed. Love coming back here
author: Jon H.

description:
Went on an urban hike recently through the city and planned to randomly stop by a brunch place for food along the way. Happened to walk a block from Olea and quickly yelped close by brunch places and decided to give this place a shot. It was still fairly early, so there was no line which made me very happy.

Very welcoming and cozy atmosphere. Service and was great, but I really just came here to eat some good brunch food. Ordered the Cazuela since it sounded interesting since it didn't seem like the normal brunch menu item. When I got it, wasn't what I was expecting but still looked delicious nonetheless. It was absolutely delicious. All the flavors blended very well together and dipping the bread into the Cazuela was heaven! Definitely a place I want to try again. I liked the Cazuela, so if this is the type of food they provide to their customers, I want to try other things as well.

Great job Olea!
author: Amar T.

description:
Food is decent, fresh ingredients, delicious. Nothing special - just like a good breakfast or brunch should taste.
Service is ok. There is always a line outside waiting for a weekend brunch, and it seems like the staff didn't find a consistent balance between navigating the customers efficiently and making them feel welcome at the same time.
We did have our own moment of "If they don't explain this behavior and possibly apologize to us for it within next couple of minutes, we will just get up and leave", so I can relate to other viewers who had poor service experience, even though it might not be justified each time necessarily.
Once you are in, both service and atmosphere are pretty good, but overall experience for me was only worth waiting in line that one time, and I won't repeat it again unless the place is half empty and there are no battles over a table.
author: Stacy A.

description:
On a recent trip to San Francisco, I met a friend for brunch at Olea.  The restaurant changed owners in May of 2013, which I was surprised to learn upon my arrival.  Fortunately, not only did the new owner apparently purchase the recipes from the former owner, but he is similarly a very friendly fellow.  We had two strollers and two babies, and he was very accommodating.  (FYI: this TINY restaurant is not ADA compliant and is not really stroller friendly, but they made it work.  The restaurant is half underground with high windows and about 6-8 tables for private parties in front of a small open kitchen and a communal table on the other side.  I have seen huge lines for this place on the weekend.)

Because it was Friday at 11:30, we did not need to wait for a table.  Yee-haw!  I had a TINY breakfast when I left Los Angeles very early that day, so I was ready to eat.  I was super bummed that the cazuela listed on the online menu was not on the menu for the day.  But, I opted for the Migas Con Huevos ($12.50).  It was delicious, albeit a bit on the small side (like TINY - ¾ of a cup of food).  They were fluffy scrambled eggs with sun dried tomato chicken sausage and shredded yellow squash and zucchini on top of crispy little tortilla squares and drizzled with an ancho pepper sauce and some sesame seeds.  It was served with two little pieces of crostini.  I inhaled every bite of this absolutely delicious dish.  My only criticism is the size.

Two in our party ordered the Olea's Challah Custard Toast.  For $13.25, it was two big pieces of challah bread, about 1.5" thick, in an excellent egg custard that was grilled to perfection and still a little goopy in the middle.  It was topped with cinnamon sugar and strawberries and served with maple syrup.  OMG.  This was so decadent.  I was lucky that my friend was full after a little more than half (FYI - the half order is one slice of toast), because I finished it and it was awesome.

In addition to the very friendly owner, the staff is friendly and attentive without being intrusive.  The café also attracts a very friendly crowd that was amenable to the tired kids in our party.  I am definitely a fan!
author: Stephanie B.

description: Very clean awesome service and some fun creative menu. Highly recommend for a quick morning or lunch.
author: Bill B.

description:
Acceptable food, less-than-gracious service, as if they'd enjoy running a restaurant if they didn't have to deal with all those pesky customers.  The net effect:  I wouldn't go back.

The bad service started with the gentleman that greeted us when they opened this morning at 9am.  He asked us how many in our party.  "Three, and the third should be joining us shortly."  "Okay," he says, "We usually don't let parties sit until all have arrived but I'll seat you now."  Help me understand the thinking behind telling us this... Do you want us to feel special?  The place is empty so I don't feel like you're really putting yourself out for us.  Do you want us to know that if we come back again and you're busy that you won't seat us until our entire party has arrived?  Seems pretty petty to me. But okay, let's move on.

My friend has an assistance dog.  Licensed by the City of SF.  The gentleman ask her for proof.  Really?!  Like if she couldn't prove it you'd turn us away?  Again, pretty petty.

Then we are all seated and the server takes our drink order.  "I'd like decaf coffee," I say.  Our server tells us "Sorry, no decaf."  Really?!  So you're the only restaurant in SF that doesn't serve decaf.  Good call. 

We order.  I ask for two eggs, bacon, and avocado.  The food comes, and all I get is two eggs -- no mention of the other items.  Okay, mistakes happen.  I used to wait tables so I'm sympathetic.  So I ask about my bacon and avocado.  They arrive in a while, my eggs are now cold, so I ask to have fresh eggs, which now arrive after enough time for my bacon to get cold.  Really?!  The right thing to do is to bring out an entirely new plate of hot food including fresh eggs.  

I think they want to be in "the restaurant business," just not in the business of serving customers.  Meh.
author: Rob E.

description:
Situation
- Saturday brunch with a friend around 11 AM
- I ordered the Custard Toast and the French Pressed Coffee

Pros
- The Custard Toast was pretty good, you get two large Toast's with strawberries on them
- The Coffee was great
- Good service
- Good portion size

Cons
- I found a piece of hair underneath of my Toast's (-1 star for that)
author: Dipesh G.

description:
I wanted to LOVE LOVE this place for brunch. I thought it was good, but not as amazing as I expected. We ordered the Eggs in tomato sauce and the pulled pork sandwich.

The portions were not large (not tiny, but for $13 I expected more). The french fries were perfect I will grant them that, and they make their own hot sauce which I also thought was a special touch.  I can think of other places I would rather go for a great brunch. 

We got there 15 minutes before it opened and there were already about 8 people in line in front of us. I had never even noticed My My Coffee Shop across the street while we were waiitng and I am looking forward to trying that, so I'll report back -- maybe the universe was just sending me to the incorrect corner of California & Larkin or brunch perfection. 

Coffee was expensive, but they serve it in French press pots, my bf said the coffee was very good (and he normally doesn't comment, Starbucks is his gold standard)
author: Amy W.

description: We came for brunch, and they were out of the avocado toast that I'd heard so much about. So I got the egg sandwich instead. It was really good! And our food came out so quickly it was unbelievable!
author: Rebecca S.

description:
French toast here is AMAZING. Comes with pear and it is just delicious. 

To try something off the beaten path I had the cazuela with egg, chorizo and garbanzo beans. It was an awesome hearty brunch choice perfect for a cold day. 

I've lived near Olea for a while now and always wondered what all the fuss is about. Seriously, try the french toast on challah bread. You will NOT be sorry. 

Place is reasonably priced too. $12 for a generous helping of french toast isn't that bad in SF.
author: Carlos A.

description: The brunch here was fantastic! Omelet and french toast were so delicious. Also seating out side made me feel in 'real San Francisco'. Staffs there were friendly and kind. I really recommend this place!
author: Doran L.

description: Really good brunch. Long wait so get here early. The tables are too close to each other
author: Ali P.

description:
I've brought a variety of different kinds of people here for a variety of different dinner occasions and it has always worked out beautifully.

The space is very small, so it's good to get a reservation if possible. With a reservation, everything goes smoothly, and without a reservation, I've only had to wait a little while (as I tend to go fairly late and with only one or two other people).

The service is prompt and friendly, and always genial and patient with people who take a while to mull over the menu and debate wine choices and so on. 

The wine list is solid, though not thrilling in any substantial way.

The menu is brief, but manages to really deliver with only about four entree options. I have yet to bring anyone here who cannot order a meal option as-is off the menu with no modifications. In such a short menu they nonetheless manage to address every allergy, every dietary preference, and even some of my friends' weird food finickiness that is unique to them. The prices are really solid in the low-mid range, so dinner here is completely reasonable to everyone's budget, too.

Once delivered, the food is delicious! Even when it sounds simple, it is prepared with finesse and sensitivity. The vegetables are never over cooked. The meat is (so people tell me) always perfect. The balance of flavors is always spot on. The textures work together harmoniously.

This place is best for a very small group, or just two people, because it is so small, but as long as you are aware of your size limits, this is a great go-to for dinner, especially on a weeknight when you want something a little nicer than usual.
author: Vivienne P.

description: Just okay. Good portions but then on the other hand $14 for what is $1.5 max in ingredients? Service is annoyed and uninspired. No single cup of coffee sold?! What the hell. Won't be back.
author: Chrstn M.

description:
A nice little brunch spot! To be honest, I was actually intending to eat at MyMy (which is actually my favorite brunch spot in SF) but the line was too long & I had a time crunch, so we decided to try out Olea right across the street, since it had no wait at all. But it was not a bad decision! It turned out to be a solid meal. Nothing to write home about but a nice brunch spot if you're in the area. Luckily, it was a nice day, so the outdoor seating was just fine and quite a nice experience to be outside in the sun. 

FOOD: tasted very fresh and light. The omelette and challah french toast were both fantastic. The portions were good. Mimosas were strong. 

SERVICE: attentive and friendly in seating us, refilling our waters, etc. 

Parking sucks around the area but if you're lucky maybe you'll score a spot.
author: Mary N.

description:
The french toast is the bomb. If I could, I'd come here every weekend for the french toast. I ordered a half order of french toast with a side of scrambled eggs and a glass of white sangria. The scrambled eggs were ok, and the sangria was a little tart for my taste. Maybe that's because I normally drink red sangria or because the only fruit in the glass were slices of lemon and grapes, but toast was heavenly. I wish there were more breakfast sides offered... since I don't eat pork but didn't want a full order of french toast, I was kind of limited with choices. It would have been nice to be able to get a side fruit salad or yogurt. 

By the way, since I was dining by myself, I opted to sit at the communal table and had no wait... whoohoo!
author: Dani D.

description: Fantastic French toast! This is my favorite brunch spot. Only cons are that you have to wait in line for weekend brunch and they don't do reservations or take out.
author: Rashmi J.

description:
Food was great. But somehow my experience here just does not bring me to want to come back. 
Service is fake friendly. I can tell the owner was annoyed we were asking for a lot. And by "a lot" I mean the following. 

We were standing in the restaurant waiting for the tony bathroom. And he came to ask what we needed. Then when the bathroom was really small and the person before us had taken a huge " you know what" we asked if we could change our baby standing in the entrance of the bathroom. It was just pee. But I wanted to ask. He said no. Which is understandable.  Then we ask for a highchair. Again his response was no. But I felt like he was annoyed because I was asking for such requests.  I just don't need to be tip toeing around the servers.
author: Xin S.

description:
This is now one of my top 3 brunch places in the area. Everything about my food screamed 'fresh'. I ordered an orange juice, huevos rancheros, and French fries. The orange juice was delicious. The tomato sauce, beans and eggs on the rancheros were amazing. The tomato sauce was so flavorful and the eggs weren't 'eggy'. You know what I mean? Like that disgusting egg taste that overpowers everything that most restaurants aren't able to get right. The French fries - OMG! They were perfect! Not at all greasy, not one bit. Salted and warm to perfection. 

Pro tip - get there before 1030am or after 1130am. This is when the lines were shortest and almost non existent on a Sunday. 

If I could nitpick: 
1) the orange juice was a little too sweet but not overbearingly so and it didn't take away from the deliciousness
2) the waiters could have been more attentive 

The reviewer that mentioned a cranky old man - I never encountered him. And even if I did...I probably wouldn't give a shit - the food was totally worth it.
author: D M.

description:
Showing up at 9:15am on a Saturday was a great idea to avoid the one-hour wait for the late birds. Our group of four was second in the young coalescing line at the time. At least six different parties were in line by the time the doors officially opened at 9:30am, but I quickly lost count. We were seated promptly at a communal table that could host a total of ten, and we got to share the table with three other parties (with group sizes of one, two, and two) during our stay. The small restaurant seemed to fill up immediately and had a wait list going.

Our side of the table ordered the cazuela, soft scrambled eggs, and two omelettes with sides of bacon, coffee, and green tea. Everything was delicious, but I think our soft scrambled eggs orderer pined for the pork shoulder sandwich when all was said and done. One of the other communal table mates ordered the challah custard toast, which looked amazing enough for me to want to come back the following Saturday to try. (He also ordered a while ale by Hitachino's Nest to go with it. I'll personally try their mimosas next time.)

I personally liked sitting at the communal table: we enjoyed the company of strangers, who turned out not to be strange after all. The guy who ordered the challah said he was finally breaking his gluten fast, and being the test for whether gluten really makes him sick, this may have been his last meal with said ingredient. The first couple who sat down went to art school and were discussing product design with the possibly-gluten-intolerent guy. And the latter couple was visiting from New York and, while they had just gotten married a couple of months ago, they were also planning a traditional Chinese wedding ceremony.

The verdict: I'm glad Olea is in my neighborhood, and I plan to make brunch somewhat more regular now that Ellen C. introduced it to me. And come early if you dislike long waits.
author: Tiff T.

description:
I know everyone mentions the French toast million times here, but I MUST say,

"BEST French toast in SF!"

I have been dreaming of their French toast ever since!
It is super fluffy and moist, yet not heavy.
The sweetness is perfect for me not having a big taste for sweets.

Although the wait can be quite long, it's definitely worth trying. 
They also serve Blue Bottle Coffee for coffee lovers! 

Enjoy, enjoy and enjoy!!!!!
author: Tomomi K.

description:
FINALLY tried this place for brunch today, and I'm so glad I did. 

First off, the service was spectacular - warm, funny, and attentive. 

Secondly, the food was superb!  My friend and I shared:

     -Avocado & Toast w/Mixed Greens, Hard Boil Egg, 
Extra Virgin Olive Oil & Sea Salt, Pimento Flakes ($11.75)

    -Cazuela; Baked Eggs, Beef, Pork, Bacon, White Beans, Tomato Sauce, 
Tortilla Chips, Parmesan Cheese ($13.75)

The Avocado dish was my favorite, and although it was simple, it was so flavorful. The Cazuela was good as well, although a little heavier, and had a nice kick to it!
author: Juliana K.

description:
Menu was a bit small, restaurant is cramped, food was oook and service was meh. The server was none too friendly.

I had the Avocado Toast and the bread was super hard while the seasoning on the avocado itself was too salty.
author: Julie L.

description:
I debated whether or not to Yelp about this since it always seems like Yelp provides an opportunity to get passive aggressive about a businesses' small transgressions (I much prefer to give feedback verbally and directly to businesses and only resort to Yelp when I don't have that opportunity), however I whole-heartedly believe that this place has earned its 2 stars. I hope, dear readers, you see this before you decide to try this place out. I wish I had.

The food would have been 4-5 stars had it been a better experience getting to that point. I had the huevos rancheros which were delicious (eggs perfectly cooked, beans on point, and an awesome little pico de gallo salad on the side, mmmm mmm!), and everything else looked awesome on the menu! A little pricey, but if the service is good, well worth it. 

What puts a sour taste in my mouth is the host/owner/whoever he is- is extremely rude and needs to treat his patrons with respect or he will lose customers. He had both me and another couple laughing with disbelief as he almost refused to seat me because he did not believe that I would order food on my own, asking me 3 times if I would actually order or if I was just going to sit there (I had a flaky friend who hadn't decided if she was coming to meet me or not, which was no hinderance to me getting my own breakfast!). Besides that annoyance, when I ordered an iced coffee and asked for a little cup of hot water to make a little simple syrup with the sugar (evenly distributed sugar, ftw!) he basically said no, and told me that regular sugar was better. Dude, just bring the girl some hot water if she asks for it! 

Either way, small enough things that I didn't leave immediately to go across the street to my neighborhood staple, MyMy, but I was annoyed enough to want to forewarn others and give feedback. It seemed like the whole staff was tired (and I can imagine that working under that kind of boss can do it- been there, done that), so hopefully he will read this review and let them do their job without the hassle. I would have loved that experience as a diner, and it seems that many other folks on here feel the same. If this kind of feedback is coming up more than once, not everyone can be wrong. I won't be back, and won't be suggesting it to friends.
author: Maija W.

description: I'm really impressed with the dinner quality. Never been here for brunch because the wait is just ridiculous. Cozy restaurant and the waiter is super attentive. I loved the shroom risotto a lot. I would definitely come back again for another weekday dinner.
author: Koalie W.

description:
FOOD
French toast - Good but hyped up. 

SERVICE
Fine


ATMOSPHERE
Good place to go day after Bastille Day. haha. Small quaint a little step below ground... very local SF feel? On California so you get the whole Nob feel, with the trolleys rolling by and what not. 

11.20.13
author: Angela L.

description:
This is a review based on my multiple brunch visits to Olea. 

My top 3 brunch items are the challah french toast, cazuela (meaty stew-like dish), and migas con huevo (essentially a scramble). 

The challah french toast is by far the best item on the menu, but if you're like me and prefer your brunch to be on the more savory side, I suggest splitting the half order with a friend in addition to what else you already intend on eating. If you are just eating the french toast, many of my friends find the half order sufficient for one person. 

While I'm generally a fan of the place, keep the following in mind to prepare for some issues that people run in to here:

* The place is small, though recently they have added a couple more tables on the sidewalk. Try not to come here with more than 4 people. 

* They do not take reservations for brunch nor can you put your name down. You must physically stand in line until it's your turn. My recommendation is that you go put your name down at Mymy across the street and grab a coffee at Contraband while you wait in line. Depending on when you get in line, the wait can be up to an hour. 

* The owner seems to have a lot of rules. One of them include not bringing outside beverages in to the restaurant. I feel it's a reasonable enough request but for some reason it really seems to upset people. Occasionally he can come across as patronizing but after a few visits I've come to realize that he is just quirky.
author: Tasmin S.

description: Really amazing brunch place. I got the Olea's Custard Toast and it was delicious! It tasted like cinnamon toast and I liked that I could order a half size (one slice of bread rather than 2). My boyfriend got the healthier choice: the omelette.  It was very different, had almonds for an extra crunch and lots of veggies. There was a bit of a wait, but worth it.
author: Zel H.

description:
This review is based purely on the Challah Custard French Toast. I reached a point of foodie ecstasy beyond describable proportions while consuming this dish. I refused to share some with my bf and ravaged through the toast in its entirety. I then subsequently proceeded to dream of the dish at night. 

Olea, you've won my heart and belly with that deliciously sweet French Toast. We also ordered the eggs baked in a cazuela with tomato sauce and that was quite good as well, but definitely inferior with respect to the French toast. But then again, ANYTHING is inferior to the French toast. 

The orange juice and mimosas were standard - freshly squeezed and delicious. 

So if you're ever craving a sweet brunch item or some homemade French toast, you simply have to stop by Olea in Nob Hill!
author: Priya S.

description:
We came here for brunch on a Sunday because MyMy was packed (as always). We thought we would try it out.

Service is a 5. 
Food tastewise is a 4.
Good selection and variety is not worth more than 3 because it's stuff you can get elsewhere without the wait. They have maybe 7 choices. All but two of which are heavy egg dishes or meat dishes. I was hoping for something more creative. Even the egg sandwich is basic on challah bread. The Arnold Palmer tasted weird and I'm guessing since lemonade is not on the menu it's made with limonata.

I would recommend you go once and try it. I won't go back but not because it wasn't tasty. It was just wasn't unique enough.
author: Cassy R.

description:
I was craving for breakfast food - pancakes and waffles, etc. Unfortunately, Olea does not have a great selection of that. The only thing that accommodated on what I was craving for was the custard toast. Meh. $14.75 for a small toast and this is what Olea considered as a full size toast. I asked if they had a breakfast menu and they told me they only offer brunch. 

The food isn't bad at all. It's delicious! But it's overpriced with a limited menu. I just didn't think spending $45 on a brunch here was worth it.
author: Karen C.

description: Nice cozy atmosphere. Excellent service. Food was fresh and full of flavor. Would return. Don't let empty restaurant concern you, this place is great.
author: Leah M.

description: A very nice place. We had to wait 45 mn to get a table for a group of 6 person for a sunday brunch. However you'll be seated much more quicker if you are only 2 to 3 people! The food was delicious and fresh. The staff really nice and pro. And I really much appreciated the cosy atmosphere of this place with its old photographs of SF hanging in the wall and its polish wood tables. I would totally recommend this restaurant.
author: Camille D.

description:
I'm not a big fan of brunch food. Don't really like pancakes or bacon... so it's typically hard to appease me with early morning foods.

That being said, I LOVE the breakfast I had at Olea. So much that I came back the next day and got the exact same dish. Which is a lot of work considering there was a 40 minute wait the first day (the second day I was lucky and did not have to wait). The place was cute and quaint, and the servers were super friendly.

My go to dish is definitely the eggs baked in a cazuela. I LOVE soup. Like I'm weirdly obsessed with it and always want to have soup after a long night out. Unfortunately, you don't really find soup on brunch menus. This is where the eggs baked in a cazuela saved the day. It's two eggs baked in a soupy, tomatoey broth with sausages, veggies, and beans. AMAZING. Perfect way to start off the morning.

Their challah french toast is good too, if you're into sweet breakfasts.

Will be back!
author: Michelle L.

description: Went here on Valentines Day for brunch since our other places had too long of a wait.  The service is very friendly here, but not necessarily on the speedy side of things. Food was underwhelming and I thought cost too much for what it was.  Just meh.  I think the location is wonderful and what they have going for them (and some outside tables but direct sunlight), but I probably won't go back with so many other great brunch options around town.
author: Angie H.

description:
If you need proof that the owner is pretentious and condescending, look no further than reading his pretentious and condescending comments to negative reviews. Instead of trying to improve his service, he responds to negative comments by being very patronizing.

My friends and I were having a reunion, we haven't seen each other in a very long time, I did not witness the incident where he was rude to my friends at the door, but I was literally across the street and my friends felt very uncomfortable Bc he was rude to them Bc I was across the street. They did not want to give their business to him, but I like to give ppl the benefit of the doubt and I convinced them to stay, I could not have been more wrong and I regret that decision.

After sitting down, he was really condescending and treated us like children, we are all grown men and don't like being talked down to, customers deserve to be treated with respect, we weren't rude and we weren't unruly, so we did not deserve the treatment we received. Completely ruined what could have been an enjoyable experience with old friends.

The remaining wait staff was extremely friendly, I guess they had to be to make up for their boss. To the owner, listen to these reviews, your restaurant would be so much nicer if you treated your customers with the respect they deserve. Either learn from your mistakes, or let your wait staff handle the customer service Bc I have no complaints for them and the food and drinks were good, even though it lacked in variety.
author: Victor M.

description:
The owner here is pretty rude and patronizing. We were lectured before we were even seated, because he was angry that two members of our party were literally across the street about to walk over. When the plates were brought out, the owner came over and condescendingly told us we needed to clear off our table and put our napkin in our laps. He took what could have been a decent time and tarnished it, but to be fair the rest of the service was pretty good and friendly. The best thing this place can do is keep the owner away from the public.

The food was also expensive for what they were offering, and the menu was limited. The food wasn't awful, but it definitely wasn't worth the price.

If you're looking for brunch, try the place across the street, Mymy Coffee Shop, that's what we should have done.
author: Travis N.

description: Delicious food and interesting wine list. But a lot of empty tables so a bit short on atmosphere.
author: Karen B.

description:
The wait sucks. And if your entire party isn't there with you they can't plan for your table. After waiting for about an hour in line and grabbing a small coffee from Contraband across the street we finaalllllllllllllly got our table.
