Okay, okay, okay...I know this place is known for their french toast, but when I went this past Sunday I really wasn't in the mood to ingest 2000 calories after an entire day of day drinking for St. Patty's Day so I opted for the Migas Huevos Scramble. It was just OK. Was it worth the over an hour wait? Absolutely not. I really wish I wasn't disappointed by this place because I've heard so many good things! Maybe next time when i'm willing to consume a French Toast doused in syrup...
author: Tina J.

description:
It's hard for me to give Olea a stellar review even though my custard toast was one of the best french toasts I've ever had. I know reviews should strictly base on quality of food... but the owner was so rude to us, it left a sour taste in my mouth. 

All the reviews about the rude owner of this place is true. I get it, the restaurant is tiny and you are trying to maximize your profit margin on a busy Saturday; but for christ's sakes, we're paying customers-- show some respect and gratitude! To be fair, the staff is really friendly and patient. 

But if you really want to try the yummy custard toast, make sure everyone in your party is extremely punctual otherwise you WILL be scolded.
author: Cheryl C.

description:
Had planned to have brunch at Mymy but was overwhelmed by the wait there.  The shorter line at Olea across the street looked appealing.  The wait was about 15-20 minutes on a Sunday.  The relatively short wait was the best part of the place.  Unfortunately, the food was only eh.  I read some of the reviews online and saw that most of the recommendations were for the Challah French Toast.  Although I was tempted, my brunch partner did not want to share an order so I ventured for the savory instead of sweet.  I had the squash enchiladas, which I am not sure if qualifies as a breakfast dish but it was in the menu so why not.  I do not think its part of the regular Brunch menu, but I guess the dish itself would also be indicative of other non breakfast dishes. My dinning companion had a more traditional breakfast egg dish.  I tasted her dish as well and was not impressed either. It was ordinary.  The enchiladas were okay, nothing great.  I really thought the squash would add an interesting dimension but they mostly tasted like mush.  The only redeeming part of the meal was the homemade habanero salsa the waiter brought when I asked for some spice.  That sauce was very tasteful, and was the right amount of spicy.  Loved the sauce but unfortunately it could not save the dish.  

For the price/atmosphere/reviews, I was expecting more.  Next time I will just wait the Mymy madness.  It might take a while but their brunch is more consistent, delicious, and affordable.
author: Lucy M.

description:
We were lucky enough to get a table immediately, we had walked by earlier going to another spot and saw a bit of a wait outside. On walking back by we checked it out and scored. Small, super cute, very San Francisco, loved it! Service was super friendly and attentive. 

All the reviews about the Challah custard french toast is no lie! It was probably the best I've ever tasted and I didn't even get that. Hubby got that along with a side of bacon and freshly squeezed OJ. 

I went with the Pimenton de la Vera braised pork shoulder sandwich on a soft roll with sweet coleslaw and fries ($13.90). The spice it's braised in (Pimenton de la Vera) is a sweeter paprika than most, great flavor. Perfect fries!

I would eat here for brunch all the time if I lived near by.
author: shawn v.

description:
The owner posts a rude response to my original review, calling me a liar, says he thought it was funny to tell my friends to park faster. Then I post the response below and he not only deletes his own comment but proceeds to message me personally regarding not returning. LEAVE ME ALONE! 


No sir, YOU are not telling the truth. If I'm apparently lying then why are multiple reviews below also testifying to your rudeness? Do we all just not get your 'humor'? I'm not the problem here.

And yes, you did take your sweet time greeting me. You roamed the entirety of the very small restaurant before even venturing towards the front door. Don't worry about me returning, with 10 brunch spots within a 1 mile radius, I think I'll be okay.
author: Emily H.

description:
You must have the lemon pudding cake at the end of your delicious meal. It is amazing. Additionally this restauRant smells amazing and the food tastes so as well. We had the scallops, duck breast, and pork belly, all of which were delightfully fresh. 
Definitely a professional dining experience
author: Vicky K.

description: Olea is back, since 4/2, and so are their delicious entries. We each had a different dish, scallop, pork, skirt steak and lamb meat balls. Everyone were very satisfied with both the taste and the presentation. If you have been there before, you will know it is time to revisit. If you are new, be ready to enjoy an excellent meal with very reasonable prices.
author: Ellen D C.

description: Terrible, awful, no good, very bad, experience at this place. And that was just waiting in line. Just don't go! Better food and service across the street.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
VERY rude owner. He seemed really unhappy.  We almost let him put a damper on our fun day out, but decided to leave and eat somewhere owned and operated by nice people. 

I hope you find happiness or find some way to handle your stress in a nice way. We had to say bye bye and went to MyMy ( which was delicious and the staff was super friendly)
author: Christina S.

description:
Two words: Challah toast! You must have it! 
Went with two friends including one who had just moved to the city. They were delighted: blue bottle coffee, amazing egg scramble, house burger and the challah french toast! As we are we could not stop raving about it. Amazing. The only downfall - it's a super small place so get there super early or get ready to stay in line. I have to say though - it's absolutely worth it! :-)
author: Simone W.

description:
For Nob Hill, parking was surprisingly plentiful on a Saturday peak brunch time. We thought we scored with one right up front across the street to find that there were about 4 available spots right in front of the restaurant which rarely ever happens anywhere in this city. 

We put our names down and hoped we weren't fated to be seated in that communal dining table. About 20 minutes later we were seated but at a lovely two seater table next to window. 

I'll have to say the Challah Custard Toast is absolutely worthy of the numerous, positive mentions in these reviews. In fact, I believe it tops as the best French Toast I have had to date. My hubs loved and finished every last bit of the Eggs Baked in a Cazuela. I had the Scrambled Eggs on a Rustic Roll which came with a small side salad. The sandwich (ok) was smallish but a good sized for me being that we were sharing the Challah Custard Toast. 

Service was fine and food arrived in decent time. Total plus tax/tip was $60-ish.  Would go back.
author: Esther A.

description:
Olea?  O yeah!  We Came here after the legendary Red Door Cafe's line got cut off at 10:25am on a Sunday morning (really?) and were pleasantly surprised.  Wait was only about 15 minutes which was cool because I actually enjoyed talking with the person I was brunching with.  Ok TMI, moving on.  We got some omelette thingy which was good and then the CHALLAH CUSTARD TOAST WHICH CHANGED OUR LIVES.  

It was both delicious and mysterious.  It looked like regular toast from the outside.  But then on the inside (or maybe it was on the bottom, I don't know because I don't think I turned it over) there was this gooey sweet custard, "like a crack filling in the middle" I was told, quite accurately.  It was served with a few strawberries which were a nice contrast.  They also gave us maple syrup to pour on it - but for probably the first time in the history of me eating French toast (is this French toast or Challah Custard toast?) I actually thought it was better without the syrup.  Which was weird.  I kept having bites with syrup out of habit, thinking they would be tastiest, and then had to stop doing it because the bites with just the toast as it was served were actually better.  They hit it out of the park with this one.  Do it!
author: Aaron M.

description: Great breakfast/brunch place in the neighborhood -- definitely come EARLY to avoid a long wait. Their french toast, flat omelette, and baked eggs are all amazing -- my personal fave is probably the flat omelette. Would definitely come back, but only before 10:30 AM...
author: Shirley L.

description:
This restaurant is too cute.  I love the atmosphere and I loved the wait staff.
Many of the options on the menu looked good; I ended up selecting the risotto.  The flavor was great; I only wish that it had more vegetables.  I think the sprout topping was my favorite part.  It gave the dish just the right amount of cool crisp-ness and bitterness.  I am excited to return here and try more things!
author: Angie I.

description: We had a really great experience at Olea tonight. We ordered the salmon dish and lamb meatball pasta. It was delish and full of flavor. The owner or server is very kind and made us feel welcome.The restaurant's ambiance is lovely. It's warm and feel comfy. We finished the meal with Tiramisu. It's a must have here, airy and creamy. Overall we love this place and definitely will come back because we live in the neighbor. We are so glad we came here tonight. One more favorite restaurant added to our list. Thank you!
author: Liz D.

description: To respond to Olea R.'s response to my first review, regardless of how I answered your check in inquiry during our meal, the truth of the matter is that every dish we ordered for dinner at Olea did not impress, and the host throwing the other waitress under the bus about the table snafu seemed very unprofessional. I stand by my two-star review of my Olea experience.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
The old Olea with the the original owner and staff would have gotten 5 stars for food, service, host and owner. This new Olea with new ownership gets:
* 3 stars for food
* 1 star for service and 
* negative 5 stars for host and owner. 
That's a total of -1 stars, unfortunately yelp doesn't allow negatives.  I'm sorry for anyone that didn't know what the old Olea was like. The early 4 and 5 star reviews on yelp  reflect the original restaurant not the current restaurant.

I've lived in the Nob Hill area for over 10 years and in that time we have definitely been in need of a brunch place. When Olea opened up several years ago, it was a welcome sight, not only because we were missing brunch places, but because the food and service were awesome. This soon became my Sat morning go to place and when they started serving brunch on Fridays, I would pop in whenever I could. The staff were exceptional and knew me by name; and the food was amazing. Fast forward to a few years ago, I returned from a lengthy trip, turned up at Olea to find it "weird", the food was the same, the staff different but more than that there was just a weird vibe. I asked the waitress if there had been a change in ownership and she told me there had been - aha! that explains the shitty vibe. My first reaction was sadness because I soon figured out that the nasty host who had made the experience that morning unpleasant was in fact the new owner. Nonetheless I perserved, thinking that his terrible attitude was a one off. Boy was I wrong, I've frequented Olea less and less mainly because of the arse-hole attitude of the cranky old looking owner, and today was yet another crappy Olea experience and my last. Hey old man, you can continue to be a prick if you like, but soon enough people will associate Olea with the arse hole owner no matter how good the food is. Your attitude stinks, you are not the only brunch place in this neighborhood, there are now more and more brunch places, one only needs to cross the street or walk 2-3 blocks away to Polk where there are plenty of good brunch places with much better customer services than what you provide. There's no need to be a prick to your customers. No food in the world is worth being subjected to that kind of behavior not even yours, and yours has gone down hill since you've taken over. I hope you sell it soon, so someone else can bring the old Olea back.
author: Elzabeth G.

description: The host/owner is ridiculously unpleasant. So abominable that this time around, I didn't bother eating at the restaurant. His unfriendly and arrogant demeanor make what should be a pleasant brunch experience,  feel like going to the dentist and getting all your teeth ripped out. Don't spend your hard earned money on someone who treats customers with no respect.
author: Jessica F.

description: We were heading to the Fairmont after dinner and wanted a restaurant close by.  Olea is cute, slightly underground but still well lit, and wasn't very packed.  The menu is not long but has good variety.  I had the seared scallops which were perfectly cooked, with mashed potatoes, and my friends had the pork chop loin, the quinoa, and the pappardelle with braised oxtail.  No one even needed appetizers or dessert, so the entrees were decent portions.  I wasn't blown away but everyone thought the food was good and the price was reasonable.  My only criticism was the wine (their only viognier) which was a bit weird.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Went to Olea for breakfast with a friend. This place is small with communal tables and has really long lines. 

Once we were seated, most of the food smelled and looked really good, but there were very few options for vegetarians, although I think their menu changes frequently. They also weren't keen on modifying. 

My fancy shmancy breakfast sandwich for $10 was good but not great.
author: Rebecca G.

description: We came here for brunch on a Saturday morning.  The wait wasn't bad for an outside table.  Overall, the entire experience was mediocre.  The food was pretty good, but service was terrible.  The outside table we were seated at had no silverware and none was brought in the multiple times the waiter came to the table to take drink orders, food orders, and deliver our food.  When our food was brought to us we asked for silverware, but it took an extra 5 minutes.  Meanwhile we saw the waiter bringing coffee to other customers.  I would not come back; the food was good, but nothing unique.  The poor service really tips the balance toward not returning.
author: Richard W.

description: Went here for brunch while visiting and definitely wouldn't come back. The servers were rude, blunt and not very helpful or attentive. There were only a few things on the menu and the restaurant was not very accommodating to modifications. I would say if you're visiting or want a fun and satisfying breakfast spot, pick somewhere else.
author: Katherine N.

description:
That comment only reinforces my previous review. 

No one said anything about platter sized portions. There is a difference, when my 100 pound girlfriend is still hungry after your "entree" it might indicate that you need to go back to your farm and put one more than one egg into your plate.
author: Ben K.

description: Tried Olea for dinner last night and loved every bite.  I tried the pan seared scallops with rice, mushrooms and topped with arugula.  The flavors of this dish were just phenomenal and the scallops were cooked perfectly.  I would definitely have this dish again but cannot wait to try the pappardelle on my next visit.  We also tried the quinoa bowl with kale, mushrooms and shallots which was also amazing.  This place often has a line out the door for brunch but this is a great new find for me for dinner.  Great service, good wine, will be back!
author: Janelle C.

description:
Absolutely terrible service. My brother and his wife brought their baby with them, and the waiter made us feel incredibly uncomfortable the entire time. He didn't greet us, but instead immediately told us we had to move in case the baby got in the way of others. How difficult would it have been to have welcomed us and then explained the situation in a polite way?

We were going to leave immediately because we all felt so uncomfortable, but had a friend in town and couldn't make other plans at short notice, so we decided to give the place a chance despite being treated so poorly. 

But it got even worse from there. When we told him we were ready to order food in addition to our drinks he snapped back that he was too busy, instead of just politely acknowledging the request like any reasonable waiter would do. Then at the end they rushed us to sign the check and interrupted our discussion. With our friend in town this was completely embarrassing. The worst service I've received in a long, long time. Avoid this place at all costs.

Edit: I received a very aggressive message from the owner about this review. The fact we were treated this badly and then received a scathing message as opposed to an apology is astounding. Steer clear of this place.
author: Peter S.

description: Great brunch! After failing to pass the owner of Red Door's judgmental eyes and passive aggressive attitude that day, we walked on over here. This place at first glance does have daunting lines outside, right across the corner from Mymy with it's equally intimidating crowd milling about. This line is in part because there's no waitlist, but after maybe only a 20 min wait after 11 on a Sunday, our group of 3 got seated.  Had a half order (1 slice) of the Challah Custard Toast and their omelet of the day. At first I was worried that the toast might be a soggy affair like LaBoulange, but in fact it was pretty much perfect - the custard toast was actually quite fluffy with crisped edges, dusted perfectly with cinnamon and sugar, and some strawberries. No need for syrup, although they supplied that as well. I'd rank this one as good as or better than the Butler and the Chef. The omelet was equally yummy, containing white corn, collard greens, garlic, cheese, and maybe something else. It was a great combination, and the garlic worked really well, being present but not overpowering. Spacing between tables can be a bit tight, but otherwise no complaints. Staff were friendly and inviting; I'd come back again any day! (Been here for dinner once not too long ago as well; good stuff.) Definitely a nice change from the previous management of years ago.
author: Linus W.

description: Overcharged us $35. They claimed it was by accident after we left but it was a really bad situation
author: Lauren G.

description: Good place for brunch today, arrived around 11am and no wait for a table outside, but a long line by noon. The corn cakes were delicious on a bed of guacamole, full of flavor. My wife had the blt and thought it was good but a little too much bread, unless you like really thick bread on your sandwich, otherwise very good. That and some french press coffee, we were well satisfied with our meal. The service was a little slow but we were happy soaking up the sun and cool breeze today.
author: Irv N.

description: The ambiance was nice and that was the first thing got my eyes but the service was not in my level of expectation. I asked for 2 glasses of water in the beginning which I never received and I have ordered for two dessert and I got only one of them in addition to this it would be nice if the waitress smiles sometime.
author: Ashkan N.

description:
This is a must-go. If you are in San Francisco, you can't miss this place! The food was unreal, so delicious and innovative and beautiful. 
We started with salads, with such crisp lettuce and delicious dressing. I loved the pumpkin seeds. 
Then, the soup--asparagus and leek. SO GOOD; the perfect blend of the two flavors with a delicious amount pepper and and a creamy cashew sauce. 
FINALLY, the entrees--the quinoa bowl and the steak. Both were excellent, the veggies and sauce with the steak were perfect, and the quinoa bowl was like something I've never tasted before. The mixture of flavors--currants, avocado, cauliflower, almonds, etc--was surprising and delightful. 
For dessert--coconut sorbet. So perfect, light, sweet, delicate, and coconutty. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: jessica W.

description: Wait for this place was nottt bad. We got the blue bottle French press coffee, fresh squeezed orange huice, the tortilla soup dish and the sweet bread. It was a very filling and delicious meal. The place is small and you're packed a little close to the next table so they can definitely listen in on your convo if they wanted to but food was good and the wait was not nearly as insane as the place across the street
author: Ruby C.

description:
I chose Olea for my birthday brunch. I didn't know how many people were going to join me so I didn't make a reservation. We waited about an hour for a table for three. 

The space is really small but quaint and you feel like you're at someones house. 

I ordered the squash omelet. The pieces of squash were cubed into tiny pieces and and was hard to taste the squash. It came with pumpkin seeds inside though. It was a nice surprise that gave the omelet a smokey and nutty taste. 

I appreciated the laid-back attitude of the staff. despite the long wait, once we were seated, we never felt like we were being rushed out.
author: Daisy S.

description:
This place has worked-up quite a solid reputation, but to be honest, it's not entirely deserved.

Don't get me wrong, the food's good. For brunch, I opted for the challah French toast, a side of bacon (which was perfectly crunchy and salty), and an orange juice mimosa (fresh-squeezed OJ). 

Was it good? Yes, of course.
But was it worth the 40-minute wait? No, I wouldn't say that.
Or the fact that you were seated at a communal table when there were two-seaters available? Yeah, about that...
Or that you were seated directly by a propped-open door that kept wafting in a cold breeze? No. No, not at all.

At least the service was decent and prices were fair-ish for (s)Nob Hill, but it's nothing to rave about, really.
author: Adena B.

description:
Yummy brunch spot. Thanks to Cece C and James N, my food adventuring partners in crime. We stopped by here last week for some brunch. Cece and I both got the Challah French Toast and James ordered an omelet sandwich and salad. We tried each other's dishes and both were rather tasty. The staff are very friendly and nice.

I don't recommend bringing a big party here though since it's pretty small. No more than 4 max. The wait was about half an hour or so and parking can be tricky even on an early Sunday morning.

All of the dishes sounded yummy so I'll have to go back again in the future.
author: Amy J.

description:
Meh. Was the food good?  Yes. I had the Cazuela and could eat that dish daily. Would I wait in line for it?  No. Not again. It's very disconcerting to be standing in line (next to a list of "house rules") and watch the slooooow pace that tables are being turned over. More than once we saw multiple tables sitting empty in this tiny place. 

Additionally, almost everyone in line had a coffee from the place across the street to enjoy in line. Upon entering, the trash can was pointed out to them. No outside drinks allowed. How 'bout providing at least some water to us poor saps standing in line?

Bottom line: go for the food, but not for the service or atmosphere.
author: Laura T.

description:
I will never return here in my lifetime.

Full disclosure, this review is based entirely on service and not the food.  

I came here early because I know there's a wait and everyone recommended it.  We just missed the first seating so we put our names down and were the 2nd on the list.  They do clearly tell you that they won't seat you unless your entire party is here.  No worries.  I went with my bf so it was just the 2 of us.  I remember the guy who put his name in before us because he had these crazy boots on.  We were told it would be 30-45min, so went next door to get coffee and apparently missed them calling our name (were back in 20 min btw).  They said we had to go to the bottom of the list, which would be at least another hour.  What????  Meanwhile the guy in front of me got to keep his spot on the list because his whole party wasn't there yet.  And as soon as his buddy arrived they got the next seating.  Huh????

So I get punished for having everyone here but he gets to keep his spot in line because his wasn't?  What crazy logic is this?  Everywhere else in town lets you go next if you missed your turn being called, as long as your whole party is there.  I get it if your whole party isn't there, but I've never heard of a place that forces you to the very bottom of the list if you miss your call.  What about the guy before us?  He clearly wasn't ready to be seated either but because he was physically there when they called him, even though he wasn't ready to be seated, he got to keep his spot on the list?  

The guy calling the names didn't even care to explain his logic to me, he just kept saying, sorry, you need to wait here on the sidewalk if you want to be seated.  Then why have a list?  At Dottie's, they make it clear you need to wait there in line b/c they have no list, so if you step out of line, well, you lose your spot.  Clear.  At Brenda's, there's a list.  You put your name down and can do whatever until they call you.  If you're not there when they do, they circle your name and call you again.  You don't have to go to the bottom of the list.  

I was so furious (and clearly still am given the length of this rant) that I refuse to reward a place with such a crazy system with my hard-earned cash.  I don't care how good their food is.  There's plenty of great good places in town.

Only go if you are prepared to wait on the sidewalk for the entire length of your wait...consider yourselves warned.
author: Jennifer F.

description: Great little brunch space, perfect refuel for all the hiking thru SF. Food was delicious and the service was quick. We had the omelette and the challah custard (amazing)! Would definitely come back!
author: Ray D.

description:
After seeing the crazy long line at Mama's, we ended up at Olea around 10:30am. 5 minute wait for a party of 2 on a Saturday! woohoo! (We all know how rare a no-wait brunch place that is highly rated is in SF)

Tip: Come early to skip the line! It's a small quaint joint, so come early!

I tried their challah french toast... easily the best french toast I've had anywhere in SF (or anywhere period!) The bread is fluffy and custard-y on the inside. Each bite is like a fluffy bite of heaven :)

Sorry, I wasn't wow-ed by their French Press Coffee. It was just okay.
author: Emily C.

description: We went here for an early dinner on Saturday night.  It was easy to get last minute reservations.  I read a lot about the amazing brunch they serve, but the dinners are also amazing, and not nearly as crowded.  A casual, but sophisticated ambiance with wonderful jazzy music in the background and candles everywhere.  Plus, the host/owner is very personable and made us feel very welcome and the service is excellent.  Now for the food.  Apparently, the menu changes frequently depending on what's fresh.  We started with the house salad that was beautiful to look at, tasted fabulous, and had a wonderful and unique dressing.  For the main course, I had the scallops in a risotto with shredded Brussels sprouts on top ($22).  I was never a big fan of risotto until I had it here.  Creamy, flavorful, and wonderful and the four huge scallops on top were tender and juicy.  My husband had a bowl of mussels since he wasn't that hungry, but they were well prepared in a delicate broth.  The serving sizes are generous and their prices reasonable for SF.  I can't wait to go back here on my next visit to SF.
author: Paula M.

description:
This place is adorable!

A great location and a cute, small space. It's tough to get a large group in, although there is one community table where you have a shot. We had a group of three and probably waited like 30 minutes last Saturday at 11am.

The menu is short but carefully curated. We ordered the following:
- veggie omelet - was good with some unexpected ingredients (peanuts?) probably the most filling vegetarians option.
- granola with fruit - this was my second breakfast at this point (don't judge) so I wanted something light. It was delicious and a fair price point. The fruit presentation was wonderful though I kind of wanted more fruit.
- huevos rancheros - my friend gobbled it all up before I got to try a bite so I think it was good. Sausage is a main component so not easy to make it vegetarian.

They have a hot cider they serve in addition to normal brunch drinks which was soo good on this blistery SF morning.

This is a great classy brunch spot that isn't too riddled with lines just yet.
author: Raina B.

description: If we were eating together and you finished before me and wanted to go, yet I had one single bite left, I would say "Olea-ve me here!" Not a single morsel to be missed.
author: Maya L.

description:
Went here last night for the first time and was pleasantly surprised. I had heard that their brunch was fantastic so I was curious to see what their dinner would be like. It's a small, quaint place with not a lot of tables which is great so it feels more intimate and you don't really have to worry about fighting for the waitress' attention. We were lucky because we didn't have a reservation but they were still able to accommodate us. 

Now the important part: the food. The boyfriend got the scallops with risotto and mushrooms and this green sauce that was to die for. His father got a vegetarian penne pasta that looked great. I got the duck leg with roasted root vegetables. I had a bite of the scallops and they were amazing. My duck was just so-so. The leg was good, but a little too dry for my liking. I find duck legs to be usually so moist and juicy but that was not the case with this. That being said, it was still extremely flavorful. The roasted veggies were good but very scarce. There really wasn't much on the plate itself. 

We got two chocolate creme de pot (with fresh whipped cream, 4 blackberries and one mint leaf) for dessert and they were good, but very dense. Not super delicious, but good. The chocolate itself was very dense and rich.

Overall, I'm torn. It seems like such a great place that I want to give it a second chance but this first time definitely was just OK. If I go back, I'll definitely update.
author: Sabrina D.

description:
Went for a friend's birthday, and the food was amazing. I had the veal meatballs with pappardelle pasta, and it was seriously one of the best pasta and meatball dishes I've ever had. It was seasoned perfectly, and the portion was just right; I was able to join the clean plate club for a change.

The only drawback was that we had to share a large table with another group. Luckily, they weren't super obnoxious, and they didn't arrive until we were nearly done with our mains.

A lovely spot that I thoroughly enjoyed, and I look forward to returning.
author: Carrie F.

description: New chef for the restaurant!!!!!!!! All they have are 4 items on the menu with rarely any apatite to eat. And I ordered a simple egg with only a single meal of egg n coffee.  And they don't even clean their cup of water. Coffee tastes like water not even hot
author: Jason X.

description: Best juevos rancheros I have had in a while. Long wait to sit but worth it. Only thing, the whole experience felt rushed. We waited in line longer than our eating experience.
author: Biby B.

description:
Tip: Come at 9:15am to avoid waiting! Opens at 9:30am and seats about 25. Seemed that wait time could be anywhere from 40 minutes to an hour, depending on how slowly the early birds finish eating. We got in at 9:30am and left after about 10am.

Food: YUM. French toast (so fluffy!) for sweet and Cazuela for savory. Order both and share with your brunch date! 

Drink: Fresssssssssssh orange juice and delicious french pressed coffee

Price: $$ with a good dish priced at $13. Overall, worth what you pay though because everything was delicious and the venue is so charming. We paid about ~$40 with tip since we ordered drinks.

Getting There: Drove and found parking quickly on a Saturday morning (albeit a long weekend so most people may be out of town). Parking is mostly metered (boo) but you can pay by phone app.
author: Pam M.

description: My fiancé and I came here for years when we were living in a 500 sq ft studio down the street... We fell in love with the chef and the servers: everything from the changing menu to the hand made hot sauce. I highly recommend the cazuela - two fresh cracked eggs in a delicious clay pot sauce. Love the small ambience here and overall highly recommend coming here for brunch AND/or dinner. cheers!
author: Melissa H.

description:
The ingredients really make a difference here!

Loved the combination of flavors used in the dishes we ordered.  My boyfriend and I shared the french toast (because every Yelper recommended it) and an omelette with ham, bell peppers, potatoes and some type of cheese.  Both dishes were fantastic.  The server helped us select the omelette dish.  

I am not giving this place 5 stars because of the price (more like $12 an entree plus the french press coffee was $4.90 instead of just getting coffee and free refills).  The wait time was not bad as we opted to sit at a community table.  They had a sign up sheet inside so the wait process was orderly.
author: Roya B.

description: I was really hoping for an amazing brunch after reading reviews and waiting in line for 45 minutes (even at 9:30 on a Sunday). I had the huevos rancheros and was very underwhelmed. I can't even think of anything else to say about it except "meh". My husband had the equivalent of French toast and really enjoyed it but it was probably 10000g of sugar. The portions are small and the prices are, well, not small. It's a really tiny place and there will be a wait. There is no "list", you just stand in line. They will not seat incomplete parties so make sure you're all there or it could be a while before another table large enough for more than 2 opens up.
author: Erica G.

description:
Finally tried Olea because we lucked out and there was no line at 9:30 when we tried to go in. Brunch was quite good. My egg, bacon, cheese, tomato sandwich was very good. Fresh grapefruit juice. Blue bottle coffee. 

The downsides of this place is the horrendously long line as soon as it fills up and a somewhat stressed and at times a bit rude host/manager. 

Overall- it's worth it if there's no line but there are better places if you have to wait.
author: Amy L.

description: Philip and his team welcomed us in their cozy restaurant on a chilly Saturday evening. The wines were intriguing and paired with the menu beautifully. I had halibut cooked to perfection on a bed of bitter and sweet turnips with their greens. The butter sauce was exceptional. My husband's rack of lamb was worthy of bone gnawing!  Salad and soup starters were light and the perfect openers. We can't wait to go back!  Thanks for a beautiful evening!
author: Nicole D.

description:
Ok, first of all you people in SF do brunch rush way too freaking early. The only reason I was up and out for brunch is because I live on east coast time, so this felt like brunch time for me. I'd been up since 4:30am PST yelping spots that I could get a good carby brunch and I originally decided on Mama's. It opens at 8am and I got there at 8:13am. The line was down the street....at 8am!! It put Clinton Street Bakery's line to shame. Daniel Humm himself could have been in that kitchen cooking and I wouldn't wait in that line.

So, I started looking for another decent spot. I'd bookmarked Olea and we waited in a coffee shop across the street for it to open. I'm so glad we did. I ordered the full order of French toast and it was amazing! It's high on my list of favorite french toast dishes. I'd definitely go back again the next time I'm in SF.
author: Brittanie M.

description:
Another excellent yelp find. My typical brunch places include Universal Cafe, Brenda's, and Butler's & Chef. Olea got a similar rating and was in a location that I could actually find parking on the street. YAY! 

The wait isn't as bad if you get there before 11. There were still a few tables left when I got there (Saturday Morning). 

They serve Blue Bottle coffee in a French Press. 

I ordered the custard french toast , which was super light. Half  portion is more than enough. It was probably the best french toast I've had in the city. 

Can't wait to go back with my husband.
author: Winny F.

description:
Passing by this morning around 9am looking and searching for a tasty spot for bruch and saw OLEA; but we had to wait 30mins til they opened BUT WELL WORTH IT.

Tasted like home, fresh and organic! Most importantly cozy and friendly. I highly recommend this place and ill definitely be back this week. 

PERFECT!
author: Michael S.

description: This is our go to neighborhood spot for dinner. We love the food and the small neighborhoody feel of the restaurant. It's never too crowded for dinner. Great value.  The owner is always very friendly. All in all highly recommend for dinner!
author: Vanessa C.

description: This place is 2 blocks from my place so I opted to try it with my mom.  We had to wait about 20 min but totally worth it.  Great service and good selection.  They did a half order on a couple of items so we could share.  Would recommend!
author: Renee F.

description:
For all that is holy how do you pronounce the name of this restaurant!??!!? OLEE? OLAY? Oh-LEE-uh?!? Someone please answer this for me.

Came here a total of 3 times now since my first post, and I have ordered nothing different. Cazuela - ordered. Challah french toast - ordered.... and sometimes, a second round of a half order of the challah french toast. [i can feel you judging me.. NO CARE]/

Love this place :) I just wish they had more seating!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Imagine entering a restaurant where you receive a heartfelt welcome and are invited to take your pick of the tables.  And imagine such a restaurant where the food is very, very good, well-portioned, and also modestly priced and the service is also very good.  That's Olea. 

I started my meal with the quinoa bowl that came with cherry tomatoes, shallots, currants, garbanzo beans, mushrooms, and almonds.   Lovely.  

Next, pan seared scallops with chanterelle risotto and watercress.  Again a big winner.  The scallops were perfectly prepared, likewise the risotto.  

And by the way, while the room is small it is a gem.
author: David D.

description:
So my lady friends and I were enjoying a Sunday in SF, all excited about brunch.  We found this charming little spot and put our name on the waiting list.  Just 30 minutes or so later, we had ourselves a table.  The restaurant is small, less than 10 tables, so it has a cozy feel to it.  And the service was top notch.  I got the Migas con Huevo (eggs, pork tenderloin, snap peas).  It was good, but not great.  And the portion size was a little small.  My girlfriends were all satisfied with their meals, but no one really raved.  All in all, a nice place to catch up and grab a bite.  But nothing to write home about.      

PS:  Be prepared for the rules of the waiting list!  :)  All people in your party must be present, you have to wait on the sidewalk outside and not leave, and you can't put your name on the competition's waiting list across the street.
author: Heidi S.

description: Had a nice brunch on a Sunday afternoon. Great food and great service. The French toasts was awesome. I always get that for starters. Then the chicken enchiladas were super duper yummy. GF had the omelet and mimosas to top it off. Will be back again soon.
author: Sean J.

description: Probably the best brunch I've had in the city. Their challah French toast is to die for. Couple that with French pressed coffee you will be in heaven. The service is attentive and the staff is so kind and welcoming. There may be a wait but we tend to go later for brunch to avoid the crowds. Popularity and quality do come with a price but this place is well worth it!
author: Rachel S.

description:
After reading reviews on Yelp, I was up for the adventure!
My boyfriend and I got there, signed our name on the waiting list and I guess we came at the right time (around 10:30-11:00am) because we didn't have to wait long (about 10-15 minutes). The place itself is tiny, but very cozy so we got seated in the biggest table they had there with other eaters ("communal table?"), but after a couple minutes we were moved to a table of our own, because there was a group of 5, but I can't complain =)

We ordered the Eggs Cazuela, which were two poached eggs swimming in a pool of tomato sauce and the Migas con huevo; they both come with two toasted bagels on the side. As much as I want to say I absolutely loved it and have no complaints... I can't. It was almost there. Three stars because as tasty as the food was, I found it to be on the bland side and waters didn't include ice in it, so it was slightly room temperature (I always drink water with ice, that's why). We asked for hot sauce (which was spicily delicious) and dabbed it on our food and it was better. Although, I really did love the eggs they used (organic, I think).

But, I shall definitely be back to try their french toast because it seemed like that was everyone's favorite.
author: Jorgess M.

description:
Delicious food and really outstanding service! The staff took such good care of us, but it seems like they just treat everyone that way. We had such a wonderful night and will definitely be back (go for the sirloin!)

I am pretty concerned about how rude the owner's responses are on yelp.. Downgrading an otherwise 5 star review
author: Leia V.

description:
Note: This is an updated review based on the fact that I have now been to brunch there. I stand by my original 3-star review for dinner, which is included in full below.

Brunch: 4-sars
Dinner: 3-stars

So if I could give them 3.5 total I would.

Brunch:
Returned to Olea based on the strength of other brunch reviews - and I must say I was not disappointed. Clearly a 4-star brunch at least!

As everyone else attests to, the custard french toast is truly great! It is rich and creamy, but without being undercooked, There is just a hint of browning and crunch on the outside edges, but without ever being overdone. They offer both a full and half portion - be kind to yourself and just get the full version! You will thank me later.

The custard french toast has enough natural sweetness that you barely need any syrup - but if you choose to add some anyway, you want be sorry, there is no fake high-fructose syrup here, just the real stuff. 

The wait (they don't take reservations for brunch) was about standard for this city on a nice Sunday (maybe 20-25 minutes). But don't worry, just leave one person in line and the rest can go grab a to-go coffee beverage of choice from Contraband coffee just across the street. Please note: the owner regularly checks the entire line and will seat full parties even if they are further back ahead of partial parties at the front of the line. Personally I think this is an A-OK practice and appreciate that it probably helps them turn tables faster, but it is just something to be aware of - if you are with a group, make sure everyone is there!

Service was great, attentive but not aggressive. The menu is small, but focused, and the quality is great. And quite honestly even if the menu was only a single item (custard french toast) I would still recommend it, that's how good it is!

Overall:
4-stars for brunch! (But sadly not as great for dinner in my opinion)

Pros:
Amazing french toast
Good service
Focused, clear menu, with great attention to quality of ingredients

Cons:
None really. The only possible con I could think of is that they don't take reservations for brunch, but then again most places in the city don't.

Summary: 
Go for brunch. 
If you are more interested in dinner, expect a similarly small, focused dinner with a focus on quality ingredients prepared in an un-fussy way. But beware of a lack of options in apps and dessert category, and a wine list that seems expensive (see below).

--------
Original review:
Had dinner here the other night, and the food was delicious. Lovely duck breast, cooked fairly well (maybe a tad overdone for my taste, but still quite good), and great pasta. But I probably won't ever be back except maybe to try the brunch which seems to get rave reviews. 

So why won't I be returning? To begin with, the lack of menu options: while there are enough entree options (a fish, a pasta, a fowl, a meat, vegetarian and vegan options), there was a near lack of starters - in my opinion two salads not constitute an appetizer menu (no hot apps, no soup). And the dessert options that night had nothing for those that like chocolate. 

Second, the pricing at Olea seems a little out of whack. The entrees are all amazingly priced (nothing over $18!) and still have large enough portions, but the wine list is overpriced for what you get ($15 for a glass of Kendall Jackson?).

Pros:
Great farm to table fresh entrees 
Great value for entrees

Cons:
Overpriced wine
Little appetizer selection
No full bar

My verdict: maybe go for brunch based on other great reviews, but don't go for a leisurely dinner expecting 3 full courses at a relaxed pace.

UPDATE: 
The owner left a note on my review that wine prices are based on a 8 oz pour. And that would be totally understandable, except I don't think I got an 8 oz pour. So I stand by my original review. 

Please note there are many great things about dinner at Olea - the entrees are remarkable, featuring excellent produce and meats, prepared in elegantly simple dishes. The limited menu (around 6 entrees) is in no way a detractor for main dishes where every option seemed great, but can be problematic for apps or dessert where there are often only 2 options. And if you are being charged for an 8 oz pour of wine, then make sure you get one.
author: Jane B.

description:
Went to Olea after hearing about it from a San Fran local. The restaurant is a nice little corner spot in an active neighborhood - great location.

The wait was about 30 minutes on a really nice Saturday morning - not bad at all. The staff was very welcoming and planning ahead for our party, which was a nice touch. I also talked briefly with the manager, who was very nice. 

The food at Olea was outstanding. The Challah Toast and Migas were very tasty and  came highly recommended - for a good reason. The Challah toast was not as heavy as normal French toast and went surprisingly well with Migas, which were balanced with spice and substance. 

The only reason I give Olea 4 stars is the mimosas were a tad weak and the price just slightly higher than I expected. Overall though, fantastic place to get brunch. Would go again for sure.
author: Andrew S.

description:
This restaurant is quite small and apparently usually has a long wait.. Luckily when my friends and I went, there was only a twenty minute wait. I'm so glad we waited! The French Toast is to die for! We ordered three other brunch meals as well, they were above average but nothing special. 

Service: The waitress was attentive.. Filled up our waters, asked if we wanted refills, etc. 

Ambience: Small / cozy restaurant :)

Bon appetit!
author: Raveena P.

description: Small menu which can be refreshing either dinner or brunch. Well curated set of options and everything is carefully constructed and yummy. Not too frilly but the owner is generally not that nice. I've had him be curt at times and downright rude at others. Fortunately the wait staff (one British guy to my memory) does not carry the same burden.
author: Carly K.

description:
This is one of the better brunch places in the city especially on Fridays.  Start your day with freshly squeezed organic orange juice, followed by the eggs baked in a cazuela or any of the other egg options that change on a daily basis.  Don't forget to save room for their orange zest cornmeal cake with whipped cream and cherries.  

The service is fast, friendly and helpful.  You'll enjoy the aromas from the kitchen whether it's the bacon or butter.  The place is small with a few tables, so be prepared to wait.  Have no fear, there are great coffee shops nearby to hang out at or keep you up.  Parking can be tough on the street, but it's worth a try!
author: Jenny L.

description: Do NOT go to this restaurant! RUN in teh other direction! SF has too many great places - skip this one. The manager was so RUDE it ruined our meal. The food was fine... but don't suffer through the treatment for food that is just okay. And when I received a request for feedback and entered it... the manager texted me multiple angry follow-up e-mails that were even more horrible than the treatment that we received at the restaurant!! Not only will our group never go back... we will do our best to spread the word about avoiding this place!!
author: April F.

description: Nice brunch spot! Came here after a spin class across the street at Uforia. The wait wasn't too bad, and it was a gorgeous day out so we loved sitting outside. Service was pretty friendly. Huevos Rancheros were so yummy and fresh tasting. The breakfast sandwich was good, but I felt it needed more of a kick of something, maybe aioli? But, OMG. *THE CHALLAH FRENCH TOAST* so so so good. Especially with that REAL maple syrup they serve. Yes. Mimosas were great but serving them in a plastic water glass is beyond tacky.
author: Alexis T.

description: I was standing in line waiting for it to open. But now I know why! The cazuela was delicious  and my fiancé had the huevos rancheros. He said he never had HR that was so flavorful. The French press was okay but the waiter we had was great. It you can handle the heat, you've got to try their hot sauce. My mouth is still watering at the thought.
author: Nutan C.

description:
We waited almost an hour for a table here while my stomach growled but it was 100% worth it. The challah custard french toast with strawberries is hands down the best french toast ever. The half order was enough for me. It beats the french toast at mama's, dottie's true blue cafe, and at la note in berkeley. For you custardy french toast, a thousand times over. 

Oh, the Blue Bottle coffee wasn't bad either :)
author: Chau T.

description: I went for a Sunday brunch. Wait was like 40 mins around 12. Food was good, but we felt like it took kinda long to make! However, the service was very kind. Overall, it's a small cute brunch restaurant.
author: Sophia H.

description:
This is one of the best restaurants in SF (in my opinion ;))!  It is a cozy and warm  (think of the feelings you get around the holidays) complemented with delicious fresh food and caring/attentive service.

For those that have just gone for their brunch, go for dinner too.  It's a lovely treat.
author: Melissa E.

description:
The toast tastes ok and is worth its price. Everything else we ordered (a BLT and a stew) was mediocre at best. 

Service is not good (just being polite here so this review can be seen). the waiter talked and behaved like a boss. (btw, even my boss don't talk to me like that). Maybe because there was a line waiting (for no obvious reason) so he thought people were begging him for food? not sure where his attitude is from.
author: Jake w.

description: Overpriced with attitude....just the way to start your day. There are better choices in the neighborhood.
author: Al G.

description:
For a place with such a long wait and good reviews on yelp, I expected more. Inside Olea, there are two long communal tables and a few individual tables set for small parties. We had the Cazuela, which was ok nothing too special, and the famous french toast. The pork sandwich was quite soggy and lacked any unique flavor. The only redemption at Olea was the french toast which we decided to take a chance on after the other two dishes. If you're insisting on eating at Olea for brunch, get the french toast that's made from Challah bread. 

All things considered, it's not that Olea is terrible. It's just nothing special and there are a bunch of other brunch places in SF that are actually worth waiting for.
author: Angela S.

description:
This review is based entirely on our experience with the host, and not the quality of the food. I have been to brunch here once before and really enjoyed the food so I recommended this for brunch this last weekend to a group of friends that were looking for a fun brunch experience.

I have to say I HATE yelp reviews that sound whiney and self entitled when it comes to service so please take this with the tone that I'm a very patient diner and get that the good places in this town are worth the wait. That said, we were completely insulted by the host and his attitude towards the wait list. He took "roll call" to see who was left on the sidewalk that was still on the list. My friend innocently asked, "we are next right?" as when we checked the list we were next on the list. He responded in the most condescending manner "as I said, i'm just taking role call"....ummm that wasn't our question. We immediately told him to cross us off the list. I don't mean to be an ass, but we aren't special occasion brunchers, we go every weekend and are not skimpy on what we order and we tip very well. 

It will be hard for me to give this place a 3rd chance based on this experience. We proceeded to go down the street and spent A LOT of money at a competing brunch spot.
author: Wendy W.

description:
I want it all. 

That means for brunch I want a satisfying savory & a delicious sweet. Olea fulfilled half of that requirement. Their yogurt, granola, pineapple, & strawberry parfait was fresh & light! Perfect ratio of each ingredient. Such a typical Californian breakfast item, no? 

The 'eggs baked in a cazuela' sounded soooo good, but it had three kinds of meats in it (bet that makes it sound even better to *you*, but it made me yack in my mouf a little.) The other ingredients--tomatoes, farro--looked great; I was totally lusting over bff's cazuela! I wish they made a veggie version. 

I had an omelet with tomatoes & toast--perfectly boring.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Bad customer service. The guy who greets is not friendly and just like another reviewer mentioned., would not want to seat unless everyone there and I just said they are parking and be here shortly. NOT RECOMMENDED!!
author: Dennis S.

description:
Pros: Quality service - very attentive and efficient waiter and food came out within 15 minutes of ordering. 
Cons: Limited dinner menu that ranged on the pricier side
author: Christine K.

description:
The lady and I drove out to Nob Hill just to try out Olea for brunch. It's a quaint little shop that only has about eight or nine tables including one large table that can sit about eight people. Our waitress and server was a very sweet lady. We enjoyed a small blue bottle french press that's perfect for two while we waited for our mains. The lady got the french toast, and I must admit that it's the best that I've had in the Bay Area. Challah must be the best kind of bread to use for french toast because it gives it a crispy crust and a thick, airy filling with a light custard. Topped with cinnamon sugar and strawberries and you have one amazing french toast. I had their omelette of the day that had very complementary flavors and a kick of heat setting it apart from most other omelettes.  

I wished I lived in an area with little neighborhood restaurants just like Olea. If their blue bottle french press doesn't suit you, head over to Contraband across the street for all your coffee needs. I'll be coming back just for the french toast!
author: David O.

description:
Okay, I know the owner but that's not why I come here. We're friends in that ex-colleague who get along and run into each other every 6 months kind of way. I don't get any special treatment or get comped any food when eating here. So even though my friend has been telling me to try the brunch here for ages - and I mean ages, like 3 years - I admit I'm lazy when it comes to brunch. I don't like getting up early on the weekend and if I have to to get dressed to gout to eat before noon I prefer it to be close to home.  So if it makes me a bad friend, sue me.

In those 3 years I've managed to befriend someone who lives in Nob Hill, so naturally when he suggested brunch (yes, men do sometimes suggest brunch) Olea was the first thing that popped into my head.  After much debate over whether brunch should be closer to breakfast or lunch, we settled on 10:30 AM.  Good thing I didn't get my way because it put us at the top of the waitlist when we arrived.  The restaurant was already full and as we loitered not eh sidewalk outside more people kept showing up and putting their names down.  Apparently Olea is the place the go for brunch and I'm the last person to figure this out.

When we sat down it was apparent that the brunch item to order was eggs.  Any egg item if you into savory brunches.  Between us we were tempted by and ordered all three egg options: eggs baked in cazuela, flat omelette and standard stuffed omelette.  I was only able to try the eggs in cazuela and flat omelette.

* large carafe of blue bottle coffee - enough for 3 people plus another round
* eggs baked in cazuela (with ground pork, bacon, kale, cannelini beans, tortilla chips) - comes with homemade hot sauce which is super hot but goes so well with this dish if you can stand the heat, great combination of flavors and textures, I love tortilla chips in soups and stews so maybe I'm partial
* flat omelette (with andouille sausage bits, chinese long beans, oaxaca cheese) - I actually liked this even more than the cazuela dish, the sausage and long beans were super tasty

I would definitely recommend Olea for brunch.  They do a great job of mixing up standard brunch items with unusual ingredients to make something new and even tastier.  Why have plain eggs for brunch when you can have eggs Olea style?
author: Jean K.

description:
If I lived in Nob Hill, this would be my go to spot for brunch. A couple of notes-- Waiting in line outside to be seated is a bit annoying and inefficient. There was a party of 4 in front of us and there was an empty 2 top.  We finally got sat after the 4 got seated... in the previously mentioned 2top.  However the food was great. BlueBottle coffee, challah French toast that appreciates the cinnamon and migas con huevo were excellent. 

For my NYC friends, the food is similar in flavor and style to the Dutch in NYC. Decor is not the same.
author: Jarrod J.

description:
The O and I came here for Sunday brunch. We walk or drive by the place so much and finally decided to give it a try. We arrived around 10:30 and there was already a line. Since there's only two of us, we were seated within 10 minutes at the communal table. We read that Olea is known for the French toast, so we decided to split that and this chilaquiles like dish. They also serve Blue Bottle coffee so I got to experience that for the first time here too.

The coffee arrived in a posh-looking French press. The place has the organic raw sugar cubes, also adding a classy touch. The coffee was mild (or some would call it "smooth"?) compared to the Starbucks stuff that I'm used to. I am not a coffee connoisseur so whatever makes Blue Bottle so popular and expensive is lost on me. Definitely happy to try it, though.

The chilaquiles-like omelette was fantastic! I've tried the one from the Ferry Building farmer's market, which is suppose to be a very good version of the dish, and wasn't impressed. Granted, Olea didn't call it a chilaquiles, but the dish had all the elements -- the scrambled eggs, the sauce (green, in this case) and the fried tortillas. The tortillas were in strips instead of chips and they stayed crunchy until the last bite. The sauce wasn't as sour as the green sauce on the chilaquiles from the Alemany farmer's market and it had small speckles of pork. The eggs were wonderfully soft and runny, just as I ordered. I would definitely get it again.

The star of the meal, without a doubt, was the French toast. They probably soaked the challah in the custard batter for a while for it to soak up all the goodness. The French toast was so soft and airy, with a mild sweetness, but not soggy. I can still feel the texture of the egg bread. The dusting of cinnamon and sugar mixture is a little crunchy and makes the treat extra special. There was so much reluctance in Orin's eyes when it was time to switch plates, it took everything he had not to run off with the plate to a deep cave somewhere to enjoy it all by his lonesome. Mmmmyyyyyy preeeeeecious...

After our brunch experience, I'm quite excited to go back for dinner. The portion size here is on the small side, but that allows you to walk out of the place without the fear that the button on your pants will pop off the minute you stand up and take out someone's eye. The service is friendly and the menu is simple and seasonal. Definitely a neighborhood gem.
author: Alice W.

description:
This is a small place so you'll probably wait a bit during peak brunch hours so keep that in mind.
I had an omelet with Kale and other seasonal greens, shallots and cheese and a mixed green salad. The meal was simple but really fresh and delicious. My favorite part about the entire meal was the coffee. So good!

The host (gentleman) was such a nice guy. Just very friendly and helpful with menu selections and helping us to work the coffee press :)

Definitely worth dropping by.
author: Rhonda G.

description:
This place, located on the busy street of California, often has a huge wait so come early - or expect to be in line. Contraband Coffee up the street takes awhile to make each cup, so it can stave the wait for a bit. The actual dining area is super cute and very comfy.

The bf and I ordered the flat omelet with butternut squash and ham, cheese crostini as well as the baked egg in tomato and cheese. Both very good, but portions were medium-sized with high price points. Just beer/wine license so no bloody mary's for us, unfortunately. 3 stars for Olea being OK -- nothing out of the ordinary, not immediately rushing back, etc. If I lived around the corner I'd probably frequent this spot, but since I live farther than that I probably don't need a 2nd visit.
author: Johanna L.

description:
Another great Nob Hill brunch place...but this one comes with Blue Bottle Coffee!!  I'm just so incredibly happy that my morning included this that I couldn't give this place less than 4 stars. 

In order of my favorite to least, we ordered the pulled pork sandwich, eggs baked in a cazuela, wild manila clams, and scrambled eggs.  The pulled pork was soo tender and I loved that the eggs in the cazuela were still super hot and in this great tomato sauce.  The clams were good but mediocre and the scrambled eggs we definitely could've done without.  

Definitely coming back here again for that pulled pork though!
author: Jane N.

description: I brought my puppy and we were seated outside where they also brought out a cushion and a bowl of water for the puppy to lay on and enjoy. They were very nice and the food was good. It gets busy here though so expect a wait on weekend mornings at least.
author: Michail Y.

description: Just a friendly reminder that this place does not do drive through.  Please do not attempt drive through here
author: Yan L.

description:
Something to cheer.

Soccer cheer: Olé, Olé, Olé.

Pasta cheer: Olea, Olea, Olea.

Kitchen deserves applause for the vegan pasta. Cauliflower, carrots, kale and tomato basil sauce more than make up for the missing flour and eggs. Score.

Petit Four dessert was just as good. Brownie, tart, sorbet and cookie were right sized and tasted just right. Quite the deal at $7.50 too.

Arugula salad was good but could have used more grilled peaches. Always.

For someone quite happy with bottles of wine in the $5 - $10 range just can't get behind $12 glasses. Save those calories for dessert.

Brunch might be a chaotic scene but during dinner Olea becomes a relaxed, dimly lit space with good food and great staff. Cheers.
author: Jason B.

description:
We arrived at 12pm and waited two hours to eat. But I ain't even mad. It was totally worth the wait, and almost no food ever feels like it's worth a two hour wait. 

I gotta say, hands down, the best french toast I've ever had. BEST.

I also got to try the baked egg in a casuela and it was delicious as well. Very hearty and one of the more unique things I've seen at a brunch place. Also it doesn't taste too greasy or heavy like most brunch places do. I tried my friend's scrambled eggs and it was good as well. Everything was good, even down to the fresh squeezed juice we got.

It'll be really hard for me to pass over the french toast next time, or any time I come back. I guess the trick is to get someone to split it with me :P
author: Julie K.

description:
Get the challah french toast if you are a fan of french toast. It's custardy and not too sweet. A half portion was enough to fill me up even though our waitress suggested a whole. That girl can eat!

The wait can be pretty long so be prepared for that.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
First of off I had a party of 6 which is a bit difficult to accommodate for these smaller brunch places. They were extremely nice and let us know that we had several options for seating arrangement, but my party insisted that we sit together. So, I would recommend this ideally for a smaller party of less then 4. Any more, then you would have to get there earlier, however, I promise that it is quite worth the wait. 

The host, Daniel, was extremely friendly make sure that my party was comfortable. he occasionally checked up on us actually while we were waiting outside. 

When it came time to order, I asked our server, Amanda, if I could have the scrambled eggs a bit runnier. She insisted that the eggs were perfect as is and I honestly took her word for it. You see I judge a brunch placed on their scrambled eggs. the beauty in the dish is that you think that it is simple, but it isn't. I expect the eggs to be a bit runnier as it create a creamy silk text. It should basically melts in your mouth. I digress.

So I believe the manager, Wade, (at least I think he was the manager) served my plate and suggested that I try the eggs with a in-house hot sauce. The first bite of the eggs and I can't believe how perfectly it hit that consistency of my ideal scrambled eggs. It was also seasoned perfectly, I did not have to add any additional seasoning, or the hot sauce. I have to say it is the best brunch place that I have been to so far. I was totally in love with Dottie's True Blue Table, but I feel that Olea edged them own just by the slightest hair. 

Wade would check on our table periodically and would be quite the joy to chat with. He suggested that we share their french toast. I have say that I was also not disappointed by this choice. IN fact, I am so happy that he recommended it. It was the fluffiest French Toast that I have ever had. They use a custard mix and soak a day old bread (it was a fancy name, but I don't remember what it was called). This helps to create that fluffy consistency without it becoming mush. There is a perfect balance between the use of brown sugar and cinnamon. And the "Cherry on top of it all" was the light brown sugar coating on the fresh strawberry toppings. The sugar balances the tartness amazingly. 

Their other server, Samantha, was also attentive as she made sure that our glasses were consistently filled. 

I have to say that this wasn't just an awesome food place, but it was also an amazing experience. The space was small enough to feel like someone's home, but not so tight that I didn't feel that I couldn't breathe. My party was extremely happy and well attended too. 

I look forward to my next visit and possibly checking out dinner.

TL;DR: great service and awesome food especially the French toast and scramble
author: Richard S.

description:
After living in SF for about 2 years now I can confidently say that Olea is one of the best bargains in the city. For about $20 a person you can get a meal that rivals the quality of San Francisco's best, but without having to kill your wallet.

The service is fantastic and atmosphere is great for a date night.

Can't recommend it enough!
author: Spencer S.

description: Visiting my son and we tried Olea for brunch. The food was good, juice and coffee were good however pretty modest portions. Decorated nicely. Just didn't feel comfortable. The vibe is a little uptight in my opinion.
author: Liz T.

description:
When the line outside is so long for a brunch place you know they either serve really good food or trick hipsters into thinking it's good with variations of dead pig on a plate. Lucky for us, the former is true (though there are plenty of pork-infused options in case you got worried for a second.)

My s/o ordered the Challah Toast (since everyone and their mother recommends it on Yelp and Foursquare.) I, meanwhile, ordered the omelet with sweet potatoes, collard greens and almonds. The Challah Toast was delicious. Not life altering like some have mentioned, but definitely worth trying. The omelet was interesting -- the almonds added a nice texture to the dish, and I always enjoy an egg dish prepared with new flavors. After finishing our main brunch meal I was still a little hungry so I ordered their yogurt & granola with agave nectar, strawberries, persimmons and fuji apples. It was as good as it sounds. I also had their fresh-squeezed orange juice which was literally being squeezed before it was brought to the table, and was the perfect way to kick start a lazy Sunday.

I don't know if I'd return to Olea for brunch again because their menu options are limited, and there's not much else on the menu I want to try - plus the lines are so long. But it's definitely worth visiting at least once to try the Challah Toast.
author: Adena D.

description:
Cha-llah-llah-llah! Boy, oh boy, is the French toast decadent yet seemingly light. Pairs perfectly with some French press coffee! 

Love the exterior and the inside is so comfy! I ate here about 4 years ago and am so happy to see it's still around and thriving! Can't wait to come again.
author: McKenna G.

description:
BEST BREAKFAST I HAVE EVER HAD. EVER.


Did I say ever?? 


Do not come hungry. They don't take rezzies, but I promise you it is worth the wait. I will wait for amazing food any day. #bestfrenchtoast #worthit #doit
author: Melissa B.

description:
My friend and I had just finished running FOUR miles in the morning, so we were STARVED. Since we were in the neighborhood, I suggested this place because I always pass by it when I shop along Polk Street.

Lo and behold, there's a HUGE red sign that says "Now Serving Brunch." Coincidence? I think not! Plus there were a bunch of people waiting outside, so that's always a sign of a good place right?
The place is pretty small, but cozy. We ended up waiting about 20 minutes, but once our name was called, we were promptly greeted and helped.

The food: GET THE CHALLAH CUSTARD TOAST. OH. MY. GEE!!!! AMAZING!!!!!!!!! It is so delicious and tasty and yahhh!! Comes with pears and cinnamon and definitely don't forget to use the maple syrup on the table! :) We also got the yogurt with granola and the omelet with squash(?), but don't even bother with those. I could've prepared it myself.  CUSTARD TOAST ALL THE WAY! Oh the freshly squeezed orange juice was delicious too :)

I gave 3 stars because of the price. It's pretty expensive, especially for brunch :P Our total ended up being almost $20 each! Or maybe it's just cause we're 3 poor post-college gals who still aren't financially stable :T
Also (and this isn't Olea's fault), we felt rushed when we were finishing up the last of our meal. I understand that there's a wait, but I kinda wish we could've sat a bit, chatted, relaxed... Oh well.

I would love to come back and try some of the dinner dishes! It'll probably be expensive, but maybe I can go with someone who'll pay for me ;D
author: Kei H.

description: Great service. The host and server were super friendly.  Loved the asparagus soup, French press coffee and tiramisu.
author: Larry M.

description: Wow!!! Super fantastic brunch. Delicious eggs in the most amazing beef tomato sauce. Rosemary took such great care of us. Can't wait to come back.
author: Cmrg G.

description:
I had never heard of this place, but a girlfriend took me here this past weekend. It is such a cute little hole in the wall place in Nob Hill.  There is always a line, so we got there early to avoid a wait. 

I ordered a mimosa and the challah bread french toast .... This was hands down, the best french toast I've ever had.... and I've had a lot of french toast in my day. Plus the server was really friendly and the food was served quickly.

I am so glad that I found a new brunch spot!
author: Taylor L.

description:
The first weekend I moved to the 'hood, I ate at Olea for brunch. It was a windy Saturday afternoon and we had to wait maybe 20 minutes for a table for two.

We ordered: Blue Bottle French pressed coffee for two, the Mexican soup dish with eggs in it (forgot the name) and their steamed clams. I thought the Mexican soup dish was pretty good. I've never tried anything like it before, so I had no qualms about it. After all, I like food. Food and I are best friends. The steamed clams were not flavored as well as I would have imagined. I suppose I'm used to ordering it at Italian restaurants and wanting to drink the sauce bath it's in. :) But, again, I like food. Food and I are best friends. So, it was fine.

I really liked the assortment of breads they gave us with jam and butter. Really yummy!

The very next day, Sunday, I came back for brunch again. It was Day 2 of my move and I knew I wanted to come back to order the custard french toast and something more traditional for brunch. We ordered two of the breakfast sandwiches that came with a small salad and the challah toast to share. I love that they have housemade hot sauces. I doused my sandwich with the first little hot sauce dish given to us and requested for more. The second little dish seemed to pack MUCH more heat and I ended up looking like I just got dumped... turning red, sweating and tearing up in a restaurant out of nowhere when all seemed fine before. Ahhhhh, but the heat hurt so good. Mmm.

Any who, my friend loved Olea so much she keeps craving for brunch here again! We shall be back soon :)
author: C C.

description:
HMMM i really wanted to review this place positively but thats not the case...
I spent $55 at breakfast and left hungry :/  for the price of the food it is not worth it at all. I had the french toast everyone raves about and it was good but nothing spectacular. Its a cute spot but not going to return
author: Natasha I.

description:
everyone raves about their brunch, but their dinner is quite good!

i don't know why no one comes here for dinner - it's always dead in the evening, but that's ok it kind of makes it my secret spot when i need to have a decent reasonably priced meal without making a reservation.

service is excellent and they have a great wine list.  everyone is super friendly.
author: Josie M.

description: We've been meaning to try Olea since we brunched at Mymy and observed the line forming across the street. Our plans were postponed by an unfortunate shutdown due to a car crashing into the restaurant. We finally gave Olea a try on 4/25 and got in with only a 10 minute wait. It seemed like everyone in line before us had their name down across the street and were waiting for the first to seat them. I had the challah french toast and the significant other tried the bacon scrambled egg sandwich. The bread was very tasty and the eggs were not overcooked. The challah French toast was rich but nothing amazing. The mimosas were fresh and cold. A solid neighborhood spot but we wouldn't wait more than 20 minutes to brunch. We'll try it for dinner soon!
author: NJ A.

description:
OH MY GOODNESS. BEST FRENCH TOAST. IT IS TO DIE FOR. 

Challah bread with fresh strawberries and cinnamon sugar sprinkled on top.
The bread is perfectly moistened, not too soaked and soggy. Just enough for it to taste sort of creamy and doughy. And you don't even need syrup! Use the cinnamon sugar for flavor, they compliment each other so well! 

WILL DEFINITELY BE RETURNING. SADLY THEY ARE CHANGING ONWERS :(
**GO SOON BEFORE THEY CHANGE ONWERS!!
author: Jamie C.

description: Have been here twice for brunch and loved it both times. High quality food, great seasonal brunch options, and warm & cozy SF atmosphere.
author: seema s.

description: Went here a couple months ago - Had a brunch dish that came in a little cast-iron skillet (bread / egg / cheese / sausage).  It was screaming hot, and cooked to the point there was no moisture left in the dish.  Also tasted another dish, and it had a lot to be desired.  Totally don't understand the huge rating, this food was lame.  Nobody finished their food.
author: Click C.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Sunday with 3 people. Arrived at around 10 and waited in a not so long line. I forget exactly when we were seated, but at the latest it was 10:30, so for brunch in SF on a Saturday, not a bad wait at all. Also, the staff was very accommodating as we were waiting on a friend who was walking up the hill from BART and they seated us even though he wasn't there yet so we could order coffee and tea while we waited for him. 

Blue Bottle french press is huge but amazing. I had the french toast - it's one of the most delicious things I've ever eaten, no joke. Order it!

Friendly service, great food - definitely will be back here!
author: Jennifer M.

description: Ok really loved this place! In a wonderful neighborhood Nob Hill perfect for walking around in. The vibe was chill & the service was excellent. My waiter Nick was funny, charming, attentive & nice. The owner Philip was very involved on the floor & both helped me with making my picky choices:) First off bloody mary's made with sake super yum! Fresh squeezed Oj & blue bottle coffee were superb. I loved the omelette with kale, parsimony, fontina cheese & pecans with a side salad. And the  Cazuela; Baked Eggs, Beef, Pork, Bacon, White Beans, Tomato Sauce, Tortilla Chips, Parmesan Cheese was inventive yummy & one of a kind. I would def. check this spot out
author: Flavia C.

description:
After absolutely horrid and humiliating experience at Red Door Cafe at hat morning I was so happy to try Olea! People are nice and service is great.
For the food - absolutely loved their French Toast :-) One of the best I ever tried - made to perfection!  Eggs were done great as well. I do not eat pork or I would love to try more dishes! Sigh - these looked fantastic! 
So do yourself a favor and try the French Toast!
author: Nastia R.

description: best french press coffee . really good mimosas, and ok the BEST Avacado Toast! i recommend that and getting the Cauzuela which is so unbeleivebly good oh my gosh the eggs and sauces and cheese ugh so yummy!!!!
author: Sophia H.
