description: Everyone from the manager to the waitstaff are just plain rude.  A smile and at the very least a friendly greeting would go a long way.  The waitstaff cleaned our table without asking if we were finished (we weren't, but nearly) making you feel rushed for them to turn tables.  Prices high, food is decent.  Not worth it.
author: Lorri H.

description: Plea has the best French toast known to man. The service is great as well! Be sure to try their fresh squeezed orange juice. You will not be disappointed.
author: Nicolette A.

description:
I've dined here twice, both for dinner.  The first go around, my boyfriend and I were super excited to see copper river salmon on the menu. As huge fans, we both ordered the salmon dish and were both disappointed. The dish was just off, the lentils or whatever was underneath the fish were really unappealing and overall, it was just not an exciting dish.  Disappointing but we both agreed we'd try Olea again in the future. Our second visit came and went and went over much better.  I got the Quinoa bowl(charged $8 to add chicken to it, a little steep IMO). It was really tasty however.  We also tried a fish dish which was great.  

I know the rave is about brunch, so will have to make an AM stop in!
author: Brianna M.

description: Easily one of the best breakfast/brunch spots in SF, trust me, the Challah French Toast is well worth waiting in line (no reservations) in the SF cold and noisy California St traffic.  The gooey goodness will simply melt in your mouth.  All of the selections are excellent, but there are definite standouts.  Try the omelette or any of the Mexican dishes, all are amazing palette popping entrees.  The restaurant is small, so be patient.  The owner is nice, but can get a bit agitated when asked repeatedly when a table is going to be ready!  Never been for dinner, but hear it is good, brunch is a standout in the area for sure.  You won't be dissapointed.
author: Jay A.

description: I finally made it in! This place is quaint and very popular. I love the fact that they give you a French press, it's genius and the best way to drink coffee next to a pour over. I had a squash and spicy greens omelette without cheese and it was lovely! The only part that was dissatisfying was in fact the side of bacon. If they cooked it any longer it would not have been edible. Anyone who understands bacon knows that it tastes best somewhere in between juicy and crispy.  Ya gotta find a balance and unfortunately, I was disappointed.
author: Bree G.

description: Our family love's coming to this place. We come here for brunch, they've been consistent with service and food. Love their Toast, soup, sandwich, and blue bottle coffee. The wait is a bit long at times, but worth it once you're seated and food is served.
author: Trish M.

description:
Came here for brunch and was blown away by their food. My favorite was their challah custard toast, which was so light ans moist. Their pulled pork sandwich was also juicy. Even their simpler things like eggs were cooked well. Great service, too!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
So worth the trek that we made to find this place.  Having looked up the menu and reviews the night before, we had our minds set on Olea and only Olea for brunch that day.  Despite what seemed to be regenerating blocks between our starting point and Olea, their pitch on organic produce from local farms and seasonal ingredients had us hooked.  Upon arriving, we were subjected to a 45 minute wait, which was more than understandable considering the size of this place.  

Once we were called and seated, we had a prime shot of the kitchen and the items coming out.  All looked appetizing and sufficient enough to accompany our mimosas with fresh squeezed "organic" oj.  We ended up with the eggs baked in a cazuela (cooking pot) and the omelet with asparagus and mixed green salads.  The omelet was as expected, but it was the baked eggs residing in tomato sauce with smoked ham and basil-almond pesto that stole the show.  Definitely something we mentioned we would attempt to replicate at home, but probably not to that level.  

Considering the extended waitlist for brunch, service was timely and efficient, but not pushy.  Our server was friendly and openly engaging in small talk.  We had a great experience and after viewing the dinner menu we even considered it as an option for that evening.
author: Nick C.

description:
In town from Chicago for a wedding, decided to check out some yelp recommendations for brunch spots.  As a note, my wife and I have developed very discriminating taste from our brunch experiences in the Chicago culinary scene.  That being said, we were supremely impressed with the brunch here at Olea.  The Challah French Toast, as you might well have read about in some of the previous posts, was absolutely fantastic. Simply outstanding.   The Fresh squeezed orange juice was delicious, coffee by french press was amazing - easily the best coffee that I have ever had.  

Summation, Olea stands up out as a great brunch option but be sure to get there early as it fills up pretty quick here.
author: Lukas Y.

description: Had brunch with a few girlfriends this past Saturday at Olea, I was anticipating a long wait for brunch, but luckily we got there right before the rush. I ordered the slowly braised marinated pulled pork sandwich with green cabbage, cilantro and yellow carrot slaw and a side of roasted new potatoes. The braised pork was a bit dry, but it had a decent flavor to it. The slaw was good, but overall this dish was not very memorable. Both of my friends ordered the challah custard toast with cinnamon sugar topped with fresh berries served with maple syrup. I thought this dish was much better than mine -- the custard stuffing was perfect, french toast was good, and the serving is pretty big!  The decor was nice and welcoming with lots of sunlight shining through the windows. There was only one waitress working on the Friday morning so service was a little slow, but she definitely managed everything well! Overall, I think Olea is a decent place for brunch but considering all of it's competition, it really needs to bring more memorable dishes to the table!
author: Elaine N.

description: We are SO glad they reopened after the car accident in the cafe (they now have more seating). Sometimes the wait for brunch is a little long but ALWAYS worth it! Great customer service, cute cafe, and THE BEST FRENCH TOAST (it's custard FT with strawberries!!) I've EVER had. If only I stilled lived in the neighborhood I'd (still!) be there on a weekly basis! We love to go here anytime were in the city and bring friends and family that are visiting.
author: Abby W.

description:
If I could do half stars, this place would be a true 3.5. It's good for some things, okay for others, and a totally long wait. It always has a ton of people waiting outside for brunch on weekends, so I wanted to see what the hype was. The wait was about 40 minutes for 2 on Sunday afternoon, so not too terrible.

We ordered:
- Cinnamon sugar challah french toast: This was really good. French toast usually tastes the same to me, but their cinnamon sugar topping is unique. They could've added more strawberries, but I'm not complaining :)
- Pulled pork sandwich: This was just okay. For $12, it was one of the pricier items for brunch but it tasted like something you could get anywhere. Too salty and nothing special. 

Other notes:
- Servers were really friendly
- Place is tiny
- Bathroom door is seriously hard to open (maybe it's just me)

I'd probably come again to try their dinner menu. The wait for brunch and the food you get just isn't worth it for me to come back on weekends.
author: Shira C.

description:
i cant even waste my time to tell you all reasons im shocked the FDA hasnt shut this place down already.  
my brother was in town and we both got sick after we ate here.. had to cancel our plans to take the ferry over to Sausilito. I still dont feel 100 percent and it's been a week.
author: Kyle B.

description:
Excellent brunch spot. Went at 1pm on a Saturday and did not have to wait. French toast is as advertised by others. Pulled pork sandwich was excellent. 

We'll be back!
author: Sean S.

description:
(See pics)

I always thought you would get tired of food that you love. There's always an exception.

I always have the one and unique Challah Custard Toast here. Every time I have it, it's like a new experience all over again. The excitement, the anticipation, the cinnamon sugar, the super soft and fluffy and slightly hinted sweet toast, the light syrup, with the compliment of the BB coffee, and the lovely atmosphere. It is heaven that keeps me dreaming of it.

I also took a bite of my friend's order of omelette which was also very delicious and fresh.

Will definitely have to come back to check out the dinner!
author: T L.

description:
I came here because my visiting cousin really wanted French toast, and this was the best option for her. While the French toast was amazing, there are just not enough brunch options on the menu. The menu was a little bare and minimal. The coffee was pretty overpriced.

I do like the intimate and quieter ambiance. However the wait staff didn't come around enough and we literally had to go up to the kitchen counter to ask for ketchup.

I probably won't come back here.
author: Jeanne C.

description: I'm sure the owner of this place thinks people come here to pay $15 for scrambled eggs, but in reality when people go out for brunch they come for the dining experience. I've never had a more terrible dining experience than what I had here. The owner was rude and completely destroyed the mood our group had after waiting 45 minutes in line. You'll see the same complaints from other reviewers -- and the "answers" from the owner -- clearly demonstrating the attitude this guy has. I was happy with what I ordered and the servers were very attentive and did a good job. But man, this guy really ruined the brunch for all of us.
author: Bryan D.

description: Mediocre food that sounds different and good on the menu, but doesn't quite come together. The best dish was the French toast. Also, the music they were playing sounded like a 15-year old girl's playlist.  Overall, the food was overpriced for what it is, and the waiter was always in up-sell mode which was strange. Disappointing since we had always wanted to go here and always saw such positive reviews.
author: Madhavi M.

description: Best French/custard toast ever! Accommodating and friendly wait staff, definitely a hidden gem.
author: Kayla R.

description:
While I felt the location was a tiny bit random, brunch was fabulous. The winning move was splitting a half order of french toast so I could get my savory in (egg sandwich) while having the brunch version of dessert. The iced coffee was fantastic as well, but to this day I still ponder: what could they possibly do to that french toast to make it so good?!

Also, try to go later to avoid the wait. We did brunch around 1:30 on a Saturday and walked straight in. If you're anything like me, I'd rather go to the gym and run errands in the morning instead of waiting 2 hours in line to eat.
author: Leslie K.

description: Pretty weak offering.  All 4 entrees our group ordered were a disappointment.  Pulled pork sandwich had very little going for it.  And waiter was pushy and awkward.
author: Lee W.

description: The food was good, but one of the waiters was really rude. I would have given it a 4 otherwise
author: Juby M.

description:
French toast is amazing!

too bad we have to wait long time and the restaurant is very small.

TIP: If you want Sunday morning brunch go to the restaurant 5 minutes before opening. U will def get a seat. Also, you can not bring your own drink. My friend bought a coffee across the street but he couldnt get in til he finished it lol
author: Rio S.

description:
Overpriced brunch but the food and service was ideal.
We hit lucky and got there about 1130am and got the last table. Before we were finished there was a que of 5 different couples waiting at the entrance.
author: Jay B.

description:
Been here for brunch a few times, it's in the neighborhood so we can get there early before the wait. I like that they bring coffee out to people waiting in line. The menu is fresh and seasonal. I tried the custard-injected challah french toast, it was okay. Sort of mushy, but the flavors were fine.

One time, we were seated at a communal table next to another couple. The girl was leaning over her boyfriend's plate, absolutely gobbling it up while he just sat and watched. We couldn't believe how much of his food she was eating, meanwhile the french toast on her plate went cold. Eventually they just switched plates and she cleared house. I made note of the dish that she was going so ga-ga for and ordered it the next time I came. It was a baked crock of eggs, beans, tomato, and cheese, served with toast. I nearly licked the bowl clean myself. It is not a dish meant for sharing, or at least, you won't want to share.

They serve Blue Bottle, too.
author: Halley S.

description:
Great for brunch (served Friday-Sunday), but unfortunately they did not have the pulled pork sandwich I came here for. We settled for the omelette and the French toast, which were both relatively standard for a brunch spot. 

Good thing is that there is nobody there on Friday so no long wait.
author: Daniel K.

description:
It's more of a 3.5 stars for me.

Really nice little corner location.  Been here for brunch a few times, definitely try to get there on the early side or there will be a bit of a wait.  Some of the popular items are the baked egg and the french toast.  I also tried the egg sandwich which was decent. Not sure why but both times i left a little hungry.  

Worth a try...get to it
author: Dilly M.

description:
Yes, this place is super cute insides. Yes, there is long wait list for weekend brunch and Yes, the clientele is a mix of hip and hipster. BUT the food is seriously not as great as you would expect from the ambiance.  The omelettes are no better than the ones I make at home, which isn't saying much.  I got their baked eggs and beans dish which was pretty yummy, but not with shooting stars.  There are much better brunch spots in the city- definitely not worth the wait.

Here's just a short list:
Just for You
Boogaloos
Ellas
Tartine
author: Skye W.

description:
I decided to come here with my group of friends after sadly realizing that the red door brunch only took groups of 2 at most. The wait time wasnt too bad but there are only 2 tables that can hold a group of 4 so that would be the only thing that could cause a longer wait time. The omelets change weekly with all the freshest ingredients they can find. Since there were four of us, we decided to all get different things to try, along with their freshly squeezed orange juice.

Custard toast with cinnamon sugar & strawberries: AMAZING. definitely a unique twist on french toast and though it was more of a dessert dish, it wasnt super sweet considering they cooked it with custard. it said it came with maple syrup, which was probably added into the toast before being served, but i wish they had a small container on the side so we could add more on our own. 

Eggs in a cazuela with french toast: hmm...definitely different then what i expected. It had an exotic middle eastern look, basically it was poached eggs inside a tomato/cheese/ground beef soup with strips of toast on the side. Although it was flavorful, I wish it had a little spicy kick at the end to make it special. plus, for $13, i expected to be a bit fuller after brunch. The bowl it is served it is probably half an inch deep, MAX. 

Mussels soup: the broth reminded me a bit of the asian sweet and sour soup with some corn mixed in. The sourdough bread that was served with the dish tasted fresh and soft, perfect compliment. Mussels were cooked nice, overall nothing bad about this dish.

Omelette w salad: definitely the most traditional brunch type of meal out of the bunch. cooked well, salad had fresh veggies incorporated in it. simple, yet classic.
author: Elizabeth Z.

description:
Visited for dinner on a Saturday night. Its a small place, but surprisingly cozy. 

My party of 3 all had delicious Fall-inspired dishes. Was a great meal.
author: Bob F.

description: best french toast ever it was like a bread pudding with sugar and cinnamon and strawberries. didn't feel rushed even though they were already starting to close and our waiter was very nice. WAY NICER THAN MYMY CAFE or whatever the place across the street was
author: Erika P.

description:
Worth the wait in every possible way. 

Challah french toast and the pulled pork sandwich were both excellent. Good iced coffee here as well. Great service. Super cute spot. 

Definitely one of those places you think about for days or weeks even after you eat here. Get here early to avoid the rush; lines can get long.
author: Sara D.

description:
This place became our spontaneous brunch destination after many "veto, no and no way" my suggestion for "girlfriends brunch" at Olea was met surprisingly well...

French toast was awesome, pork sandwich was flavorful. mussels were smokey and baconey  (really unusual and good!) and scrambled eggs were pretty good as well.

Service was warm and nice. Nothing was wrong there, but something was missing... or maybe it's just me on Sunday morning or maybe because we had to wait for or always late girlfriend? ;) 

They use organic/local produce/meats - which of course always a "yes!' for me!

All of this with 4 glasses of mimosas cost us $88.00
author: Anelya S.

description:
Six of us had brunch here this morning (Friday).  Seated immediately.  Wonderfrul.  Service was very personable and informative.  Mimosas all around.  Barefoot Champagne (oo kay I guess) with just a dash of fresh squeezed orange juice.  The fresh squeezed  made it wonderful.  Within our group we had everything on the brunch menu except the Challah French toast.  All items were wonderful. 

 My opinion:  Portions could have been a little more generous.  I could be saying that because it was so tasty! The setting was clean and inviting with quality flatware and dishes and I like that.  

Only critique is maybe throw a few potatoes on the plate, but everything was cooked perfectly.
author: Beth Y.

description:
I've lived in the Nob HIll/Polk Street area for a few years now--since before Olea opened, in fact--and I've only just recently tried this restaurant. I really cannot point to a single reason why I avoided going here for so long (is that hideous font on their sign REALLY a reason to pass it by for years?); however, having finally given it a shot, I can safely say I have no reason to go back. 

It's been a suspicion of mine that brunch is, perhaps, one of the most over-hyped things of the 20th/21st centuries. It always seems overpriced, it's rarely memorable, and, frankly, I can't help but feel like I've been had every time I've ventured out for it. Though perhaps "had" is the wrong word... or perhaps it doesn't convey exactly what I'm going for. What I mean to say is this: every time I go to brunch, the feeling afterward is akin to what I would feel after getting not-so-subtly groped by an ugly stranger on a bus.

And after eating brunch at Olea, I'd add the following: that feeling you get while you're looking through your wallet the morning after a pretty wild, drunken night. You know the one I'm talking about? That moment where you're pretty sure you should have $20 - $40 more in your wallet than you currently do, and you're also pretty sure it fell out of your pocket in the cab because you were too fixated on getting fresh donuts instead of organizing your money properly...  

Yea... 

So my boyfriend, Joaquin, had the french toast. It was "good enough". I need to put that in quotes, because I need to somehow stress that this french toast was not at all the ground-shaking dish many here seem to claim it is. It's FRENCH TOAST, Yelpers! Do we realize how uncomplicated this dish is? They use challah bread, which is a wise choice for french toast, but trust me, I've been making and eating french toast for years (one look at me in person will verify this statement), and this is not a difficult dish. Olea's output is not surprising or unique.

I tried the cazuela, and it's no lie that I was expecting something far more interesting and flavorful than what I received. It's one of those dishes where you know--you just KNOW--the individual ingredients are more flavorful than the semi-watery pile of egg scramble you've been handed. You look at the menu again, and you just can't figure out how 1 + 1 + 1 somehow ended up a 0. There were tortillas in the mix, so it had a bit of crunch, but beyond that, it just didn't amount to much of anything. 

My iced coffee was good, as was the orange juice, but that by no means redeems the  meal, much less the price we paid for it.

If I was somewhat skeptical of the brunch concept to begin with, this place sealed the deal. It's just not worth it.
author: Brian K.

description:
This place has wonderful food! My mom and I went here for breakfast and both ordered the french toast, it was delicious! Not too rich and the cinnamon sugar on top was a nice touch. I also ordered a side a egg whites so I could try their homemade hot sauce, it was also delicious. 

I highly recommend arriving 15 minutes before they open to avoid a wait. We arrived at 9:15am on a Sunday (they open at 9:30am) and we were first in line. Several others were lined up after us and the restaurant was full as soon as it opened. Would love to try their dinner menu.
author: Katie N.

description: A rainy EASTER morning demanded a warm, comforting meal--we found it here!  Smooth, all: The custard toast and Stratta, the service and staff, the ambiance.  And kudos to my spouse for finding this little gem on YELP!  We'll be back soon! Save us a spot!
author: Gayla C.

description: Found this place on accident while trying to go to the restaurant across the street that wouldn't sit me because I wasn't on the list and I am happy now I wasn't on that list. I come up to San Francisco often from LA when I want to get away for a weekend and this place is by far one of the best restaurants I have been to in San Francisco. The food was cooked perfectly, felt like a home cooked meal and gave me that satisfied "i just had comfort food" feeling. The space inside is small but very cozy and the staff was extremely kind and helpful, some of the best service I have ever had. I will definitely come back here again and again and bring my friends whenever I'm in the area. Feeling really happy I wasn't on that other restaurants list now, this place was so good that it inspired me to write my first yelp review
author: Stephen J.

description:
I'm giving Olea 5 stars for their French toast! This is as good as it gets and definitely worth the (small) wait for a brunch on a Sunday!

To make their French toast, Olea use their own challah custard (which is very close to brioche without dairy) rather than bread. It came along with cinnamon sugar, sliced strawberries and pretty good maple syrup. 

The dish turned out pretty awesome from the first bite to the last. Everything was fresh and fluffy. The core of each bite was actually chewy but in a good way. I think if you love French toast and would like to discover them from a unique angle, you should go and try them at Olea!

The service was a bit on the slow side, but since we weren't on a schedule this was actually great to make our stop by Olea an awesome brunch experience in the city!
author: Cedric L.

description: The wait during the weekend is long -- be prepared for 45 min - 1 hr or so. There also aren't many seats in the restaurant, but it is true: the challah custard toast is out of this world. Unfortunately, the egg dish didn't come warm (bummer), and our waiter was a bit pompous which is ultimately why this 4 star rating was brought down to a 3. With so many SF brunch options to choose from, Olea really needs to be on top of its game to stand out above the rest. I will, say though -- the manager there is absolutely delightful.
author: Mel G.

description:
When coming to the city for brunch, especially in this area- do expect a little bit of a wait. 
Is it worth it? Absolutely! Why? Because all of the reviews about the french toast are true. They are heavenly. 

Dude had the savory pork cazuela and devoured it. He then moved on to my french toast, but I give a mad evil eye so he only got away with taking 2 bites. 

As for the morning beverage, well Blue Bottle Coffee of course.
author: Bomb D.

description: We waited for about 45 min (or maybe more). The price and quantity was not worth the wait. Don't get me wrong the food was good but not spectacular in the city you can find more quality and quantity for lower price. We were a party of 6 we all agreed.
author: Patricia R.

description: My default brunch place coz I live right across from it. Must try the strawberry toast when strawberries are in season otherwise the apple/ cinnamon toast is equally good. Be sure to have the entire party in line. They don't do reservations or waitlist.
author: Anji S.

description:
Cute, small, neighborhood spot, but the food lacked. This place had been on my to-try list for a while, so we came on a weekday night and the place was dead. Okay I thought, more time for the chef to make my dish p-e-r-f-e-c-t because you know when it's busy, they just rush to get it out. Sadly, I don't see what the hype is about for this place.

- Pan Seared Duck Breast: duck was tasty! with a very thin layer of skin and fat, brussel sprouts burnt on outer layer and i had to peel it off, couscous okay  *note: duck was raw in the center - no biggie for me because I like my meat rare, but for many others, it could pose a huge problem
- Cod: fish was very buttery, lots of shallots, lentils blah

The service was wonderful. (I would have been really disappointed if it wasn't since we were the only table). But the food was just okay and I felt ripped off with the portions and prices they charged. Maybe I'll come back to try their brunch since everyone is raving about that.
author: Linda C.

description:
Quaint little place for brekkie or brunch....

Olea is known for its breakfast and lunch, though it is open for dinner tue-fri 6-9:30pm.  Came on a friday morning around 10:30am and there was 30 minute wait for the two of us.  When you walk in the door, there is no foyer or space to the side to wait, you're pretty much standing their awkwardly in front of everyone.  So you're better off signing your name on the waitlist to the side and then waiting outside where they'll call your name. 

FYI: you can choose to have your own table or to sit at a communal table.  They do take reservations.

Service was attentive.  Olea was simply decorated and clean.  My man loved the fresh blue bottle coffee served in a french press on our table.  The OJ was freshly squeezed and tasty.  I liked their popular cazuela with eggs.  I don't think it was mind boggling ah-mazing like I think some people were expecting and were disappointed with, but it was good and I ate the whole thing.  My man loved his french toast, said it was one of the best he's had.  If you're in the Nob Hill area, I def. recommend for brekkie or brunch.
author: Bernadette M.

description: Lacking in vegetarian options & strict about no substitutions, additions or subtractions. Two strikes, not bothering with a 3rd visit.
author: jizzie b.

description: Great neighborhood spot BUT servers need to not rush patrons just because there is a line outside when eating!!!
author: Sharon M.

description:
Got the Challah custard french toast. It was AMAZING. The taste, the consistency, thickness of the bread, it was all so good. Did not even need any maple syrup at all. The cinnamon sugar was such a nice touch.
Blue bottle coffee was awesome too.
author: Monica A.

description:
Olea is named one of best brunch places by a number of magazines. So it has been on my list for a while. I came here on a Saturday morning. The Mymy across the street was lined up, but this place was half empty. I was wondering if I made the right choice? 

We ordered OJ mimosa, coffee, half order of Challah custard toast and strata. Mimosa tastes fresh. Coffee is served in a french press, also very good. The most impressive food is the toast: so soft, yummy, and just right hint of cinnamon sweetness. It is perfect! However we ended with strata, not my favorite. 

Staff is extremely friendly here, a family feel.
author: Emmy P.

description: This place's only saving grace was its decent food. My smoking hot gf and I waited 30 minutes in line to be seated, meanwhile there multiple 2-person table tops available (4-5). The staff ran around like chickens with their heads cut off. When we finally did manage to get seated, our waitress was your typical SF snob. No drink refills and I think maybe she managed to check on us one time. People next to us got their food before we did, even though they were seated after. The food was good, so we had that going for us, which was nice. My babe had the avocado toast and I had the huevos rancheros + French toast. That being said, food isn't good enough to justify the terrible customer service from start to finish. You are better off going to Sweet Maple in lower pac heights, much better food and customer service. You'll still wait 30-1 hour to be seated, but it isn't due to an incompetent staff, it's bc people actually want to eat there.
author: Matt M.

description: Best French toast ever. I've been looking for anyplace as perfect on the east coast, but alas, I'll have to fabricate reasons to return to SF again for this place.
author: Keith B.

description: After reading the great reviews it was disappointing to be let down. Omelette was super salty and the coffee was burnt. Service was with a smile but unfortunately didn't make up for the food. If you're getting the Migas Con Huevo be warned it's on the small side!
author: Kate B.

description:
Absolutely wonderful.  Went there after reading the yelp reviews with my Mom and sister for brunch.

Got there right at 9:30 when they opened, walked right in and were seated.  We had wonderful grapefruit mimosas.  Food took a little while to get, but was absolutely delicious when we ate it.

The space is super cute and cozy.

The staff, particularly the waiter named Wade was an absolute delight.  He was very friendly and made our experience there even better!

I would recommend!
author: Heather M.

description: Took my in-laws here for dinner.  My father-in-law ordered the halibut, my mother-in-law got the bavette steak, my husband got the lamb stew, and I ordered the duck breast. We all cleaned our plates.  Seriously.  Not a crumb left.  Thanks for the wonderful meal, great wine, and amiable service, Olea!
author: Riz W.

description:
My "new" go to brunch spot.  I am ashamed to say that I have been in the City now for 4 years and I havent been until just recently!  The restaurant is small and this leads to a wait, so prep for that.  The menu is also relatively small but all of the offerings that I have tried have been wonderful.  Stand outs are the French Press coffee and the French Toast.  Its more savory than sweet in my opinion and absolutely wonderful.  Its a tight squeeze and you may be asked to share one of several communal tables but the vibe is fun and friendly.  

I will definitely recommend and bring all out of towners here.  Its worth it.

I haven't tried dinner here yet, but it's on the to-do list!
author: Mark C.

description:
New fav brunch place in SF thus far. I've heard from friends about this place time and time again, but didn't really believe it until I tried it for the first time about a month ago. And I still think about it, and wonder when I'll return next.

What we ordered (best to least favorite):
1. challa french toast with a side of bacon: BEST combination ever. Their challa french toast is the perfect density, sweet but not too sweet, and just tastes fresh. Add a small piece of bacon to a bite of the french toast, and you're smitten. The bacon is not greasy, it almost seems like it's been baked or something. Anyway, the crunchiness of the bacon with a bite of the "chewy" (in a good way) makes you just want more.

2. Cazuela: DELICIOUS, savory in every way possible. The toast that accompanies is more like slices of french toast baguette toasted, which brings a great texturewhen eaten with the cazuela. The cazuela was soupy, but rich and almost creamy-like.

3. xuxo's fresh corn torte (not at all bad, but something has to be my least favorite): Think of corn bread, but sweeter and like a dessert. It comes with a very dense/rich cherry syrup with cherries. Delicious, more like a slice of cake than an entree-type of dish, but still delicious. It was a nice ending to our feast of a brunch.

Thoroughly enjoyed every minute of my meal here. Service is also great! Location is rather small, so if you want to get in quickly, make sure you go early!!
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: I had the migas and my fiancee has a banh mi inspired pulled pork sandwich. The scramble was done almost to perfection in my book, fluffy without being overcooked, and the squashes were done in a way that preserved a good natural sweetness. The pulled pork has a good citrusy bite to it and very tender. Their home made hot sauce was very flavorful without being overwhelming. Service is fast without much wait. Overall a great experience.
author: Eddie W.

description:
I've been going to Olea for years and even through the management change, I've been extremely satisfied and loyal.  They kept the cazuela and the addicting french toast and the secret have to ask for spicy sauce.  They still have the best brunch in San Francisco and we consistently go every 2 weeks at least.  Most importantly they kept that wonderful neighborhood feel.    Incredibly low prices for organic, farm fresh food.  Simple menu but everything is executed perfectly.  Whether it's a crispy french fry with just the right amount of sea salt flakes clinging on or the baby lettuce leaf salad with castelvetrano olives and pumpkin seed (just layers of flavors so fresh!), I've never been disappointed here.  If you've seen Gordon Ramsey's evil revamp restaurant show, you'll know that a smaller, tightly edited but perfectly executed menu is what will drive a restaurant to success.  And Olea is a great success in my book.  

But I'm updating this review to defend the management and staff.   I think the owner and all staff go out of their way to make for happy customers.  I'm notoriously late and will call around 2:15PM and explain I'm on the way and place my order over the phone.  Also, its busy at brunch, but it's a fair system.  And he tries his hardest to ensure everyone gets in as quickly as possible.   The owner just doesn't sit around chatting or lording over the staff, but busses, serves, and gets right in the thick of things to help run the place.  

I really hope people come to see this kind of soulful small business ownership but I know you'll keep coming back for the best brunch ever.
author: Jae H.

description:
I've been to Olea before and have been impressed by the food. That said, it gets two stars from me for the very unpleasant customer service. When we asked the host to put our name on the list, he told us that the wait for a table for 2 was 30-40 minutes. He then added a series of "rules" - he told us not to "wander off" and also not to "put our name on the list of the place across the street". 

I'm sorry, but this is San Francisco - brunch is competitive business, especially in nob hill. Your customers are going to shop around for the best brunch experience they can find. Also, if customers are expected to wait over half an hour to give you their business, they should be treated with far more courtesy than that. 

I'm disappointed, Olea. Your food is great, but I'm not going to start my Sunday brunch with a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Riah F.

description:
On a random Sunday, we decided we wanted to try someplace new and chose Olea based on previous reviews. They did not mislead us.

The menu has a fine selection of breakfast/brunch items, most notable being the Challah French Toast and the omlette, the latter of which changes weekly depending on what vegetables are in season.

Blue Bottle coffee from a French press is a great touch while you wait for your food, and the fresh-squeezed O.J. was perfect.

It should be noted that if you want a private (versus communal) table, the wait-time looks like it could be rather long...but if you don't mind sharing a big table with other friendly patrons, you might just slip right in as we did.

Service was friendly and snappy and the bill was less than I'd have expected for the quality of the fare.

We'll be back, and we'll bring friends!
author: Erich N.

description:
I ordered the omelet and realized I probably shouldn't have done that because it had cauliflower in it... and I am not a fan of cauliflower.  That being said, the egg itself was amazing.  I think they use organic eggs because I could definitely taste the difference.  My friend got the Challah French Toast and he absolutely loved it -- it looked and smelled amazing. 

I definitely want to come here again and try their other stuff.
author: S R.

description: Very disappointing. French Toast is ridiculous...piece of bun for 13.5$, not even house made. Small portions, tortilla chips everywhere, frozen french fries, dry stew meat. Does not worth that line outside in brunch time at all!
author: Nadya P.

description: Amazing. Bloody Mary here virgin are not are one of my favorites. There are maybe only 10 things on the menu but everything is really good.
author: Vishal V.

description:
Stumbled upon this spot while a friend and I were in the area and wanted to grab brunch food.  My first impression of this place was very cute and cozy.  We were seated after about 20 minutes of waiting, and decided to order their famous and popular french toast and the casuela with baked eggs.  

Wow, the french toast was so yummy!  I don't think I've ever tried such good french toast before.  The bread was so soft and fluffy, which went along great with the fresh strawberries and syrup.  Casuela tasted almost like a Mexican dish, with ground beef in a brothy sauce - wasn't my fave.  

I think I'd only come back for the french toast!
author: Nancy S.

description: I loved the cute and intimate ambiance of this place, and our server was awesome. The food was solid, especially the pork parpadelle (although I wish the pasta had been cooked slightly more al dente). We also shared the salad, which was excellent, and the beef stew with orzo pasta, which was my least favorite (the meat was slightly on the dry side but the flavors were great). It seems like the menu changes quite often, and I would definitely come back here to explore the rest of the menu.
author: Jia H.

description:
We arrived around 10:30 and waited 30 minutes for a table. Not a terribly bad wait for brunch in SF. 

The not so good...
Tables are a little tight and I kept getting bumped into which got to be a bit annoying after an hour of it. Oh and my friend got scolded for waiting outside the washroom. Guess it's a bit too tight of floor plan to have people waiting for the WC.

We celebrated my b'day so my friends brought in a cake. Unfortunately, they cut up the cake - must have been a spacial thing as well. I didn't even get to see my birthday cake or blow out the candles. Oh well -- it tasted great (thank you Schuberts). 


The good...
The best french toast I've ever had! It's light, creamy and doesn't feel heavy like most french toast. Light like a dream :P

My friends all ordered the eggs baked in a cazuela and all commented on how delicious it was. Unfortunately, they all felt they needed more crustini's with it. They ended up sharing a side order of toast to scoop up all the delicious sauce.
author: Leanne S.

description:
French toast, you are still oh so delicious!

PLUS WE SAW OSCAR FROM THE OFFICE BRUNCHING IT UP A FEW TABLES AWAY!!!
author: Kim B.

description: We tried the French toast with a side of bacon and some orange juice. It was all good, high quality food. Service was friendly.  The French toast was excellent and a must try if you like French toast.
author: Piper W.

description:
I went here approximately a month ago with some of my husband's out of town friends because it was nearby and had good ratings. We had to wait in line even if it was only 9am (I did not mind waiting). Just Make sure all of your party is present otherwise the host won't put down your name and you'll just be waiting in vain. 

I was expecting to be wowed by the but
It was just ok for me. serving size was pretty small for the price. But the staff was really friendly and courteous. 

* added a couple of details more to this review to answer some questions from the owner :)
author: Paula U.

description: Ew! Waste of money, tasteless food! Worthless coffee. Never again. I'll stick to mymy cafe thank you. The only reason I gave it a two stars was because the servers were the saving grace. Place is dead
author: Sanaya S.

description:
Great atmosphere, service is honest, food is great.

Like walking into someone's home and having them cook their new breakfast creation for you.  Very unique dishes that have simple twists that give them something extra.  Everything on the menu sounded divine!  Probably not the best place to take your children because it is small and quiet, but perfect for an intimate, quaint brunch date!

Definitely recommend it.
author: Angeline C.

description: Nothing too special here - long wait for a pretty standard tasting brunch. Seemed overpriced for the small portions and the tiny menu left me wanting more. Very intimate environment with a small dining area - could be good for some but I like a more lively, exciting brunch vibe. A decent meal if you need a brunch spot in Nob Hill, but would much rather wait it out at Mama's, Zazie, or Plow.
author: Anne A.

description:
I'm confused what all the hype is about. I have been to Olea three times now, each time there is a wait for a table and every time the food is subpar. It's not terrible, but it's also not memorable. 

I guess Olea has a "nicer" ambiance but I prefer Mymy Cafe across the street. Mymy has so many more fresh options and the toast is delicious.
author: Britney R.

description:
It's a Friday morning, at 10 am. My friend wanted to try Mama's for her first time but when we arrived, the line was crazy long! Probably 1-1.5 hrs wait..but ain't nobody got time for that! Also, I was on a time-restraint to head to work at 11:30, to the East Bay. (Dam you BART strike!!) Any who, we decided to search for the next closest brunch place with good reviews. It led us to Olea! Olea is about 1-1.5 miles away.

My friend and I were walking down the block, smelling good food. We were trying to find Olea and we stumbled it at the corner of Larkin & California Street. Olea is half underground with high windows, so it may be hard to find. The entrance was a half door and when you step inside, there are 3 steps of stairs (going down). There are 6-8 tables inside (big and small!..big like a family dining table that can seat up to 8 people and small that can be seated for parties of 2-4..or more if you push the tables together).

The atmosphere inside the restaurant was nice and cozy. This place was just so cute! The staff is friendly and super attentive. I dropped my fork by accident and as I was picking it up, she was already bringing me a new one! 5 stars for this! The owner seems nice too! He brought out my mimosa for me, and he would check up on us to see if we were enjoying our meal.

Now the food...
I cannot get over their Olea's Challah Custard Toast with Korintji cinnamon sugar and strawberries, and bacon! (Yes, bacon!) Their menu is small compared to other places but you know what? That's okay! Because their food is amazing! When I had the first bite of french toast inside my mouth, I felt like I was in heaven! The texture is very soft and fluffy, and it felt like it can just melt in your mouth! so that's why I say it's quite heavenly. I love the touch of strawberries to it! This is probably by far the best french toast I've ever had. When I first saw it on the menu, I said "Dam, $13 for a french toast..This better be worth my money." It was definitely worth my money, because it exceeded my expectations. After I finished it, I couldn't stop talking about it..and honestly, I don't think I can! I'm about to rave about it on my instagram, haha. My friend tried my french toast and she loved it too! She didn't like the cinnamon too much but I still think it's good. 

You probably don't expect much from bacon right? Unless you're a bacon fan like me! I asked for a side of bacon and honestly, at first I thought it was a bit over-priced for like 3-4 pieces of bacon for $4.25. Nope, it wasn't over-priced, because the bacon was cooked to PERFECTION. Not over-cooked, and not too crispy or crunch. Just perfect. 

My friend ordered the Cazuela and she liked it. She wasn't expecting what she ordered upon arrival but after trying it, she said it's not bad for a "hardy breakfast." It's like a light chili meal! I had a taste of it and I thought it was alright. The bread that came with it was kinda hard though..at least only the outer layer was. (The crust is hard!) So..I didn't like it too much. 

Oh, forgot to mention but I had ordered a mimosa (for the first time!) And I'm not really a fan of it..but maybe because I'm not used to it (I did just turn 21 not too long ago). My friend has had mimosa's before and she tried a sip of mine. She said it was alright but she thinks their OJ was too fresh, haha. But I guess it can be a good thing if you order OJ by itself :) 

I definitely recommend their Challah Custard French Toast and bacon! They're both delicious and it's just .. perfect! I can't wait to come back here. I was raving about it to one of my other friends and now she wants to try it! Worth the drive across the city for me :) 

I live in Hayward for school, so it's a bit far but in the meantime, I'll just reminisce about the food until I can bring more friends here. I love it that much!
author: Mandy G.

description:
Came here for brunch, went too late (I did read the reviews and I planned on going early to avoid the lines, but alas, not everybody is keen on getting up "early" on a Sunday morning), hence the 45 minute wait... 
The place is small, the menu is limited (they don't do substitutions), you can't make a reservation for brunch, and the mimosa was just so-so, for these reasons I'd remove 2 stars, but they got one back because the staff is nice, when we finally did get in the service was great and the french toast was fantastically delicious!
When you get there, read the sign, it says to wait; when they've got a table available, they'll come get you.
author: N S.

description:
Great French Toast!! fantastic service! 

Yet long waits and the place is small!

If anything though the wait is well worth it and small is more like cozy! 

You can make it their early, 5-10 minutes before 9:30 am on Sunday to avoid the wait or for a shorter wait!
author: Sumit G.

description:
We were looking for a great breakfast spot, and this fit the bill perfectly!  I loved Olea, in part because in our quest for finding it, I became best friends with the operator of the California line cable car we were in.  This guy was the NICEST public transportation worker I have ever encountered!  

We took the cable car to get to the top of Nob Hill, which in itself was one of the great highlights of our trip.  The California line stops right in front of Olea and we got there just when it opened, along with a few other parties who had the same idea.  It's tiny but airy and light-filled and has that same laid back service that we found in most of the restaurants we visited.  

The orange juice is fresh squeezed-- everything is better in California, we would later reminisce-- and the breakfast food is wonderful.  I had eggs, bacon, and tomato on a rustic roll, which came with a side salad with a light vinaigrette.  I feel like a broken record with my SF reviews, but each individual part was amazing, adding up to an egg on roll that would put any other egg on roll to shame!

However!  That's not even the best part.  My sister had the challah custard toast with cinnamon sugar and fresh berries.  We had yet another "I've never tasted anything like this before" moment-- the inside of this french toast is literally SILKEN custard.  Silken.  I have NO idea how they accomplish this with simple egg and bread.  It was a huge serving that she couldn't finish and I am happy to report that this still tasted wonderful cold a few hours later, eaten as a snack while strolling the Golden Gate promenade.

In short: a perfect breakfast in an adorable neighborhood!
author: L C.

description: I wish I could give Olea 6 stars. Everything about this place is Just Right. The warm welcome you always receive as soon as you walk through the door. The cozy feeling of sitting right below street level, looking up. The farm-to-table mentality, with all ingredients being fresh and delectable, organic and sustainable. And the flavors.. oh the flavors. All this for an extremely reasonable price. Last Saturday, I called Philip last-minute, with a party of four. We were seated immediately and given a five-star dining experience - duck, pork belly, salmon and quinoa - all tasted perfect. We left feeling so pleased with our night. Olea is the restaurant I've been looking for all my life, and just my luck that I live five blocks away.
author: Alyona P.

description:
If Jesus were a chef and we were at his loft having brunch one day, I'd imagine his french toast would taste very similar to that served at Olea.

I'm not just saying this because he's Jewish and Olea's french toast is made with challah bread. I'm saying it because a creation so divine -- with homemade custard soaked inside and hearty dashes of flavorful cinnamon on top -- must've been whipped up by the skillful hand of God.

Though, turning water into Blue Bottle coffee might've been a more glorious miracle. Olea, using french presses and expert pulls of espresso, delivers some of the smoothest morning brews you can get.

Our Father, who art in Heaven, challah be thy name.
author: Keane L.

description: Perfectly fine place for brunch if you're in the area. Limited menu of 5 or so main options. I had the scramble, which was a simple, ok dish that I really could have made at home. Somewhat disjointed but very friendly service.
author: Nick C.

description:
Awesome. I got in a fight with my husband the night before so I snuck out of the hotel room before he woke up to have some "me" time. My favorite thing to do on vacation is have solo breakfasts at fantastic places, so it worked out. I ended up finding this little place, and I'm so happy I did! 

The menu is pretty limited, but what they do have looked amazing. In the spirit of trying new things, I had this tomato-based poached eggs thing with mushrooms in it. I also ordered a french press, which was perfect. My server was very helpful - he event discreetly informed me that there was a better way to eat the dish - mix it all up and let the egg yolk cook, instead of the awkward way I was trying to eat it. He made some small talk with me which was nice, since I was the only person in there dining on my own. Friendly service can really go a long way.

My husband apologized shortly thereafter and we had a fantastic day. :)
author: Naomi H.

description: Beautiful little place with a wonderful owner and great staff. My friends and I had dinner here before a Beck concert.  We each picked a different menu item and all loved our choices. The menu changes periodically but the quinoa (delicious!) and Vegetarian pasta (my friend's choice) are staples. I probably won't do the long brunch line just because I live far and detest waiting in lines even though the brunch menu sounds amazing. All three of my friends and I highly recommend dinner here!
author: Anony M.

description: Migas and fresh orange juice = best brunch in town.
author: Jeff S.

description: Claiming itself as an 'upscale bistro' with a focus on local, sustainable practices and a limited but interesting brunch menu Olea seemed like a great choice for my first meal after stepping of the plane in San Francisco; unfortunately it was not...though it did end up complimentary.  Apparently having just changed hands in terms of ownership it seems hard to imagine that a space with less than thirty seats could be so inefficient, but from failing to seat me for five minutes while the owner kibitzed with a customer to the waitress first forgetting to bring me a menu or silverware and then, no kidding, forgetting to place my order with the chefs (also standing around chatting in an otherwise idle kitchen) the service was a veritable disaster.  Admittedly, when my French Toast finally did arrive it was good, a crispy golden exterior laden with cinnamon wrapping a delicate crumb and topped with typically impressive California strawberries and pure maple syrup, but it certainly did not live up to the French Toast available elsewhere in the city (nopa, just for you, plow, Brenda's, Dottie's, Zazie, etc) and even if they do get their act together under new management I really can't think of a reason I would return.
author: Michael U.

description:
Came here for dinner. 
Friendly service, excellent wine and perfect portions.

Duck breast with some fancy brown rice: It was great. The rice was so great. Complemented the duck breast, which was juicy, medium rare and perfect. 

Pork Shoulder: we ordered this from waiters suggestion. They only have 7 orders available for the night, and we got the last one. It was so good my friend ate it before I can figure out whats in it.
author: Emily T.

description:
We arrived on a Sunday around 9:45 and were immeadiately able to sit at a family style table with a couple of parties.  When we left around 10:45 there was a pretty good crowd waiting outside so I'd suggest getting here early if you want to get right in.

A lot of farm fresh choices on the menu but the Custard French Toast seemed pretty killer.  After some tasty french press coffee I was staring two delicous slices of candy-like custard filled goodness in the face.  I can confidently say this was the BEST French Toast I have ever had in my life.

Service was friendly and prompt, and the setting was intimate.  A great overall brunch experience that I would highly reccomend to anyone.
author: Josh B.

description: The French toast was really good! Bacon was amazing. Cocktails are delicious and the servers were on top of their game as well. One of the owners seemed a bit pompous but it's hard to not while being condescending. All in all I I would recommend Olea to my friends for a solid brunch. Hopefully the owners will step aside and let their staff do what they do best.
author: Laura W.

description: This was a good brunch discovery. I see some other reviews talk about small portions, but I thought the portions were just right. Very fresh and healthy tasting. Sometimes I'm in the mood for a big, heavy brunch putting me in a food coma for the rest of the day. But sometimes I want a brunch that makes me feel satisfied and ready to get on with my day. Olea's brunch is the latter.  Plus the service was excellent. Nice classic SF ambience.
author: Luke K.

description:
I was pretty shocked (and dismayed) that Olea changed ownership recently. I admired the chef owner that started it some years ago and went nearly every Sat. a.m. for breakfast for a few years now. I'd always get the same thing - the egg sandwich and coffee. The way the chef made the eggs was sublime - they were so fluffy and light, just the best egg with crispy bacon you could possibly imagine.
I haven't been in since the change but decided to try today. I was seated at the long table even though I was in line and should have gotten my own table for 2 as I always did before. I didn't complain so I took the seat but I do not like eating my breakfast less than a foot away from total strangers. Even worse I was at the foot of the table so I was facing this threesome that was probably wondering if I was listening to everything they were saying (I wasn't because I'm hearing impaired). 
The service was good and attentive, so no complaints there. The eggs were not as good as they were though. They were good but not great. The said diners next to me had the famous french toast and it looked pretty good but I noticed it is not presented as well as it was previously. People still seem to rave about it so undoubtedly the owner trained the new staff on his culinary secrets but regrettably I don't think it's the same.
I'd go back but will not consider it if I'm seated at the long table again. Maybe I'm the sole loner in the place (it is a great place for couples) but if I stood in line like everyone else I should have the same seating options as everyone else. May be it for me and Olea but I'd still recommend it for others to try as it's better than most other places around for brunch.
author: Matt H.

description: The food is 5 stars. Unfortunately the service/wait/experience is what hurts here. Instead of a list to add your name to they make you stand in a line outside. Across the street is a coffee shop, so I, like many others in line, grabbed a coffee there to drink while waiting in the long, cold line. But what they don't warn anyone about is that they require you to throw out your coffee before entering. The policy is up to the restaurant, I'm ok with that, just warn us or perhaps even have some coffee for the people standing like fools outside in the cold.
author: Captain B.

description: I wish I could say I loved it but the one brunch I had there just wasn't very good. Kind of unimaginative and not very flavorful baked egg dish. Sadly, wouldn't go back.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Went here for a girls brunch lady weekend and was quite pleased. There was a wait list, but not a long one. 

The food was great but our server was pretty inattentive at times and their menu is fixed and the don't allow substitutions.

Luckily there were a couple gluten-free plates and plenty of mimosas. 

Overall a great way to start a Saturday.
author: Renee P.

description:
Looking for a brunch place for a Saturday morning (more like afternoon =/) I yelped Bruch and came up with Brenda's, Cafe Delucchi and Olea. Not wanting to wait an hour at Brenda's or half an hour at Cafe Delucchi the bf and I decided on Olea and it was definitely a goood decision!

I'm always a sucker for food that's different and unique which we definitely found at Olea. When we got there around 2:00 pm there were two bigger groups that looked like reunions and a couple of smaller tables that were all open. The services was great and the Eggs Baked in a Cazuela and the Flat Omelet were phenomenal! The Cazuela is kind of a clay dish in which the eggs are essentially poached and the flavors were so great we requested some toast after we were done with the eggs to soak up anything and everything left. The flat omelet was a refreshing change from the increasingly popular trend of overstuffed omelets and I swear I could taste the quality of the eggs (they use cage-free eggs).

The seating area was pretty small so I would suggest making reservations or calling ahead to check on the wait. Perfect place for brunch and I'm so glad to finally find something different from the usual omelets, toasts and eggs Benedict. Olea = GENIUS!!
author: Christina L.

description: Very good food. I ordered the French toast, side order eggs, and side order bacon and shared it with my 3.5 year old. All three were delicious! Coffee comes as a French press ($6.50) so that was my only complaint - couldn't get a $2.50 cup of coffee had to buy the whole thing... Kinda pricy. But I would definitely go back. Servers were friendly.
author: Amanda M.

description:
To say that it was dark and stormy night was the understatement of the year.  
More like the skies were dumping monsoon quantities of freezing rain on us as we made our way to the faint light barely illuminating this hidden gem.   Once inside we were immediately greatly very warmly by the owner Phillip who immediately sat us at our table.  I must say that with much trepidation we agreed to come to this restaurant, however, our good friends highly recommended this place and I wanted to vet out the truth behind the negative reviews on this restaurant myself.  In short I have found that the owner Phillip is a genuinely warm soul that truly loves what he does.  His love for his craft comes through in every detail of this fine restaurant.  The staff is exceedingly professional, very polite, very helpful yet non-intrusive to let one savor a fantastic meal at their leisure.  He has selected one of the most masterful chefs that we have experienced at any level.  She is plating up fare with her own interpretation of American Fusion if you will.  The pappardelle meatballs were the most succulent blend of mouth watering pork and beef cooked just right to be moist and savory with a fantastic flavor accented with perfectly prepared spinach mixed into the beautiful presentation.  The scallops were prepared just perfect, stunningly fresh bringing our their true flavor without a heavy sauce to mask their nature.  The waitress suggested that the chef could prepare an off menu side of Swiss chard and I can tell you that this was almost worth the trip by itself.  Fresh and tasty with garlic and carrots with just the right amount of salt to enhance the flavor, just perfect.  They also carry a modest selection of very nice and reasonably priced wines.  In fact, everything on the menu was an exceedingly reasonable price in an arena were you could easily spend more than double!  So dear Yelpers, those of you that crave a hidden gem, that are looking for truly fantastic fare in a setting that not only nourishes your body but your soul at a price that is more than reasonable give Phillip and his staff a try you will not regret it !!!  Oh p.s. what makes me say Phillip has a warm soul ?  Out of the blue this man offered two complete strangers (us)  his own umbrella to keep the rain off of us as we made our way back to our car!
author: BGinLove B.

description: Came on a Thursday afternoon so it was fairly empty and the service was quick. I was slightly hesitant about ordering the omelette because I personally prefer having some kind of meat in my omlettes but I was pleasantly surprised as it was flavorful and filling! Quaint place and very delicious!
author: Taryn Q.

description: Don't be fooled into thinking it's great coffee because it's by blue bottle. It's a very light roast, coarsely ground, therefore bitter. I prefer a dark roast myself. Other than that, the food was very good, nice atmosphere, good service.
author: Marsha K.

description: The french toast here was the best I have ever had in San Francisco. Downside was I had to wait 30 mins for a table but it could be because the french toast was the best I have ever had in San Francisco.
author: Joyce K.

description:
This was a very good brunch place.  It's bigger than the other brunch places in the area (Red Door, Nob Hill Grill), but not by much. I was actually expecting to get a regular brunch(eggs benedict, bacon and eggs, waffles or pancakes, etc.), but Olea didn't have any of them, so I ended up getting the pulled pork sandwich.  Even though it wasn't what I was craving at the time, it was still really good.  The spices they used on the pulled pork was fantastic and the fries were good too.  I also ordered the Blue Bottle cappuccino which might have been a mistake because I started feeling jittery before the food even came out. 

The wait staff was very friendly and the wait wasn't super long for a Sunday morning.
author: Joe N.

description: As I found later, this place is known for its brunch.  Too bad I came here on a Friday night for dinner service.  I liked the space and the server was very nice...the menu was a little indistinguishable from just about anywhere else in SF you might eat.
author: David S.

description:
I have been coming to Olea for years, and it's amazing how they've maintained their excellence for so long.

The chef, Gabriel, is a virtuoso -- pairing incredible flavors on a small but efficient menu.  Their selection of local/seasonal foods is limited, but there's inevitably something for everyone. 

As for ambiance, it's one of the nicest/cutest/coziest restaurants in all of San Francisco.   With enough advance planning, you can rent out the entire space for an night and give 20-30 of your closest friends an evening they'll never forget.

Olea is among the finest restaurants in the City for dinner or brunch.  Truly extraordinary in every way.
author: Meher S.

description:
The food was all tasty. My only complaint was that the scallops were soooo tiny. I got 4, each about the size of an inch in diameter. I am not opposed to small plates, but the menu is limited without many appetizers. There was no suggestion by the waiter that it would not be enough food. I had to go to Whole Foods after to be full. This all being said the food is good and the prices are reasonable. The scallops just may not be for everyone...

However, the quinoa was absolutely delicious and the wine was well priced also.
author: Brandon C.

description:
Hamburgers should always be made with a fried egg.

Olea will gladly accommodate if you request a fried egg over your burger. It's cooked perfectly so it's still slightly runny. Mmm.... The server was great.

The menu is limited but solid. My only complaint is that they don't have pancakes because I'm not a big fan of french toast. Also I love eggs and the menu was limited to a small frittata and one omelette that I wasn't a big fan of. 

For some reason, I really like this place. I'm not sure if it's their location on a corner, their comfy small space, or the great service. I would raise my rating in a heartbeat if I come back on a day when they have a different menu.
author: Jess C.

description:
I take all credit for picking this place to eat brunch and what a place this is.

I had an omelette sandwich (white bread) with bacon on the side, which was yummy and crispy... BUT what my girlfriend got was beyond delicious!!! She order french toast that was warm and soft and the flavor was sweet. I was surprise she shared it with me because it's a dish you would want all on your own. The mimosas and orange juice were delicious as well.

Getting a table will be tough since a lot of people go, so come early... OR prepare to share a table with others (that what we did). 

This is a must go back place!!!
author: Dennis D.

description:
Great food, service, ambiance, etc.  Overall perfect for breakfast or even lunch.  

Plan on a very long wait since they have limited seating.
author: Scott S.

description: We had Olea tonight and I can't sing its praises enough. With five of us, we ordered four dishes to share and every single one was amazing: quinoa, lamb, scallops, and beef stew cooked to absolute perfection with a unique mixture of pastas and spices that seemed very posh since I'm not very familiar with them. Our waiter was witty and friendly, the place was clean and had a lovely ambience, and for an extremely fancy dinner for five people, the bill of $80 wasn't bad at all.
author: Michelle G.

description:
We arrived at Olea Sun AM about 10:30. There were several people waiting out front when we got there. After signing in on the clip board we waited about 15 minutes before being seated.

Menu's arrived quickly as did water. We started with the Med size (about  three cups) Blue Bottle coffee "French press".  As other yelpers have indicated, the coffee is smooth, not too bitter ala Starbucks.

Food arrived fairly quickly. We had the popular French Toast, fluffy and very tasty "the best I've ever had in a restaurant" according to my wife. I had the "Eggs Cazualas"? (two eggs poached in a tomato based sauce), also very good. 

The total bill came to $37 including coffee and "extra bacon" (my bad...waiter asked if we wanted extra bacon...I said sure without asking how much...really guys...$5 for 4 strips of bacon???).  Wait staff was friendly and efficient, and everyone including the manager, thanked us for coming in. We will definitely be returning to Olea next time were in the city...I'll skip the extra bacon next time.
author: David C M.

description: We had the brunch, had to wait outside in line.  It was worth the wait.  Best brunch I've had in a very long time.  Great place, must go if you get a chance.
author: Rene B.

description:
I am a fan of this place for the following reasons:
- Breakfast Menu is small but everything is prepared with great care
- All ingredients are local produce, organic and match seasonality
- Small and intimate space with excellent service
- All items I have ordered so far (coffee as well as food) came out excellent

I have only been here for breakfast but my favorite dishes are the baked eggs in cazuela, savory but not heavy, and the french toast. 

However be aware that the wait time can be very long since the seating space is very limited.
author: Sonja S.

description: Great brunch. I actually like that the menu is limited and not the typical breakfast menu with dozens of mediocre options.  I do not like waiting in line when I'm hungry, but if you plan accordingly, it all works out.  In my opinion, the owner is great -- I can only imagine the rude and entitled customers he has to deal with.
author: Janelle F.

description: Anything I get is always great.  French toast, granola, short rib and the latest trout.  Always a winner.  The service is fantastic, attentive, prompt and friendly.  I am lucky to have restaurant like this in my neighborhood as my go to.
author: Karol C.

description:
I expected big things from Olea who seemed like a favorite for brunch. Unfortunately I have to say a lot of underdogs out can easily beat this place out. 

Olea is not fancy, sitting on the underground of an apartment building. The crowd is fairly casual but the waiters are extreme casual; they wear street clothes so you might not even know who works there at first glance.

Their signature dishes according to Yelpers are the Cazuela and French toast. The Cazuela is interesting but basically eggs poached in tomato broth with crostinis. It taste as simple as it sounds so nothing stellar here. French toasts were a masterpiece with the nice custard Challah bread. This was magnificent but for $14 it better be the best bread I have ever eaten, even if it is kosher. What disappointed the most was the pulled pork sandwich. It totally lacked flavor and originality. In addition, the juices made the bun soggy so it looked like wet dog that you could not pick up. Horrible execution all the way around for a $14 sandwich.

Avoid the sandwich and you will be much happier in life.
author: Ed L.

description: Came for brunch. Ordered the omelette with mushrooms, feta, yukon gold potato. Also got the yogurt/granola. Waiter tells us to get the challah french toast. The look in his eyes. It was genuine. I says ok. LIfe changing. Get a half order and split it just for the taste.
author: Noah D.

description: Dinner here on Friday eve - best meal After 10 days of great meals in San Francisco, Northern Napa, and Carmel. Cozy little place- try the beef and the tagliatelle. I will recommend this restaurant to friends who visit SF
author: Catherine P.

description:
Came here Saturday night for an early Mother's Day dinner.

The four of us each ordered (and shared an entree):
- Grilled Cod
- Pork Chop
- Beef Stew
- Burger
(better descriptions on the menu)

We also got a couple appetizers to share as well.

Hmmm... I have to say, I enjoyed everything we had. Wasn't especially thrilled about the flatbread (appetizer), but other than that, everything was pretty good.
author: Victor C.

description: 4 stars because the wait was only 20 minutes :-) I had the omlette with mushrooms, onions and cheese. It was a huge portion and tasty but I had to put lots of salt and pepper on it..I think they did not use enough eggs or too much milk. However the coffee and mimosa were good and the service friendly. Be aware that the menue on their site online is wrong.
author: Chris S.

description: I've had brunch at Olea before (the French toast is phenomenal!), but this review is for dinner. After a hectic week at work my husband and I booked in for a Fri night date.  Firstly, the place is adorable, cozy and inviting. You definitely feel like you're part of the neighborhood. All of the staff we met with were super friendly, relaxed and helpful which added to the positive experience. The place wasn't packed, and we were able to slow down and enjoy catching up and actually hear each other ;-) We ordered two glasses of the pinot noir ($13/each - hefty pours) and shared the lamb skewers ($18.50) and the pappardelle pasta w/o duck ($19.50). The wine was perfect and the food was homey and delicious. We left feeling happy & satisfied and excited to come back again in the future to try additional dishes!
author: Stephanie B.

description: Great place for brunch, can't believe it took me this long to go there. I loved the French toast and they are pretty snooty about their French-press (fine with me!).
author: Meredith K.

description: Really people think this place is good? Maybe the morning I ate at Olea the brunch chef was off? My dish was horrible. Eggs was over cooked and meal very unmemorable. I forgot what I ate but remembered it was over cooked and had no flavor.  Too bad Olea seems to have bad luck this year so far. Hope things pick up for them. As well for their food. Maybe it was a fluke just like their bad luck.
author: flashegirl e.

description:
BEST.FRENCH.TOAST
Come early otherwise, a line tends to form.
author: ZW N.

description:
Very impressed! Recommended. 

Though it was our intended destination, it looked closed as we approached and we even stopped at the door to read the hours.  Then we tried the door and discovered it open. The exterior is decorated nicely but maybe some lighting indicating 'open' would help Olea remain in the neighbourhood. 

A comfortable, welcoming feel to this place. It reminded me of a family dining room. Maybe Sunday dinner with Aunt Molly? Table manners, good people, familiar conversation, hardwood floor, dark wood table and vase of fresh cut flowers. Some tables for two and a larger one for 8 or 10 in case the neighbors show.  

Semi-open kitchen that told you the chef knew who he was serving (a warm smile and dark eyes above chef whites had greeted us from above the glass as we arrived), but the functionality of the kitchen didn't intrude on my desire to be served & not in the kitchen tonight.  I liked it. 

The glass of Argentinian Melbac was to satisfy a craving tonight, not pair with my yet-unknown order.  So satisfying. Lush, smooth, big without tannins. 

Perfectly done flatbread.  Very different presentation with the goat cheese, grilled peaches and greens with oil on the side.  A fun share plate.  Refined flavors.

Quinoa with mushrooms.  My friend ordered.  I'm not sure I even looked at the menu.  Without discernable oil or sauce it could have been dry....and wasn't.  It was a perfect backdrop for the flavorful mushrooms and a slightly bitter green to contrast.  Simple, straight forward, nicely done.

We split a french press coffee and pot de creme that was cool and thick and decadent.

We were there for a light meal and between the flatbread, quinoa and dessert we were satisfied.  Now it's up to my friend to keep them going (and introduce as many as she can to it!!) until my next visit to San Francisco.
author: Littlefish B.

description: Amazing restaurant!  The food can only be described as "creations of amazing!"  The service was outstanding and the staff was so into our satisfaction!  Awesome urban atmosphere as well.  Overall 5 stars!  We will be back!
author: James A.

description:
Hmmmm....I don't really know how to rate this one because they have a few great things going for them yet, there were a lot of things I was unsatisfied with.

Let's start with the good:  
-I loved their menu choices.  They had some great vegetarian options.  
-Most of the staff were very friendly.
-The fries were the best part of the whole meal.  That is never a good thing though.

The bad: 
-They only have a sample menu online and the menu items we got were radically different and actually less appealing.
-Restaurant is TINY!  Make sure you either go early or are prepared to wait outside in the cold.  
-There is no inside waiting area.  That's how small it is.
-This place is SO tiny that the cold air filters through quickly when the door is left open.  I recommend requesting a table as far away from the door as possible but again, it's so small that the cold hits everywhere very quickly.  It was just a very uncomfortable experience.
-Food wasn't all that good considering that people raved about it.  Their specialty was the Fried Egg Cazeula and it was ok but it wasn't as flavorful or savory as everyone said it was.  It was served so hot that I couldn't eat it for at least 10 minutes.  It also cooked the egg too much and it became rather hard in the middle.  I was hoping that the eggs would be runny.  The bread that it was served with was rock hard and combining it with the boiling hot soup, made for a very unpleasant culinary experience.  They served it with grated Parmesan.  This powdery substance ruined the dish.  I would have like to have a fresh Mexican cheese. 
-Got charged $3.75 for tiny rock hard "bread" slices with butter enough for 1 person even though there were 4 of us.
-French toast was just ok.
-Pulled pork was dry, cole slaw not good.

After reviewing my experience, I can not give them more than 2 stars.  When there are other restaurants around that offer a comfortable environment, this place ends of being way below average.  Enter at your own risk, but if you do, it will not be worth it.
author: Victoria C.

description:
From looking at the reviews of Olea, it seems like brunch is really good, so hopefully I will have a chance to return and try that out.

My friend treated me to dinner here on a Thursday night for my birthday. Service was super slow -- I think we waited like 20 min. for our entrees even though we were the only ones there. oh, well some people did arrive while we were waiting for our food. My friend tried the duck and I had white bass. Our dishes were good, but the portions were kind of small! We were still kind of hungry, so we went somewhere else to eat more... (See below review of Fuzio hehe)
author: Jessica W.

description:
We came by on a saturday morning for brunch and were afraid wed have to wait like an hour, but since it was pouring we only waited about 20 minutes.  Brunch was definitely pleasant- i like the small feel of this place and the friendliness of service.  i had the baked eggs in catalan sauce and we also had the challah french toast.  the eggs were good but not amazing and the challah french toast was pretty solid.
