reasonably priced though not a great value- i might come back here, but i definitely would not wait an hour for this brunch.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Solid 3 if not 3.5 stars.

First thing to note - the menu has about 10 dishes and I'm not sure you can ask for a la carte dishes (ie. scrambled eggs with bacon and toast).
The dishes themselves are fairly intricate and specific so you have to be open to what's on there....check out the menu in advance!

My flat omelette was good but just decent and it was about $13! Bit much in my opinion. I rather throw that $ down for Out The Door brunch.

Went around noon and the wait for 3 person table (with a few 3 and 4's ahead of us) was at least 30 mins but probably varies during different times of day.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Olé, Olé! (cue silly conga music)

Nice selections. If I go back I'll try their baked eggs concoction-- it looked wonderful and I saw about three come out of the kitchen and everyone looked happy.

Blue Bottle Coffee in a French Press was a great treat. 

I ordered a flat omlet which was, by my def, burned on the bottom.... you know, that brown color that changes the flavour of the eggs. The feta(?) cheese and the potatoes(?) on top were cut into the tiniest cubes I've ever seen in my life. Like even smaller than the cheese samples at Rainbow Grocery. So I wasn't sure what I was eating.

But the ambiance and conviviality was nice-- especially since it was low drama, low posturing, and there was a pleasant hipster vibe that did not smell and was even semi-welcoming- you know, in a simultaneously purely distancing way.
author: Max L.

description:
The Challah French  toast is worth 5 stars, but the host at the door was so unpleasant we almost left without even sitting down.  

It was a Saturday, and there was no line outside (burning man weekend + bridge closed.) My friend put our name on the "list" while I parked the car on the street. He would not seat her even though I was only half a block away parking (he could see my car from the doorway) and there were open tables & no line. He made her wait outside while I parked, and then he complained she was standing too near the front door and made her move further away. She asked for a coffee while she waited outside and he said no to a sidewalk coffee & was generally acting put off  from the moment we arrived. 

The reason she had to wait outside  was because I had to go scrounging for  quarters to feed the meter. Our host got super annoyed with my request to exchange some cash for quarters. He would only give me $1 worth (20 mins! clearly not enough time to eat breakfast.) Your patrons have to park on the street, at least be ready to exchange quarters so we can park and spend money in your restaurant!

All in all, the host guy needs to learn a few things about warm and welcoming customer service. Were it not for the lure of the french toast we would have gone across the street in a flash. I'm not sure I'll go back. I'm sure i can find Challah French toast somewhere else in SF.
author: Chris B.

description:
Olea is a wonderful brunch place especially if you live in the area or happen to be in Nob Hill. I won't say it's necessarily worth going OUT of your way to eat there.

The menu changes weekly, but I am telling you right now that you should order the eggs baked in cazuela and/or the French toast. I love the how the eggs come with a toasted piece of bread that's just perfect for dipping. I've had it twice, once with a tomato based sauce and the other time had a chili verde sauce. I really like the tomato sauce but the chili verde is also good. The Challah French toast is nice, THICK slices of bread with fresh fruit and maple syrup. It's simply divine.

I've also ordered the flat omelets and the combinations are always interesting. That doesn't feel quite a filling though because it seems thin in my mind.

Also, how can you really beat Blue Bottle coffee? I mean that's pretty much the best brunch ever.

I will say that the only thing I've ordered and not liked is the pulled pork sandwich. The sauce was too vinegary and it was not delicious. I didn't really even touch it cause it was so inedible.

They don't take reservations for brunch and the place is small so you may have to wait and share a table. I've waited an hour once. 

If you stick to the cazuela and the french toast, I don't think you'll be disappointed though.
author: Jackie T.

description:
3.5 stars. very quaint and cozy restaurant with only a couple tables.  The staff was very friendly!

When I was looking at other people's food, the pear french toast looked delicious.  But I was in the mood for something savory.  So I ordered the flat omelet and had total food envy.

I ordered the flat omelet with pesto, potatoes, chicken and asiago cheese.  The omelet was bland - the side of toasts was more flavorful than the main dish. .

I want to go back and try the french toast. "Challah custard toast with cinnamon sugar topped with grilled pears"

I have a feeling I will give 5 stars for the french toast!
author: Christina C.

description: Great service and delicious food! I love the owner, he is so professional and accommodating. The food is really tasty too. I have tried a few dishes and my favorite are the scallops with risotto. Definitely going back here again.
author: parisa e.

description:
I've been coming to Olea since it opened. Living directly across the street makes it easy to frequently enjoy breakfast & dinner here. I mostly come for breakfast on the wknd b/c the coffee is insanely good & ingredients are always fresh & top notch & I typically make dinner at home.

However, I ate here last night for dinner & it was FANTASTIC! Started with the flatbread & finished with the duck & had a glass of the Syrah with both.

Flatbread is REALLY GOOD! Bread is baked & perfect for making your own noshy deliciousness. Like most great California restaurants it's the freshness & quality of the ingredients that push dishes over the top. Amazingly fresh ricotta. I swear they have a cow back there!! Great sauteed grapes & escarole to perfectly balance the dish. (BTW - perfect to share for 2)

Had the duck. It was also AMAZING! Perfectly cooked over brown rice with diced squash. So GOOD! Also came with flawless brussel sprouts. Not only delicious, but healthy as well.

In Nob Hill there are only a couple places that I consider "neighborhood" restaurants & this is one them. Warm ambience, friendly service & chef/ownership; not to mention great food!!
author: Tyler B.

description: The food here is incredible. I had the French toast and would definitely recommend it. Light, fluffy, full on flavor. It rivals my favorite french toast place miles from the city.
author: Renata P.

description:
After a crazy night of drunken dancing we needed to fill out stomachs with food...ANY FOOD.  

Since I was visiting the city, my friend took me to Café Olea; she said she's heard good things so we decided to try it...boy are we glad we did.  

The "eggs baked in a cazuela with tomato sauce, steamed farro spezzato, diced niman ranch applewood smoked ham and basil-almond pesto; served with toast" was DELICIOUS!!!  The sauce was really light and flavorful and the egg was perfectly cooked; not too runny.  

We also ordered the French toast which came with 2 large pieces of bread topped with pears cooked in brown sugar.  The French toast was so fluffy and the pears so light (not heavy and sticky at all).  

We were lucky to have met the owner, a super friendly guy originally from Hawaii.  Needless to say, we were looking for any type of food that morning but were thankful to have found AWESOME FOOD.
author: Dayna T.

description: Custard French toast was delicious and a must get. The place doesn't seen too busy at all. We went here on a Friday afternoon and there was just another person in here so no wait. I was surprised given that the place is rated 4 stars. Price is a bit on the high end though. 2 meals = 30 bucks  no drinks.
author: Ronny L.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant! ! Very friendly service.  The Challah is very good, and there egg dishes are tasty. They make lattes so my friend likes that, and when she is happy I am as well. I can't wait to return and try some new dishes. When you see a huge line at MyMy, just go across the street and step to Olea. They will not disappoint you!
author: Fat ass g.

description: My friends and I have done the weekend brunch scene enough times now, that the reviews for Olea tipped us off enough to show up at 9:30 when they opened. We were actually a little worried that we wouldn't get a table in the cute little place, but we sat down pretty quickly. Between the three of us, we ordered eggs baked in a cazuela, the flat omelette and the challah custard French toast. My French toast was hearty and filling and delicious! It is a bit sweet, but I've got a major sweet-tooth, so it was perfect for me. I don't think my friends were as impressed with their meals. Service was not memorable actually, which is both a good and bad thing I guess. Would I show up again so early on a Saturday? Probably not.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Came here for brunch while I was visiting a friend in SF. This tiny little restaurant does a pretty good job of serving up a tasty brunch. We got there about 10 minutes before they opened to get in line for one of their 8 (9?) tables. Since we were so early, there were only about 5 groups in line, but it got full within 10 minutes and we saw people who had to wait.

As far as what to get here, I think it's pretty simple. Recipe as follows:

For 2 people:
1 french press of Blue Bottle
1 eggs cazuela dish (when we went, it was in a tomato sauce with peas)
1 french toast

Boom. Done. Seriously, the cazuela was really savory and wonderful and the french toast was HEAVENLY little pillows of goodness. Not overly sweet at all. I just wish there had been a few more strawberries.

Portions were quite generous for brunch, but I don't know about dinner. I wouldn't mind coming back to find out.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Great servers, great coffee, really great Challah French toast! The other food was also unique. 

We got there within ten minutes of its opening, and got a seat immediately. This who arrived 20 minutes later did have to wait in quite a line - I do recommend an early start at this popular location.
author: David T.

description:
My friend Glen is opening up this restaurant next week and I am excited to go try it.  (10/15/07)
___
(10/22/07)  I went last night to the opening party and I am going back for a real meal tonight.  Everything was wonderful!  The decor was homey and inviting. I loved the three steps you had to walk down to get inside.  It gives you a wonderful perspective of the street.

The food was amazing and although I am sure that all the food served there will not appear on the menu, it really highlighted the chef/owner Gabe's talents.  There were wonderful cheese, flatbreads,  meatballs with roasted tomatoes, back rice with shrimp, and a wonderful steak that melted in your mouth with a peppery olive oil.   Lemon infused chickpeas and escarole crotins finished off the food.  Everything was delicious and I cannot wait to go back tonight and try more.
___
(10/22/07)  My sister, my friend D. and I enjoyed dinner here tonight.  We shared a lot of things to get a good sense of what was available.    The menu is small, but varied--and as an added bonus it changes every week. 

We started with an Italian cheese plate (backward in the meal sense but it looked so good--and was!).  

We proceeded with appetizers of grilled shrimp with black rice and butter bean crostini with arugula.    For our mains, we shared a green bean salad with a citrus vinaigrette, the BEST halibut I have had in my life and a vegan plate with farro, broccoli and walnuts.   Dessert was an amazing cheesecake with layers of vanilla, walnut and chocolate.  The top of the cheesecake was "bruleed" and accented with swirls of a blackberry coulis.

We all drank 3 glasses each of different wines.  The selection is small, but it was nice that it was.  A different change of pace.  

Prices were very reasonable (apps starting at $3.75 and entrees at $9.50).  A very enjoyable evening.   Service was good....our waiter Ryan was very accommodating.
author: Katharine A.

description:
I've always passed by this place and finally tried its brunch this weekend. This is a super cute and cozy cafe. I usually order something savory for brunch, but I decided to order the french toast after reading the reviews on Yelp and I was glad that I did because they were probably one of the best french toasts I've ever had. They were soft yet perfectly toasted; the pear and syrup complemented the french toasts well -- I felt warm fuzzies in my tummy :) 

My vegetarian friend was pleased with their vegetarian option as well. She had an omelete that was light and fluffy. My other friend had the cazuela and that was also a delight. A huge bonus of this place -- they serve Blue Bottle Coffee!! 

While the food is great, I thought the service somewhat fell short. I asked the waiters to take away my menu three times and they ignored me all three times. I guess I can sympathize since they don't seem to have enough staff to serve a packed restaurant. The brunch was excellent so I'd like to come back another time to try their dinner.
author: Melody L.

description:
Fabulous meal:  shared the pasta w/ veal meatballs and braised beef with a friend, then we had to try the scallops.  OMG!  We've eaten at many wonderful restaurants in SF, from the Embarcadero to Sea Cliff, North Beach to Hayes Valley, the Mission and Potrero Hill, but the food, service and music at Olea was perfect.  Who knew?!

Walk through the hobbit door at the corner of Larkin and California into a small casual-elegant place fit for a date or special treat for a visiting friend or relative.  We topped off the meal with the Petite Fours and Blue Bottle coffee (french press).  The entrees are under $20.  This was a top-notch dining experience.
author: Ted R.

description:
Came here for brunch today and the restaurant is in a super cute downstairs of a house. The place is super small tho so there's always going to be a wait unless you show up right when they open or after the lunch rush (after 2pm).

We had the challah custard toast with korintji cinnamon sugar topped with fresh mc ginnis farms berries and the wild manila clams, penn cove mussels and califonia halibut, steamed with pink wine and shallots. I've never had french toast that was soooo soft and tender that it melts in your mouth. It's absolutely delicious.  The clams were good too with the sauce. We also had a side of french fries that was yummy!

The only downside is that you have to wait and if you choose to sit at the communal table you might get shafted and have to sit across from each other and not be able to hear what the other person is saying. :) That's why this is 4 stars and not a 5 stars. Food is definitely 5 stars though!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I took a few of my friends for a "thank you dinner" a few weeks ago, and we decided to try out Olea.  As soon as we settled ourselves down in the room, one friend commented that she felt as if she were a guest in a person's house.  In addition to the homey feel of a entertaining room, the staff was also very pleasant and answered all the questions we had about the food.

The flatbread was a great starter - lightly salted with a very satisfying crisp.  I ordered the hamburger (upon reflection, I simply ask myself over again, "why??") and it was as well made as a hamburger could be.  The meat was tender and tasty, but I was a little disappointed with the size.  I understand that I'm going to a cozy little restaurant that changes its menu each day instead of a place that boasts "big as your face" burgers - but it still felt a little too small for my liking.  

I took a taste of the steak, duck, and mussels (what my dinner companions ordered) and I thought it was very tasty.  Overall, it was a great dining experience, minus my small misgiving.

But please, Olea, don't hate me for docking a star off for the portions.  If I could, I would only dock half a star.  Honest.
author: Shay F.

description:
Friendly service + bombest custard french toast EVER + Blue Bottle coffee = 5 stars.

Tip:  The place is small so if you're thinking about coming in for weekend brunch, come early.
author: Jill M.

description:
The colorful, bohemian, and low-brow Red Door Cafe has been appropriately transformed into the quaint, French-country inspired, and high-minded Olea.  Expect appetizers in the high single digits, entrees in the high teens, and a nicely balanced menu featuring out-of-the-mainstream local and organic meats, fishies, and vegetables.

We had the duck breast over purple sweet potato mash with reddish/orange chioggia beets.  Beautiful.  We also had the cod with cinnamon, nuts, and (cannelini?) beans.  Delicious.  Dessert was a tri-layered cheesecake with pears.  Yumm.

Service was special.  The waitress took all the time in the world to explain the dishes and make recommendations.  Definitely worth a visit if you're in the 'hood...
author: Laurence W.

description:
i had such a nice brunch experience at olea- everything from food to service to atmosphere. i got there just before opening and got one of the last tables in the place before the end of the line had to wait until we all finished for the next round. 

i ordered fresh oj, french press coffee, half order of french toast, and a side of bacon. all of it was really good. it was just enough food for me and i like the sweet / savory combo. the bacon looked burnt when it came out but it was actually really tasty so was fine by me. the french toast was soooo good. really sweet but hit the spot. 

the place has some regulars which i always appreciate and the manager and server both checked in during the meal. lovely neighborhood spot which i would want to be a regular at if i lived anywhere in the vicinity.
author: Christina H.

description: I loved the cozy interior with its half farm door, little vases with fresh flowers, and one commual table. All dishes are made from local or homemade ingredients and I could definitely taste the difference! The French toast and the yogurt + granola were my favorites. Service was amazing and I could see why there is ALWAYS a wait here.
author: Vivian D.

description:
A friend of mine and I decided to check out this place for dinner on a Thursday night. It's an adorable venue, very small and intimate. Our server was very friendly and attentive. I ordered a pasta dish that was cooked to perfection, and my friend ordered the cod, which she said was delicious. The menu is a little limited, so check it out before you go to make sure that there's something on it that you will like. I would have preferred to see a chicken dish as opposed to or in addition to a duck entree.

My only issue with this place is that the glasses of wine are very pricey. The cheapest glass of red wine was $10. Just a few more options would be great. 

I am looking forward to going back and trying their brunch!
author: Lori M.

description:
I came here for brunch this past Sunday and ordered the following:
1. Eggs cazuela
2. Omelette with potatoes, cauliflower and side of bacon
3. French press Blue bottle coffee

The eggs cazuela were delicious!  It reminds me of eggs in purgatory.  Poached like eggs were immersed in a delicious tomato sauce.  Sliced and toasted baguettes were served on the side.  

The omelette was also very tasty and fresh tasting.  The bacon (I believe it's Niman Ranch bacon) was cooked perfectly (I don't like the fat uncooked and not crispy.)  

A huge French press of Blue Bottle coffee is served with your meal which is nice b/c you don't have to keep asking for refills. 

In addition to great food, I love the fact that they use organic, sustainable products.

One star minus for okay service but they were pretty slammed.  Be prepared to write your name in and wait for a bit.  On a beautiful day in SF, it's not so bad unless you are starving!
author: Avant R.

description:
OOOOLEEEEAAAA

I've been trying to remember the name of this place FOREVER.  Good work, guys.
author: Wade C.

description: My friends & I were visiting the City from Monterey...so we wanted a fun, hip, yummy, local brunch spot with creative, fresh food & great service...Olea is it! We waited about 30 minutes in line in the rain & it was so worth it. Philip the owner was warm & wonderful The Spicy Bloody Mary with Sake hit the spot perfectly. Omelet with sweet potato, kale & peanuts sounded a little strange but was truly a flavorful, great creation. And, the Cazuela was the topic of conversation on the drive home...good seems to be an understatement. I will highly recommend Olea as a standout in the city that has so many choices.
author: Kalena M.

description: I really disliked my entire brunch experience here.  We went to Olea's because Mymy had a wait.  The service was slow, the server unknowledgable.  I requested basted eggs as a substitute for the hard boiled eggs.  I think of hard boiled eggs the same way I think of well done steak--you 'can' do it, but you really 'shouldn't'.  The server looked at me like I had a head injury.  She said a little smugly that she didn't know what that was.  I said that I was certain the kitchen would know.  Since they're already frying eggs, it takes very little to squirt water in the pan or on the grill and cover it, instead of frying both sides. It's a pretty standard prep for eggs if you're a restaurant that serves breakfast.  She came back 10 minutes later and informed me that the kitchen doesn't do 'basted eggs'.   It should have been an easy request to accommodate. Seemed a little goofy that they were so inflexible.  When I finally did receive my avocado toast it was uninspiring.  My partner was equally unimpressed with his omelet.  Bland and overpriced.  And although the location and interior of the restaurant should be cozy and welcoming, the staff was cold and impersonal, so I never did feel comfortable.  I was really surprised, but after reading quite a few reviews and the owner's response to those reviews I can see that I wasn't alone.  The owner seems particularly defensive.  Rather than taking constructive criticism and responding accordingly, he seems to think that just saying the word 'organic' is a panacea for an array disappointments.  I think the owner's response to the reviewers reveals something of the character of the restaurant.  Nobody likes criticism, but when people take the time to comment critically, you would do well to listen rather than leave glib retorts or patronizing scolds.
author: Fifi L.

description:
We tried this place based on yelp recommendations and the proximity to our apartment, and we were not disappointed.

The french toast is simple - challah toast with cinnamon sugar, fresh strawberries, and yummy syrup.  It was so light and delicious... I cannot wait to go back.

My fiance had the scrambled eggs with a side of toast, which made for a perfect make-your-own egg sandwich.

On top of it all, they serve blue bottle coffee (always a nice supercharge on a saturday morning).

Olea isn't huge, but if you have a big group, you'd want to make resos for the big communal table. Otherwise, its mostly tables for two.

I can't wait to go back next Saturday.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Super mega enjoyed this place. Friendly service, even if a bit quiet, but definitely knowledgeable...I can respect that. Even the bus-boys smile, instead of shuffling about with the usual "idungivea" mug.
Had only brunch here, and found it hard to decide what to order-everything sounded awesome! Got the breakfast sammy-only the bacon was a skosh over-crisped (is there really such a thing??), but the side salad was perfectly dressed. Big enough for 2 if you're not starvin'
My pal got the egg pot-she ate the whole thing, so I'm assuming it was delicious, haha. We sat at the community table and people kept telling us how amazing the french toast is here, then they left us half their plate to share-SO nice....and it WAS some of the best I've had.
Would love to try their lunch and dinner fare, but sounds like these guys are doin' it right!
Way to go!
author: Virginia D.

description: Amazing french toast, and the baked egg dish (cazuela) was super tasty. Yes, you'll have to wait in a line, but that's just how it's going to go at a small place.
author: Karl S.

description: Brought my fiancé here for brunch during our trip to San Fran celebrating her birthday.  We were exploring SF & stumbled across this place.  Providence.  Very quaint on the inside & we were promptly greeted and seated.  I had the egg sandwich & my fiancé had the migas...& we split a half order of the challah French toast.  All of it excellent...especially the toast!  It was thick but not dense.  Perfect texture & flavor that really knocked our socks off.  Our waitress was a lovely woman named Michelle.  She was warm, funny, & made our experience terrific.  Highly recommend asking for her if you decide to try his place.  We'll definitely be back!
author: William P.

description:
Food here is good. I've had their brunch items twice and I have to say, their tomato-based soup and french toast is really good. 

Their portions are kinda small but it is filling. And I usually don't have to wait that long to get a table which I think is nice. 

I recommend this place.
author: Kissy F.

description:
I guess I should have really read the reviews for this place and come during brunch.... 
I set a reservation at 8:30 on a Thursday night and when we showed up there was literally one other table sitting in the restaurant. We ordered a bottle of wine and started with the flat bread appetizer. Flat beard really must just be fancy for cracker... because that's all it was a huge cracker, some tasteless cheese, grapes, and escolar. 
I ordered the duck and the bf ordered the pork chop. Duck was WAAAAY too salty! the pork chops were pretty good, very moist. However we had the nopa porkchops a week before and these paled in comparison. 
All in all i really can't give it any more than 2 stars. Considering there were only two tables in the restaurants I didn't expect such a time lag between the appetizer and the entrees. 
Two stars... because when i left here all i could think was Meh... I've had better
author: Lisa H.

description:
I think the next time I come here I'd have to try the French toast that everyone is so enamored with.  

Fair warning though, anything above a group of 2 will get you a good amount of waiting.  This place is NOT group friendly.  I came with a group of 8 and we ended up having to split into two groups of 4 as their one group table as taken.  They also could only accommodate two tables of 4 so one group had to wait extra long for the other 4-person table to vacate.

That aside, the service was phenomenal and the interior is pretty cozy.

I feel though for the wait and for the price point, the portions are dreadfully small.  The cazuela seemed pretty good and the French toast of course seems to be popular, but I had the pork tenderloin and it really felt like the dish wasn't very inspired in addition to being a tiny portion.  The eggs were well cooked but there most definitely should be more involved.  

I believe a restaurant should have a varied menu with a lot of good choices...especially at the prices Olea charges.  For a place that makes a note of their egg choice and preparation, I was also pretty surprised to see that they did not have any benedict choices.

I'd probably come back again.  Definitely with a smaller party to try a different dish though.
author: Chris C.

description: This place was good, I reccommend the french toast for brunch.
author: Spencer R.

description:
Preface:
We had dinner here.

Ambiance: 
This is a small quaint place. Watch your step when entering. There are 2 waiters at peak dining hours. The service was great. They are very helpful with choosing a wine because I am not a wine connoisseur. 

The Meal:
I am surprise they did not bring us bread. We had to request it.
I had the duck breast and it was cooked perfectly. The layer of skin was crisp and the meat was tender. SOLID! My girlfriend had the fish (I forgot what kind) but that was also SOLID. 

Gripe:
The portions were sooo darn small, I know this is fine cuisine but I would like to be at least content after paying $90 for a meal. We came here for STYLE. We then proceeded to head to Chinatown for SUBSTANCE.
author: Tony N.

description: After a long Saturday adventure, my husband and I came across Olea for Sunday brunch. We didn't have to wait long (20 min), and shared a table with other guests. The place was cute and cozy but as we sat down to peek at other guests plates to help us order, we noticed all the tables were still waiting for their food. About a half hour later all the food spilled out of the kitchen at once. The food was ok, the menu listed items with cute contemporary names, but in truth it was spin offs from classic brunch items, French toast, breakfast sandwich, mexican chillaquilles. The food wasn't anything special. But the oj was fanstastic. The dishes were also a bit pricey. We feel that SF forgets to create spaces to want to make people return. We didn't get that vibe from this place.We will be trying somewhere else next time.
author: Yvette B.

description: The french toast is really good! I come back to Olea just for it.... Everything else on their menu is good, but just average good. I heard the owner changed a few months back, but I haven't seen a change in the quality of the food. They serve blue bottle in a coffee press. Tons of metered parking outside. Wait can be long but it's because the restaurant is small.
author: Wei-Wei C.

description: Best French toast I've ever had! Service is good but arrive early because the line can be long sometimes since this is a popular places and relatively small. I love coming here with my boyfriend and friends.
author: Shoua K.

description: Olea is a lovely little hole in the wall! One of San Francisco's hidden gems and it is certainly SF through and through--local, organic, sustainable. The only knock is that you have to wait ~30-45 minutes, but it IS worth the wait! If you have a sweet tooth, you have GOT to try the french toast--treat your tastebuds.
author: Ashley P.

description: Pretty amazing fusion food. Great service but, expect a wait!
author: Robert M.

description: This is one of my favorite places in SF. Fresh orange juice, Bluebottle coffee, pulled pork sandwich. Nuf said.
author: FrOg SoU P.

description:
Awesome new random ass find!!!!! We followed an apt listing to this block and was lucky to find parking right outside this restaurant. After looking at the apt my husband and I decided to check out the neighborhood to get a feel for what life here would b like. It was a gorgeous balmy 78 degree day in sf, great for a stroll right? Nope - cuz I was retarded and wore a big thick heavy wooly sweater instead of layering.  After 2 blocks I melted and could go no further and turned bak. Desperate for food and water, ice cold water we stopped in olea for food.

Small cramped seating but sooo charming. Great food and really wonderful staff. We got the French press - they serve blue bottle coffee!!! And I got sherry steamed clams. Minus the heat of sitting by the kitchen which magnified my ordeal, the meal was perfect. Really recommend -such a lovely neighborhood brunch spot!
author: becca w.

description: Really awesome coffee but that is about all I can say for this place. If you want to wait a long time for french toast, be my guest but I'd much rather go across the street to Mymy's if I want french toast and a wait.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Not all meals are created equal. I made a same day reservation for 2 for dinner due to the high ratings for brunch (I figure if the restaurant can do a good brunch they probably won't be too shabby for dinner). Arrived 10 minutes early but there were no customers, so I guess the reservation was overkill for a Thursday night.

Duck duck duck! Is my favorite poultry of all time and Olea's duck dish does itself justice. These are my only gripes: 1) the duck is laid over a bed of bland tasteless cous cous (unless I'm lacking the culinary tastebuds for this I needed salt) and 2) I could barely find my duck! I do understand that they use all free range and healthy politically correct ingredients, so maybe I'm just used to all my food being blown up by hormones and pesticides but I wish there were more duck on my plate is all. I will say that the duck is very very good - it is crispy and there isn't much fat. My friend ordered the Alaskan Cod - I had a taste of it and the sauce seemed bland but the fish itself was very tender and a little crispy on the edges.

I will definitely be back for Brunch to see what the craze is about, as for dinner, I left hungry (we ended up going to another place to get more food) and probably will not return. The service is polite, but the wait time for your food is a little killer, we spent more time waiting than we did eating.
author: Joyce L.

description: My brunch party and I had a terrible experience with the service/manager here. Incredibly pretentious and patronizing. If you're thinking about brunch, consider mymy's across the street.
author: Ryan P.

description: The omelet was the best omelet I had ever had in my entire life. I could not even believe it was an omelet, every bite amazed me. The French toast was good too but the omelet was just unbelievable.
author: Sonia R.

description:
Brunch at this cute neighborhood bistro with 3 other friends on a warm Sunday morning, is the best.

We came around 10 am and there was no wait. YES! We even had rockstar parking, right in front of the restaurant. YES! YES!

We sat at the communal table (the only large table for a group). 

I wanted to try the Challah (pronounced Hallah) custard french toast. It was absolutely delicious! It was not overly sweet and there was a hint of cinnamon sugar. I really didn't need syrup. It was just perfect. It went well with my french pressed Blue Bottle coffee . 
My bf got an entree that resembled a huevos rancheros and he didn't like it. He barely touched it. He said the peas ruined the dish. I'll take his word for it. My other friends got the omelete and bacon, tomato, egg sandwich with side of salad. They both enjoyed their dishes. 

The menu at Olea changes frequently. I think the Challah custard french toast is a staple though. They use fresh, local grown ingredients.

Get their early to avoid the wait. Sundays are the best because of the free meter parking. 

Service was great. Staff was pleasant.
author: Molly T.

description:
A group of us came by Olea for their Sunday brunch.

While the yelp listing says this place is good for big groups, this is not the case.  They have one community big table that seats about 8 to 10 people, however, it's hard for that table to be completely empty.  This place is best suited for groups of 2 to 3 people.

I ordered the cazuela which was very tasty.  I like the flavor and the mixture of bread/croutons in the cazuela.    

Pros
- Food here is pretty good.  
- Service here is pretty quick and friendly.  I asked them to bring more bread for me to dip into my cazuela and they brought by a two pieces very quickly.

Cons
- Long wait.  We had to split up into two tables of 4 and it took us about 30 minutes before the first table was seated and another 60 minutes before the 2nd table was seated.
- Portion size here is small for the price.  The cazuela was on the smaller side for brunch portions I feel and I still felt a little hungry after eating it.  One of my friends ordered some scrambled eggs which looked even smaller than the cazuela.  

I think next time I come by Olea, I'd definitely try to come by earlier in the day or later in the day.  The noon time wait is just too long.
author: Janice C.

description:
After a long, hot, expensive day doing a wine tour in Sonoma, we wanted a relaxed, cozy, yummy, inexpensive dinner. We found Olea and it sounded pretty good, so we gave it a go. 

The restaurant is small and quaint and cute. The menu is very small and organic and changes every day. Unfortunately, on this particular day, none of the meals really appealed to me. We decided to get the clams to start off with and I got the Cod while the BF got the pasta special. 

The clams stole the show. Tender and flavorful and the broth had chorizo in it which was yummy. I needed way more bread to soak up the broth with. No bread came.

My fish was just OK, it was pleasantly prepared, but I just was not in the mood for it at all. My BF's dish was soooo much better, I was jealous. He got the pasta special with ground pork and to be honest, it tasted like fancy delicious hamburger helper. It was warm, flavorful and satisfying. 

An appetizer, 2 glasses of wine and 2 entrees only set us back about $80 with tip. Not too bad...
author: Jessica M.

description:
Olea was a great  find on my first trip to San Francisco.  Approaching the restaurant on foot the area seemed a bit sketchy, but I was immediately relieved of any apprehensions upon walking in . It was nice to visit a restaurant that was not overrun with tourists and had a great local neighborhood vibe.

The interior was cozy and  very inviting.  Service was friendly and attentive.  I had a light breakfast consisting of yogurt, granola, agave honey, and a mimosa.  My friend raved about her french press coffee and garlic fries.  We were very tempted to make a return visit there just for the coffee.  They change their menu weekly and have a daily fresh bread picked up from a local bakery.  We arrived early, so we were able to be seated immediately. 

I felt like it provided a glimpse into the life of a local and I hope to re-visit my next trip.
author: Melissa F.

description:
Split the callam custard french toast and bfast sandwich at brunch w the wifey.  Verdict = delicious.  Will certainly be coming back when in SF again.

Second time around...still delicious, but a monster wait time.  Be prepared to wait...but very much worth it.
author: Garrett N.

description:
Came for brunch with some out of town visitors and luckily Olea did not disappoint. Small corner restaurant in Nob Hill, we were drooling from the wafting aromas emitting as we waited for our party to arrive. And yes, EVERYONE must be present in order to get seated. With only 1 large table, groups larger than 4 or 5 really can be a challenge in this small space. 

the FOOD - yes, agree with yelpers that Challah Custard Toast ($10.75) was delicious. Two thick slices of challah bread are immersed in a vanilla egg milk mixture and then fried or baked to a nice golden brown. Cinnamon and sugar sprinkled across the top, finished with strawberries, made for a very fluffy light french toast. 

I complimented my sweet carbs with a side of bacon ($4.75), where I had 5 crisp bacon strips that was plenty to share with the table.

I also had a bite of the Baked Eggs Cazuela ($11.75). Cazuela is a S. American soup which Olea gave its own interpretations to. It was tangy warm and a nice change from the usual brunch items.

Blue Bottle Coffee was nicely served in a french press, your choice of 2 or 4 cups. One downside is that one cannot order coffee while you wait for a table. You must actually be seated to get some morning wake up fuel.

Overall, great food and atmosphere though they are a stickler for rules. Oh, and they don't take AmEx.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Cute little place that I've been wanting to check out. We went here the morning of the Bay to Breakers, because we slept in. Of course...

I'm not much of a fan of the open seating, especially in the morning, because I wanna yawn and bitch and be myself and not disturb others, but at this place I actually was cool with it.  Me and my girl placed our orders. She got the breakfast sammy, which was -- for something so simple -- they do it up amazing. Perfect eggs, perfect like I've never had before! 

I ordered the casuela, egg pot dealio. That was grrrreat. Made me see how such a simple dish can be turned into something truly unique with a twist in the preparation. Now came the dilemma... we wanted French toast, but weren't sure if we had room. Enter: neighbor's extra bites of frenchie toast! They shared! That blew me away. 

Go here. It's cute. The people are nice. The food is fabulous and you aren't gorging yourself on crap that you would normally get a a regular breakfast joint.
author: Rich_kids_of_yelp Z.

description:
If you don't believe the other reviews, it is true. the best french toast i've ever had. AND, I didn't feel sick or regretful after. It is creamy, crispy, sweet but not too sweet, and very tasty! 

Next, the rustic egg sandwich with bacon was delicious as well. the bread was fresh and the eggs were soft and flavorful. Simple but great.

A must try. the decor was simple and homey. the atmosphere was very calm, pleasant staff, and no ridiculous wait times. 

my only complaint is that there are no pitchers of mimosas :)
author: Payal A.

description:
Had brunch here today as I do once in a while since I live just up the street.  This is definitely a neighborhood joint with a clean and pleasant atmosphere but nothing overly fancy or going the other way, overly rustic for that matter.  

The food is organic.  For brunch, the Challah French Toast is awesome and the fries are very good.  If you're reading this before going to Olea for the first time, you should have just decided what your order will be.

Today, I had a flat omelet which was okay - too much potato and too little of anything else.  My only issue with the food is that they push back if you try to substitute anything.  I understand why but as a vegetarian and considering that their menu is very "meaty" I wish they were a bit more flexible.

Seating is either at  individual tables or a large communal one.  They don't take reservations so be ready to wait although not as long as at some of the other brunch places in town.  BTW, Glenn is the guy who'll take your name at the door and he's really nice and helpful.

Booze choices are limited to wine and beer so that hangover beating Bloody Mary will have to wait...
author: David A.

description:
Very cute and quaint.

Came here for dinner with some of my coworkers after work on a Thursday night. What's nice about the menu is that it's subject to change daily based on what local ingredients are fresh. 

I had the vegan option, a warm quinoa salad, because I just got over the stomach flu...didn't want to risk it with some duck or pasta with lots of cheese. The quinoa was really good and I cleaned my plate - nice healthy option, however maybe not for the price. it was $12-13 for a bowl of quinoa with an assortment of mushrooms. 

Based on the other items my coworkers ordered, good quality food, but small portion size. The male coworkers definitely left hungry. 

Overall, good restaurant for what San Francisco is all about - fresh, local ingredients.
author: Julia K.

description:
What a great little brunch place. 

After hearing good things, my bf and I popped in and shared the challah custard french toast, a pulled pork sandwich with fries, and a french press of Blue Bottle Coffee. 

The portions were moderate, but everything was tasty and incredibly filling! The menu changes frequently and focuses on sustainable, local, and seasonal produce. 

There are only about 7 small tables and one larger communal table so I would not recommend this place for large groups. If you are however in the lower nob hill area with one or two people, and would like a delicious low-key brunch definitely check it out!!
author: Ashley S.

description:
Came to this place with three of my lady-friends for brunch.  I must say the wait in line/lack of reservations was mildly discouraging, and the space is quite cozy.  However, the menu is spectacular and the service is friendly and helpful.

I will gladly come here again and again!  Just when I'm in a hurry.
author: Francesca H.

description: Been here for breakfast and dinner - would recommend both. Great, quaint ambiance, nice menu, friendly staff, and very reasonably priced.
author: Justin N.

description:
Minus one star for not having ventilation and needing to leave the door and windows open when it was FREEZING out!

However, the Blue Bottle coffee warmed us up post Tiger Run (in the rain) and the mimosas eased the pains of running. The omelete with mushrooms was fantastic - very tasty. The side of fries were super good and the staff were wonderful. We went in all icky from the race and no one even batted an eyelash. The other patrons... well, let's just say there was a gap between us and the other folks at the community table. Hee-hee.
author: Sarcastic T.

description: It's been awhile since I've paid a visit to Olea, but I was definitely pleased.  We only had to wait for a little bit on a Saturday morning.  The french toast was still amazing (must order).  Their blue bottle coffee in a french press and you can ask for Stevia.  The baked eggs were amazing as well (this time it was served with chorizo, kale, and yukon potatoes).  Olea is still one of my favorite brunch places in the city!
author: Carli F.

description:
Great brunch spot. Limited seating, usually a wait, but not too bad. Party of 4 seated in under 30 mins late Sunday. 
Challah custard toast w strawberries was delicious. Friends had the  scrabled egg on acme bread roll, and eggs baked in cazuela (which is a mexican clay dish). All fantastic. 
And as everyone else has said, amazing French press coffee. 
Good service and reasonably priced. 

They don't take Amex however.
author: Danish H.

description:
I've come here for brunch several times with friends and family, and nearly every time I've had the challah french toast. It's really good, you guys! Also, every person I've come with has agreed that the french toast is tops. Seriously: *every* person.

I took my parents here when they were in town visiting from my Chicago; my mom called a few weeks later telling me that she was craving the french toast.

Look, I'm just reporting the facts here. These are actual things that actually happened.

I've occasionally tried the other items on the menu, and they are also quite good. It's classy food made with care and from good ingredients.

The restaurant is a bit on the small side, and going in a group of four or more is probably going to get a little crowded. There's sometimes a wait for brunch, but in my experience it's never been too bad.

I'd definitely like to head here for a non-brunch meal sometime.
author: Greg P.

description:
Went here for Mother's Day brunch with my family. We made it a point to show up early so we didn't have any problems getting a table. The food was delicious. The Challah French toast dipped in custard was heavenly!

The only thing I wasn't impressed with was the service. Our waiter was a bit snobby. Their menu clearly states that they prefer no substitutions, well when one of us asked if another cheese could be substituted for parmesan in the cazuela dish the waiter said, "No." There was no explanation or politeness. I realize that certain dishes make substitutions more difficult than others, but he simply needed to politely state that rather than reply indignantly. 

The other thing was that it was quite a chilly day and we were seated close to the door which was open we were seated. We were all quite frigid and asked the waiter if he would mind closing the door. He said sure, then proceeded to walk away and do several other things. We ended up just closing it ourselves, but were a bit peeved by the overall lack of politeness. Lastly throughout the meal several members of our party got up to go to the restroom. Well after we had all finished eating my dad went to the restroom and the waiter came over to fold his napkin. Weird. I'm all for folding napkins when people leave the table, but be consistent. He hadn't done that for anyone else and then he did after we were all finished eating.
author: Henriette P.

description:
Alright look I can explain, now, normally I think I would have given this place a higher rating...had I ordered something else. So I ordered a dish that I wasn't sure if I would like but wanted to try because it was so different. It happens right? You order a dish you're not sure about for the experience. Well in my experience that's almost never a good idea. And this was no exception. 

I had the eggs baked in a cazuela (a pot) with basque style tomato sauce and spanish chorizo. Now, I can't say for sure what did it but it smelled and tasted like vomit. Sorry, graphic I know, but seriously it was absolutely disgusting. And this seems to be their featured dish. Don't order it. Unless you want to spend the rest of the day apologizing to your mouth.

Also, while their orange juice is freshly squeezed and delicious, I was pretty much mauled by the amount of pulp in my glass. I get it..it's fresh..you win, you don't have to prove it by leaving a shitload of pulp in there. Now, some may not mind pulp, for you guys, YOURE FREAKS, no I'm just kidding, you guys won't mind it. But ladies, so not appealing to the eye when we have pulp slipping off our lips.

Anyways, my friends' french toast looked phenomenal so I think I'm going to try that next time. But for now, this place has left me with bad memories.
author: Shreya C.

description:
I was looking for somewhere good to eat around Nob Hill and luckily Olea came to the rescue.
The place is tiny with only a few tables. Service was great.
Ordered the challah french toast with strawberries and a side of bacon. 
The french toast was really really good. It was light and fluffy with cinnamon sprinkled on top.
Bacon was delicious and great fresh squeezed OJ as well. 
Great spot for weekend brunch or a nice lunch.
Kind of pricey though, but quality and taste of food makes up for it.
author: Thomas D.

description: Wonderful service and a cute little restaurant, but the food is only so-so. I went there for brunch and found the dishes to be lacking in flavor. I enjoyed the overall experience enough, but don't think it's worth a repeat (or wait, on a weekend).
author: Brett B.

description: Weird they make it a point not to have avocados in the entire restaurant.  There's something I don't trust about a brunch spot that doesn't have avocados. And they don't split credit cards three ways.  And they made me press my own coffee. The breakfast sandwich was pretty good though-could've used some avocado.
author: Jeff B.

description:
* Omelette w/ spinach, mushrooms & Monterey cheese- It oozed just the right amount of melted cheese :)
* Challah bread French toast- holy moly, so good!!!
* French-pressed Blue Bottle coffee- nice touch

Small joint. Get there early. Communal table option.
author: Minh T.

description:
Let me tell you why I thought this place was so awkwardly wonderful.

We either had to (a) wait about 45 minutes for a table or (b) get seated in 20 minutes in between two other parties. Below is my diagram, where the three parties are denoted by A, B and C:

   _ a _ a _ b _ c _
a_     _    _    _    _  c
     a     a     b    c

We were party B. The waiter informed us that we only have 45 minutes to order and finish our meals. It was a rushed brunch in between the discussions of drunken one night stands (group A) and oh-my-god-I-can't-believe-she's-getting-married-she's-such-a-slut (group C).

And while the food was organic and natural and all of that bullshit, it still tasted dreadfully average.
author: Jamie C.

description:
OMG! I think they have the best French toast ever. The eggy custard center is absolute deliciousness!!!  Unfortunately, two pieces is just not enough for this little piggy. Oh, how I wish I can justify ordering two helpings. 

I wish, however, the rest of their menu was as impressive (please note this review is only on their brunch menu and not lunch or dinner). The baked eggs are good...but the black eyed peas were a little too al dente for my taste and the meat was blah. The egg breakfast sandwich was dry and something I can just make myself at home. 

I only return for that darn French toast! I wish I could resist...
author: Chanthi L.

description: Challah French toast was great- fluffy texture, great taste. Came at 10.30a and the wait was app 10 mins. Not bad. After 11a though, the lines got looooong
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I take my brunch very seriously.  Which is why I was willing to wait over 45 minutes in the rain this past Sunday for a table at Olea.  Olea has been on my radar for quite some time now, but the first time I attempted to dine there, a water pipe had broken and they had to close early.  Feeling lucky, (yet dumb for deciding noon on a Sunday was a good for brunch), we made it to an open-for-business Olea, along with many other San Franciscans looking to enjoy a warm meal out of the rain. 

The small, cozy interior compliments the comforting food that is served.  I tried the omelet w/ kale, leeks, butternut squash and feta (the host mentioned that most omelets won't be repeated until the next season because the chefs like to get creative with different seasonal veggies each week).  Also at the table we had the pulled pork sandwich and the ever-popular challah french toast.  All 3 were fresh and divine.  The french toast really is all it's cracked up to be.  

I'm an avid coffee hater and I abhor pulp in my orange juice, so I was upset when they told me they don't serve hot chocolate, but my coffee and pulp loving companions exclaimed the orange juice was some of the best they ever tasted and obviously the blue bottle coffee didn't disappoint.  

I like that the menu changes every weekend, and I like that I finally made it here.  I do hope to go back soon since the portions are hearty but the prices are reasonable.  Plus they do the whole local organic thing, so really everyone should be happy about this place.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
I had the challah custard toast for brunch and it was a dream.  It was perfectly balanced and not too sweet, even though it was dusted with cinnamon and sugar, and was served with maple syrup.  The orange juice, while a bit pricey at 6 bucks for a large, was outstanding.  It wasn't tart and all and was loaded with pulp, as it should be.

They don't take reservations for brunch, and it's a little bit of a smaller joint, but the tables seem to turn over pretty quick.
author: Spencer K.

description:
Great for brunch. The challah custard toast (French toast) was the best I've ever had -- not too sweet, which is my usual complaint about French toast; very fluffy and light; and served with pear slices (a nice contrast to the sweetness of the cinnamon sprinkled all over it and the side of maple syrup). My friends all got Blue Blottle coffee in a French Press and said it was great.

The atmosphere is also really cute. It's very friendly and homey feeling, and classy without being stuffy or uncomfortable.

Only downside is the long wait (I usually go early -- around 11am -- or late -- around 1pm -- to avoid the line) and priciness.
author: Jackie C.

description: I got the challah french toast which was scrumptious and my girlfriend got the cazuela.  She expressed disappointment that she didn't just get the french toast like me.  I'd give it 4 stars, she'd probably give it 3, but I'll round up for the good service.
author: Isaac R.

description:
GREAT breakfast place. If you're looking for a unique brunch spot that supports local farmers this is the place for you.

My friend and I ventured here early Sunday morning last weekend, it's one of her favorite breakfast places and she's been raving about it for months now. Upon entering, this restaurant has an almost European feel, as if your stepping into a quaint, almost intimate cafe. They have a larger communal table that can be used for larger groups, but they mostly have 2-4 person tables. The staff was very attentive, constantly refilling water glasses and checking on us, but not in a suffocating way.

I had the yogurt and granola, drizzled with honey and topped with grilled pineapple (yes... it was a-mazing)! My friend had the french toast which was also so delicious, she graciously gave me a bite. Such cinnamony-pear deliciousness! Their menu is continuously changing depending on the season, which I am always a fan of because I find that restaurants that pay such close attention to the seasonal fruits and vegetables are the ones that pay even more attention to the quality of their food. Being a restaurant that bases their entire menu on what is in season, makes it that much better.
Definitely a go-to if you are looking for a great breakfast spot. Definitely a plus that they serve blue bottle coffee!!
author: Emily S.

description:
This review is just for brunch.

When you don't feel like slumming it at your local greasy spoon, come to Olea. The menu is small but their produce is local and fresh. Eat well and feel green. Challah custard toast was pretty damn tasty. Bacon was nice and crunchy. And you got to be impressed with french-pressed Blue Bottle Coffee. 

Their con was (besides the $5 price tag on a side of bacon) was the price of a mimosa $8.50. You only get half of a flute of champagne! Perhaps its for the other half of fresh squeezed oj, regardless I couldn't justify paying for that. I rather pay for another order of french toast...hahaha.
author: Ezduzit S.

description: Olea is not only one of the best spots for brunch, it is also a great dinner spot! The duck is a must have-it is seared to perfection. We also had the salmon, which was superb! Every flavor note was spot on and the service was nothing short of exemplary! MUST GO!
author: Lindsey H.

description:
"Can I just see you every [Sunday] morning when I open my eyes..." -Eric Benet & Tamia

I can honestly say I wake up every weekend and crave Olea's custard french toast.  I used to live 2 doors down from Olea and didn't visit this restaurant for over a year.  Once I tried their brunch, I kicked myself for not stopping by sooner.  

Be prepared to wait for a table on the weekends as I've noticed this hidden neighborhood gem is becoming more and more popular.  Really, get the french toast and some blue bottle coffee.  It's the perfect way to start a lazy weekend.  I promise, you won't regret it.
author: Melanie T.

description:
This is the cutest place for breakfast or brunch. The french toast was amazing. I loved the cinnamon sugar and the fresh strawberries on top. The ratatouille omelet was also amazing! 

The place is small and there could be a wait but it's well worth it. Also, be prepared to share a large table with other brunch goers if necessary. Who knows maybe you'll make new brunch friends :P 

I also love this place because they use fresh wholesome ingredients so it's nice to know you're supporting local produce.
author: Janice H.

description: hands down the best french toast EVER. It's a small place so I wouldn't recommend coming with more than a party of 2 or 3. And like most brunch places in San Francisco, expect a line on the weekends, so go early!
author: Amy M.

description:
A great place for brunch!

It's my first try in SF, n I do like here. They change menu evey week. We had eggs, omlet n challah bread. The tastes are good, especially the bread! Also the blue bottle cafe is plus.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
The brunch here is very good. My friends and I ordered the flat omelet and all of us only had good things to say about it. The omelet came together very well and I loved how it was served with crostini. The service was nice and the atmosphere was very relaxed. 

The restaurant is really small so I'd anticipate a wait, although my friends and I showed up early enough that there was no wait and the restaurant was actually just starting to wake up. If you're willing to get up early, showing up around 10am is not a bad time.
author: Christine C.

description:
Went here with a business friend. Did the usual, iPhone stumble through the city. This place was nearby and seemed good by the ratings.

The lentil omelet was excellent. I would go back for that alone. But for that and only that.

The server was a douche. We ordered two of the same and only got one. An apology would have been nice, but that didn't seem to be on the menu (or maybe only at extra charge). Since my friend was eating and I had to wait another round for my food I asked if I could get some bread in the meantime. Says the lady who I asked, "I can bring you 5 pieces of bread, but it's $5". To which I exclaim, "I am going hungry here, and it's certainly not my fault. Just bring me some bread". She comes back with two tiny baked paper thin slices of baguette. Seriously - to date I wasn't able to figure out how anyone can cut bread this thinly.

The highly advertised Blue Bottle Coffee was tasty but lukewarm. But it was $5 a cup, so it least my wallet must have thought I had some good coffee.

On the upside though - the location of the place is great and it feels cozy. With better service it should be easy to come up to par.
author: Dr K.

description:
If I could give zero stars, I would. We waited for a while at breakfast on Saturday, Dec 10 at 11 am, and the guy who called our name had a condescending attitude that was the first negative sign. Two of our friends had stepped away and he asked if we had our complete party, I said they'll be here in two minutes, they just stepped away over there. He turned and said sarcastically "so, no. I only seat full parties" with a thick tone of his power in deciding who would get a table. 
A couple minutes later, our friends came and I looked for him, and he said "I've already sat the next table". So we waited 10 more minutes and read the menu, which looked delicious, and he came back out and called another name, party of four. I said, "wait, we were here first, and you just called us first last time". He said, "I have many names on my list. You may get seated in 20 minutes" and took in the other group.  Again, there was no tone of "I'm sorry, you are a paying customer. We want your business.". It was more like, "I get to decide who gets a table, and you are not going to get a table". So, while we wanted to eat there, we left and went to Nob Hill Grill up the street and it was very good.
author: Desiree K.

description: Met some friends here for brunch last week. The restaurant manager was friendly and very accommodating of our rather large group of eight people (the restaurant is VERY small.) We ended up sitting at two separate tables (no big deal), and the wait was only about 20 minutes. The menu was pretty short, but the food was excellent. AMAZING French toast, and delicious pulled pork sandwich for something a little more savory and lunch-like.
author: Kathryn P.

description:
Expect a line on Sunday morning. We ended up waiting about a half hour for a two top. They'll try to accommodate groups but due to the size and table limitations, this is not a good place with a large party. 

The menu was creative but a lot of the dishes seemed very similar so veto factor might be an issue for some. I had the flat omelet with Italian sausage, ricotta and farro. Somewhat bland in terms of flavor but not unappealing and it was a healthy sized portion. The dish could have used some vegetables of sorts to add more flavor and color. 

The wait staff was friendly and quick. Do have the French press coffee, always a treat when done right.
author: Thomas C.

description: I have been to Olea for both dinner and brunch and had amazing service and food for both. Obviously you will have to wait for brunch but you can make a reservation for dinner and the food is fresh and delicious. Highly recommended!
author: Nancy F.

description: Very cramped, busy, but pretty good! The french toast is YUMMY!!! GO, but don't go if you're super hungry. Expect to wait 30-60 mins for brunch!
author: Mary I.

description:
4 stars for the challah french toast - it is truly delectable. 

I only had a few bites of my friends french toast and it is absolutely dreamy. I had an egg entree that is only 3 stars. The french toast alone is worth a trip back and the only thing worth getting.

The restaurant is pretty small, even though we came on the later side of brunch (12:30 on a Sunday), we still waited about 45 mins.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Wow. I was very impressed with my groups meal here last night.

First off, they only have 6 tables so make a reservation. You have to call to reserve a table - no opentable.com

The menu changes often and that means its fresh daily and that they run out of items often as well. However, everything we ordered was unique and Delicious. I had the duck breast over cracked wheat with veggies - so amazing. My friend had the quinoa, the others had halibut. We shared the salad with peaches, goat cheese and flatbread. 

I would highly recommend dinning here. Service was nice. atmosphere was homey and they also have a nice wine list. In fact, we had one of The best tempernillos I have ever had.
author: Jessica L.

description: love this place! The french toast is amazing~
author: Yve H.

description:
The French toast will change your life.  

Doors will open, traffic lights will turn green, you will get laid IN THE AFTERNOON.

Everything on the menu is simple and good.  The menu changes weekly, but there is always something on there that makes me change my mind about cooking dinner that night.  

They also update on Twitter on the weekends for brunch about wait times and menus (@oleasf).
author: Dottie G.

description: The challa french toast served for brunch here is RI-DI-CU-LOUS. SO good. Finish it off with some great Blue Bottle coffee and you've got the makings of the best post-walk of shame meal you'll ever have.
author: Raffy E.

description: Good food but the brunch line was long. Service was also a little slow.
author: Alfred L.

description:
Best french toast I've ever had in my life. Hands. down. 

Blue bottle french press and great service are also a plus!
author: Jenna W.

description: Read so many excellent reviews on Yelp about this place so my boyfriend and I decided to try it out.  IT WAS DELISH!  The service, food, and ambiance were just what we were expecting.  I think Stefano was hoping for second helpings.  I found my meal to be amazing....egg sandwich.  I only wish I lived closer!
author: Francesca C.

description: Hands down, the BEST French toast I have ever had. Ever. Like, ever ever. It is a small little place but had very friendly waiters and excellent food. Two thumbs up
author: M L.

description:
Had the french toast + blue bottle coffee and yet again blown away. I'm normally one that doesn't like sweets in the morning but I had to try since so many yelpers suggested it. 

The french toast was dipped in some kind of custard and was covered in lite cinnamon and sugar topped w/ fresh local strawberries. I decided not to use much if any syrup on my toast, since the sweetest was perfect for my taste.

Blue Bottle french pressed coffee. Perfect, if you haven't experience it.... do so.
author: David C.

description:
It's true, their french toast is some of the most fantastic in all the land. Add a french press of Blue Bottle to the mix, along with the perfect companion and a sunny Sunday morning with a modest wait, and you have yerself the start to a right-fine day. 

Having done this twice now, I can confirm its positive effects.

Might I suggest you continue it as we did by hopping the California St. Streetcar down to the ferry building, where you can equip yourself with wine, cheese, chocolate, bread and fruit and make your way up to golden gate park for an amazing picnic, then down to Sutro's for a cocktail with a view.

Good day.
author: Jon L.

description:
My husband and daughter brought me here for Mother's day brunch.

there was about a 20 minute wait, which with a toddler we normally would not do... but we were so glad we waited. We had one of the best brunches ever.
I had the pork shoulder sandwich, excellent flavor, soft bread and enough to take home to finish later.

My husband had the dungeness crab scrambled eggs..which were done perfectly..and his side of bacon was just right too. (I don't know why so many places fuck up the bacon??)

My daughter had the french toast (my husband helped) with strawberries.
My husband LOVED the french toast... 

My husband is not easily impressed or excited about food, but I think Olea changed his mind.  I definitely enjoyed every aspect of my meal including the service.

The staff was very patient and accommodating to our child.  That gets the 5th star!

We cannot wait to go back and have dinner.
author: Karlee D.

description:
A small place, with really only a couple of seating options for our party of 4, we ended up sharing the large "community table" they have just by the windows and front door.

Hubby went ga-ga over the blue bottle coffee (3 Africans' variety) that they serve via french press, and he had to have the "life changing" french toast. (Which, I have to admit, were amazingly light - for french toast - and deliciously custardy.)

I had the eggs baked in a little crockery (some name I couldn't remember) with a tomato sauce and a little sausage for added flavor... The crockery actually keeps them cooking while they're waiting to be eaten - so you can decide how firm you like your eggs.  YUM!

Worth a visit - and I guess worth getting there a little early on a Sunday. While we didn't have to wait more than a few mins - when we left the wait was camped out on the sidewalk outside a block up the street.
author: Victoria S.

description:
If you want a more frou-frou eating experience for your brunch, this place is a wonderful option.  If you just want slabs of bacon and grease and biscuits, you should wander elsewhere.

I love that all the ingredients were seasonal, locally grown and organically raised.  I'm more than happy to support an establishment that's so conscientious.  I had the challah french toast and was not disappointed.  They even made a special vegan quinoa option that wasn't on the menu for the friend I had come with.
author: Sarah M.

description:
LOVE this place, some of my faves...

dinner
- quinoa and veggies (first time I had quinoa and it was AMAZING)
- pan seared duck breast (tender, tasty, and not a lot of fat under the skin)
- his fish dishes are really good too

brunch
- challah custard french toast
- eggs baked in a cazuela with tomato sauce

dinner portions could be a tad bigger, but otherwise, really really good, simple, thoughtful, and delicous food
author: Olivia C.

description: Original breakfast dishes, French Pressed Blue Bottle Coffee, and very good service. I like hearty helpings at breakfast/brunch so my only complaint would be the smaller portions that they serve up. Also be warned that the restaurant is extremely small so you might be in for a decent wait at peak times.
author: David F.

description: Nice neighborhood restaurant with an excellent chef and a darling, friendly, competent waitress. I had the mixed greens salad which was so good I almost canceled the entree and asked for another salad. I had the burger and matchstick fries, which seemed to be popular with other diners as well. Quite tasty. Small room with maybe ten tables so get there early (which I did) or call for reservation. Right on the corner of California and Larkin.
author: Robert H.

description: I just keep coming back, and every time its something new.  Dinner or brunch, you cant go wrong here.  One of my favorite place's in nob hill.
author: Anthony P.

description: Amazing brunch!  Love this place, yummy eggs and delicious olive oil cake.
author: Poppy C.

description: I love these small corner brunch places, it really makes Nob Hill a charming district. Service was attentive and the brunch was excellent. I wasn't in the mood for their famous french toast and opted for the eggs baked in a cazuela with tomato sauce, steamed farro spezzato, diced niman ranch applewood smoked ham and basil-almond pesto; served with toast. That's a mouthful, but it was definitely tasty. No words were spoken for about a few mins as we ate. Pretty delicious.
author: William H.

description:
+5 stars for the food.  The pork chop was absolutely perfectly prepared, the brown rice it came with was incredibly delicious.  Plus there was a pesto on the side that was unlike any pesto I have ever tasted...it was complex and unusual, as if there was some mint and lemon in it.  The pasta dish was also cooked perfectly and the light meat sauce was very delicate and just delicious.

+5 stars for the service. Friendly, relaxed, efficient.
+5 stars for the ambiance.  This is a very cute little place.  Warm and inviting.  Soft music plays not too loud but just loud enough to give you privacy in a small place.

So why only 3 stars?

-1 for a small wine list.  The wines are nothing special.
-1 for only 1 beer on the list.  Granted it was Duvel, which I like, but I think my boy would have been happier if he was able to have a choice of beers.

-1 for a very small glass of wine for about $12.  I was a bit indignant about how small the pour was and that my big earthy red came in a small chardonnay wine glass.

-1 for small portions for how high the price is.  Sure it is tasty but everything on the menu should be reduced by about $3-$4.  We would have spent the same amount on dinner had the prices been more reasonable but we would have left without feeling cheated...and hungry.
(and they don't serve bread which would have helped fill up my big hungry boy and he would have complained less about not getting enough to eat)

I hate to give a low review to such a cute place with good food prepared so skillfully.  But I think the customer deserves a little more for dropping $75 on a Tuesday night than just two meager glasses of mid range wine and two skinny girl portioned entrees...no starters or dessert on that bill.
author: Nilu r.

description: This place is to die for. The food was so fresh and delish! I went with a group of girlfriends and the waiter was so friendly and accommodating. The chef even greeted us while we were eating and wished us well. We had a very nice experience here overall. Thank you Olea!
author: M A.

description: Olea was amazing, the service, the ambiance, the food, everything was even better than expected. Phillip the owner came by and spoke to is about the menu and the restaurant in general, giving is tips and great advice. I would recommend Olea to anyone and everyone!
author: Michael N.

description:
Had my first date here last night...Gabriel, the owner, totally went out of his way to help make our dinner very romantic...I had stopped by earlier in the day to drop of a gift for my date to be giving during dessert and he was more than willing to help. 

On to the food :)....I had the Rock Cod...very good...a definite must try...While my date had the duck...I never had duck before but i had always heard that it was more on the fatty side...the dish was prepared with very little fat...Loved it!

THANKS GABRIEL! YOU REALLY MADE MY NIGHT! HOPE YOU READ THIS!!!
author: Jeremy T.

description:
This place is absolutely delicious!!

I had a chance to try a bite of my friends' dishes, and all were good. I have to say that the challah french toast was the BEST I've ever had. I'm not a big fan of french toast in general, but I can totally have their french toast every day for the rest of my life.
author: Kyoko M.

description: Excellent French Toast here at Olea!   The service was fast and friendly.   Blue bottle coffee was served in a 2 cup French press.  Something about the French Press makes it taste that much better.  Highly recommended for Sunday brunch.  No wait.
author: Lee B.

description:
this is a great spot for weekend breakfast & brunch.

we got there around the time they open and i am so glad we did it. this place is quaint and tiny and got packed with people waiting out the door very quickly.

the menu offers a variety of dishes that are familiar and some, not as common. we tried their cazuela.. this dish was absolutely delightful. not too heavy, just savory with great flavors and ingredients.

pork shoulder sandwich; tender and juicy.. definitely one of the best pork sandwiches i have had.

mussel steamer: they killed it and so did we. it was great.

they also change menu weekly... i can't wait to try this place again!
author: Sung C.

description:
I went with my friend Cathy who seems to know a lot about restaurants around SF so I figured whatever she picked would be pretty good! It usually gets packed but we got there early and snagged a great table. The wait staff wasn't the most attentive but in her defense our waitress did make the right decision and took my credit card instead of my friends since it was a makeup birthday celebration. 

I got the omelette and it was delicious.  I definitely would go here again for brunch! :)
author: K T.

description: Went for a Saturday brunch and loved it.  The challah custard french toast was amazing.  We also had the pulled pork sandwich which was yummy.  The service was good and we didn't even have to wait for a table (we arrived at 1pm).   Not recommended for groups of 4 or more since it's a relatively small space.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
One of the best brunches I've had so far in San Francisco. This place is quaint and cozy. It's really small, so there's not a lot of seating and there was a wait. We sat at a communal table which was fine. We were just excited to try a new place for brunch.

I ordered a delicious omelette with yummy veggies and cheese. The side salad had a bit too much dressing, but was still good. The french press coffee hit the spot and was the perfect size for two people. My friend had an egg sandwich that she devoured so quickly and happily. 

The staff was funny and friendly - a bit quirky, but hey you're close to Polk St so it is what it is!

The only problem was that the creamer for the coffee had little bits of dust and crap in it. I don't understand why so many places leave their creamer sitting around uncovered...that's just plain nasty. They gave us some fresh creamer right away so it was fine.

Perfect place for brunch - totally check it out!
author: Zeke A.

description:
What a cute place, a bit hidden in Nob Hill.  I came here with a friend for Sunday brunch and it was a delightful experience.  My friend is a regular here and knows everyone.  When he comes in, they plop a fresh squeezed orange juice in front of him and make him a special meal.  Not to be excluded, I also ordered the same meal.

The atmosphere here is cute and pleasant.  It has good lighting, a nice open kitchen, small tables, a few plants, and a large shared table.  I don't know if they have wifi here, but if they do I would like to come here to do work and hang out.

I noticed a wall of lovely wine and champagne glassware on the side wall, which is a nice addition.  While I didn't have wine, next time I will.  I did not notice a wine list on the menu, so I recommend presenting one to extend the bottom line for this restaurant.
