While we did not have wine, we did have a fresh squeezed orange juice and a french press of Blue Bottle coffee.  Nob Hillers, come here for your Blue Bottle coffee fix.  Also, the fresh squeezed oj is among the best I have had in San Francisco.  Olea, what kind of oranges are you squeezing?

Our meal was a flat omelette with shreds of pepper, a wheat grain, avocado, and cheese.  The food was very light and incorporated a combination of subtle flavors.  If I had to describe the food here in one word, I would describe it as subtle.  

The menu here changes a bit every week, although I believe there are a few standard items.  I noticed a neighbor eating an egg dish with tortilla chips in it which I will have to try next time.  We also had crispy fries, which are like the fries they have in France.  Thin and slightly crispy.  Olea, will you consider making mussels so I can have Moules Frites with you?

A great experience.  Everyone here is so friendly.  I want to be a regular here.  Perhaps next time I am here, they will plop an apple juice in front of me.
author: apple r.

description:
I just moved into the neighborhood from Alamo Square, and I gotta be honest, I am probably most disappointed with the non-neighborhood feel of the area, and lack of many "cute" neighborhoodie restaurants (how many times can you put neighborhood in a sentence?). 

But then I found Olea - and it is delicious, and locally grown/organic all that hippy BS that I heart about San Francisco. Also, every time I go there are new things to try on the menu. The portions are a little on the small side, so if you are very hungry, this is not the place for you. But honestly I am so over the giant sized portions at most resturants that leave me feeling like I ate a whale. 

I have been for dinner a couple of times and I always find the waitstaff super accommodating, helpful, and friendly. 

I haven't been for brunch yet, which I guess is what they are famous for, I can't wait to try it and I will update my review then!
author: Marissa C.

description: I'd like to give Olea 2.5 stars. Since I cannot do that, I believe they're closer to two as opposed to three stars. Their challah French toast was quite nice.  It was really delicate and definitely different from many of the French toasts one will see.  However, the eggs baked in a Cazuela, Olea's signature dish, was pretty pathetic. Because they failed at impressing me with their self-acknowledged signature dish, I have to give them merely two stars.  Again, when comparing this to what one can get in the mission at places like Chloe's and Mission Beach Cafe, I think it does not compare well at all. Those two places simply don't have such big misses. On the whole, I'm finding myself disappointed with the food in the Nob Hill area.
author: George E.

description:
The french toast here is amazing~ 

I've been in the city for 9 months now and this is the first time that I've found french toast that I can actually say was deeelicious. It's made from Challah bread (y use anything else?), blanketed with brown sugar, and sprinkled with strawberries. The best part is that it's dipped in custard to give it a sweet creamy texture! I admit that I've definitely got some NYC food snob in me but this french toast finally met my expectations. yumm...strong bid

Also, the decour is very cute. Small, quaint, fresh flowers~ Great for brunch~
author: Fawn Y.

description:
Olea is super small, and super cozy.  There are likely between six and nine tables throughout the restaraunt.  The kitchen is in plain sight and you can see all the delicious food being prepped nearby.  It's a proper neighborhood restaraunt, and doesn't try to be something larger and more grand.  It's simple, clean, and really well done.

First courses, salad with beets.  Simple, light, tasty and very refreshing.  Flatbread with ricotta, pears, and spinach/endive.  The flatbread was crisp, salty, tasty, and paired well with all of the components above.  The ricotta and pears worked really well together, the spinach/endive was less successful in my opinion, but I'm not a big fan of either ingredient to begin with, so that would make sense.

Main course was duck.  Nicely seared, thick coated, sitting on top of a pile of couscous, corn, and mushrooms.  While I'm not typically a fan of couscous and mushrooms, they played really well together.  The duck was surprisingly sweet, and perfectly cooked and tender.   Sadly, the chef told me it was the last night he was preparing this item in this fashion (and being the last dish of the night, it was the last preparation of his duck in that format), but I'm sure if he's looking to improve upon this, it will be pretty solid in the future as well.

For a shot of the duck course, see Flickr - http://www.flickr.com/photos/swnktstic/4045020848/

Sadly, didn't have time for dessert, but Blue Bottle coffee is served here, so plus one there too.  Overall, a great little spot.  Their menu is a bit limiting and small, but it also likely means that what they do serve, they cook really well and nail it down solid.
author: chris c.

description:
My friend returned from a summer in Peru this saturday, so we decided on a "welcome home" brunch here.

Our experience was very much worth the 20-ish minute wait (expected, as it was 11am on a saturday). We each enjoyed the challah french toast, prepared with a remarkable custard batter, cinnamon, fresh raspberries, and fried to just the right texture, and split a press of blue bottle coffee and a delectable mimosa.

The cafe is sunken about half a level on the street corner, and a light breeze through the open door provided the perfect reprieve from the heat. Very friendly and attentive service as well. This is the place to take someone special for a truly delightful meal.
author: Alex B.

description:
OleeeeAhhh!! 
This place was very fresh indeed. I tried the clams in Rose wine and it was so good. The clams were not too over cooked and had tangy flavor. I also tried my sister's Challah custard and it melted in my mouth- no syrup necessary- the slightly sweet custard was enough to satisfy my palette. 
Very cramp which made me give it a 4 star instead of a 5...
author: Anna C.

description:
Very fresh and light.  Got the baked eggs and they were very simple, not very much spice.

If you're in the mood for simple, simple, simple fresh organic cookin.
author: Melanie C.

description: I was very impressed with this place.  Yes, I had to wait about 40 minutes to be seated, and we were starved after hiking about a mile from our hotel.  We both agreed the wait and hike were worth it as the food was excellent.  My girlfriend had French Toast, and I had eggs Benedict.  The orange juice was very fresh and loaded with pulp.  I plan to stop again on my next trip to SF.
author: Kyle M.

description:
The moment you see Olea -or even see the menu online- you realize this place is unique. The restaurant space is pretty tiny, the door resembles the portal from Being John Malkovich, and the selection of food is meticulously local and seasonal. It looks like a neighborhood spot featuring a menu with city-wide appeal. 

We went for brunch this morning, but I'm sure we'll be back for dinner since we just moved to Nob Hill. Boyfriend got the french toast (per my recommendation, per Yelpers' recommendations) and I got a flat omelet with fingerling potatoes, dandelion greens, onions, and pecorino cheese. We also got sides of toast and bacon, french press coffee, and bf got the fresh orange juice.

Can I just say... the french toast was phenomenal. I'm tempted to use expletives to convey my zealous lust for this "custard toast," but I think you'll get the drift with g-rated language. It was sinful, perfect, and absolutely incomparable with most french toast on earth. It is by no means good for you (I think -I KNOW- I've had healthier desserts), which is why I let my boyfriend order it, but HOLY crap is it worth the calories. I'm not sure I'd ever get it for myself because I'd likely polish off an entire order, but if someone is willing to split I say "do it!" Do it.

Flat omelet was good... it reminded me of something a chef would make himself for breakfast. In comparison to the french toast, it was just alright, but that's not really a fair comparison. Especially because it's so much better for you and not covered in cinnamon-sugar. 

Also, the side of toast is really cute... as opposed to most breakfast places that give you 2 pieces of toasted bread, it's sort of like a bread basket at dinner. There were 2 types of bread (challah and something else like sourdough) lightly toasted served with butter and jam on the plate.
author: Amanda C.

description:
i've been meaning to try olea for a while now after reading all the positive reviews. i finally got around to it the other day. first impression is that at first glance, the menu seemed very well thought out and the dishes unique.

the server recommended the flat bread with peaches and ricotta cheese. both my friend and i had the same reaction when the dish came out because it wasn't at all what we expected. i guess i was expecting the flatbread to be more like a foccacia, but it was exactly like papadum, the thin, crispy cracker like bread which is typically served in indian restaurants. the ricotta, peaches and another item, i think it was onions (??) came on the side and you scoop them on to the bread.

i guess we didn't realize it was such an 'involved' appetizer but certainly would not have ordered it had we known what the dish actually was. moreover, the flavors of the three items were pretty bland and did not complement eachother. overall, the idea of the appetizer was nice, but it just didn't work...at all.

the salmon and pork entrees were okay, but nothing memorable. the portions were small and the flavors weren't really there. 

to sum it up, olea was pretty disappointing.
author: Jae C.

description:
I have no real excuse for not eating here sooner, it's less than a block away.  In any case, I had walked by plenty of times and been intrigued.  It seemed like a 'special occasion' place for dinner so J and I finally went in tonight to celebrate our anniversary.  

Where to begin?  The place is rather small, with a cozy feel, not like a big impersonal restaurant.  The food changes seasonally, and presumably this is why its just so incredible.  Clearly these folks also get an organic box delivered!  Everything was incredibly fresh and delightfully yet lightly seasoned.

I had the halibut, J had clams.  In-fucking-credible.  Seriously, even the chickpeas, radish and cucumber garnishing the fish were delicious.  And I don't even like radish!  Every element seemed to be perfectly placed, and prepared with such care as to render the meal no less than exquisite.  Truly amazing.  

I must caution you that I am a grad student and do not usually spend this much on dinner, so perhaps not having been a party to much truly amazing food, my awe is explained.  But in awe I was, truly, amazing food.  

The dessert was beyond words.  A rich chocolate mousse with a sprinkling of sea salt and fresh raspberries.  I thought that it was like good German chocolate died and went to heaven to be crowned by wings and a halo, while J argued that it was more akin to the pure and perfect soul of German chocolate unsullied by sin.  Whatever it was, it was pure delight.  

I love the setup, its very intimate and the magic happens in the little kitchen just beyond the tables.  The place is set slightly below the sidewalk, you walk down a set of stairs to enter.  In all the effect was one of being transported (or maybe that was the wine?) to another land where flavors perfectly complement each other and each element is urged to share its own subtle and unique being.  

Since when did I care what a chick-pea tasted like? Since now that I know of the genius that results when the magic happens.
author: RJ M.

description:
So I've come here for breakfast twice now.  Both times I was ravishingly hungry and both times I left a teensy bit disappointed.  

The first visit I had some veggie-egg dish that was delicious, but left me wanting more and having none.  Although it may not have been possible to completely satisfy my oversized appetite (thank you, munchies), I was sure I could get close enough to full that I could forgo second-breakfast.  Unfortunately, Olea couldn't do it for me this time around.

The second visit had some high and low points.  
High Point: Blue Bottle Coffee...absolute perfection

Low Point: My friend and I were sat behind a pillar and it took our server waaaay too long to notice us.  Don't get me wrong, I'm down with the privacy that a giant cement column affords me, but please be sure to peak in every once in a while to, oh I don't know, TAKE MY ORDER.

Mid Point:  I, too, had the Challah Toast and, at first, it completely changed my perspective on french toast (a dish which usually leaves me feeling more thirsty than necessary).  Theirs struck a flawless balance of moisture- not too soggy, not too dry.  So why the mediocre mark, you ask...  Part way through the meal, I was so overloaded on sweetness that it became nearly a chore to finish.  I so wished I had a small bite of a savory ANYTHING to counter the utter richness.  I guess sweets for breaky isn't my thing...
author: Christy F.

description: Amazing spot! Great dishes that takes thing a step beyond. I only tried breakfast though, next stop is dinner!
author: Jennavive P.

description:
Olea is a true nob hill gem.  Although teeny tiny, this place boasts big flavors.  With only 7 small tables and 1 communal table, one can expect a short wait.   Their brunch menu is a simple one pager with good variety.  

I ordered the omelet with kale, cheese, and chopped almonds with a side salad ($12).  The kale was perfectly seasoned, cheese was not overpowering, and the almonds added a nice texture and flavor.   

The ULTIMATE must try is the challah custard toast with cinnamon sugar topped with slices of poached bosc pears ($11).  It's was just a thick fluffy layer of custard-y goodness.  It was so deliciously moist that there was no need for syrup.   We also made our meal complete with an order of their crispy thin cut french fries ($5.50) - you can never go wrong with that!

The service, food, and environment, was reflective of a place I would call "home" - just so warm & inviting.  I look forward to spending several weekend mornings here.

P.S. I don't recommend wearing your best Sunday clothes.  They don't have the best ventilation, so expect to walk out smelling like breakfast.
author: Nancy G.

description:
I'd never been to Olea, but one night I was craving a hamburger, my Yelp search brought me to Olea. I thought I'll try it. It was sooo good! 
I got it to go and asked for it medium rare. When I got home I thought hmm i wonder if it will still be on the rare side... because a good chef knows it will keeping cooking once it out of the pan. 
I opened up the container to red meat goodness. It was cooked perfectly and was delicious. you can tell they use quality meat. The fries were yummy too. I'll definitely go back and dine there! Can't wait to try their brunch!
author: Colleen m.

description:
The wait was long, but it was so worth it!

Olea is not your typical brunch place with the same usual menu. The menu is small, but they have very creative and good brunch dishes. My date and I ordered the challah custard toast and the neimans ranch burger. I recommend both, as both dishes were amazing.

The coffee is super strong and really good! I want to try the mimosas next. The atmosphere is cute and quaint. The service is great and the staff was very friendly! You have to try this place at least once!
author: Mai L.

description:
Wow, I'm still reeling from how good that challah custard toast was. The texture and flavor were so perfect, I can never go back to regular french toast. The flat omelet with ham and oaxaca cheese was also very good. I also loved that I asked for hot sauce, expecting Tabasco or the like, but they bought a little dish of their homemade jalapeno & peanut hot sauce, and apparently the hot sauce changes each week. 

The space is very cute - clean, simple, modern. The fact that it's a few steps below street level makes it feel cozy. Had to wait 35 minutes on a Saturday morning, but everything else about my experience there was perfect. 

A number of people seemed to love the cazuela, ordering that next time!
author: D K.

description: A small cosy restaurant. Dinner was good. The menu is small but the chef is very accommodating towards vegetarians. This place is very popular for brunch, but don't discount it for dinner, an overall pleasant dining experience.
author: Anna J.

description: This place is delicious. The food is good, nice quality, and unique. Love the baked egg in casuela. I would be so proud of myself if I learned how to make this. And I find the place kind of romantic for some reason. Can't put my finger on it. Maybe cuz I like the ambiance. It makes me want to have sparking wine with my breakfast to start my sat or sun off right.
author: Laurie W.

description:
We came here based on good reviews from yelp...
I think we came on an off day. 

To be frank, our waitress looked like she really couldn't be that bothered serving us and would rather be closing up shop. The menu states you have to ask for bread, so we did. She finally brought it over after we finished our entrees. Hmmm. Interesting timing...

I cant fault the actual quality of the food. It was super tasty - there just wasn't very much of it. We all left hungry and somewhat despondent.
Considering the cost and the service, I cant see myself coming back to Olea again.
author: Michael H.

description: Small restaurant but great ambience. Attentive and friendly waiter and staff. Highly recommend the French toast.
author: Chris A.

description: Great spot for brunch.  The french toast is possibly the best I've had anywhere, while the migas con huevo is a solid option as well.  The fresh squeezed juices are also very fresh and pulpy (and a little pricy).  Also has a pretty reasonable opening time (9:30) so you don't have to wake up super early to get one of the coveted first wave of seatings.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Most of the Olea reviews seem to be for brunch (which is quite good) but I wanted to emphasize that it is also a really nice dinner spot. It is pretty small and has a cozy feel to it. Definitely a good place to take a date for dinner. 

I live about a block from Olea and have eaten there several times. The food is always solid. They don't have a long menu but what they do they do well. The staff is very friendly and welcoming. 

Whenever we have people in town and want to show them the neighborhood, Olea followed by Hyde Out is a great night out.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Came here for brunch on Sunday with the usual crew (Hi Omar, Lori, Wakako and the rest of you guys!!). I have to say, this is a REALLY cute dining space. It's like you're dining in someone's home living room. Needless to say, it's small.

I went with the slowly braised bbq pork shoulder sandwich with fries. It was AWESOME!!!! I ended up just taking it off the bread though and eating it plain. I had them add cheddar cheese to it which was really good. The fries are super good too. Nice and crispy. 

I'd love to come back here for dinner. Everything we had for brunch was amazing. I can only imagine that dinner would be even better.
author: Jen D.

description: I really liked how minimalistic this tiny corner brunch establishment is. The interior decor is exceptionally clean and the light that bounces off the white walls gives this place a certain glow. Their bacon scrambled egg sandwich was very fluffy while their soft french toast was complimented well with fresh strawberries. By no means was their food unique but you can instantly tell how fresh their ingredients are. No need to hide behind combinations of spices, this cafe shows off their substance.
author: Nathan L.

description: We like Olea very much, friendly, good prices, delicious Food. Its in the neighborhood and rarely Busy... The menu is pretty limited but they always have what we want so its fine. Brunch is very popular, we have done it once and it was Excellent, but we mostly do dinner and Love it.
author: Peter J.

description:
1. Blue Bottle Coffee - check
2. Baked eggs with veggies - check
3.  Delicious, dessert french toast - check

Pretty perfect breakfast without the crowd or pretention of alot of brunch places in SF.

I also think I need to repeat for my love of the french toast. I normally don't like french toast but this was delicious a rich custard filled creation. Good enough to have as dessert.
author: Sara K.

description:
Brunch is something I can do. In fact, I do it well. I can sleep in late, put on some stunner shades, stroll down the block, sit down, cross my legs and be served great food and drink all while smiling and chatting with friends. Amazing - I know. That's why the phrase "Let's do brunch" is often spoken with such confidence and flair. Low point-of-entry to qualify, highly enjoyable payoff once engaged. I'm good at brunching. And Olea is good at brunch. I'd go as far as saying Olea is my newest BFF - Brunch Friend Forever. 

The smoked salmon & asparagus omelet lives up to it's fluffy, eggy potential, the sparkling mimosa is a cheery citrus & champagne quencher and the challa toast is the best thing, since..well, other really good toast. Maybe even since sliced bread. Plus it's all local, organic, daily rotating, guilt-free goodness.  Did I mention the Blue Bottle coffee lattes and French-press? The service is friendly, the room is pretty. How can you go wrong? You could go wrong by not going. I'll be going right. Right to Olea. Frequently.
author: wendella a.

description:
Yup, brunch at Olea is all it's cracked up to be. 

The French Toast is indeed some of the best you'll have, the inner depths that perfect warm, chewy texture that only moms seem to know how to achieve. 

The egg, bacon, and tomato sandwich was delicious--eggs cooked to just-this-side-of-runny perfection, thick, lean bacon, fresh tomato slices, all packed between nice chewy bread with a crisp outer crust.  How they manage to keep this from turning into a greasy heap is beyond me.

The French press coffee is a must as well. 

Service was fast and friendly.  Fresh food enjoyed with a fresh breeze from outside--this is a good way to wake up.
author: Daryl E.

description:
As much as I'll miss the Red Door Cafe, Olea is a welcome addition to the neighborhood. There aren't a lot of mid-price dining options in the area but Olea definitely helps fill the niche.  Portions are smallish but so are prices - I'd rather pay $15 for an entree that fills me up (without feeling stuffed to the gills) than $20 for something that I can't finish.

I had the pork shoulder served over pasta: the pork was really tasty but the noodles were just ok, they reminded me a bit of tuna casserole noodles (and not in the good way)  The olives with flatbread appetizer was also hit and miss: the olives were a hit, the flatbread, not so much. They definitely needed some hummus or a spread to go with the crunchiness.

Olea was pretty good and has the potential to be great. I can definitely see myself becoming a regular here, especially since I live only a few blocks away!

ps...I hope they add the outdoor seating back and please, lose the salt shakers that look more fit for a Denny's than a nice, neighborhood restaurant!
author: phil h.

description:
lesson learned: must order the french toast.
the fiance and i decided to take a nice morning walk to olea and when we got there we were craving some hot egg dishes. he ordered the flat omelette with louisana poached shrimp and i had the omelette with butternut squash, pumpkin seeds and mozzarella cheese. both were just ok and we felt alittle unsatisfied with our meals. we decided to share the yogurt with sliced apples and pomegranate seeds topped with light honey and granola and that was delish!

every other table seemed to order the french toast and it looked damn good. we will just have to come back and get that on our next visit.

oh and the fiance loved his french pressed blue bottle coffee (2 cups).
my japanese sencha tea was pretty tasty too.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Went to brunch and had a great meal.  All locally grown and fresh food for our meal.  

The coffee is fabulous and a must.  The menu was limited to choices wish there were a few more sides I could have purchased (like a fruit compote).  Otherwise a great meal with fabulous service.
author: Karen H.

description:
My first review was for brunch, which I have been to many times- every experience pretty solid.  We've taken to sharing the french toast as an app each time so that we don't have to be torn about what to order for entrees.  

Recently went there for dinner and the experience was very nice.  We went on a weeknight and had no trouble getting in- though I did call first and would definitely recommend doing so based on the size.  It's like a lot of our higher quality food, dress up or down your good, somewhat casual yet highly knowledgeable staff, California cuisine places.  Flatbread app was so-so, duck was great, pork was great, chocolate dessert with sea salt was great, wine recommendations were accurate.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Dina A.

description: I absolutely love Olea. Went on a week night to avoid the crowd and had a lovely dinner with two friends. The space is great--very romantic and just below the street level. The food was fantastic and very well prepared. I really enjoyed watching the chef work in the open kitchen in the middle of the dining room. Also very happy with the seasonal menu and sustainable practices, i.e. wild caught fish, fresh local and organic veggies, etc. I'm always willing to support that, especially when it's so tasty! Will definitely be returning. I hear the brunch is great! Excellent spot for a first date or romantic/casual dinner setting.
author: Jessica M.

description: On our server's recommendation we had the cazuela (Baked Eggs, pork, bacon, spinach, tomatilla Sauce, Tortilla Chips, Parmesan Cheese), the migas con huevos (Soft Scrambled Eggs w/ house made turkey sausage, sauteed kale, roast eggplant, Tortilla Chips, Ancho Pepper Sauce, Sesame Seeds).  We finished with the challah custard toast.  The migas was great, but the ancho sauce was a bit over powering.  The cazuela was outstanding.  Flavorful and nicely balanced.  The challah toast was a great way to finish the meal, really rich.  Coffee is french press and you should get the large pot for 2 people.  Service was good.  There's no table list, so you have to wait in line which is a bit annoying.  But we did get a table for 2 in about 20 min on a Saturday morning.  A good find.
author: Jordan W.

description:
We just had our brunch today, I would say that this place is good.

Let's start from the menu, first, We got baked eggs with the tomato sauce and the second dish was flat omelet with fresh corn. They were great dishes. I can tell this place use the fresh ingredients. but these two dishes came out in small portion for us( one is Asian size and another is American size) so in the end (Later, we ended up to eat early more.)

For the service, I'd say it was great, started from  line  until we got the table was great. I was happy with it.

and Yes, i'd come back again to try something else.
author: Sasitorn O.

description: I love this place. The long waits for brunch are totally worth it. Some of the best french toast I have ever had. I was pleasantly surprised by their dinner offerings as well. Their menu is constantly changing to suit whatever is in season. The dishes are well thought out, flavors are fantastic, and the service is always friendly and knowledgeable. This is definitely my favorite neighborhood place for great eats.
author: Jordan R.

description: Everything you want in a brunch place! Cute atmosphere, great service, blue bottle coffee, and absolutely delicious food.
author: Rebecca B.

description: A decent brunch place in nob hill. The place is small so the wait can be long if you don't come at the right time. Portions is not this place's strong point but at least flavor is. I got the scambled eggs dish. At best it was ok. Again portions were small and it was not cheap. I understand it was all organic and all that jazz but adding some potatoes or something won't kill ya. My friend had the french toast or "custard toast" and it was AWESOME. You actually don't even need syrup as the custard in the middle is just full of flavor. Overall I'd say this place is just ok. It has some good stuff but I'd say overall it is just ok and at the price they charge I won't be back often.
author: edward k.

description:
Yummy spot. It's tiny, so be prepared to wait, especially for brunch.

I ordered the omelet with tomato, spinach, and feta. Mmm. I also liked that the "side of toast" I ordered came with three different varieties of bread.

French press Blue Bottle is a nice touch.
author: Vandana M.

description:
Olea is our new favorite restaurant! Everything is fresh, organic, the menu is creative, nothing is pretentious yet of great quality. I love it that the menu isn't 5 pages long. The wine list is also pretty short, but the selection is very good. The service is also great and personalized because the place is small and manageable. I love it!!!

I also saw in a bunch of comments that the portions were small. Well people, I have to disagree!! The portions are normal, that's the portion size that is actually healthy for you. It's the American eater issue of needing giant portions to feel satisfied. Or needing giant portions so that you feel you got enough for your money. Think again!! Isn't quality better over quantity? When you say you left hungry, was it your stomach or your brain that was hungry?

I think we need to cut the crap on portions. They're just fine.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I went to Olea for dinner and really loved it. The restaurant is both comfortable and pretty. The server we had was very attentive with us and knowledgeable about all the menu items. I had the Halibut with new potatoes, which was delicious and my (handsome & charming date) had the Osso Bucco and polenta which was tasty as well. For dessert I (unwillingly) shared the Gateau Breton, with strawberries and figs, do not leave without trying it, the perfect end to a satisfying meal! The one con I would say there is with this restaurant is that for the price we paid, $20-22 per plate, the portions could have been bigger. Otherwise, I would definitely return to Olea and I encourage others to check it out as well. 

Can't wait to try the brunch next. The french toast made with challah bread dipped in custard came highly recommended and sounds like heaven.
author: Fabiola M.

description:
I'm convinced Olea has the best brunch in the city! 

Their french toast is like nothing I've ever tasted - the bread is so light and fluffy and absolutely melts in your mouth. They also have the elusive Blue Bottle coffee that I've heard so much about and it was every bit as good as everyone says.

The restaurant itself is tiny- there is only seating for about 25 people and at least one of the tables is communal, but the decor is very charming and rustic. Service was extremely friendly.
author: Lindsey S.

description: I've been meaning to write a review about Olea as this place struck a chord with me. It wasn't the best meal I've had in my life, but it was a meal that had a lot of heart added to the great ingredients. It's not a flashy place with a flashy, famous chef. It's a quaint, polished neighborhood restaurant with a chef whose culinary passion is reflected in the food he puts out. Yeah yeah, gettin' a bit spiritual here. I'll blame it on the fact that I am a fan of the small businessman. It's a lot of work, but it's the passion that makes it all worth it.
author: Al L.

description:
If you're planning on going, go soon.  This place has a flaws that I don't think will get settled soon enough to save it.

I really wanted to like this place.  Their general idea is exactly what should be the next phase in SF restauranting: well prepared modern food at (almost) moderate prices.  The Nob Hill Grille has started this route and is pulling it off: I was excited to think we'd have a second in the neighborhood.

First, the menu is off-putting. Once you get past its clumsy layout (no capitol letters- Wow! Edgy! Or rather: wow! edgy!) then comes the problem of not knowing the preparation of the dishes.  Was the Steelhead poached, broiled, or seared?  Who knows?  Past that, the dishes just didn't sound all that appetizing.  "Duck breast and vanilla poached quince slices."  Is the duck breast poached too?  What's the seasoning?  Is there something to contrast the vanilla, an odd choice for savory dishes, one that almost always fails. 

Each dish we had misfired on some level.  The ricotta cheese and flatbread dish would have been delightful if not for the cold, under roasted grapes.  This dish needed acid and punch to wake it up, not sweet and floral.  The mixed greens salad was good but over priced at $8.50.  It's still just a mixed greens salad. The scallops were greatly overpriced at $14.50 for three small scallops on undercooked, hard chick peas.  The steak was smallish and served awkwardly by itself with a small pile of veg on the other side of the plate with a ramekin of mostly oil salsa verde to pour on yourself.  The plating style is that sparse, separated look which works well in cookbooks and magazines, not so much in real life.  The squash and potatoes with the steak were wonderful, but looked pitiful and small by itself.

Obviously, the place is too focused of its food-cost and not focused enough on creating the impressions of value and satisfaction, the cornerstones of being a moderately priced eatery.  And, actually, we spent $40 a person for three courses, which qualifies as "spendy" and not "moderate" according to the scale at the bottom of the screen.

The service was competent even if the server was a condescending putz.  Our table was made up of  professionals, thirty-five to forty-three, all experienced diners who did not need a teenager treating us like we just got off the turnip truck.  He actually said to us, "Our dessert tonight is a Gateau Breton.  Are you familiar?"  Good service does not include a pop quiz that can only embarrass or insult  the customer.

We went elsewhere for dessert.  Discussing our meal, up popped phrases like "learn to walk before you run" and "style trumping substance."  This conflicts with the positive comments others have written here, I know.  But, the crowd I see each night as I walk by is made up of non-neighborhood people and they aren't enough to support a "neighborhood" restaurant.  Ask Harvey's, or Zare, or Red Door, or King's Cafe . . . you get the idea.
author: Christopher S.

description:
The chef has a great taste for flavor.  He uses locally grown and organic ingredients which is a highlight of Olea.  It adds to the cost of the entrees yet nonetheless supporting our local farmers is a plus.  

The quinoa was excellent.  A high protein vegan dish filled with ingredients such as sweet onions, sugar snap peas, mushrooms and currents.  The pork shoulder was also delightful.  It came with a tomatillo and pumpkin seed sauce on a bed of polenta. The cod was good but not as delicious as the other two dishes.

Olea is a gem of San Francisco. I shall return and perhaps go earlier for their brunch.
author: Jeannine L.

description:
As a child growing up, my mother would make me what she called "milk toast". Sweet, custardy-soft on the inside, but golden-crusted on the outside, it epitomized comfort food for many years. 
Olea's challah french toast is the closest anything has come to replicating this breakfast of my youth. And dare I say it - it's made even better with the addition of cinnamon sugar and berries. (Mom, don't hate me, your awesomeness is still beyond doubt.)
My husband's aspargus, pea shoot and cheddar omelette was great too, so fresh, you could smell the garden. Quality of ingredients is clearly the star here, but prices still seem a little high for a neighborhood restaurant.
author: Purnima M.

description: Had brunch here recently.  Good selection of items, fresh and delicious food, attentive service.  C'est bon!  If I want a fancy brunch (with great coffee) - this is a go-to place.  The only drawback was the skimpy amount of 'toast' and the wait to get our food (why can't there be breakfast appetizers??)
author: Julienne G.

description:
My friend Kathy was desperately trying to avoid putting on a costume Saturday night. As many of us know, costume generally equals getting drunk and making an ass out of yourself, which is generally pretty fun, but Kathy is in a yoga teacher training program on the weekends and she is trying hard to be good.

I suggested dinner at Olea, a new Mediterranean place in Nob Hill. I had been to the opening party, which was thoroughly enjoyable, and I wanted to go back and try the food for reals. 

Olea is one of those places that feels like it's giving you a hug when you walk in. The decor is inviting and stylish, great for a casual friendly dinner and could also work well for a romantic date. We ordered the green bean salad, which was good, though it could have used a bit more of a bite- maybe more lemon or garlic. It was served with a nice piece of cheese that livened up the flavor considerably. We also had the green olives and flatbread. The olives were mild and fruity, the flatbread crisp and salty. It was a good combination. We shared the vegan entree, which was farro with broccoli and walnuts and was superb. It was served with a delicious peppery, savory sauce on it. The wine list has some interesting selections. The malbec I ordered ($8.50/glass) was perfect with the food and everything a good malbec should be- smooth and subtle.

Sadly, we were too full for dessert and Kathy had to get going so she could get into her slutty German beer girl costume (yes, she did!) and go to not one but "several" Halloween parties. I have a feeling her Om Shanti was dragging the next day. The dessert menu was quite tempting and I hope I have room for it next time I am there.

I thought the prices at Olea were really reasonable - two appetizers, one entree and three glasses of wine for under $50.
author: Angie R.

description:
Olea is a lovely jewel right in my neighborhood. A friend and I have found the pristine food and simple clean ambience a delight! Twice in a few weeks, we chose to order the vegan dish and I even took some home, as I was more than satisfied with the incredibly fresh ingredients, brilliant combination of tastes, and impeccable seasonings.The chef, Gabriel, is talented, has a subtle  touch, and his kitchen is discreetly quiet, tho it is open to the dining room, no kitchen noises intrude on your dining experience. The wait person Ryan was friendly, caring, and totally knowledgeable about each menu item.

I look forward to going  for brunch this coming weekend...run, don't walk to this incredibly special spot in a city of many interesting dining choices...you will be pleasantly surprised.
author: Kay H.

description:
It was love at first sight.  Really.  I first saw this place on a "friend's" flickr page (thanks, Cinnamon!).  After being awed with the Chihuly exhibit at the de Young, Mom and I were very hungry.  The parking karma gods were in full effect that day and there was no wait, so we were seated immediately.  

We shared the Challah French Toast with fresh fruit and the egg dish baked in a cazuela.  Absolutely heavenly.  Later that evening, I lamented the fact that I didn't have the Olea chef in my apartment to make me more french toast.  I could have inhaled it, it was so good.

I'd already had plenty of Blue Bottle coffee from the kiosk in Hayes Valley, so no coffee.    I was very tempted though.  Any restaurant that serves Blue Bottle is a winner in my book.

One of the co-owners, Glen, came by to make sure that we were pleased with our meal.  I love personal touches like that.

The interior is tiny, but beautifully furnished and decorated.  Even the vintage desk where our efficient server entered our meal choices was gorgeous.

Next time, I'll definitely get more french toast to go.  Or I'll just get the chef/co-owner to come home with me!
author: Tamiko J.

description:
Yelp really needs to implement a half star system. I'd give this place a 3.5, but not quite a 4. 

Super cute and cozy little eatery.. I loved that it boasts fresh produce, Blue Bottle Coffee (in a french press!!), and a small menu (I hate when small restaurants try to do EVERYTHING.. I love that the menu is selective but good).

We started with mimosas (made with fresh squeezed oj -- even a little plup!).. then I danced between ordering the sweet French Toast & Flat Omelet, but last minute, chose the latter.. I knew I should have gone with my first instinct!! I had food envy the entire time!

The flat omelet had pesto, potatoes, chicken and asiago cheese. It was a bit uneventful and needed doses of crushed pepper and sea salt.. 

I'll give this cute place another shot to satisfy my taste buds, since everything else seemed so good & service was friendly.. upon seeing all the other reviews, I think the french toast might give me what I'm looking for.
author: Tammy S.

description:
To say that I was not impressed by Olea is an understatement.  First the "OK":
The food.  
It was just "OK".  To read some of the reviews here on Yelp I would have expected a gourmet wonderland that left me gasping for air on the shores of an ocean of gastronomic delight.  But no.  It was "OK".  Nothing exciting, nothing remarkable.  Just "OK".  The food was cooked "OK", and the flavors were "OK".  

Now for the "not so OK":
Pretension:
The whole restaurant reeked of pretentious assiness.  From the wait staff to some of the customers, I was just plain annoyed by the level of "look at me" and "I am so cool" that seemed to pervade the place.  Hint to wait staff:  Don't try to make cake sound overly fancy by calling it "Gateau" and affecting an air of "I am cool because I can use a French word and I must school you in cooking."  Desert was slightly less than "OK" as the cake was not so fresh and had a hockey-puck-like consistency.

Physical atmosphere:
It's a cute space, albeit a tad small (it's San Francisco, what can you do).  It was overly warm in the restaurant and at one point in the night apparently there was a mishap with one dish which quickly filled the restaurant with a heavy burnt smell, opening the front door for a few minutes would have cleared it out but apparently no one thought to do that.  Hint:  Fix your range hoods.  The little fans in the windows don't really cut it.

Plating:
Either get smaller plates or give bigger portions.  While I disagree with one of my companions on the size of the meat portion on the plate, I do agree that sides like fingerling potato's and squash etc are cheap and more of them would have gone a long way to making the plate look "fuller" without substantially increasing plate cost.

Price:
For the plate size and the food being "OK" at about $40 per person (without drinks) it's a bit high.  $14 for three rather small scallops on a bed of stuff (can't remember what it was outside of blood oranges) and then $17 for the undersized (when viewed on the large plate) hanger steak it should be more than just "OK."

Will I go back?  Honestly?  Probably not.  Sorry Olea, but I believe strongly in first impressions and as I said at the start of this review, I was not impressed.
author: Matt E.

description:
One of my favorite breakfast combinations anywhere is is french toast, a side of bacon, and coffee.  Olea happens to do this combo insanely well.

The challah french toast is amazing.  I prefer it to the french toast at Mama's, which is saying a lot.  It's a big portion, it's cooked and garnished appropriately, and it's oh-so-good.

My side of bacon wasn't crazy good, but it was certainly a cut above your run-of-the-mill bacon, and they gave a sizable amount.  It was cooked right, firm but not burnt to a crisp.

And the coffee, served in a french press, was the perfect compliment to this meal.  For some, this might not be ideal, as not everyone likes the the french press.  But good coffee is good coffee, whether it's press or drip, and they serve good coffee here.

Prices were reasonable, service was good, and the decor/atmosphere was pleasant.  I met a friend here for brunch on a Saturday around 11:00 or 11:30.  We didn't have to wait, which was nice although that might have been a rarity.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Joseph N.

description: What a cut little neighborhood brunch spot! I have to admit our waiter may be right when he said they had the best french toast in San Francisco. Perfectly moist with just the right amount of sweetness. There was no wait for brunch on a Saturday afternoon and the prices are reasonable (brunch items averaging about $11-12). I was also excited to see that they serve coffee from the Blue Bottle Coffee Company. Blue Bottle is known as the "Microroasters of organic and shade grown coffee". The coffee came in a french press for either 2 cups or 4 cups. The meal was very pleasant the the staff is extremeley attentive and friendly. I recommend this place if you are looking for a brunch place with some more creative options than the typical breakfast fare.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Olea serves food in that perfect little portion that makes you feel like you have self control, but doesn't leave you feeling cheated.

I had the salmon, which was about as perfectly cooked as salmon can be.  The salmon was not overpowered by the lightly seasoned bed of lentils it rested upon.  I ate it all and felt satisfied and healthy.

I feel like this was a meal I could have cooked at home myself, but not have done such a good job.  It was pure and simple and didn't have a million little weird ingredients to make it "fancy."  I wish there were more restaurants that strove to make elegant simple food with choice ingredients.  I will return, and next time, I'm trying the bread pudding!
author: Kara D.

description: I've been for many a brunch and dinner. The food is simple; straight forward; nothing you've never heard of but just delicious and satisfying. I had the Niman Ranch cheeseburger with crisp fries and a glass of Tempanillio (spelling pending). We walked in and practically had the place to ourselves. Not the case on weekends - they'll always be a brunch wait. Blue Bottle French available too.
author: Catherine C.

description: Expect a wait!! We were lucky to find parking on the street. The food is organic and locally used, if possible. They serve Blue Bottle Coffee too. The portions are quite large. I had the egg and tomato with bacon on Acme bread and a side salad. The eggs were perfectly looked and the bacon was nice and crunchy. If you don't like a lot of pork, you might not have too many options here.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I'm big on brunch so while I was visiting SF, my friend suggested we come here. We ordered french pressed coffee to start, which I prefer over drip coffee. It's usually stronger and has a nice kick to it. Olea's version goes down nice and smooth. :D

I ordered the french toast and it made me melt! If I'm ever back in town, I'm definitely stopping by again to savor in more french-toast-goodness.  They use hallah bread -- which is nice since it allows the flavors to seep through the entire piece of bread. *please drool here*
And it is garnished with fresh fruit (i got strawberries and raspberries) and cinnamon. 

Olea has a wonderful wait staff and I found the atmosphere to be very pleasant. It almost felt like you were eating in someone's home. Brownie points for the cozy decor. :)
author: Ellen C.

description:
Adorable little place up at the top of TenderKnob.  I yelped for [vegan brunch] and this turned up; I called and asked if they could do anything brunch-y for vegans, and they sounded not only accommodating but excited to help.  Worth the cab ride over -- they put together a quinoa/almond/peas/sumac-y thing that was just delicious for me, and my omnivorous friends appeared to love their prosciutto omelets.  They did'nt even mind that we scooted in there right before the kitchen closed.

Lots of lovely details: BlueBottle coffee which they serve in French presses; nice white cups & saucers for the coffee with pretty raw sugar cubes; walls painted olive on the lower half and white on the uppers.  Very small, but very cute.  The chef even made sure to ask that the vegan had liked her meal, and told me he'd always have something for the vegans.  I'll be back.  A great nook to know about!
author: Nori H.

description:
It's always sad when one of your regular joints closes its doors for good, but that's life in the city. When it happens, you can only hope that the next business to open in the same spot is a deserving successor. Maybe this is why some seemingly prime locations seem to be cursed - a favorite business shuts down, and then the locals eye each successive venture with suspicion, giving the owners the stink-eye at every opportunity and generally spreading ill will about the place.

In this case, I'm talking about the Red Door Cafe. It was a humble and charming place, with mismatching furniture and chipped pottery, but it was one of my favorite breakfast spots in the city because the food was good, parking spaces were generally plentiful, and I never had to contend with a line stretching around the block (rare in this city when you're talking about good breakfast on a Saturday or Sunday morning).

Anyway, this is a long way of introducing Olea, the successor to the Red Door. What it lacks in the Red Door's humility and charm, it more than makes up for with an obvious dedication to the fine details of breakfastry.

The menu is small and changes weekly - a thing I always love. The coffee is served in a French press for two or four people, and this is always a reliable way to make very good coffee. Juices are fresh squeezed. The bread and other baked items are fantastic, and the main courses are carefully crafted and perfectly prepared.

As a bonus, parking is still pretty easy, and there's not usually any line at all.
author: Shawn S.

description:
Definitely underwhelmed.  I actually came here a few weeks ago when there weren't as many yelp reviews.  Based on what I had read, I was prepared for the meal of a lifetime.  

Maybe it was high expectations, but I was not blown away but the fantastic organic fare or other details of the restaurant.  We were first tipped off to the inexperience of our waitress when she proceeded to pour us each a FULL wine glass of wine.  I'm talking almost to the brim of the large glass.  We asked a couple questions about ingredients on the menu and she didn't seem to be familiar with them.  Slightly disappointing when there are only a few appetizers and entrees to remember.  

I was prepared for the small portions (and boy, they weren't kidding about that!) and the tight quarters.  I'd only recommend this place for couples or small, well-mannered groups since the atmosphere is definitely quiet and more reserved (due to the fact that there are only about 6 tables in the whole place).  

The food was good.  But just good.  I've had other organic, locally-grown meals that far surpassed this.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
Olea is my favorite brunch place in SF.  Everything I order here is amazing and the service is great.  I recommend this place to all of my friends.  I took my friend from LA here once and now everytime he is back in the city, we HAVE to come to Olea.

A few of my favorite things to order for brunch.
French Toast
Pulled Pork

I can't wait to try this place out for dinner.
author: Elsa H.

description:
If you want your taste buds to go absolutely crazy, then go here for brunch and order the Challah French Toast. I did that once and it made my taste buds spin.
Now when we go here (quite regularly, but we try to be there before 10am), I usually get the veggie omelet. It's always, always delicious.
(No, the French Toast did not get less tasty, I just try to avoid white bread when I can)
Blue Bottle coffee in French Presses, but unfortunately no decaf.
author: Alexandra D.

description: What a great place! Super cute, the atmosphere is so cozy! Cazuela egg bake was so delicious. The texture of the eggs are amazing. The sauce was incredibly flavorful. My husband had the challah french toast which he said was also delicious. He let me have his fresh strawberries that came with it, wonderfully ripe. Everyone was so friendly making for a relaxing and fun experience.
author: Laura S.

description:
The host lied to us!  He said 30 minutes wait, but turned into more than an hour.  I guess I shouldn't blame him.  It is not his fault when people lingers for a long time after they are done eating, knowing other people are waiting for a table.  How inconsiderate!  I was hungry and needed to be fed.  The host was so funny, told us to stare at the table so they'll get the hint and leave.

Besides the wait, everything was great.  One of us ordered the omelet with lentils.  It was very refreshing and light.  The serving size was just right, different from the other omelets, full of artery clogging cheeses and non-creative ingredients.  I had the custard toast with sprinkles of cinnamon and fresh berries, aka fancy french toast.  Yum!   Did I mention the mimosas are strong?  By the end of our brunch, 3 girls were giggling nonstop.
author: Muncia S.

description:
We had brunch at Olea this past Saturday & really enjoyed it. 

WAIT: There was none. We ended up getting there before they opened at 9:30 because we were unsure of how crazy the line would be (last week's trip to Brenda scarred us, I guess). Turns out there was no line... in fact, they were still seating people immediately when we left about 10:30.

FOOD: The wife and I shared two dishes. The challah French toast was quite possibly the best French toast I've ever had in my life (wife agreed). It was sweet, but not overly so, and had a delicious custardy inside. I'm salivating thinking about it! The eggs baked in a cazuela were fairly tasty, but needed a bit of salt (better under-salted than over-salted, of course). Also, I wish the "stew" part had been a bit thicker... it was more like chicken soup with poached eggs than what I had imagined. The coffee in a press and fresh-squeezed orange juice were great!

AMBIENCE: It's an adorable little space. It was getting close to full by the time we left, but the noise volume was not at all painful (again I show my scars from Brenda's).

SERVICE: Mostly good, with a few misses. On the plus side, our waitress was friendly, attentive, and efficient. The first miss was that they didn't let us in until about 9:35--we and another couple were waiting outside in the cold, windy morning & it would've been nice if they had opened the doors a tad early (or at least on time!). 

The second miss didn't affect us directly, but I'll relate it here in the hopes of encouraging the staff at Olea to be a little more flexible. After they finally opened the door, the wife and I snagged the 2-top farthest from the door, and the other couple went to sit at a 3-top even farther from the door. One of the staff asked them to choose one of the 2-tops, which would be reasonable if they were at all busy, but they weren't. So the other couple somewhat reluctantly sat at one of the remaining 2-tops closer to the *open* front door. Of course, like 15 minutes later, the 2-tops were all full and the host promptly sat two people at that same 3-top. So it was kinda dumb to hassle the couple who showed up early and waited in the frickin' cold.

The last miss was that our waitress helpfully brought us a couple of plates to help split the food, but one had old cheese stuck to it, which was gross (it was stacked under a clean plate, so she didn't see it).

OVERALL: A delicious and (mostly) pleasant experience. With 2 entrees, small coffee press, and small juice, it was $42 with tax and tip. We'll definitely go back sometime to see what other yumminess the chef has whipped up.
author: James K.

description:
If you like coffee this is the place to have brunch. Personal french press for every table with steaming hot fresh everything. 

The service is extremely nice and the place never feels hectic since it has so few tables. The french toast is slabalicious, the egg and bacon sandwich sublime, and I am not a breakfast person but I'd go back there any time. Excited to try lunch and dinner now. Shhhhh!
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Solid 4.5 stars!

We arrived on a Saturday morning a little after 10 a.m. and didn't have to wait at all! It pays off to wake up "early" on the weekend and walk 10 blocks for breakfast :)

Absolutely the best french toast I've ever had, although they called it Challah Custard toast with fresh berries and cinnamon. It was soft, gooey, and the berries and cinnamon complemented the eggy bread perfectly. The flat omlette wasn't as good, so if you enjoy sweet things in the morning, don't even bother looking at the menu...GET THE CHALLAH TOAST!

I also tried the oh-so-chic Blue Bottle coffee, which honestly wasn't that impressive, nor was it worth nearly $5 dollars. I'm not a coffee connosieur and perhaps the milk "spoiled" the true taste of the coffee, but I couldn't taste anything special!

Good service and a quaint, inviting space that allows a peak at the chef at work. My only gripe was that I was given my latte in a glass cup, meant for water or soda. The cofee was so hot that I couldn't even hold on to the cup long enough to sip! Still, they were nice enough to give me a teacup to pour it into...strange!
author: Sherry R.

description:
Had Olea for brunch this past weekend and I was pleasantly surprised.  The staff is super friendly and super accommodating which makes any dining experience that much better.  Our party tried a good selection of items from the menu and I had a taste of all of them ... the verdict?  Yum!  Bacon?  Yum!  Blue bottle coffee?  Yum!  Although I think it's pretty hard to mess up brunch food, Olea felt cozy and warm like I was eating at home on my kitchen table.

I haven't been out for brunch in a long time (I've been spending $50 at Whole Foods for brunch ingredients recently) and I'm glad my return wasn't disappointing.
author: James F.

description: I love this place, it's cozy and serves healthy  and delicious meals elegantly. And if you are not a customer who appreciates elegance or style - take note loud self centered nob hill princesses - have your pancakes elsewhere.
author: Carron O.

description: Went here for brunch. We really wanted to try the pork sandwich but it was sold out.  We got the egg sandwich and french toast instead.  I'm not a big fan of French toast but these were really quite creamy, custardy and oh so yummy! Olea is a solid 3 stars but I'm not sure it is so wow that I'd wait in line for a long time to eat here...
author: Mao K.

description:
I am one of those neighborhood people that hated the Red Door (read my review).  And I haven't been extremely impressed with many of the restaurants in my 'hood.  So I wasn't exactly optimistic about Olea.  Granted the first week it opened, I kept taking peeks at the interior every time I went by and was impressed with the look.  I found myself reading any new review of Olea on yelp, waiting for some nasty review or at least less than stellar review.  But that never happened, so I finally made reservations last night and decided to find out for myself  about this new neighborhood restaurant.

It is Great!!!  They are not trying to be everything to everyone.  The menu was simple, the wine list was simple, and the decor was simple.  Simple but by no means plain.  A truly wonderful addition to the neighborhood!  I will definitely be back :)

UPDATE: Well, not really but I just have to comment on some of the other reviewers....Are you serious when you compare Olea to The Red Door Cafe?! The Red Door was ...and please pardon my french,  complete Shit!! Now, I have been to Nob Hill Grille several times at different times of the day...good ...not great and definitely not as good as Olea....Sorry people!
author: Amanda P.

description:
Very mediocre.  

The entree sizes were laughable.  Seriously, we all laughed when they arrived.  The lamb was tasty, but it was literally four bites!!  I had to pause in between each bite to avoid finishing it in 2 minutes.  They were actually out of a few of the items that had come recommended, so that was disappointing.  

Our waitress wasn't knowledgeable about the menu and didn't know how to pour a glass of wine; she filled it all the way to the top every time!  In fact, we had to ask her to stop filling up our glasses and let us pour it ourselves.  

The restaurant is quiet and intimate, definitely more ideal for a date than a group dinner.  

I'd have a hard time recommending Olea.
author: Brian H.

description: The most amazing and unique French toast I have ever had. I loved their challah French toast topped with cinnamon sugar, fresh strawberries, and Vermont maple syrup. The dough was soft and chewy like a mix between bread and croissant, and the batter coating the bread was sweet and light. I devoured the entire plate happily. I also tried my friend's blue bottle coffee and eggs...equally delicious. Only had a 15 min wait for a table for two on a Saturday afternoon! Would love to come back again soon!
author: Joyce H.

description:
Three words: CHALLAH FRENCH TOAST. Thick slices of challah bathed in custard cinnamon magic, cooked golden to perfection! The fruit toppings often change (strawberries, pears...) The dishes change frequently so I always like to try something new as well and split the french toast as it is VERY rich. 

The place is small and occasionally a line extends up the hill but I have never waited longer than 20 minutes. The wait staff is pleasant and attentive, especially with those free Blue Bottle coffee refills...I stumble out on a bright afternoon heavily caffeinated and with a happy belly.
author: Jesse L.

description: Another great find thanks to Yelp! Loved the food here - I tried the scrambled eggs on roll with tomato and my husband tried the migas con huevos - food tasted fresh and eggs were delicious. I'm a big fan of Blue Bottle coffee and loved the French press option here! Cozy ambience, service could be a bit faster. Only peeve is that the menu is limited, especially a bit of a dampener if you don't eat meat but want to eat scrambled eggs, there's not too much they can offer.
author: Shweta V.

description:
My husband's a bit of a foodie, which means we occasionally splurge on some really fancy restaurants... and I have to admit, I don't get the appeal.  I'm sure I've had some "extremely good" meals, but $50 entrees never taste THAT much better than $20 ones.
Olea's on the $20 side, and the meals are always incredibly delicious, if not better than the fancier places!  Every time I go, I am surprised by some flavor combination, and impressed with the food quality.  It is one of my absolute favorite restaurants in the city.
No matter what it is, you must get the flatbread appetizer - the flavors change every week, but they're consistently fabulous!  Beyond that, just order based on the first 3 words... I never recognize all the nouns in the description, but once it shows up, I don't remember what they were anyway.  All I know is it tastes amazing!!
author: Alison M.

description:
I love this place. The brunch is excellent esp the changing -always delicious baked eggs! But today all the dishes when I was there came out with rosemary Focaccia which is not on the menu. 
If you are going to substitute breads let the customer know please so we can make a decision on the dish. 
I really did not love the egg sandwich with rosemary bread. 
At least I was not completely bummed like the guy who ordered the pulled pork with slaw served on Rosemary Focaccia/. Yuck.
I understand it was late on a Sunday but you have to mention something that will completely change the flavor of the dish.
 I would have gotten my usual baked eggs instead of finally trying the egg sandwich!
The special hot sauce was really good this week which gave an extra star.
author: Susan M.

description:
Arguably, one of the best brunch experiences in the city. Go for the French toast and the fruit salad. The yogurt with figs and honey. No, really. You will be surprised. Even the basic stuff is delicious.

The place is small, cozy, intimate. The coffee is top class (Made in Blue Bottle). Portions emphasize quality over quantity. The menu is both eclectic and essential and pretty much everything on the list is ace. 

The staff is friendly and amiable, like good old friends from high school that nowadays you only see on FaceBook. If you feel like sharing a conversation, you can sit at the big communal table right at the entrance and discuss the day you were fighting with Che. 

The atmosphere is classy without being pretentious. A lovely place.

Warning: can become addictive.
author: Matt B.

description: We're from foodie city Portland OR where restaurant expectations, especially for neighborhood cuisine, are exceedingly high.  Olea did not disappoint!  While in SF for leisure, having read the rave reviews, we checked it out for a Friday morning breakfast, making sure to arrive promptly upon opening at 10am.  The first ones there, we were greeted warmly and seated by one of the many windows which makes the daylight basement location seem inviting.  Soon all of the tables were full, and the scene was in full swing.  We had the baked eggs special-of-the-house and the pulled pork, which they graciously agreed to serve without the bun (there are no substitutions as a house rule).  Both were flavorful and pleasing, though average portions, but who's complaining.  The owner, who works the tables himself, confided that his second favorite city is Portland.  What's not to like about that?
author: Ellen T.

description:
I think they bill their fare as California/Mediterranean.  I had this wonderful baked egg dish (you'll see it on the menu) and since we have both chickens and eggs in Calfornia, as well as in the Mediterranean countries, I guess they bill themselves correctly.  :)  The bread was fresh and homemade and simply perfect.  I don't typically eat much breads, but oh oh oh, don't pass it by.  My dish also came with a little salad that tasted of the fresh organic of the backyard garden-grown variety.  You could just taste the freshness.

My absolute favorite touch was the french press coffee pot at table.  Nothing as perfect as a cup of french pressed in the morning with the full pure flavor and aroma of great coffee with the glisten of the bean oil floating faintly on the surface.  mmm mmm mmm - heavenly.  I am just a breath away on this side of the thin veil of imagination of being able to really smell it.  It's lingering in my mind no doubt.  

The space is on the (super) small side but if you are patient or can get right in, jump on it.  This is truly a cute little gem of a joint with a super simple menu and very fresh fresh fresh ingredients.  Not to be passed by.  I spyed the dinner menu and really want to swing by one evening to give it a sampling.  I am suspecting there won't be any disappointment. 

The menu (both brunch and dinner) was nice and simple and straight up.  Nice friendly service and considering the space, they were very mindful of not being too in your face every second.
author: Kathleen K.

description:
Oh my gosh!
Everyone must try this place!
Everything I've eating here is a party in mouth!
You can definitely tell all the ingredients are fresh!
I ordered the amazing quinoa (vegan) entree and my cousin ordered the duck.  I'm a cook and i don't know how the chef managed to make quinoa taste so incredible- what's the secret?!
For dessert we ordered the chocolate moose with sea salt- which has been my new favorite  combo lately.  
The chef/owner really is talented-  He's so great at combine seasonal ingredients to make mouth watering flavors!  He even came to our table to see if we were enjoying everything. 
Our server was great and very attentive.  He could also answer all our questions about what was in the dishes.
The portion sizes are perfect- you leave feeling satisfied not stuffed- the way it should be.
I'll definitely keep coming back!
author: Claudine D.

description:
ehh. meh.

And I really wanted to like it.  I really did.  Came here for brunch, and this place was adorable in its 6 table glory.  But sadly, the food was nothing great.  I had their special "cazuela."  This tomato based egg dish with pulled pork.  It was different and that made it special.  However, the general lack of salt was just unacceptable.  It had more of a tomato soup esque thing happening.  Sadly, the dish made me sad.  It also came w/ two crostinis.. which just isn't enough.  So when my friend asked for more (she ordered the same thing), the lady then gave us an order of various toast, which also came with just 1 crostini.  So fail on that.  But I guess we got some challah toast.

My other friend had the omelet, that seemed ok. She ate most of it.  The menu changes weekly, so maybe this was an off week for them.

I will say their french fries were perfectly crisped.  Sadness, would I be back?  Maybe not.  With so many great places to eat, why give it another chance.

On the side note, the french toast looked like the popular thing to order. So I guess, stay with the trend and get what they are good at.  Savory just wasn't it for us.
author: Natalie G.

description:
Olea is such a cute and hidden surprise in my hood. Loved how warm and cozy it felt, even on a busy street like California with the cable car passing by. 

Based on the reviews from my fellow Yelpers, I followed their recommendations and sampled breakfast/lunch with the braised BBQ pork shoulder sandwich and the egg sandwich. The best part? Their french-pressed Blue Bottle coffee! It's soooo good. 

I like this brunch place as another option to my other neighborhood favs - Nook and Boulangerie. Olea does a great job reinterpreting the brunch basics in their menu which makes for a tasty, but not heavy meal.
author: Karen L.

description:
Very cute, but they failed my first try.  I may go back to check it out, but if they mess up again I'm out.

The menu is VERY limited, and the choices aren't logical.  So they had 2 shellfish apps, 2 vegetarian apps, and not much else.  For entrees they had a vegan dish, a pork dish, a duck dish, a burger, and a cod dish.  The duck dish was out by the time we got there for our reservations at 8.  It was the only dish that looked good.

Already disappointed, my boyfriend and I shared the burger and the scallops app, our companions had the cod and the pulled pork.  The pulled pork was boring...just pork on polenta, neither of which were that good, and nothing else.  The cod was okay.  The burger was nice, but tiny on a huge bun.  It just didn't work.  Who doesn't offer poultry other than game?  What if I kept kosher but needed meat?  I'd be screwed if the duck was gone and I didn't want a $15 burger that wouldn't fill me up.

The service was weird.  The guy would come over and bring us something, turn around, and literally turn right back around in two seconds and ask us how it was.  Very distracting and annoying.  

We were really disappointed.  The owner is really nice, though, and I wish him the best of luck.  I'll go back if the menu looks appetizing and give it another shot.
author: Monika M.

description:
Olea approaches breakfast the way many places approach dinner -- small portions of expensive, extremely tasty food. This is such a badly thought out and misguided approach to breakfast that I have difficulty putting it into words. EPIC FAIL, I guess.

$10.95 for two pieces of French toast with a tiny ramekin of strawberries? Give me a break.

They get one extra star for serving me tasty coffee in my own mini (but not tiny) French press.

Never going back.
author: Dan S.

description: Great spot!!! Worth the wait! Service was friendly and food was delicious. I highly recommend the french toast and cazuela. Perfect brunch :)
author: Marisa S.

description:
My brother picked this place for brunch on Sunday, I had never heard of it, but I will definitely be coming back.

We got lucky and the 4 of us were seated at their communal table right away (the people who came after us didn't look like they waited much more than 15 minutes which I think is beyond reasonable for a tasty brunch place).

Our server was SO nice, you could tell she really enjoyed working there and was really enthusiastic about the menu. I had this egg coszuela ( poached eggs in this amazing salsa-y sauce made with all these different spices topped with homemade tortilla strips and baked in a clay pot thingy) and my husband had the challah custard cinnamon french toast. Everything was SO fresh tasting, you can tell they really use only the best ingredients. 

Apparently they serve dinner also, I can't wait to try that too.
author: Carson H.

description:
So delicious. I came here last weekend with 6 others, half of whom don't live in the city, and it was the perfect San Franciscan spot  to enjoy - its local, seasonal, sustainable bit was perfectly indicative of why I love our restaurants here.

Given the quality of the food, it was so refreshing to be in an uncrowded, quiet setting on a Saturday night. We took up the communal table, and there were only another 3 parties of 2 the entire night. Actually, for such a charming place, I sort of wished they had more diners!

I had a spectacular short rib over a bed of polenta. The two ribs were huge pieces and fell off the bone. They were fork tender and quite flavorful. I usually don't like polenta, but there was something so buttery about this one that I nearly finished it off. The sugar snap peas on the side were a bit soggy and seemed like an afterthought, but that's ok because I looked at it more as a pretty green garnish. 

Our table ordered the Syrah and prosecco, both of which was just lovely. Oh, and backtracking - we were served warm bread to start (warm! I love that touch) with a nice olive oil. 

The service was wonderful as well - our server was Ryan (well, the only server on duty that night) and he was very knowledgeable of the menu and attentive to our table. I think I liked him even more because he knew the wine maker of my favorite winery.

Why 4 stars? Well, for one I'm trying not to give all my Yelp reviews blanket 5 stars. The final tab was on the pricier end. I also wasn't completely in love with my appetizer, a mushroom flatbread, although I do recognize that may be because I'm a soft and chewy person rather than a crispy...and uh, flat...person. And, nothing in the dessert selection really blew any of us away, so we opted out of dessert.

Anyway, all in all, I highly recommend Olea. It's a good date spot too, for those of you looking for one. I can't wait to try it for brunch!
author: serena l.

description:
Food was ok. I had the Pork pulled sandwich and wife had the French toast. My sandwich was 6/10 and the french toast felt like it was a little undercooked. But what was good about this place is the french press coffee which was just great! Service was pretty good as well. 

The place is very small so we had to wait for about 30 mins for a table on a Sunday. When we finally got a table we were not too happy about sharing our table with another person. They made a lady site right next to us and it was like we were having brunch with her. They only have a few tables so expect to share.
author: Kaushick N.

description:
Yes, that's right! "As good as it gets!"
Not quite sure if it was the intimate, petite atmosphere that we embellished or the exquisite yet, select menu we encountered. By "select" I mean, the chef changes the menu weekly, if not daily. He creates his menu around the fresh veggies, herbs and delicacies he finds at the farmers market. I couldn't tell you what to order  because it changes everyday! And I must say, everything is lovely.
Dinner was so enchanting, we decided to come back for breakfast!
Big on coffee and french toast: french press and brioche french....hmmmmmmmm....I want it now!
In addition, the kitchen is wide open and the chef is present, how convenient to thank him! And the server was nothing but the best as well!
Think i'll make it a point to go to Olea every time I hit the city!
author: Monique C.

description: I love the simple clean taste of the food offered here.  I have been here several times now and pretty much enjoyed everything that I have ordered.  Lately I have really been into their brunches and as you can see I am not the only one!   One of my favorite brunch dishes is the Huevos en Cazuela, a baked egg dish.  I pretty much get it every time I go for brunch because they seem to do it differently each time, and each time it's fabulous.  I haven't tried the french toast which everyone is raving about (because I always get the Huevos en Cazuela!!!) but must try it the next time I am in.   Blue bottle coffee is a big bonus!
author: Gordon S.

description:
Dinner serves a great burger, epic quinoa and everything in-between. The pork shoulder leaves no room for improvement, save more bites. Atmosphere makes for the perfect 'hey nice but low-key' date spot.

Brunch is unbeatable - try the Umbrian Faro Salad if you're a foodie. Blue Bottle french press is always a plus.

Water snobs will stoked that they serve Lauratana. It's the best!
author: Josh G.

description:
Olea knows how to make you happy.

The service was gracious but not overattentive, the prices are fine, and the food, all of it, was right on the dime--perfectly planned, cooked, seasoned and presented. For a predictably great meal under $50, only Wood Tavern in the East Bay gives Olea a run for its money.
author: Denny S.

description:
I really want to love this place because it's local and it's cute, but the food is just so mediocre.  I tried it for both brunch and dinner and came away disappointed both times.  Maybe I made the wrong choices in ordering,  but the food seemed less exciting than something I could make myself.  

For brunch, I shared the mushroom and goat cheese omelet, which was okay, and the egg dish in the clay pot , which simply consisted of eggs over easy in tomato sauce and a few nondescript spices.   For dinner, I shared the flatbread appetizer with chickory/goat cheese/etc., which was good, then had the burger for my entree, which came completely unadorned - no lettuce, tomato, onion etc.  Just bun, burger and cheese.  Overall, the food is too simple and boring for a place that looks so cute and charming.
author: E. C. P.

description:
I have visited several times because I really want to like it.

Breakfast is good but just good. Portions small.  I like that they use local and organic ingredients and serve Blue Bottle coffee.

Food is very simple and elegant but perhaps a bit too simple. I feel like most of the dishes I can make myself after a trip to the farmers market.
