I don't consider myself a big eater but after ordering the french toast for breakfast I was a little sad. Super small portion with a teaspoon of ricotta next to it. After paying ( $8?) for it i did not feel like ordering a egg to supplement my meal. 

Dinner:
Me and three friends came for dinner. We spent over $200 dollars on drinks and a good (but small) meal. We were there for about a hour and as soon as we signed the bill I felt like we were being stared down by everyone working there. Seriously, there were 4 other open tables. Its not like we were hogging all the space. It turned a otherwise pleasant meal into something that's been bugging me for weeks.
author: jammie F.

description:
very cute neighborhood restaurant.  this review is for brunch only:
On a cloudy morning, my friend visited me.  I want to show her what she missed out for moving out of the city, i took her to Olea, which is down the street from me.  Hey, what a pleasant surprise, they serve blue bottle coffee here!  We had french toast and baked egg in a casuela, and boy, they are excellent!!! Olea, i will come back for dinner very soon!
author: Sophia L.

description:
It was a lucky morning when my SF travel companion and I walked past Olea and saw the crowds waiting outside.  "This is a place we should probably try," one of us decided, and so we went back the next day, bright and early. Yes, Olea is tiny and if you don't go first thing there will be a wait.  But what do you expect?  It's cozy and delicious!  

All you need to know is: order the french toast (everyone around us was getting it too) and coffee drinkers get blue bottle in a french press (2 or 4 cup).   SO GOOD.  The room is simple, full of light (for being a few steps down), and welcoming, with friendly service used to the descending brunching crowds.  If I lived in SF I'd be here every weekend.
author: Monica M.

description:
I had what I call a "fancy mcmuffin" here. Scrambled eggs with bacon on artisanal bread with tomatoes. Oh my god, it was perfect. Great with salt and pepper (although I wish I didn't have to ask for pepper from the server). 

Also, no drip coffee, only french press for two, but it is delicous!
author: Netty L.

description:
You'd miss this place if 1) you weren't 3 feet tall or 2) you weren't checking out all the street numbers for the restaurant.  You'd have to walk a few steps down from street level to the "in-law" restaurant, else you'd miss this charming little place.

I was all hyped up to try brunch here because it'd been written up highly by other yelpers.  While I agree their service was great and I loved the fact that there was no wait, I was a little disappointed by my eggs baked in a cazuela.  The tomato sauce was hearty, but the egg had been baked a little too long so that it was tough and a bit chewy.  Plus it was expensive for what it was, given how humble the dish was.
author: Janet L.

description:
So good! My boy and I went last night for dinner with four other friends and we had a great time! For apps we just ordered a couple for the table to share. The flatbread was delicious, really yummy with the cheese and fruit. The mussels and scallops were also amazing. 

For my entree I ordered the duck, and I was really impressed! It was served over this yummy purple sweet potato and was just perfect! Our server was very nice and professional...we all had a great time!

I'm so lucky to live nearby, I can't wait to try their breakfast and lunch!
author: Zoe W.

description:
Brunch is wow!

eggs baked in a cazuela with tomato sauce, basil, and cracked wheat toast - was off the hook.  ok, i guess i'm a sucker for runny eggs.  tomato sauce was very very light.  basil was fresh and vibrant.  imagine huevos rancheros deconstructed.   but better!!!

challah custard toast with korintji cinnamon sugar and fresh yerena farms berries - was a wow +5.  perfectly french-ed toast with tender 'flan' custard embedded into the Texas size toast.  generously sprinkled with mild spice 'sinnamon', this oh-so-yummy-dip-me-in-thick-warm-sizzurp was off the charts.  THIS IS A MUST ORDER.

the blue bottle french pressed coffee was a lovely touch.  super strong so  if you're participating in the Milton Bradley "Operation" tournament in the PM, opt for the orange juice.  i had the shakes for hours.

the quaint intimate below-street-level spot made it feel warm and private.  seats 5 two-seater tables and one 8 person communal table for big parties.  server was way awesome - patient and professional.

be prepared to wait - no reservations unless over 5 guests.

definitely coming back here for some yum fun.
author: Isaac L.

description: I got the french toast and it was delicious! The wait was around 20 minutes though, which is why it didn't get 5 stars. But overall, it was good brunch
author: Amanda L.

description:
Wow, this place is great! They have a wonderful revolving, seasonal menu. The service is great AND they serve Blue Bottle coffee! The space is a little small so probably not ideal for large groups and we did have to wait for about 20 minutes for our two top...but definitley worth the wait. 

I have not been here for dinner yet-looking forward to trying it sometime!
author: Casf K.

description:
The service was great.  The flatbread was tasty. The restaurant was totally quiet (Tuesday ---- recession).  Our food was made to order and there is an exposed kitchen so we could see our chefs working on our food.

The shrimp appetizer and pear salad which I made into a dinner was delicious, not too much spice in the aioli for the shrimp and the salad had a nice variety of locally grown greens.

The BF had the halibut which was "moist, fluffy, flavorful and delicious"

Great presentation on the food as well.

It would have been nice to see a few other patrons, but it was also nice to have the whole place to ourselves.

Should have stayed for the cheesecake...that will have to be for next time.

Cute, quaint little place.
author: Erik K.

description:
- 30 min wait (I know it was around 12:30 pm on a Sunday, but still, I'm a hungry girl). The bf and I walked around Polk to pass the time, so it was not so bad.

-/+ Small or intimate dining space, depending on your disposition--makes for a long wait. Super cutesie nonetheless. Bright, pristine and clean, but in a cozy way, if that makes any sense. 

+ SUPER friendly staff! The host was AMAZING (I think he was one of the owners too)--amicable and charming, in a genuine manner too. I LOVE such personal service. These people know that the food is only half of the battle when making for a great dining experience.

+ Brunch menu was small but had lots of variety (i.e. eggs, a burger, french toast, etc.)

+ CHALLAH FRENCH TOAST (challah challah challah!)--need I say more?!?! 2 pieces dipped in custard and garnished with yummy strawberries. I ate one slice there and saved the other for a snack while watching the playoffs--I knew I'd want to savor the goodness again later. Good at room temp too!

+ French fries - The bf ordered the burger, which came w/ a heaping side of fries. I'm not usually a fan of fries, but these were good. Not over-fried. Not greasy. Lightly salted and seasoned. Crispy. Yum! The burger was definitely on the small side, so if you're cravin' a BIG, HONKIN', all-American burger, don't expect one here.

Cutsie place. Fresh tasting food (indulgent but doesn't leave you feeling like a total glutton somehow--how do they do it?). Great service. Will def come back, but either earlier or later (past 1 pm).
author: Kristine W.

description: Been enjoying Olea for a few months after a friend suggested it for brunch. The small space usually means there is a bit of a wait, but it's never too long and the food makes it worth it. Most of the standard items on the brunch menu are consistently well prepared, even when some of the ingredients change depending on what's fresh locally. I recommend Olea without reservations to anyone willing to listen, and look forward to my next visit.
author: Ryan M.

description: My girlfriend and I came here right before the rush.  Thank goodness because the wait would of been half an hour or so due to the popularity of this neighborhood restaurant.  We got there at 10:30 am on a Sunday and we were seated right away.  We looked over the menu and it took us about 15 minutes to decide on our order because the other items on the menu sounded so good.  Once we finally ordered and took a bite of our dishes we were not disappointed.  We shared the challah crusted toast and the eggs baked in cazuela tomato sauce.  Both dishes were delicious!  The place is very warm and enviting.  It's like eating in your moms kitchen.  So I will be going back here and often.
author: Eileen B.

description: This is a review about dinner - it is freaking delicious. I've come to the point where I start to crave it if I haven't had it in awhile. I LOVE the quinoa bowl, and the pork chop dish is excellent. This has become one of our go-to places for dinner now. Yay Olea!
author: Jan R.

description: Everything that's wrong with SF.  40 minute wait on sidewalk aside obnoxious signs barking rules at you (no outside coffee, no pager system, stand on this inch of the sidewalk, reminders that you'll be booted if party incomplete, etc.).  Waitress was your typical faux liberal bohemian snob who takes your order passively instead of proactively (blank look instead of "what would you like?").  Then you look at the menu and there are more offensive and outlandish rules barked at you (no deletions or substitutions, etc.) and only like 4 plates to choose from.  My GF pointed out that my water glass had leftover lipstick on it, we had to ask for new glasses.  Waitress mumbled.  Hair in my food (seriously). My smoked chicken dish had these lame cruton things and fritos in it and included chicken sausage like from those ones they sell at safeway in packs of five.  As we were leaving I watched the dilbert doorman make an entering patron dump his coffee out into a bucket, as if that made the patron more likely to buy more coffee from this place.  Do me a favor goosestepping mediocre bohemian snobs -bulldoze your cafe and go back to designing hipster glasses in the mission.  I'll take my money to a place that earns its customers and soars beyond mediocrity.
author: Anon A.

description:
Went there Saturday night for a great meal.  The appetizer of grapes, chicory with ricotta and flatbread is a great starter.  Really a good dish.  My companion had the day boat scallops which were cooked perfectly and very flavorful.  I had the vegan farro and escarole, which we both liked a lot.  The atmosphere is simple, charming and intimate.

Service was great, Ryan our server was all over us (but not too much).

Not cheap but not expensive either, relative to other San Francisco restaurants of their class.  My price rating at $$$ includes wine; would be $$ without.  By the way, the wine list is short, and the choices are very reasonably priced.  I think that the priciest bottle was around $50.  Our total bill for two with tip was around $110, including a bottle of wine.

We'll go again.
author: Dick B.

description:
I think Olea might be my new favorite restaurant in the neighborhood.  We came here on a weeknight and I had made a reservation anyways just because I hate waiting around.  We were greeted as soon as we walked in and shown to our table- throughout the meal the service was excellent.  Our waiter explained every course that came out and each course was perfectly timed so we weren't sitting there without food for more then about 10 seconds.

We ended up getting the grilled shrimp with black rizo to start with and it was tender on the inside and crisp on the outside-delish.  I ended up getting their vegan entree which was butternut squash with toasted sesame seeds and barley and I loved it, and I usually am a meat and potatoes kind of person but was feeling the butternut squash that night.  My friend had their  rock cod with lentils and it was also very very good.  We shared their three layer cheese cake (chocolate, walnut, and regular cheesecake) and they brulee'd the top which gives them extra points right there.

Overall this was a very enjoyable dining experience, the service was very attentive and polite and the food was amazing but not at a whole paycheck price.  At one point we had a question about feta cheese that our waiter wasn't sure about so he asked the chef for us (we weren't even eating feta cheese we were just discussing it).  Not to mention that our waiter was a Patriots fan and talked football with us too.  

I can't wait to come back and try their brunch.
author: Tanu R.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped in after a long walk looking for places to eat.  We wanted a decent meal but nothing too fancy.  And right where the Red Door used to be awaited our new favorite restaurant in our NobHill/Russian Hill neighborhood!!!

Try the Pork Chops they are grilled to perfection and the sauce brought out the juicy pork, which we normally do not eat! 

The service is also not hoighty toighty, but just right.

LOVE IT
author: Susan K.

description:
Or maybe 2-1/2.  The French toast was perfect, served with strawberries and lots of real maple syrup.  But everything else.....bleh.  I ordered the "cazuela" which supposedly was an egg on top of ground meat and white beans with tomato sauce.  Couldn't find any meat (should have sent it back) and there were maybe 10 beans?    And the "toast" that came with it was like 2 pieces of dry Melba toast.  At $12+ I expect a little more/better.

On the other hand, the coffee and service were quite good.
author: Ann T.

description:
This is my favorite weekend breakfast place in SF.  Parts of the menu change weekly, but the food is always good.  The french toast is the best I've ever had.  It is even better than my dad's french toast (sorry dad).  

I also really like the servers and the staff.  Always friendly.

There is sometimes a wait, but it is always worth it.
author: Lexi B.

description:
I came to Olea with hopes of something better and I left with the same hopes.  I wasn't let down by the experience exactly, but there are many things I hope will be better next time.

This upscale simple organic fair is a little too simple for its price and like my not-so-fond experience at Chez Panisse, it feels they are resting on their organic laurels too much.  I came with a Olean neighbor who had really liked her first experience, which gives me hope for entrees we didn't try that night, but the two we did were too underwhelming.

I ordered the quail ($16.50) which was a very small quail a top bed of fingerling potatoes and scrumptious honey.  While generally potatoes are too starchy to get me as excited as my potato head friends, these were lovely.  They were quite soft and the honey was one of the best I had.  As an appetizer, this would have satiated me with its simplicity, bit the quail centerpiece offered little to be excited about in its little quail frame.  It was a little too reminiscent of chicken and was seasoned in a way that remind me of reasonably good chicken legs from the oven, though not the kind of potent flavor that makes you cherish every little bite.

My friend's yellowtail ($18.5) was the opposite.  The three pieces of yellowtail were scrumptious.  The meat was flaky and tender and well seasoned, but quite small.  This would have been OK if they were paired with something tasty, but instead they weren't on a bed of black eyed peas that were far from fergilicious.  While they had a very thin and earthy sauce, they never let you forget "we're beans, only beans, don't expect too much".

The menu changes often which means that next time my options will probably be different and hopefully better, though with only five entrees, being disappointed in two is not the best of records.

The waiter was charming and knowledgeable about the food and wine and recommended the Syrah ($9), which was smooth and slightly chocolatey, though a little flabby.  We also ordered the three layer cheesecake ($8) dessert which was more enjoyable and an interesting take on cheesecake, which though it can come in 50 flavors, somehow always feels too familiar.

I will probably be back because this place is so close to a friend's place, but if dining were like speed dating, Olea would inevitably have to be cut.  We'll see on visit number 2.

And if you don't go to the TenderNob/lower Polk area much, allocate a lot of time for parking.
author: Tom W.

description:
This is a cute little place in Nob Hill.  Went to Olea for brunch yesterday and found it to be a nice venue for a good Sunday meal but not an amazing one, but still pretty good.  

We got there right at 12:30 and despite the rain, not surprisingly, SF folks were still having brunch, and every table was taken.  When we got there, there was only one guy ahead of us on the waitlist and then we put our names down for 3 (2 of us were there and another friend was on his way) after his.  While we were waiting for a table to open up, more people trickled in and got their names on the list after our's.  Still the friend we were waiting for hadn't made it in as he was making rounds in the neighborhood looking for parking.  During this 20-30 minute period approximately 3 to 4 parties that came in after us, were seated and we were passed b/c our friend was not in, though we did inform the host that he was nearby, but just looking for parking.  The host was very nice but still did not seat us.  At a few mins before 1:00, when our friend made it in, we still waited and had not been given a table yet.  We started to walk out at I think 1:10 to go somewhere where the wait wasn't as long, but the host stopped us (again, just want to say that he was very polite) and said a table was paying and we would be seated immediately.  

I wanted to mention this in case you ever go to Olea and do not have your party all together, you can expect to wait.  With that said, here's something about the service and food, both of which were great.

I got the eggs baked in a casuela vessel, which comes w/sausage.  Since I'm vegetarian, they were cool about substituting the sausage w/potatoes.  The tomato stew tasted alright and it came with three small crisp baguettes.  I liked my dish, but it wasn't that filling and by the time I got home, was still hungry so I ended up snacking on stuff I had in the fridge.  My friend on the other hand, ordered probably THE best French toast (and really fattening!) any of us had ever tasted.  It basically was like a cinnamon roll covered in the most mouthwatering maple syrup, it was insane.  He got protective of his food (understandably so!) and only let us each steal a bite.  My other friend got a burger and fries and seemed to be happy w/his order.  Our waitress was slammed but was great about checking in w/us and was very friendly.

I would say this place is ideal to go to if you live in the neighborhood (I don't), but not a place I personally would go out of my way to eat at otherwise.  Good service, atmosphere, and overall vibe though.
author: Swetha G.

description:
Came here for brunch with the siblings.  It's small, but we only waited about 5 min on a Sunday morning for a group of 4.  

Coffee was great, juice was very fresh.  I had the omelet which was delicious.  My husband had the open face omelet that he really enjoyed.  But I would say the star here was the Challah french toast.  I'll be getting that next time :)
author: Beth K.

description: This rating is solely based on the custard toast. It's the best french toast I have ever had, period! No contest. It is a custard toast that is light (unlike the monstrosity that is nopa's french toast) and flavorful without being overpowering....mmmm I must go back before I move!
author: Puneet S.

description: Stumbled in for early dinner Saturday night (no reservation; lucky we were early because it filled up soon thereafter).  Could not have been more pleasant.  Service was attentive (not intrusive), and the food beautifully executed (pork chop, pasta with veal meatballs, and duck breast, all done perfectly).  A badly needed gem in the neighborhood.  Will be back.
author: Keith J.

description: Don't know how good the food is because they could not have been less helpful with our surprise birthday brunch. Not much of a party if they were going to make us sit at separate tables and eat at different times, thanks for nothing
author: Judy M.

description:
Olea is a great addition to the neighborhood.  Their emphasis on local products is laudable, but what will keep me going back is the quality of the food.  The flatbread is really good--strong flavors, a nice contrast in textures.  Unfortunately, the smallness of the portion is magnified by how good it is.  I've also had a shrimp starter that offers an unusual combination of savory grilling paired against fresh heirloom tomatoes.  Their short ribs are great, but I preferred their black cod, which was cooked just right.  

Staff and guests are very friendly.  I like it when table neighbors are chatting with each other and staff periodically join the conversation.  With only 25 seats, the space is intimate, not cramped.  I expected it to be a bit noisy, but it's not--so if you're looking for a place where you can chat with your companions, consider this place.
author: QuodE D.

description: Just want to add yet another horrible review. My meal - luke-warm, half-cooked noodles with a suspect medly of crushed baby carrots and overcooked kale- was unpleasant. But the arrogance of the owner was astonishing. He decided to give our table an unsolicited lecture on how he was putting money back into his precious food, wine, and servers by refusing to split more than 2 credit cards and sacrifice $0.50/card/transaction. Nevermind the significant and totally avoidable inconvenience this causes a group of customers that don't tend to carry around exact change or lots of bills. Someone should remind this pretentious fellow that it's the customers that ensure he has a business to worry about in the first place. Customers don't eat out at fancy restaurants so they have the pleasure of being insulted. For what's worth, he's lost my business forever and I'll encourage everyone I know to avoid Olea, its mediocre and overpriced food, and above all, its wretched customer experience. I'm pretty sure that the lost CLV will exceed the savings associated with his two-card-only policy.
author: N H.

description:
5 Mother f-ing stars!!! Love this place from top to bottom.

Seamless service started quickly, but courteously, as our waters were  filled by the back-waiter while our server took our order for  Blue Bottle lattes, freshly squeezed orange juice mimosas, and a beer. The server was well versed in the menu and did a great job of describing and recommending items from the menu that changes with whatever is fresh and in season. He also described the beer that I ordered in perfect detail. Our food arrived in what felt like a very appropriate amount of time, not diner fast, not annoying slow. In fact, everything in this meal was so on point that I found myself more focused on the feeling of ease and pleasure than feeling annoyed by things not being done well, and my need to diagnose the situation and then rant to my friends about what's wrong. (haha, I've been working in the food industry from a long time now, maybe too long.) Olea in this case was the opposite of that. My pulled pork sandwich was more delicate that in your face. The flavors less aggressive and intense, than they were refreshing and uplifting. Fresh shredded carrots and cilantro added a sweet and aromatic touch to the pork that was perfectly dressed so that I could still taste and appreciate the flavor of the meat. My friends had the soft boiled eggs with ham and blue lake beans, and a mildly spicy red sauce the topped it off. Deliciously rich without being too much. Yum. Another one of my friends had the vegetarian omelet with feta, kale, and something else that I can't recall. The omelet, just like all of the other portions was perfectly satisfying, without making anyone feel gluttonous. Oh, one last thing about the food, The FRIES were perfection. Perfectly salted, perfectly crispy, perfectly natural, just perfect. This was by far one of the best overall experiences that I have had dinning out in recent memory.
author: Nolan W.

description: A great go to spot for a sunday brunch. I like the decor a lot. The french toast I ordered was very good too. Very tender and just melt in the mouth. I do like it a lot. And with the glass windows, light can easily get in, just exactly what you need for a Sunday brunch.
author: Fung S. O.

description: Olea has become one of my favorite spots for fresh organic fair that is hard to beat.  The service is very efficient and friendly. So far, I've had their dinner and brunch and I must say that I savored every bite of the halibut(dinner) and huevos en cazuela (brunch). Also, don't forget to save room for the gateau breton for dessert and pressed Blue Bottle coffee. Yum!
author: Cynthia H.

description:
What a great find! I've had dinner here twice now and they always have something interesting on the menu. Here's what I had on one of my recent visits.

Appetizers: I had the grilled sardines over pickled onions and garbanzo beans and it was soooo good. This was my first time having fresh sardines and to my surprise I liked it and they were large.  My friend started with a mixed green salad with kumquats and goat cheese. The  greens were very fresh and the combination of flavors were yummy to my surprise.

Entree: I had the hamburger that was thick and juicy and simply delicious....but wait the fries are to die for! It seems like they worked out the hamburger kinks. My friend had the lamp chops and they were cooked to a medium rare perfection. The serving was not small at all as one reviewer mentioned. I also don't get why some people feel that the portions are small here because we both found them to be just right as it allowed us to enjoy several items on the menu. Perhaps these diners are looking for a place that they normally find on Polk street? Go figure......what I say is check it out for yourself and make your own decision. I think you'll leave satisfied and not stuffed but feeling just right.

Dessert: Many of other yelp reviewers said they loved the three layered cheesecake so we decided to share that and they were right. We are not huge fans of cheesecake but this one is delicious. We loved it!  I was surprised to see that they also sell the blue bottle whole beans.

So my main points about Olea is that it's a very casual place, great service with food that is not over seasoned and simply delicious. I would recommend Olea and will definitely return to see what's new on the menu. I hear that brunch is good too so I'll have to try that soon.
author: Mary C.

description: that french toast. don't even think about getting anything else.
author: Pauline H.

description: The french toast IS divine. Worth the wait on weekends.
author: Heart T.

description:
this place was grand!!! We went with a party of four last night for an on the spur dinner. My boyfriend had gone to this spot when it was a Thai restaurant that he loved but once we walked through the quaint little cottage door and down stairs we were greeted with a warmth of welcome and smiling chef.

We were sat down promptly and we ordered a bottle of Prosseco and the muscles with chorizo to start. The dish has this great smoky flavored broth that was brought out when you dunked your fresh bread into it. 

After the appetizer we were really impressed and ready for our entrees. I got the halibut which was cooked perfectly with this light broth and black eyed peas. My boyfriend ordered the steak with mushrooms and potato wedges (which was also cooked well!
) The other two ordered the vegan dish and the pork chop with polenta. 

It was very charming almost home cooked meals that made this place so enjoyable last night. Unpretentious and comforting without being heavy. On the menu itself they use seasonal fresh ingredients and I love any restaurant that utilizes their location. 

We didn't try the desserts but that's because we were pretty full and well fed. Next time we go I'll have to try that bread pudding our waitress was telling us about. YUM.

We'll be back and wish the restaurant good luck!!



---------------

Been there for brunch the last two weekends and it's just magical!!!!!
author: Ariana M.

description:
Hands down, the best French Toast I've ever tried. I wasn't sure how I'd like the custard in the toast..but it definitely works. It's softens the flavor while still keeping the toast crispy and fluffy.

The blue bottle latte was divine as well.   My husband tried the omelette with potatoes and mushrooms which was decent..but nothing special.

I definitely prefer this place over Nob Hill Grille..and overall a better dining experience than Mama's as well.  The staff was very attentive as well.
author: tina y.

description:
I've been to Olea many times and I've never been disappointed. The food is wonderfully consistent. The french-press coffee is outstanding - rich and full of flavor, it doesn't even need sugar.

I've eaten at Dottie's for breakfast on more than one occasion, and I would definitely put Olea into their category. Let me qualify this though, Olea does what it does extremely well. Dottie's has more variety and is the type of meal that you have to take a nap and leaves you very full and satisfied in the way mom used to make. After you eat at Olea, you will be able to walk home, and not have the waiter roll you out of the restaurant.

I would definitely recommend the french toast, I always end the meal with it. The challah bread that's used is a perfect choice. Since it's a custard variation on French toast, you get all the richness of the flavor, yet the bread doesn't fall apart, whilst the korinjinti cinnamon matures the sweet enough that you can even use maple syrup (sparingly).

Another dish that's always good is the niman ranch hamburger. I wanted to try everything on the menu, however, once I tried the burger, it was kind of hard for me to do anything else.

The omelets can be excellent or so-so. I'm not found of the cazuela eggs, a bit too little for my appetite. It has its charm, but there's something missing, can't quite put my finger on it.

I've also been to dinner, which is not as outstanding as breakfast. This is mostly due to the lack of variety from week to week as well as the portions are modest.

If you're going to come here, get in line and go on the weekend, you'll be glad you did.
author: Adrian J.

description:
What a lovely addition to the neighborhood.

This small cozy little place can only be described as fresh and delicious. The menu changes weekly, but this week it included: roasted scallops with sliced beets in lemon sauce, grilled shrimp over riso venere, pan seared cod with escarole, marinated olives with flatbread, slowly roasted pork shoulder over polenta, and -- a vegan dish -- butternut squash over farro. And for dessert? Slices of grapefruit with local honey, artesian cheese plate, or chocolate walnut cheese cake!

The only thing to keep in mind is that everything about this place is small. The menu is tiny (5 appetizers, 5 entrees, 3 desserts). The portions are small which, while incredibly refreshing and unusual, means you will probably need to order an appetizer to satisfy a healthy appetite. You know what else is small, though? The prices! They are surprisingly reasonable for the high quality of food you get.

Even the food itself has a very simple (small?) taste. No overpowering flavors. No over-seasoning. Just light, fresh, and subtle.

Frankly, I really loved the reigned-in self-control this inspires. There's no over-eating and stuffing yourself here. The menu feels very carefully chosen and so, when you are eating here, you feel welcome to take your time and enjoy the moderation. 

Another big bonus point is the fact that everything is available for takeout (Really! High-end food to go!!), and a very nice little wine selection.

So, what I'm saying is, if your looking for a simple, fresh, tasty, comforting meal Olea is definitely the place to go. Here's hoping it becomes a long-lived neighborhood institution.
author: erin b.

description: Great brunch spot -- expect to wait quite a bit though.  Their french toast is AMAZING.  I had a baked egg dish that was just so-so (too runny), but my friends had an omelet that looked great.  Will definitely come back.  Cute place, great food!
author: Oliver S.

description: Cozy neighborhood restaurant with excellent service. The waiter was patient, pleasant and happy to explain the menu and wine in detail. I thought the ambiance was great at dinnertime - candles and large windows on the street. Great vegan, veg and gluten-free options. It was all really reasonably priced too, I think all the entrees were 18 or under and everything was delicious. Went with a large group and had an nice time, would also be good for date.
author: J. W.

description: Wow, Rebecca M. and I had a great brunch here with friends. 4.5 stars for food, menu is nice with good eggy and pancakey/waffley/French toasty goodness. Sweet owners and great service make it 5 stars for me.
author: Sam P.

description:
This place has some amazing unique creations...........an omelette with ground up walnuts, zuchinni and asiago ... delicious. Custard dipped french toast covered in cinnamon and sugar ... dastardly !

I had a very nice experience here with a few minor problems.... I did start out ordering the baked eggs with chorizo which ... came out REALLY salty and the eggs were not close to poached .. more like hard boiled. 

I switched it up and ordered the aforementioned omellette which saved the day! 
The server was told about the bad eggs ... I think the fact that I ordered another dish could have tipped him off... but he still charged me for it ... and I still tipped him on the full amount... lucky for him I was having lunch witha  great friend on Valentines day and I wasn't in the mood to complain .. which IS unusual for me :) 

Also lucky for him ... EVERYTHING else was great and to top it all off the french pressed Blue Bottle coffee put me over the edge. 

Brunch nirvana acheaved ..... 

Oh ... I also figured out something else here.... 

Mimosas taste WAY better with EXTRA pulp! From now on .. when I make them at home ... it's all abotu extra pulp .... thank you Olea .... you may go now.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
This IS as good as it gets for me thus far into my new foray into SF territory. My friend took me here for birthday brunch this past saturday. The friendly host greeted us cheerfully and the wait was only about 10 minutes (for a restaurant this yummy, at 11:30, I think is rare...so far). The atmosphere is cozy and classy, like an approachable Connecticut or something. 

I had the Niman ranch burger with absolutely perfect aioli sauce and bacon, didn't come with tomatoes but they graciously served up some fresh bright red organic farmer's market tomatoes on the side. But the burger was better without them anyways! Came with thin sliced crispy fries tossed with some parsley (nice touch). 

My friend had the French toast and while it looked boring to me, then I tasted it and it was the creamiest most 'custard' like french toast I've ever had (hence the name on the menu). Served with an ample dousing of cinnamon sugar and of course real maple syrup... sweet and mmmm. 

Also they serve Blue Bottle coffee, which at work we lovingly refer to as "magic crack." Serious jolt. 

Serious joint, upscale by way of being so endlessly accommodating and friendly... and the food was nothing short of fantastic.
author: E W.

description: If I could eat challah custard toast every morning...I would be a very happy camper.  And, I'd be enormous.  Meant to be a brunch entree, our table of five ordered a couple of these as an appetizer.  It's perfect!  Sweet, savory, with hints of cinnamon, custard, and fresh strawberries on the side make this dish a must.  For my entree, I ordered the flat omelet with eggs whites.  They seem to change what's in the omelets from time to time, but mine was delicious.  I wish the portion was slightly bigger, though.  Overall, it was a great brunch experience
author: Joel F.

description: What a gem!! My husband and I found this place via yelp reviews and it happened to be 6 blocks from our hotel. The place holds 24 people tops. The chef/owner prepares everything that hits the table so you know it'll be good! We opted for the clams and osso bucco to share. Both dishes were delicious but the blood sweat and tears that went into the osso were well worth it!!! Creamy polenta and bone marrow make my heart skip a beat. Fallowed by a French press of blue bottle coffee and an amazing French shortcake with figs and strawberries. The wine list was something to be desired but right on point with the daily menu. We chose this place over fluer de lys and are thrilled we did so. Make sure to visit this place whenever you're in the bay area!!!!
author: Erin D.

description:
Really, really, really good experience. A clean and pleasant space, friendly staff, a very prompt service, deliiiiiiiiiiiiious food... What else would you want from a restaurant?
For brunch their challah custard toast is a knock-out. Oh yeah, they also serve the Blue Bottle coffee! You simply have to try it.
author: Al K.

description:
Thanks to yelp for leading me to this little gem! Decided to brunch it up here a few weekends back. Will definitely return for the heavenly french toast.

Service- good, but not memorable enough to write about.

Food- Had the challah custard toast with korintji cinnamon sugar and fresh yerena farms berries. OoooLaLa it was scrumptious! Probably one of my favorite french toasts of all time. My buddy had the yogurt with raspberries, kashiwase farms peach and a sprinkle of coconut granola with marshall's farm wildflower honey which was pretty commendable as well. Of note, they also have blue bottle lattes!

Ambiance- We sat at the communal table after waiting about 20 minutes. Don't have anything to complain about. I might just be in a good mood ;)
author: Aaliya Y.

description: This place is very small but it has a very inviting, relaxing, warm atmosphere and It's always a treat watching the chef work his magic in the kitchen = )
author: Teresa F.

description: I went for dinner here and had a much better overall experience. My husband took me here on a Friday night so it was on the slow side which made for a nice quiet evening. The waiter was outstanding, the food was incredibly fresh & creative, and the price was reasonable.  A+
author: Heidi B.

description: Staying at Mark Hopkins hotel.  We walked 5 nice blocks down street and waited 10 minutes for a table.  We would have been willing to wait an hour had we known how good the food is.  Eat here, period.  The food is outstanding.  Get some house made hot sauce to put on your omelet and enjoy your French press coffee.  This is the real deal!
author: Mark J.

description:
Brunch is definitely my favorite meal of the week, and Olea delivers.  Why else would I wait 20min in the rain for a table on a hung-over Saturday morning?!  I had the cazuela (hispanic ramekin)-baked eggs covered in warm and spicy tomato sauce, with steamed farro, applewood smoked ham and basil almond pesto.  It definitely hit the spot and continues to be my favorite dish there.  And, did I here Blue Bottle coffee is served there as well in a French press brought to your table?!  Yeah, that's right, this meal was definitely my manna. 

I also came back for dinner on a Saturday night and was pleasantly surprised to find that there wasn't a wait, given how small the place is.  I tried the pan-seared duck breast, which was cooked too perfection.  The meat was tender without being raw; the seasoning was flavorful and contrasted nicely with the duck and japonica rice.  They must have ran out of the asparagus, because my plate came out with oven-roasted brussel sprouts instead, which were a little on the bitter side (unless you properly core brussel sprouts, parboil and then bake with salt and pepper, you're gonna get bitter brussels sprouts....just saying).  My partner had the pollock, which wasn't anything spectacular in my opinion, but tasted fresh and tender.  The orange cornmeal cake we shared for dessert was also good, but nothing that was too out of the ordinary--cornmeal is not quite my cup of tea, but the orange flavor provided a nice contrast and so what you end up noticing is that the cake has a different consistency than if made with purely flour....meh

As for the service, the waitress and the host are incredibly sweet and will chat you up about anything.  The place is smaller, so be prepared to wait, though they do take reservations (for dinner at least).  Definitely come here first for brunch (5 stars) and then if you're in the area and can't find any place else, check out Olea for dinner (4 stars).
author: Ben T.

description: Olea is a charming restaurant with great service and a comfy, neighborhood feel.  The menu is hit-or-miss.  I went last week and it was definitely a "miss".  I'm an open-minded foody, but there was almost nothing on the very limited menu that appealed to me.  The food was good, not great, and the portions were pretty small for the price.  We ordered the pollock which was alright, but the osso bucco was delicious.  The pineapple pot de creme dessert was fabulous.
author: Lia S.

description: My experience here made me sad as I was so excited to try one of the best brunch places according to YELP. A friend and I came here on a Saturday afternoon right before the brunch was over at 2:15, so getting a table was no problem. That's usually not the case, I hear. Anyway, the menu was odd... It changes frequently, I was told, but I had a really hard time picking anything that sounded good. Finally, I settled... yes... settled on "Eggs in Cazuela" or something like that. I asked a very nice waiter what that meant, and his description majorly failed as I basically got egg soup, the sight of which almost made me sick. Now, I am an adventurous eater, but I just couldn't do it. I am one of those people who is barely comfortable with "sunny-side-up" eggs even though I can do Eggs Benedict with not problem. Yes, maybe I should have told that to the waiter, but NOTHING in the menu or his description alarmed me. Fine. The server was very nice and took the dish away. I felt weird asking, but he saw I wasn't eating it, so kindly took it away. He then recommended a supposedly very popular egg dish with tortilla chips mixed in. Yes, it was weird, and barely edible. Honestly, the waiter was so nice and I so hungry that I just didn't want to make a fuss. I struggled through my disappointing breakfast, but managed to finish most of it. Oh, no hot chocolate in this place either, which was disappointment #1. BEST freshly squeezed orange juice I've had in a while, though, but I won't be back. Just weird, weird unappetizing menu, in my opinion. Brunch experimentation gone wrong. Sigh.
author: Marina S.

description: This place is amazing. The food has a special touch, the host is a super nice asian guy that made our wait very pleasant. I can't wait to go back to try a new dish. This is one of the little treasures that you have to try.
author: Sil P.

description: Love the frnech toast thing. we also got the baked egg in casuela, that was soso. my bf loved it tho
author: Cindy L.

description:
Okay - quick disclaimer. I know the proprietors but I've been there a couple of times now so I feel I can give an objective review.

During dinner on opening night, I had the roast chicken and it was really good. I wish I had the pork loin (which they ran out of) so I'll have to try it again. Dessert was very simple - a cheese platter and a chocolate cake. Both good. The wine list is very limited but enjoyable.

The friends I was with had the fish of the evening and it looked really good and he seemed to enjoy it too.

Yesterday, I went back for brunch. I had the butternut squash omelet with dragon-tongue lettuce and potatoes. It was so sweet and yummy. I never would have thought of putting the squash in an omelet but it really worked. My partner had the salmon omelet. Not as good as mine but maybe it was a little cold by the time we switched plates.

I also checked that they plan on offering a vegan dish nightly so I'll definitely be coming back with my vegan friends.

To sum it up - a great intimate restaurant with tasty food not overly done. I'm looking forward to future visits with the seasonal menu.
author: Glenn G.

description:
Cute spot with communal dining. I didn't realize that the dining was communal until I introduced myself to a girl at our table, and she wasn't part of our group! The menu is small but creative, and everything is organic. The food was very good, though a little less amazing than I was hoping for. The service was also great.

Finally a cute spot for dinner and brunch in this part of Nob Hill!
author: Jamie C.

description:
I went to Olea on Friday evening as part of my birthday celebration. My friends know the staff (some of them well), so I was expecting everyone to be friendly, but I didn't know just HOW friendly, understanding, accommodating, and welcoming everyone would be.

I began my evening (it was almost 100 degrees in SF on Friday, by the way) by sitting down and finding out that a bottle of hair mousse had exploded in my bag while I had been walking up Nob Hill, COVERING my DSLR in white (lovely-smelling) foam! This would normally have been a humiliating disaster, but I was immediately swept into the back and given a rag to wipe off the camera. No one made me feel like I should be embarrassed or feel stupid, which, seriously, meant the world to me. I know I am a walking disaster and to not have it brought up again or even at the time was so fantastic! Plus, my camera is fine.

One of my friends brought a bottle of wine with her, and our waitress (I am so sorry, I have forgotten your name--must have been all the wine!) offered to bring glasses and cork it for us, which was really nice of her. The food was AMAZING. I tried a bit of the green salad appetizer, which was light and extremely yummy (and included feta); and had the sea bass for my entree. This sea bass was of the highest quality and was prepared flaawlessly--yum! Lastly, I was brought out what my other friend termed "sex in a bowl"-- a chocolate creme dessert with sinfully good mousse. And it had a candle in it, natch. The intimate setting was a great place to be sung to in.

What a GREAT birthday dinner this was--truly special! I couldn't afford to go here other than on special occasions, but what a worthwhile venture. My recession-earned dollars were VERY well-spent.

Thank you for everything!
author: Amber G.

description:
Good toasts, very tasty.
But light salad, a bit expensive.
author: Bruno P.

description: Boring bland food. They refuse to customize the order, such as even removing onions from an omlette or having a mocha instead of cappuccino seem to be too much to ask for. Hot waitress. Quick service.
author: Deboshree D.

description: Quaint restaurant in Nob Hill area. We found this place by accident today and had the most wonderful brunch. Service was excellent and friendly. Food was sooo delicious and creative. It's small inside so its easy for them to focus on quality!! Had their signature dish, cazuela, and LOVED it. French toast was good too!!
author: J B.

description: The food was delicious!! We had some quinoa and duck which was suberb. The waiter did an awesome job.
author: Luis A.

description: Great coffee, good service, cozy atmosphere. A small menu of nicely-done brunch food.
author: Robert P.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Olea for brunch a few weekends ago and everything was scrumptious! I had the Challah French Toast--light and fluffy with succulent poached pears. He ordered the Pulled Pork sandwich, which was a perfect savory complement. 

The coffee is superb as well; all Blue Bottle--my latte was divine. Service is prompt and friendly and the owner is just about the nicest man ever whether you're sitting down for a meal or grabbing a coffee to go!
author: Jackie G.

description: their Challa french toast has got to be the best french toast I have had in my life!! The fresh squeezed orange juice is also divine. Let's put it this way, if you were on a super strict diet and gave yourself 1 day a week to eat whatever you want, this french toast should be your #1 choice of what to eat every single time.
author: Rachael T.

description:
I wouldn't say I am a HUGE fan of Olea, but I am certainly a fan.  It's original, like no other brunch spot I have been to in the city.

I love walking down the steps into this cozy little restaurant.  I would say that it feels like home, but it's so much better decorated than any home I have ever known.  Almost looks like Martha Stewart had a hand in it.  Jack Johnson tunes fill the air (both times I have been there).  This might normally be kind of irritating, but it fits the mood of the place...kinda swanky, but not stuffy.  

Admittedly, I have only been there for brunch.  They have a very limited menu, but everything that I have eaten is tasty and unique.  Flat omelets, AMAZING french toast, egg bakes...different each time, but always yum.  Get different things and share, so that you don't have to commit.  They have Blue Bottle Coffee, which they bring to your table in a french press.  The server cracked us up (unintentionally) telling us to wait 180 seconds before pressing and pouring the coffee...why not just say a few minutes?!  Anyhow, this is good stuff, apparently $20 a pound, and the difference is noticeable.      

What I don't particularly like about Olea is that you get what they give you.  I tried to order wheat toast, and they only had a toast plate (for sharing) with whatever they thought looked good that morning...a composite of challah, sourdough and a darker toast with nuts in it.  Don't get me wrong, it was good, but not exactly what I was hoping for.  And, this is not stated anywhere on the memo, so the first time you go, you inevitably feel like you didn't get the memo.  You have to ask for skim milk, which they will bring you, but not without making you feel like it's a bit of an odd request.  Don't even think about asking for sugar substitute...it's raw sugar cubes or nothing.  I have to remember to bring my own next time.

As far as value, I have never left feeling ripped off, but the place isn't cheap.  The serving sizes are modest, but they do the trick...this last time I left very satisfied (the french toast is filling).  Brunch menu items are about $12 or $13 bucks, and then add in coffee, toast, french fries (the closest you can get to homefries or hashbrowns) and/or bacon, and it can easily get you up to or above $20 per person.  Typically, this much would buy a decent breakfast, toast and potatoes included, plus coffee AND a mimosa, but you're paying for quality and ambiance.  I suppose I am okay with that.  

This certainly isn't your every weekend brunch spot, but it's great for a special occasion or for a treat when friends are in town.  OH, and it's a small place, not a lot of tables, SO GET THERE EARLY OR CALL FOR A RESERVATION (only available for groups of 6 or more).  And, keep in mind that they won't seat you without your entire group.  Be prepared to spend some time hanging out on the steps just inside the door drooling over everyone's food or standing on the corner of California and Larkin.  Perhaps because the food comes quickly, tables turn over reasonably fast.  Though, my friend and I did almost have words with a girl who stood up, put on her jacket and purse and then sat back down to slow play the paying of the check.  We were hungry.

The host said they are very happy with their brunch service, but are struggling a bit more with dinner.  I would imagine the food is just as good, though probably a bit more expensive.  If you're looking for a nice dinner without the huge wait that comes with upscale SF restaurants, check it out!
author: Mara L.

description:
"olèa celebrates the real flavors of food.
we use organic produce from local farms whenever possible and procure our meat and fish from humane purveyors.  we only use all natural meats and sustainable, wild caught seafood. 
our menu changes weekly depending on seasonal availability."

LOVE IT!  Chez Panisse without the price tag and with more love and soul.
author: Wakako U.

description: Not sure what the big deal is with this place.  I went for brunch because of all the Yelp reviews.  Had to wait 30 or 40 minutes only to be underwhelmed.  Prices were more than they should be for what is served.  My friend got the french toast which is their "signature" dish and it was good, but not life changing.  If french toast is the best thing a place can make it's got a long way to go.  I think this place is popular because it's a small cozy place and there isn't much competition in the area.  Maybe their dinner is better.
author: Jason D.

description:
Went to Olea with a friend for brunch on a Sunday morning.  Got there at 11:15.  No wait.  Sweet!

I ordered the greens omelet, which came with leeks, mixed greens, brown rice, yummy asiago cheese and a side of salad.  My friend had the fresh toast.  We each ate half and then swapped so I was able to try both dishes.

I had never had brown rice in an omelet before.  It was different, creative and, more importantly, it worked.  Yum.  I typically don't like fresh toast because I think that it is too sweet, but not at Olea.  It was also relatively light and airy with just the right amount of sugar.  

I am an orange juice snob.  If it's not made on site, I don't order it.  I was happy to get me some *truly* fresh squeeze orange juice, made to order.
author: Sara K.

description:
damn, lately i've just been hit with disappointments left and right.

the french toast is supposed to be superb, according to prior reviews. custard like and amazing is the claim. the texture, to me, was that of raw dough. it wasn't custardy creamy, it was soggy and not cooked through. 

le sigh....another day with my tummy left unsatisfied.
author: Regina C.

description:
A very good start for this new restaurant. I think they've been open for a little over a month now, and I felt like a lot of the bugs other reviewers mentioned have been ironed out.

No-one played with the dimmer setting while we ate, though the waiter is still a little whimsical and very eager to find out how everything is going. He also cleared everyone else's plates while my wife was still eating. That's one of my pet peeves. It might be OK at casual US style restaurants, but for anywhere nice it's too crass - please wait until everyone is finished before rushing around, bustling and interrupting the conversation. 

The food was really good. The portions are relatively small - but put it this way: that means you can have a starter, main and dessert without feeling completely stuffed! Too many US restaurants serve waaaay oversized portions of mediocre food, instead of smaller and high quality. If you want to supersize your meal, go to McDonalds! 

I had the shrimp starter, delicious grill flavor to the shrimps. I had the beef with turnip fries - the beef was amazing, the fries good (though I wish I had more, since everyone kept eating them!) There was some kind of sauce in a little ramekin for the  beef, but to be honest the meat was so good (and the sauce a little nondescript) so I ate most of it without sauce. Dessert was the highlight - I had the 3-layer cheesecake. The top layer was torched, almost like creme brulee. Soooooo good!

I thought the price was quite reasonable for the quality of food & service. Expect around $40/person for 3 courses and sharing a bottle of wine.

No real bike parking around, but a very convenient post right outside the window.
author: Magnus B.

description:
Adorable neighborhood place, great for brunch

I went to brunch at Olea this morning to catch-up with a friends and was absolutely delighted. It's a small corner place in Nob Hill, probably seats about 25. The menu (which changes weekly) is all about what's fresh and local, with some really interesting takes on traditional brunch foods.

I had a great little dish that had a base of green lentils, baked in a clay pot and topped with two eggs and crumbled goat cheese. It was slightly salted with what tasted like kosher salt, beautifully complementing the lentils. Quite yummy and the perfect portion size. To drink , I was all over the blue bottle coffee (when it's on the menu, is there any other choice?), which they prepared as well as Blue Bottle themselves.

Overall, it's a good deal (brunch dishes ~$6-10), fresh yummy food and a very cute set-up. Can't wait to return!
author: Daniel M.

description:
I finally came back to this restaurant to try again after my first mediocre experience.  This time, the service was excellent, attentive but not in your face and the food was good (but not great). 

The food - we shared 2 appetizers - the flatbread and the salad.  The salad was very small, maybe 5-6 leaves of romaine with barely noticeable dressing, in fact, I'm not even really sure there was dressing on it.  The flatbread was good, but came as one big cracker on a plate, then on a separate plate, a little scoop of ricotta, a few grapes, some cooked veggies and olive oil.  Very bland although the bread was tasty.  Not worth paying $10 each. 

There were once again only 3-4 entrees but luckily this time they had them all.  I had the skirt steak, which was cooked perfectly at medium-rare, and very flavorful.  It came with a polenta/corn side and a green chile salsa.  All of the flavors together were excellent and the corn/polenta was particularly tasty.  If i had been rating purely on the flavors of this dish, it would have been 5 stars.  Again the portion here was very small.  

They only had one dessert left by the time we were done, which was luckily chocolate so we got it - but it makes me wonder if they are still in the habit of running out of menu items.  

Overall I would come back here but it's not one of my favorites.
author: Amy W.

description:
We FINALLY tried Olea after hearing good things about it on yelp and walking by it many times.  Got to the point of peeking in and looking at the menu in the window, but never quite pulled the trigger.

This neighborhood definitely needs more decent eateries, especially since Ti Piacera down the street is really not that great.  I'd say that the closest competition is literally right down the street-- Nob Hill Grill.  

Though it's open for dinner, it seems that Olea has established itself as a brunch hotspot.  On a Saturday around noon, it was crowded enough that they have a sign up sheet and there is often a wait.  The place itself is quite small with limited seating, though they have smartly put in a community table that seats ten.  We didn't mind eating at this table at all.

The brunch menu is not very large either, but at least the selections are well selected with a decent variety.  I had the pulled pork sandwich, and my brunch companion had the scrambled eggs and bacon on a roll.  The pulled pork came with some delicious, perfectly done fries and the egg sandwich came with a tasty, fresh side salad.

The egg sandwich was pretty good, and the eggs were fluffy and tasted fresh.  The sandwich itself was a bit on the petite side, but tasty.

The pulled pork sandwich was not anywhere near as good as I've had, however.  It tasty vinegary.  We determined that it was some sort of sauce that they put on the bun and not the pulled pork filling itself.

We also had a glass of very pulpy, freshly squeezed orange juice, and the french press coffee for two.  Both were quite tasty and fairly priced.  Service was good, and we didn't have to wait long for our food, either.

Overall, I'd say that this place is pretty decent, but it doesn't knock your socks off.  Compared to places like Brenda's, Zazie, and Ella's, the brunch food doesn't quite match up... but the location is good and the wait isn't long like those other places.
author: Dave N.

description: Brunched at the communal table with 4 friends this weekend. As a local, seasonal, healthy food junky this place fits my ideal for a restaurant. They listed where the eggs are from, get their Acme bread fresh at the farmers market, and feature seasonal dishes. My cazuelo egg dish featured the currently ubiquitous fresh corn studding its flavorful tomato sauce, along with ground pork and mushroom. The eggs were baked perfectly. One of the most wonderful brunch entrees I've had in a long time. My only wish would be that they include whole grain bread options as well. I can't wait to come back and try dinner. And the french toast sometime, which looked insane...
author: Shoshana D.

description: I love this place.  The food is simple and always delicious.  Gabrielle and his staff are always warm, friendly and efficient.   On weekends this place is packed so you should get there before 10:00 if you don't like waiting in line.  Don't miss the french toast.  The bacon, egg sandwich on a crusty baguettte with a side salad is my staple and hangover cure.
author: Blaise M.

description:
Three important food-related places for me in a city are 1.) a great date place, 2.) a great brunch spot, 3.) a great place for hot chocolate.  Olea fulfills the first two of those requirements.

The ambiance is darling and laid back, with calming music being played over a charmingly inappropriate iHome.  The restaurant is placed slightly underground with a view of people's lower halves as they walk by on the street and the vines as they grow over the windows.  The tiny space makes for an intimate dining experience, but the high ceilings and wraparound windows keep it from feeling too claustrophobic.

I've been for both brunch and dinner, and while the dinner is good, the brunch is EXCELLENT.  Eggs in a cazuela changes a little each time I go in, but it is always delicious.  The coffee is phenomenal.  The burger is yummy.  The pulled pork sandwich is divine; not too gloppy and with a perfect amount of vinegary cole slaw to balance out the sweetness of it with some acidity.  Yum!  

If you want to be a fat kid like me, I definitely recommend getting one of those as a first course, then finishing your meal with an order of the orgasmic custard toast to share with the table.  That way, you get the savory and the sweet--it's the best of both worlds and is sure to make your tummy full of delight!  (The french toast is easily the best I've ever had.)

The servers are also really cool and laid back.  Expect prompt service and just the right amount of friendly conversation.  

Just thinking about this place is getting me excited for the weekend...
author: Ashley S.

description: There were only two vegetarian items on the menu at the time I went (they change their menu regularly though) and the one I had was very good (an omelette). The atmosphere was okay though we had to wait outside for about 10 mins to get a table.
author: Lori L.

description: I've eaten here three times in the last week. If you want good quality food from local sustainable sources go there. The brunch on Sunday was great, but get there early to avoid a wait. I've had the pork chops and cod dinners and they were excellent. They also have vegan and vegetarian selections as well. It's a small place, but very inviting.
author: Rob S.

description:
The food was amazing.  My wife and I came here for brunch and the service was very prompt.  Granted, we were like the only ones there, but our host was really nice and knowledgeable.  I ordered the scrambled eggs with butternut squash and dungeonness crab.  My wife ordered the toast.  

We ended up swapping plates because I couldn't really take all the creaminess from the crab and squash.  My wife absolutely devoured it!  I thought the french toast was amazing.  Someone warned fellow yelpers that the portions were too small.  We didn't think so!!  We had to take some home! 

Excellent food.  Excellent service.  Blue Bottle coffee. What else can you ask for?
author: Stan V.

description:
Dinner reservation for 4 last Friday night.  Very accomadating.  We got there at 8pm.  While I knew it was a small menu,  it doesn't leave much room for flexibility.  Case in point....at 8pm,.  they were out of the tastiest dish on the menu,  a pomegranate molasses duck dish.  What else was there to choose from?

Well.....cod (not as  menu-friendly as say catfish,  trout,  salmon,  or god forbid...chilean sea bass),  a vegan dish with a butternutsquash something-or-another on top of faro,   a very boring sounding pork tenderloin over polenta, (thats pretty much all the menu stated),   and maybe another dish or two but i can't remember.  No red meat available,  not even a chicken dish available.  

The constant adjustment of the lighting was a little annoying as well....its as if an 8 year old was playing with a dimmer switch in the back.  Or maybe it was haunted. Who knows.

Our scallops appetizer tasted good,  but was warm on the outside and cold in the middle.  Tsk Tsk.

The service was great.....almost a little too friendly.  We barely had two bites of our food before we were asked how things were. Let us breathe and enjoy the food....some of us hadn't even had a bite yet. 

We'll give it another try......but nothing about this place WOWed us.  I really debated giving this 2 stars,  but the third is because I see some potential.....I know the turnaround was quick....but i wish this place irons out some of its opening kinks before it turns off its neighboorhood clientele.
author: Pete D.

description:
Stopped in for Sunday brunch before a matinee at Lumiere.

I was happy to see that they serve Blue Bottle coffee, but sad that they don't have soy milk or other non-dairy creamer options available. Since I'm sensitive to the dairy, no coffee for me. :(

I ordered the chicken soup, which was great. My partner had a burger and fries, which was also really good. The food and service were solid, and the other people at the communal table seemed to enjoy their food as well (there was lots of sharing and yumming among their group). 

I also love that the place serves local, organic, sustainable food. I love to support places that do that.

Overall, a good, solid experience. If we are back around Polk St or going to the Lumiere again, we'll be back.
author: Kellie P.

description: Olea is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. It's menu is small, but everything I have ever had there has been exceptional. Great for brunch (sometimes a wait) and dinner.
author: Molly G.

description:
wait was a little long and during the wait i felt the service was a bit slow...

once we were seated, though, the service was great!  very attentive and our glasses were refilled with water frequently.  the fresh squeezed oj was about 5.85 and while very pricey, i'll gladly pay that price again bc it was phenomenal.  SO FRESH.  

i quite enjoyed my flat omelette but not sure if i'd order it again, not because it wasn't good but every time a server came out of the kitchen area, there was a delightful looking dish that i wanted to try.  

glen, one of the owners is wonderful--so cheery and friendly.  easily one of my favorite brunch places in SF and i'm definitely going to return.
author: Karen N.

description: A very enjoyable place for a weekend brunch. I've been here twice. The first time, we arrived mid morning and had to wait about 30 min for a table, and the second time we arrived shortly before the restaurant opened and got a table immediately. However, our party of 3 was sat at the same table both times, which results in us being squished and truly not having enough room for our entrees and our coffee at the table... next time i'd opt for the family table and share with another group. Great blue bottle french press coffee and OJ. Great meals both times I've been here - I've had the challah french toast, which is magical, and probably the best french toast I've ever ordered, as well as one of their egg cazuela dishes that was quite tasty, and interesting. The menu isn't too large (which is probably the only reason its a 4 star instead of a 5 star for me), so to keep it fresh I'd probably only brunch here every other month, but I plan to keep on returning.
author: Kelly B.

description: My husband and I were looking for a place to have dinner before a show at the Masonic Auditorium. At 6:00 many places were full, with waiting lists or would not even be able to serve a dinner before a 7:30 show. We luckily found Olea and had a delicious dinner in a cozy and pleasant setting where we could actually have a conversation. The menu is small but well chosen and every dish we had was excellent. The vegetarian/vegan option is also excellent, both tasty and offering excellent protein. Service was also excellent.
author: Laurel E.

description:
I have been here a few times now so I thought it was time to review it....
The food has overall been pretty interesting! The duck was probably the most memorable dish I have had with such a strange combination of ingredients  - but it was FABULOUS! I have been for brunch, and I love the Blue Bottle Coffee, so that was a nice surprise, and they have a different spin on some of the classics which is nice if you are in the mood to be adventurous in the morning. 
I am glad to have this in my neighborhood, being practically across the street!
author: Dash H.

description:
Olea is my favorite restaurant in the city. Oh, I know what you're thinking: 'that is such an overused word' or 'she really hasn't eaten many places' or 'she's just lazy' but honestly, my favorite. You could say I even have an infatuation with them. I've been a consistent diner at Olea since they opened-- and I don't know why I've waited so long to review them. I guess because I just felt so close to them and I didn't want to lose the magic by putting down on paper... er.. website... for all of the world to see. Sometimes when you try to put something so fabulous in words, others tend to doubt or judge. And I know that's what yelp is all about, telling others your take on it, but I didn't want to feel judged for my deep held love for Olea... is that wrong?!

First of all, I eat there mostly for dinner and I've always had an amazing dish, every time really. The chef, Gabriel, is so thoughtful about his cooking, so intelligent with his use of ingredients, so subtle the play of flavors that I can't believe he's not more of a big local star. I've had their brunch a few times, and I've loved it too. But I'm a huge fan of the dinner creations. And I know that Olea has reached my favorite status because, as my husband pointed out, I always want to go there. Always. Whenever friends or family come in town, I want to take them there. It's perfectly sized to actually have a conversation and be able to hear the other person. Somehow, the music they play seems to have been taken from my iPod and self-indulgently I love that. Plus, not to mention, they always take care of us in the most caring way. The wait staff is super kind and friendly. And Glen, the manager/co-owner, is a sweetheart. My husband even arranged to have a birthday dinner for me there and they were incredibly accommodating about it. We practically took over the restaurant, and they didn't even blink, while serving unbelievably tasty dishes the whole time, completely unfazed.

I just feel like Olea and I are on the same wavelength, ya know? They just *get* me. Kind of like when you meet someone and have an instant connection, except that this is with a restaurant... didn't know that was even possible... but so glad it is...
author: Nina W.

description: Haven't eaten there yet but thought it might be helpful for people to know that they do NOT take brunch reservations.
author: Shannon M.

description:
another charming neighborhood spot for brunch.

they don't take reservations for parties less than ten for brunch so come early or late.  otherwise expect a 30 mins wait and bring shades to wear while waiting outside.  all parties need to be there before seating so don't think you can sip a mimosa while waiting for your friend.

all annoyances aside, you'll see that it's definitely worth the wait.

there is one large communal table with some smaller table seatings where  you can see the hustle and bustle of the kitchen.  despite being busy bees, the service always stayed friendly.

i'd come here just for the blue bottle coffee - go for the big press if you are sharing with a friend.  and of course, you can't miss the mimosas.  i love any excuse to drink in the morning.

if you are hungry and order the baked eggs in the cazuela that comes with moroccan tomato, sausage with carnaroli rice and breadcrumbs, you may want to order a side of toast since the dish only comes with two small pieces of toast.

for future, i heard that the challah french toast and the burger are both fantastic.  

i'll just have to come back!
author: Anh V.

description:
The vanilla bean panne cotta at Olea rocked my world. Seriously, you've got to try it. 

As for everything else, it's really good, simple food with fresh local ingredients. If we weren't in this stupid recession, I'd eat here way more often.
author: jcie k.

description:
DH and I tried this restaurant as a suggestion from a friend. I liked the intimate atmosphere, and it proved to be a pleasant surprise. 

We were the 1st ones there and service was better than fair. Our server explained a good bunch of the menu as well as wine selections. When it got a little bit busy, we waited a little bit for our check. I thought it was pretty reasonable considering there were only 2 servers plus one of the owners doing the seating and helping with the service.

Not too many choices as far as entrees are concerned, but the choices proved to show a good variety with steak, fish, chicken, and vegan dishes. DH had the hanger steak. My 1st taste of the steak was a bit rough for a medium cook, but another taste proved otherwise. I guess I just got the end part of the steak. I had the halibut with brown rice. I enjoyed the relish sauce it was paired with, but I think the fish was a bit overcooked. OK, but not buttah; I wanted a bit more relish to cover the taste of the fish that was left over. We had the squash with flatbread appetizer which was a good starter for us. For dessert, we had the homemade 3 layer cheesecake which went well with our French Press coffee. I also liked our wine selection, but you're probably better off getting a bottle if you and your company plan to drink. 

For us, it's a restaurant we definitely want to revisit, but not the type yet where we'd go back the next week. We'd probably try other dishes and maybe their brunch to get a better feel. For now, it's a 4 stars.
author: Berna P.

description: "Great atmosphere; really friendly staff; unique yummy food"  Went there for brunch and there was a small wait but it was well worth it.  Had blue bottle coffee that was one of the highlights.  Perfect Saturday brunch spot.
author: Julie C.

description: Like most reviewers, the challah custard toast is a must try! I love it! Especially pairing it with the french press blue bottle coffee that they serve. The pork shoulder sandwich was ok, a little too tangy. Overall I am a fan and when I'm craving for some french toast I will definitely come here!
author: A L.

description: The Challah Custard French Toast was truly as amazing as all of the other reviewers have made it out to be. Wonderful staff, wonderful food. I look forward to returning the next time I stay over in SF, just so I can explore the rest of the menu.
author: Eric F.

description:
I'm always looking for new brunch places with creative, fresh food in a great atmosphere.  This place exceeded all my expectations.  It's rare that everything on the menu appeals to me, but at this place I wanted to try everything!  

My friend and I ended up trying the challah french toast which was amazing!!  Probably one of the best french toasts I've ever had!  We also tried an mexican style egg dish that was perfectly cooked and very tasty.  Blue bottle coffee to top it off just made my morning.

I will definitely be returning here.  The place is small and they don't take reservations for brunch, but we only waited maybe 5 mins or so for a seat and the wait staff was friendly.
author: emily C.

description:
as time goes by, i get lazier (er, i mean busier) with my yelping. in short:

You should eat here. 

small, cozy, with one waitress that held the place together and 2 calm, collected chefs that made cooking look like a breeze. 

we shared challah strawberry french toast and "eggs baked in a cazuela with basque style tomato sauce". translation: 2 pouched eggs baked in tomato sauce, this week with pesto and pork.

great french press coffee and even better vibe.  i like!
author: Dee C.

description:
My last favorite brunch spot, Red Door Cafe, went under- and Olea took it's place. I was about to write it off until I read some reviews on Yelp and decided to give it a try. I wanted to try everything on the menu - I didn't know what to choose- but I eventually decided on the omelet with basil, fresh mozzarella and squash. Man, that dish rocked my socks off. 

As far as atmosphere, it's just what I like for a brunch spot: A place with no wait time, no pretentious crowd, quiet (for the inevitable hangover), attentive wait-staff, and amaaaaaazing food.
author: Trish B.

description:
French press blue bottle cofee.  Tasty food and a good atmosphere.

All in all a very pleasant brunch. I'll be back for sure!
author: Allen K.

description: Usually by the time we head out to brunch this place is busy with a line outside, last weekend we got there just before the crowds.  I really enjoyed their food, very down to earth feeling, I guess rustic is the word?  I gotta say though, the Blue Bottle coffee served in your very own french press was the highlight for me!  That is some goooood coffee! The space itself was small and cozy....yet not small to where you felt clausterphobic....being 6'4 that was refreshing!
author: Brian S.

description: Can anyone really swoon over quinoa? I thought not until my first taste of Olea's quinoa. Pure heaven. The entire meal was delicious, and the service was perfect. Olea is now one of my favorite places.
author: Paige W.

description: the waiter isnt very nice to us... we only got 4 people but he wants us to split to 2 tables which is side by side.... but the blue bottle coffee is good!
author: Susan H.

description: A hidden gem of brunch place in SF.  Love the "french toast" - quite out of this world!  The blue bottle coffee can't be beat either.
author: Saurin S.

description: While my brunch was delicious, delectable, and amazing, I wish I hadn't been slightly hungover and in need of gigantic diner brunch instead of tiny high class brunch.  Regardless, that's not really Olea's fault so I won't hold it against them that we drank 3 bottles of wine at the Hidden Vine the night before.  Unfortunately, my amazing open face omelette with chicken and tomatoes didn't fill me to the brim.  However, it was delicious, delectable and amazing.
