So - in conclusion - you should certainly go here and have fantastic breakfast and amazing french press coffee.  But you should not do so after drinking too much wine the night before.  After those nights, you should go to the Pork Store.
author: Lauren L.

description: Great for brunch. I would come here and get the french toast every morning if I could. It's light and not too sweet, which is perfect for a brunch that doesn't leave you feeling coma'd.
author: Amy W.

description: Worth a visit solely for the challah cinnamon custard french toast. Best french toast I've ever had. It's nice too because it isn't too busy early if the lines at Brenda's and Dottie's are out of control.
author: Bill R.

description: Went for dinner last night and could not have been more pleased. The food was fantastic, our waiter could not have been nicer. It felt like being taken care of by a friend.  We had the pork shoulder, quinoa, duck breast, mussels and a green salad. Each dish was well prepared and attractive.  We will definitely be coming back.
author: Debra Z.

description: I tried to make another trip to Red Door Cafe and ended up getting turned down from there since we had a party of 3 and they don't allow parties of 3 :'(. Ended up coming here for brunch instead. I got a giant french press coffee here which is pretty good (blue bottle coffee beans). I tried one of the omelets, this egg with pork dish, challah custard toast, and umbrian farro salad. I think they make these dishes with a few slight variations in ingredients based on what they have and what was available. I liked the omelet the best out of the four. The custard toast was my second favorite since I was impressed by the consistency, fluffiness of the toast. The egg and pork dish was my third favorite. The farro salad didn't taste bad but I expected a warm dish, not a cold dish. It was a bit of a disappointment since I wanted something warm for the soul. Everything tasted wonderful. Portions are slightly smaller than some other brunch places I've been to already.
author: Liwei Y.

description: i have been to olea 3 times for dinner and each time was equally fantastic. the service is friendly, relaxed and professional. the food is cooked to perfection. hats off the chef. nothing was over or under cooked, and nothing was over or under seasoned. just a wonderful experience. i will definitely be back!
author: Cat C.

description:
if you want a tasty brunch place without the long line, come check out this place (fairly easy street parking).  their french toast (challah custard toast with korintji cinnamon sugar and fresh yerena farms berries) is very tasty and lives up to the acclaim, esp. if you like the type with a very thick moist soft custard outer coating.
eggs baked in a cazuela with chorizo sausage is also very tasty
also, the pressed coffee is quite good
Sunday's 1 hr wait at prime time, still serving awesome french toast this time with pears, a nice egg cazuela, which is warm.  also the omelette eggs were very fluffy
author: Rob C.

description: Some friends and I started a brunch club. Every weekend one of us picks a brunch spot, and we rate it in various ways. Factors like wait time, food quality, good service, coffee, ambiance and all the regular stuff all count in our rating at the end of the meal. This place got a solid 9.5 from all of us. Blue bottle lattes (YES), cute little dining room, very cool servers and holy mother lord the french toast made me moan out loud. Best french toast I have had. Maybe ever. Fricken delicious. My lady got the baked thing with beans and an egg on top. I don't even know what it was, but it was okay, not something I would order when there is that french toast on the menu. The wait for 4 was about 30 minutes at noon on a Sunday.
author: Natalie D.

description: Waow, this place is cute! Came here with girlfriends for Saturday brunch. There was no wait, GREAT! I am not a big fan of any kind of toast, but I ordered their French toast anyway, since everybody say it's good :) I have to say it's very good indeed! Too bad it is so sweet that I had to steal some cheesy omelet from friend's plateee~ which is also very delicious!
author: Marlis T.

description: Olea is a cozy place with a communal table and delicious food.  Went here for brunch with a friend and ordered their popular challah custard french toast which was very solid indeed despite the hype.  They also had a pork shoulder sandwich which I will try next time.  Had some of my friends clams which were very tasty with a hint of spice in it.  I've also been here for dinner a year ago or so.
author: John L.

description:
Ate brunch there today.  Went with high expectations after reading the reviews and unsuccessfully trying to go last weekend only to find they were closed and on vacation.
The good:  very nice and helpful staff, cozy atmosphere, efficient operations, e.g. they will only seat you when your whole party is there which makes sense given the very small number of seats.

The not so good:  I had the French Toast based on the reviews and it was ok.  Granted I'm not a fan of french toast to begin with.  It did smell wonderful, and it tasted fine, but in the end, it's smushy bread.  But here's the kicker it's advertised as "with fruit."  Guess what I got, ONE strawberry sliced into tiny pieces.  ONE.  To me that's garnish and therefore does not qualify as "with fruit."  When I questioned it, I was told that strawberries are out of season and therefore I'd have to pay $2.50 for more.  Well, then why choose a fruit that's out of season.  Give me a whole apple or pear and pile it on.  

Summary:  nice people/atmosphere, ok food, not really worth going back given difficult parking and the plethora of restaurants in SF.
author: Q E.

description: Olea is definitely one of my favorite if not my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  They have really nice friendly service and a delicious menu that is always changing.  I also recommend them for Brunch, as they have great french toast and pressed coffee
author: George M.

description: Great ambiance, small portions.  Good but by no means great food.  The Desserts were considerably better than OK.  The price-- on the higher side.
author: Aaron S.

description: This is hands-down my favorite brunch spot in San Francisco. Do yourself a favor and come early so you can be seated right away. Service is excellent, food is amazeballs, and the Blue Bottle Coffee is the best, of course. I always order the french toast (it's like eating french toast made of churros) with a side of the yummy bacon. BF always gets the pulled pork sandwich. We both leave incredibly happy. It is small, so make sure to allow enough time to be seated - it is worth the wait.
author: Sara J.

description: This place had absolutely delicious brunch. I really love their french press coffee concept.  We waited over half an hour for a table on a Sunday Morning and  I wouldn't mind waiting again.  It is a fairly small restaurant with one communal table and probably 9 tables.   I had their omelet with butternut squash, cheese, and pumpkin seeds and am a BIG FAN.The other half had their steams clams which was good as well.  Their toast is nice and soft and sweet which goes especially well with their strawberry jam. I would love to come back!
author: Sarah T.

description: As good as the savory food is, the reason to come here is dessert. Both the chocolate pot de crème and the dense cake with fruit are divine.
author: Vena V.

description: Good f-ing god we arrive here at 10:00 on a Saturday morn and waited at this place for almost an hour after being told it would be a 15-20 minute wait. We finally gave up with about half the other people there, scuttling off with hunger pains to catch a passing cab or bus, or just hoofing it.  They don't take reservations for less than parties of 4, so good luck getting in. Wasted my morning, please give a better estimate on wait time so you don't piss off your clientele.
author: Greg D.

description: THIS is why I love San Francisco: cozy restaurant, farm fresh & seasonal ingredients, great service and simply touches (like french pressed coffee & simple syrup instead of sugar packets).  Well done, Olea.
author: Jaimey W.

description:
Located on corner of Larkin and California in Nob Hill. You open the door, descend on several steps and begin to feel like you've entered familiar territory in the form of someone's simple and charming home. On my first visit, I immediately noticed the fresh flowers and plants that tastefully adorn each table and window sill. Next, I noticed the chef (the guy in the yelp picture, HA!) appear in the rustic little kitchen at the left side of the restaurant. I've been here twice for brunch and I especially enjoyed my second visit when my group was seated at the communal table. 

I am drawn to this place for brunch because the menu is creative while being contrite (10 items) and they serve blue bottle coffee in a french press.  Like other brunch places in the city, menu items are made from organic ingredients that of local farms. However, Olea has been somewhat more creative with their menu options. The challah custard toast with korintji cinnamon sugar and strawberries (berries vary by season) was heavenly and perhaps the best I've ever had. The flat omelet option stays on the menu but the ingredients change on a weekly basis. The omelet was the perfect portion for me, it's focus on the ingredients- peppercorns, homemade fromage blanc, purslane greens and tomato was a nice departure from my usual mushroom, cheese, canadian ham trapped within an insanely amount of egg type of omelet. The eggs baked in a cazuela served with crostini was also very good and something that I've never had before. Our table ordered french fries which were the 'good' kind of fries - skinny, just the right amount of salt and sprinkled with parsley...yum!

Mimosa's are made with fresh squeezed orange juice and the coffee is good. I am going to try dinner here on my next visit.
author: Annie Y.

description:
Looking over the lower ratings I really wonder what people expect from a restaurant. Hello! It most meals are not going to change your life, but breakfast or dinner at Olea just might make your day a little brighter.

I've been three times, once for dinner and twice for breakfast and every time I have had a lovely experience. The place is tiny and sweet and the kitchen is visible. The food is clean, tasty, organic and, for the most part, locally sourced. All pluses.

I have a lot of food issues, and I've found the waitstaff and kitchen to be very accommodating, not that it's that hard when the food is so fresh and beautifully prepared.

Yes, the place is pricey. If it were cheaper I think I'd be there every weekend for breakfast, but having a nice neighborhood place that serves delicious food is always welcome. 

One benefit of the teeny tiny space is that you feel like you're someplace special. Another benefit is that  you can always check out the other patrons and make up stories about who they are and what they're doing there.

There's a community table and I've never sat there, but now that I think about it, it's a good opportunity to meet people, especially if you go out alone.

And I think the portions are just right. When food is good I will eat it until it's gone. By providing enough to satisfy me without overdoing it, I leave feeling good.

Go there. Chill out. Enjoy.
author: Molly R.

description: Fabulous brunch - the Casuela is amazing.  Have ordered this twice and had slightly different ingredients each time, as they periodically adjust the menu.  This time it was chicken hash and tortilla chips, so was like a basque take on huevos rancheros.  Love that they use cage free, organic eggs, organic greens, etc.  Only downside is the long wait for brunch (even though it IS worth it) and the tiny size of the dining room.  Slightly cramped, and you might sit at the communal table, but has great food.  And even with a line of people outside they don't make you feel rushed.
author: Brooke N.

description: Came in for brunch and if I was basing this on the french toast alone, it would be 5 stars hands down as it was the best french toast I have EVER had (and I'm not even into french toast normally). However, I have to take away a little for the lack of accomodation. In addition to the french toast we order the eggs baked in a cazuela which is basically a very soup like egg dish. It came with three small pieces of toast which was no where near sufficient for the amount of soup. We asked if we could have a couple more slices and were told a simple flat out, "No". Not even a suggestion as to something else we could do. I couldn't believe they just wouldn't give us more bread! We'd even be willing to pay but the only option would be to order a huge basket of bread. We only needed a couple more slices. So that just took the stars immediately down. Despite my love for the french toast, I just don't think I can go back.
author: Lindsay A.

description:
It isn't everyday that you wake up, go about your daily routine and walk outside to have something great happen.  That is just not the way of things.  On occasion though, serendipitous winds come down from the that cloud that you didn't even see and collide with your intentions to walk through a city with completely aimless intent.  It is encounters like this, coupled with the brush of unexpected fortuity against your shoulder that lead you to places like Olea.

There I was, watching a confrontation between a cab driver on a cell phone sitting right there on the track refusing to turn left left and a cable car driver (the front man) screaming at him to get the hell out of the way.  I was really enjoying the energy of the skirmish.  It was a showdown in the sun and I had a front row seat.  Then I dropped my book.  I barely had a hold of it to begin with; just pinched between my index finger and thumb.  I turned to pick it up and noticed that the Red Door was no longer the Red Door.  It was new.  It was revamped.  It was, a brand new addition to the corner of California and Larkin.  Forgetting about the cab driver who needs to invest in a blue tooth headset, I walked in.  The layout was new to me - very simple, yet welcoming and clean.  It reminded me of Carmel.  I chose a seat facing the window and ordered a coffee and an omelet with cheese and spinach.  My waitress brought me an empty cup, which I initially thought was strange (that there wasn't any coffee inside the cup) but I opened up to "you can't kill the rooster" in "Me Talk Pretty One Day".  A few minutes pass and she comes back over with a great big French press carafe and then it all made sense.  "Let it sit for about a minute before you press down on the handle", she said.  I obeyed.  Then I poured...  I think this must be the first time that I've ever had French pressed coffee because it was fantastic - I think I'd remember this flavor.  Anyway, I went back to my book and kept trying not to laugh while sitting there alone at my table, but I really couldn't help it.  Sedaris is funny.  A man with a white coat came over and sat himself in a chair at the table next to me.

"I'm being committed", I said to myself.

"We're all out of spinach, my friend.  How about green beans instead?", he said.

(realizing this was the chef, not a member of the SF mental ward staff) I said, "hell man, you can use green beans or broccoli - I'm indifferent.  Whatever works best for you."  He smiled and tucked away behind the counter to the kitchen.

The food came out.  Superb!  I've never had green beans in an omelet, but I assure you this will not be the last occasion.

The sun shone in through the window and the music played on - Flamenco style.  I stayed until a couple came in and sat next to me and ask the blinds be pulled shut...  Entitlement-centric bastards.

I'll be back here for sure.
author: Benjamin G.

description: Olea has hit the spot as my number one restaurant near my house. Amazing! Good for both brunch on Sundays and dinner any other day of the week. You can even get blue bottle coffee to go if you don't want to sit down for a meal. Moving on, the restaurant is really small--one really big table that seats 7-10 and five or six small two people tables. They also have a limited menu, but everything on the menu is always delicious--seriously, everything. When I've gone for brunch, which is twice now, I've had to get the burger AND the challah custard toast. The burger comes with thin cut fries and is just the right size to get you full. The French toast practically melts in your mouth. I need my salty and sweet. I can never decide between the two! And I don't have to! Great food and great people. Try this place out.
author: Maureen B.

description: Seriously.. the challah custard toast.. INSANE. Like a perfect cross between my mom's french toast and my favorite bread pudding from a restaurant back east.  It's a pretty hefty portion, I had to use some fierce self control to not devour the whole thing in minutes.  There weren't many strawberries, but when I got to a bite that had strawberry in it there was a party in my mouth!  Pair this with some blue bottle fresh press and all will be right in the world, even if only for the short time you spend inside this adorable little restaurant.  Can't wait to go back!!
author: Jen R.

description: The Wait is a bit long but the food was great and the service was good. I have no complaints and iif your looking for somewhere to go for brunch/breakfast its always a good option
author: Amy J.

description: Came here for breakfast and it was delicious. I have been here for dinner and liked the dinner a little bit more.  Had a nice time with my friend and really enjoyed my french press blue bottle coffee.  I would recommend it for a nice low key breakfast.
author: andrea g.

description: Adorable little restaurant right in Nob Hill.  Came here for brunch with about 9 friends - totally didn't realize how small and quaint the place was though!  We waited a while before there was a big enough table to fit all of us...we had all decided on our order, but the waiter explained that there was only "eggs baked in a cazuela" left and like 4 of us had wanted that.  Friendly -"oh no worries, I'll try something else" ensued and it ended up going to 1 friend (who of course let us all try a little).  I ordered the Omelet with sausage and cheese - pretty tasty.  And others tried the niman ranch burger, pulled pork sandwich (also only 1 left - busy day?) - and everyone was raving about the food.   Definitely a nice atmosphere for brunch!
author: Karen T.

description: This is an updated review and the five stars is for their brunch. Nothing comes close to Olea. The challah bread french toast is divine!
author: Esme V.

description: We had a really lovely brunch at Olea on a sunny Sunday a few weeks ago. Our friends have become regulars at this little spot, and it's not hard to understand why. The servers are so friendly, the restaurant is cozy and airy at the same time, and the food is delicious. My french toast was amazing, as were the eggs, salads, and apps that my friends ordered. Add some strong coffee and fresh squeezed OJ to the mix, and it's a perfect brunch! We'll definitely make frequent trips to Olea from now on.
author: Caroline G.

description: Solid but a bit pricey for what it is.  I just don't know if I'd go back again.  But, the one part that was fun and tasted great was the coffee!  Gotta love French press.
author: Carol S.

description: Came here on Sunday for bruch with my BF. The burger could have been better, but their French Toast is the best in SF!  The iced coffee I had was yummy as well.  I will be back when I'm in the mood for french toast.
author: H. A.

description: I'd heard about Olea from some friends and decided to give it a try. What an awesome brunch place! I had the OJ which was super fresh and for my main I had the challah bread with cinammon and strawberries on top. Great choice using strawberries since they are ripe and in season. Definitely will be returning here again.
author: Keyvan R.

description:
Challah. Custard. Toast. 

I ate at Olea's months ago for brunch and I still can't stop thinking about their french toast! It is THE best french toast that I've ever eaten. You have to try it for yourself! It's moist and just the right amount of sweet. I can't say enough good things about it!
author: Cecilia W.

description:
A friend and I tried Olea this past weekend based on the Yelp reviews I read.
We arrived around 12:30pm on Saturday and were seated in under five minutes.
We started with Bellinis, which were a lovely treat on such an unusually warm November day.
The French toast definitely lived up to the descriptions! Perfectly Yummy!!
My friend had the pulled pork sandwich and loved every bite of it.
Our brunch was worth every penny.
author: Jenny J.

description: Cozy, nice atmosphere, attentive staff. Limited menu but everything was very good. I had the persimmon salad and the clams + chorizo, both of which were tasty. BF had the Ono which I tasted and it was quite good too. Sour dough bread provided upon request was tasty. Would return again and see what they come up with as their menu purportedly changes frequently and uses local and organic ingredients.
author: Au N.

description: Extremely short menu; extremely bland food.  The whitest place you'll ever eat.
author: Jesse Z.

description:
what a great place to start off a sunday!  got there pretty early as there were only two large parties seated.  very quaint corner entry that challenges you as soon as you approach it - must stoop down a bit as the door and the handle are a bit shorter than usual.  not a very kid friendly place as i almost swept one little boy away while opening the door to walk inside.....there just isn't that much room for a kid or kids to "roam" around and explore.  the french press coffee (blue bottle) was tasty and warming.  the ambiance was cozy and the staff was extremely friendly and attentive.  my omelet with neiman ranch ham was delicious as was my date's french toast - very hearty and creamy.  

as always, yelp came through again!  thanks all!
author: Grant T.

description: Get the scrambled eggs. They come on a roll, complete with a slice of tomato and bacon and a side of greens. It really is tragic that I discovered this place after moving out of the 'hood, but even so, I'm becoming a regular bruncher.
author: Carolyn C.

description: The food was okay, but too expensive for a brunch. I got an omelette that came with no bread, and when I asked for it, the waitress told me that I should order some toast (and pay for it, of course).
author: Silvia P.

description: After living 2 blocks from Olea for the last year, we moved to a new neighborhood a month ago.  I already miss our weekly dinner of Gabe's cuisine and good friendship.  Olea, you are wonderful.  Truly a hidden gem in SF.
author: Tim C.

description: i came here during a quick conference stop in SF a while back & yelped for a brunch place before my colleagues & i had to head out of the city... and i give it 4 stars for the custard toast. omg. i have NEVER had such amazing toast before.. it's so soft, so scrumptious, and i wanted to eat it all day.. and it wasn't even the dish i ordered. oops. had to restrain myself from reaching across the table to scarf down the rest of my friend's dish. The restaurant itself is a very small venue, very nicely done on the inside and we went with a pretty large group and they were fabulous at accommodating and squeezing us in! I would definitely go back with a more intimate group to sit near the window and munch on some brunch. yummers.
author: Jo C.

description: I went for brunch for the second weekend in a row, it's just fantastic.  The french toast is the best i've ever had, and the blue bottle coffee keeps me coming back.
author: G W.

description: This is a cute little brunch place that is reasonably priced. The coffee comes in a french press (you can order 2 or 4 cups) so you know it's fresh. I ordered the flat omlette and my friend ordered the pork sandwich with fries. We both really liked our dishes! The food comes out fairly quickly and the servers are nice. I live one block away so I'll def be coming here more often!
author: Jane M.

description: Waited 50 minutes for a shared table.  Waited 10 minutes for the waiter to take our order.  Waited 25 minutes for our food to arrive at the table.  As you can tell the one star is for the long wait and poor service.  The food was very good but not worth waiting this long.  I cannot believe they do not have reservations.  It is 2010 have they not heard of open table.  Keep in mind this was for a one course meal.
author: Allen B.

description:
i really want to give this place 1 star for the experience we had to go through just to eat here. i'm certainly no stranger to waiting to be seated, but my boyfriend and i showed up at 11 and were told that several tables had their checks and we would likely be sat within 20 minutes. the host did tell us that some people linger and you never can tell, but an hour and a half later we were still waiting. so listen to me, party of two middle aged blonde women...get the hell up! i finally planted my butt right in front of their window and sat down hoping the view of my ass would move things along. it did not.

the wait madness aside, we have driven by many times since to guage the line just to eat here again. of course, it's always packed and we haven't had the chance to go again but my god, we drive by like salivating dogs.

we ordered the french toast as an appetizer and i had a flat omelet with roasted corn, spinach, and cheese. people, as i think about the perfectly sweet wonderful taste of that corn, i am actually drooling. TRUST. who would think that someone would dream of the taste of corn? but i have to say, it was fantastic. i can't wait for the day when i actually wake up early and get there ahead of the masses and can be sat without developing age spots in the interim.

i want to tell y'all to go here but then i'm just going to have to punch you if you're ahead of me in line.
author: marisa g.

description: I am no-where close to vegan, but I almost always get the vegan entree, because it never fails to impress my mind, fill my tummy, and dance on my tastebuds.
author: Jen X.

description: Came in here for dinner for 2 on a thursday. The place was quite quiet so we got to choose a table anywhere. the menu is small but delicious. We started with steamed clams, which were delicious. We then split the duck breast and the sea bass. The bass was quite good, but the duck breast was cooked and seasoned perfectly. I'm not sure i've had a better duck breast anywhere. This place needs to have more people in there, especially for a place that could be a great neighborhood spot.
author: Rich B.

description:
My partner and I had dinner here last night, a Saturday, at just after 6, and left feeling that the only thing that was a damned shame about the whole experience was that every table in the place wasn't filled. 

In this immediate neighborhood, while on a short-term stay, I have found most of the restaurants to be inexpensive and inadvisable if you're looking to do anything but satisfy your bare daily caloric requirements. We kept getting whiffs of delicious things when passing Olea, though, so we ventured in. 

It's a timeless little place where it seems that you might be anywhere in the world--perhaps Paris, Italy,...? The colors are serene, it's spotlessly clean, there are simple flower arrangements on the large tables, and you are welcomed into a tiny little community for an evening when you walk in. Since it was so early when we arrived, there was only one other diner, and we engaged in a short but friendly conversation with him and the waiter before our food arrived. We were already thinking that this would be our favorite place in the neighborhood if we lived here. 

I had ordered a vegan quinoa and veggie dish, and my partner had the fish. He loved his right away, saying that he often wishes he could get food just like this--beautifully prepared, high-quality ingredients without overpowering seasoning, just balanced, honest flavors. At first bite I thought of mine, well, it is very simple, but by the third bite I was savoring every delicious bit. We also had the chocolate pot au creme with sea salt and berries, and though I'm not actually a big fan of salt with my dessert, we both loved this too. 

Our waiter, Steven, and the gentlemen in the kitchen (which is one corner of the establishment and totally visible) were so nice to us that I only wanted to patronize their establishment again all the more. We will definitely be back, and will tell others about this wonderful little find.
author: Wendy F.

description:
I give this place a solid four stars for brunch, and three stars for dinner.  Really cool atmosphere inside.  As others have said, the French Toast really is top notch.  Had the blue bottle coffee, which, if you like coffee, you are pretty much assured to be a fan.  The pulled pork sandwich is served like a Vietmanese banh mi sandwich with carrots, cilantro and cabbage -- if you like a classic pulled pork with cole slaw, this is a really nice way to mix it up.  

I had the burger for dinner, which was definitely good, but I've had much better -- and it was a little too done for a medium rare order.  I really liked the fries -- they were just about perfect.
author: Luke P.

description:
Olea is an entirely warm experience... the food, the wine, the service, and the owners are all wonderful.  The ambiance at Olea is perfect for friends and for romantic nights out.  This is because the prices are reasonable, the menu is eclectic, and everything is enjoyable!
My boyfriend and I have been in for both brunch and dinner, and have tried some of the most creative and yummy dishes.  
My favorite brunch so far was the crab and organic egg scramble, served with a fresh baked croisant.  My mouth still waters thinking about it!  For dinner my boyfriend was blown away by the braised short ribs, that literally fell off the bone...no steak knife needed!Everything is organic and is made with whole foods!  We had great service every time we have gone to Olea, and the owner and co-owner the chef, have come to the table to chat and inquire about or experience, and they are both so welcoming!  We look forward to every meal at Olea!  Go try it!
author: Sweet C.

description: Great little spot - an unexpected surprise. Communal table. Nice menu. Great staff. Very warm and welcoming place, but dressy/refined enough for a nice date/dinner. Mixed older/younger crowd. Steak was excellent. I had duck, which I rarely order, but I enjoyed it. Servings were just the right size - not large at all, but enough to satisfy without overfeeding. I'll be back for sure.
author: Bowen D.

description:
food - 5; service 5; atmosphere 4 (nice open kitchen); value 3.5

So good we went 3 sundays in a row for brunch.  the pull pork sandwich and the french toast are THAT good.  did i mention blue bottle cofee?  yum.  egg dishes are good but doesn't have the same wow factor.

warm neighborhood restaurant type size but be prepared for hard parking and a potential wait as the place is TINY.
author: Stacy N.

description: We were looking for a new place for brunch and found this little gem near the Lumiere Cinema in Russian Hill.  The restaurant is small but homey and well lighted, and our server was very attentive without being obtrusive.  While the menu is a bit limited, it is carefully thought out and is based on availability of the freshest ingredients.  I ordered the scrambled eggs on bread, with bacon and tomato.  It turns out this was served as a sandwich, on a wonderfully fresh slice of Acme bread.  The combination of flavors and textures made the dish absolutely sublime.   My partner had the omelette with asparagus, pork tenderloin and a reddish pepper sauce . . . out of this world.  The coffee is Blue Bottle, served in a french press, and was superb.  Not a cheap brunch (the entrees are priced in the $10-13 range), but well worth it.  We can't wait to check this place out for dinner.   Due to the small number of tables, reservations are highly recommended.
author: Alan S.

description: Excellent food, service. Local and healthy. Salmon, peaches/cheese/greens with flatbread salad, chocolate mousse-like desert. Delicious. Atmosphere is cozy. Walkable from Nob Hill. I'd go back in a hearbeat!
author: Lynn N.

description: Living in Nob Hill is wonderful. It's centrally located, quiet, safe, beautiful and I can walk to work in less than 20 minutes. The biggest downside is the lack of good, quality food in the area. Seriously, most of the restaurants I can think of wanting to go to are in the Mission. But Olea is the answer to this problem. You want locally sourced, seasonal, fresh, interesting and DELICIOUS food? Go to Olea.
author: Jen R.

description: What a place for weekend brunch - and I felt warm and welcomed when dining alone. The Chef Gabrielle is very talented and a master in his miniscule kitchen. Wait staff couldn't be nicer. Returned for dinner and delighted with everything we had. Brunch reeled me in and dinner brought me back again and again.
author: Judi B.

description: This place has amazing french toast. I want it in my mouth. Now!
author: Luke R.

description:
a little intoxicated from the rolling ripe tannins in our malbec and jetlagged (just got back from 3 weeks in my birth country), i'm logging into my dusty yelp account to share this most welcoming home meal...

olea took over the cosy little corner at larkin and california, previously occupied by the red door cafe.  we'd put it off for a while, coming here. but now, i know this is a place you can come any night to just relax and just be yourself, receive knowledgeable, yet personal and friendly service (ryan) and enjoy a fresh, organic, colorful, healthy, and truly delicious meal (organic green salad, sourdough bread, vegan rice dish, seafood stew and french dessert were all perfectly prepared.)  

the chef had this caring and serious, yet non-chalant way about him - the way he cooked (you can see from the tables) as closing time approached, he read the paper, like he was fully occupied, and yet a part of his mind found it's way to the final bites of our meal, sharing with us his mexican upbringing and passion.

i want to take my aunt, quite the gourmand back in japan, here.  my little sis too.  it's a little off the beaten path so you may be able to get by without reservations for a little while more.  we'll be back soon.
author: Haru K.

description: I love it when a restaurant can get the simplest things right - and more than that, it presents the essence of the ingredients honestly and harmonically. What did we have? Basil mushroom omelette and french toast. So simple but so good.
author: Pei-Chin W.

description: What a wonderful little spot on the corner of Larkin and Cali. Warm, inviting atmosphere with a friendly staff. Chef definitely knows what he is doing in the small, open kitchen. Had the most scrumptious butternut squash and thyme omelet for brunch along with a well-priced and oh so delish prosecco. Nothing extravagant here, just really good, well excecuted food with fresh and seasonal ingredients in a classically cool atmosphere.
author: Jane I.

description: Organic food with clean flavors. It didn't blow me away as a top brunch spot, but the atmosphere was soothing and the service was attentive but not pretentious.
author: Madeline N.

description: Well, i can't say the place was terrible. Just not my cup of tea. Too many purees whic to me is kind of like baby food. I guess everything is sustainable which is great.. but couldn't appreciate the quality cause everything was swimming in mush!
author: Michelle D.

description: Outstanding across the board- duck was amazing, accompanied by the various "stuff" that came with it (little flavorful seeds of something, etc.).  Tiny place, so you can sort of see the chef doing his thing.  Will return.
author: Daniel R.

description: the eggs in the cazuela, a must...simple yet delicious...fries were delicious too, have to try the french toast next time, and they have blue bottle coffee!! the wait can be long, since the restaurant is small....def. get there early.
author: Monster E.

description: This place far exceeded my (already high) expectations.  Amazing fresh squeezed orange juice, delicious Blue Bottle cappuccino, and one of the best omelets I've ever had - kale, swiss chard, mozzarella, and almonds.  Delicious and unique!  Fully worth the 30 min wait, and I will definitely be coming back.
author: Sara B.

description: I love this restaurant. My only complaint is that they are not open for lunch anymore. If you're reading this OPEN FOR LUNCH dammit!
author: Adam K.

description: Practically a subterranean restaurant!  Excellent medium rare hamburger, replete with grilled onions, tomato and housemade aioli!  Good table service.
author: M. B.

description:
maybe i've turned into a french-toast snob (or at least a brunch snob) from living in Boston the last two years... but this place (and san francisco in general) is pretty.. unexciting.

i went with a friend for sunday brunch, we didn't have to wait at all, which was nice, but the menu is pretty limited, and not exactly cheap. there are a few breakfast-type items (eggs, and one french-toast option), a few lunch/dinner-type items (pork chops i think were on there..?), and that's it!

i had the flat omelet, which was boring, and my friend (another boston french-toast-aholic) had the so-called fabulous challah french toast. meh. we both decided it was just ok. I sincerely hope this is NOT what you san-franciscans consider great brunch (any suggestions??).

if you want really good challah french toast-- the super thick, fresh baked chocolate-batter-challah bread kind with more chocolate and some amazing raspberry sauce-- go to Zaftigs (oh boston, sometimes i miss you so much).
author: M M.

description: So I finally had the french toast at Olea this past weekend and let me tell you... it was the most delicious, softest, cinnamon-y, melt-in-your-mouth french toast I have EVER had. Not to mention the strawberries! My mouth waters at the mere thought of it. In fact, I think I can still smell the cinnamon... MMMMMMMMMMM. We (there were three of us) also ordered TWO french-pressed blue bottle coffees which, although amazing, were definitely overpriced (we spent $20 on coffee alone!), but I must admit, also very delicious. The service was great and the atmosphere was cozy. Although I was bent on having the french toast (and also convinced my two friends to do the same) I will definitely go back to try everything else on their menu!
author: M K.

description:
Best hamburger in nob hill. The aioli sauce is delicious.
The quality of the meat (niman ranch) is wonderful.
And unlike most sloppy hamburgers you can taste each ingredient including the cheese.

The shoestring fries were awesome. It woulld be nice if they added some kind of additional seasoning other than salt, but still great fries.

The portion for a $13 can't be beat, especially in nob hill.
I highly recommend this place if your looking for a great burger.
author: Anonymous S.

description: I've had brunch here several times now and dinner once.  Overall, this is a great place that I'm glad to have in the neighborhood.  The custard challah bread (their version of french toast) is to die for!!!
author: Henry L.

description: Probably my favorite brunch in San Francisco if it wasn't for the high price. The combination of the french toast and french press Blue Bottle coffee is pretty amazing, but $50 before tip for brunch for 2 is a little high for a regular place.
author: Chris B.

description:
Best burger in town.  The combination of Niman Ranch beef, house made aoli, and *mild* cheddar cheese was wonderful.  My wife and I shared a delicious salad and she had the shrimp and vegetable main course, which she liked very much.  Wine by the glass were excellent.

I can't give it a fifth star yet because I've only dined there once.  Going back soon, though.
author: seth k.

description:
challah.... challah, where art thou?  the challah french toast is SO good.  my brother recently got the fluffy egg smoked bacon sandwich, and the saltiness of the bacon made my mouth yearn for another bite.  but he didn't want to share.  the bread was delicious!  and i'm a total bread snob, so it's rare for me to say that.  love sitting at the communal table... of course, no one has sat with me yet other than the people i've come with.  but the idea that some people might sit with us is always fun!  

service is friendly, and the atmosphere is sunny and warm.  woot woot!
author: Karina V.

description:
Been here twice (in 1 week) so far and it is AMAZING!  So many lovely little touches here.  They have done a great job with such a small space; the minimal decor, soothing green color palette, and below-street-level feel make it a little getaway on a busy SF street (complete with cable cars, so you still know SF is nearby)!  The ambience is romantic but also very sophisticated, and the waitstaff couldn't be friendlier.

Definitely order the challah custard toast and a french press blue bottle coffee.  You can't go wrong with that.  The pulled pork sandwich is a perfect lunch, and the prices are completely reasonable.

Please support this emerging restaurant in these hard economic times.  I know I'm going back next weekend!
author: Matthew A.

description: The 5 stars are for the custard toast, Olea's version of french toast but with challah. Service was great. French press was delicious. My boyfriend's burger was amazing, and the price tag was reasonable for the quality.
author: Katherine D.

description:
Their Challah Custard Cinnamon French Toast is some of the best FT I've ever had.  It's so tasty that I didn't even need syrup - and I usually drown my waffles/pancakes/french toast in syrup, so that's saying a lot.  It also wasn't heavy and I didn't feel weighed down afterwards.  Awesome.  A friend got the burger and said it was excellent but a little small.

The staff was very friendly and the place had a good vibe.  On the downside the weekend brunch menu didn't have very many breakfast items, which is a little disappointing because I'm a huge breakfast person and there aren't many things I'd order besides the FT.  I'll definitely go back and plan to try it for dinner.
author: Marc G.

description:
good, not great. nothing special for a $50 brunch for 2
short wait around noon on a sunday, and everyone is very friendly
author: Lia A.

description: I went early (9:45 am) on a Saturday. Loved the cozy and warm, intimate space. Service was nice and unhurried. And, quite simply, it was: The. Best. French. Toast. Ever. Cinnamon custard challah with fresh strawberries. Heavenly. The egg dishes looked incredible too. I will definitely be back. And I will definitely go early, as there was quite a wait by the time I left.
author: Pidge M.

description: just went there yesterday for dinner...the panna cotta was awesome.  I like this place.
author: Cheester O.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but sadly they were a disappointment. We arrived a few minutes before 2 other tables for a Saturday night dinner and had bad service--both other tables were finished with dessert before we even got our entrees! I even had to send my glass of wine back because it tasted moldy. The food was also a disappointment--they stress their use of fantastic ingredients but somehow they were not put together in such a great way. The food lacked flavor and a sense of unity.

Definitely overpriced for what it is!
author: k. v.

description: Nothing to write home about.  Went here for brunch around 1:30pm and we sat right down-definitely a plus! Ordered the omelete with corn, mushrooms, onions and cheedar.  I asked for egg whites and waiter came back with regular eggs.  He apologized and sent them back, but I had to wait an additional 15 minutes for cooks to make another the way I originally ordered it (and the waiter still charged me for the egg whites in the end!). It was a substandard omelette.  Tt lliterallly had 4 pieces of corn, two mushrooms, and a few small onions.  Definitely not worth the $13 I paid.  It only came with a side of mixed greens.  I could make a better, more hearty version at home!  That said, I am giving 3 stars as my bf ordered the eggs baked in a cazuela with tomato sauce.  It was a unique and delicious dish. Spent a total of $35 for only two entres (+tax, tip).  Over priced and does not live up to my expectations.  Won't be going back.
author: Margot M.

description: this is a place i wanted to LOVE.  cute, neighborhood restaurant with fresh ingredients.  based on all the reviews of this place, i expected great things and unfortunately, have been disappointed.  i've tried olea a few times, including the french toast and house favorites, but sadly there's nothing spectacular that makes anything memorable.
author: Helen T.

description: All I have to say is Challuah bread french toast and blue bottle coffee. Its a great brunch place. I have taken many out of town guest here and never a complaint.
author: Linda N.

description: Had the scrambled eggs w/ tomato and bacon on a roll, w/ salad on the side for brunch.  Clean, simple, delicious.  Place is pretty small, has a nice feel.
author: Jesse L.

description: OLE for Olea! It was happenstance that I stumbled into this new venue in my Nob Hill Neighborhood late this Saturday  morning, after being pampered at my favorite Recharge Spa which is just a few doors up the street (now this combo on 1 block could be addictive).  The entire scenario was so welcoming I ended up staying for brunch,solo, as in all by myself with no book or newspaper in hand. Stating I was only inquiring as to the new place, I was warmly greeted, not pressed into staying,  and the Host Glen was one of the Owners, a savvy and effervescent man. Pointing out small tables for 2 that I could dine at, he hit the right button when he showed me the"communal table" - why not? Met some great ladies, chatted over our plates and my experience was divine.  If you've ever had an omelet in France - then you know what real egg dishes are and this chef (the other partner!) created an exquisite moist scrambled eggs and prosciutto cotto. These eggs rank way up on top of my foodie taste buds and I can't wait to return to order what I didn't: the organic eggs baked in a little dish with chorizo - more OLE for Olea. I'm so happy this establishment has come to our Nob Hill neighborhood - now let's all go for lunch and dinner and support a totally affordable and aesthetic restaurant. This is a winner for our taste buds and Visa cards! PS - It's the perfect venue for a private party , maybe 24 diners: intimate and the chef is right there for you.   I'm going back this week to try the take out lunch (came home with all the menus!).
author: Guido B.

description: Were in San Francisco for a week and had a lot of disappointing meals at famous and fancy restaurants.  Gave Olea a try and wow!  Very small, simple space.  Short menu relying on mostly local ingredients prepared beautifully.  Salads were gorgeous greens, the most delicious cucumber I've ever had, lightly dressed with the best feta ever.  I had rock cod and my husband had pasta--both spectacular.  Dessert was an olive oil, corn meal, orange cake served with whipped cream and preserved cherries.  We only got one serving and a fistfight almost broke out. . .it was that good. Kudos to the chef and out waiter who was very professional and yet warm and friendly.  Loved this place!
author: Jane D.

description: The host lied to us too-- only, we didn't forgive him.  I called and made a reservation for three. I asked for something next to a wall or a little more private if he could and he said he'd try.  Now, while I figured I had about a 50-50 chance of actually getting my request, I was not at all prepared for what he ended up offering us.  3 seats at some one else's table!  WITH the other people!  I'm not talking about 2 tables close together or something, I'm talking about ONE 8 top with 5 people already sitting at it.  Are you kidding me?  Is this Benihana?  If I want to do the counter thing, I'll go someplace where I'm not about to drop $200+ on a nice dinner.  I really think Olea needs to tell a person that they might be forced to share a table with other diners when they make the reservation-- not after they've gotten all ready and driven all the way over there with no other dinner plans.  We refused to endure the uncomfortable setting in this place and left.  Thank god for Yelp mobile... or we would have never eaten that night.
author: Matt L.

description: Brunch review:  Truly kind staff & delicious food.  Egg dishes change all the time & don't repeat until the next season/year.  The challah custard french toast is actually as good as everyone says.  Just prepare for a wait.
author: m c.

description: everyone already knows to order the french toast with Blue Bottle coffee. but if you're not in the mood for breakfast, the pulled-pork sandwich worked for me.  $8.50 for a mimosa is pretty grip, though.
author: J M.

description: When you walk into Olea, you feel as if you're entering a neighbor's Victorian cottage, rather than a commercial restaurant. The menu changes every week depending on what is in season, and the chef and servers are welcoming and friendly. There is always one vegan dish that is usually quinoa based and there is often a vegan salad. We started with a mixed greens salad with beets and pumpkin seeds that was delicious. The beets were a very nice touch, and the salad dressing was salty and zippy. We then shared the quinoa dish, which had some very nice mushrooms and other veggies in it and was pretty yummy. One thing I noticed was that a lot of the side items to the meat dishes sounded really delicious. One meat dish came with green lentils and some of other veggies that sounded really good, and I thought it would be really nice if they would offer them à la carte or offer a second vegan dish comprised of those items (no extra work needed!). I do love a good quinoa pilaf, but it's also something I can make on my own pretty easily. Some veggie protein like lentils or fava beans or something of that nature and/or some fresh seasonal veggies would be a nice addition to the menu. We paired our whole meal with a reasonably price bottle of Prosecco that I think had a bit of residual sugar on it. Overall, it was a lovely meal, I would just encourage the chef to offer a bit more on the vegan front.
author: Jeani H.

description: Just like everyone says - custard french toast was excellent, coffee fabulous and flat omelette superb.  Don't worry about not getting enough food - portions are plenty large.  We went early Saturday for brunch (around 11:30 am) and didn't have to wait for a table.  When we drove by later, there was quite a line and the place is tiny.  We've been back several times and the later you go, the more you wait - but it is always worth it.
author: Amy W.

description: I've been to Olea for brunch awhile back and remembered enjoying their food & service. This place is cute (aka small!) and because of that, I made reservations for dinner last night. To my surprise, they were not busy (only 2 tables were occupied) considering it was a Friday night. I had the clams & my husband had the sole and we were both very happy with our dish. We ended our meal with the chocolate pot de creme which was good but I didn't like the sweet sauce that was layered on top of the chocolate. Our waiter was very nice, attentive, prompt, and helpful. I will definitely be back to have brunch to refresh my memory!
author: Xuyen H.

description: I visited Olea for Saturday brunch - very cute setting and beautiful flowers which make it a cozy spot. The service and food are great.  I had the eggs baked in a cazuela with moroccan tomato - really enjoyed it! It comes in a shallow dish, has two eggs baked in a light tomato base, and I think it's got bread crumbs or something baked in there with it.  It comes with few slices of crostini - excellent together.  My friends and I shared the french press coffee and each had a mimosa.  The coffee was superb, and you could tell they use fresh squeezed oranges in the mimosa, very pulpy!  We split a side of fries which were great.  I tried a bit of the french toast (challah custard toast with korintji cinnamon sugar and fresh yerena farms berries) that my sister ordered... YUM! Fantastic! I am not usually a fan of french toast, but Olea's got some GOOD french toast - I highly recommend it! This is a great spot, I'd go back again for sure.
author: Christine Y.

description: Challah Custard Toast...AKA the best french toast you'll have in SF!  I was muy impressed with the french toast with fresh berries.  It was nice and soft on the inside without being gooey.  I also ordered a tall glass of the $6 OJ which I proceeded to devour in 2 minutes it was so good.  Not a good ratio of consumption to spending, but I enjoyed it.  My bud Madhu had a nice healthy salad since there aren't too many vegetarian options on the menu and she doesn't eat eggs so I tortured her while I smiled happily eating my french toast.  We saw some frites go by and couldn't help but ordering a plate for ourselves.  I hate when people order fries because when I see them I'm compelled by the power of the potato to order me some.  Death.  All in all, very impressed by brunch at Olea.  Waiter was super attentive and helpful.  He refilled my glass of water like 5 times unprompted.  Small place, great service, excellent food.  Olea ranks right up there with Universal Cafe in my book for best brunch places in SF.
author: Dave L.

description: this place is super refreshing in every way - its this place thats sort of sunken in, you walk down a few steps from the street into a little well-lit and sunny cafe-like place with friendly service. their salad is VERY fresh, and so is their orange juice. i think this place is for people who are looking for brunch, but not a hefty, 5000 calorie brunch.
author: Angie K.

description: It really might be the best french toast in the city.
author: Anna J.

description: My gf and I just ate here for brunch and want to come back for dinner. I had a savory baked egg dish, and she had a sweet and fluffy plate of french toast. Best and unique brunch food I've had in a long time. The atmosphere is casual and, for lack of a better word, lovely. The service was just the same. Go here. It's really freakin' good.
author: MJ S.

description: the french toast is as fantastic as everyone says it is. olea serves richly organic/sustainable cuisine and there is a definite difference in the quality of their food. brunch at olea is simply delectable.
author: Blythe H.

description: just an update:  ive been back to olea for brunch again, and also had the chance to go for dinner. couldnt have been happier.  we had a large party and were able to eat leisurely and without being rushed.  we had a fabulous malbec, wonderful bread and excellent service.  everyone enjoyed their time.  i really cant say enough about this place, love it!
author: Kristin K.

description: I'm not a fan of fennel.  Actually, the taste of anything coming close to fennel (like anise) will make my mouth pucker up for hours on end (It may have been the bad reaction to ouzo I had one time in Greece).  Which is why this place surprised me.  Now mind you, I didn't realize there would be fennel in the food.  In fact, I was there with three other people, we all got different dishes, and there was fennel everywhere.  Apparently, it was a fennel themed evening, and you know what?  I actually enjoyed my meal.  Fennel spores, which are very light in flavor, the waiter informed me after I nastily asked him if there was fennel in the food, aren't that bad, as it turns out.  Indeed, the steak I ordered was cooked perfectly, was seasoned well, the service was great and the place was quite charming.  And given that this eatery is literally 1 block away from my apartment, well, I think I'll be going back.
author: Hoot A.

description: Visit #2. A birthday dinner for a friend of mine. We started with roasted bitter greens with preserved lemons, olives and house made farmer's cheese and flatbread. The lemon added a really nice flavor and took the bite out of the greens. We shared two dishes... shortribs over polenta with a side of beans (the beans didn't really add anything to an otherwise spectacular dish. The polenta was creamy and buttery and perfect and is making me drool right now.) California white bass with chickpeas and a light orange peel/onion/pepper sauce had a delicate flavor that didn't overpower the dish but the pepper added a nice little kick at the end. I tipped the staff off when I made the reservation and they were kind enough to put a candle on our dessert (warm vanilla brioche bread pudding with amarena cherries. so crazy good. I think my friend wanted to lick the dish). Add Blue Bottle coffee and accompanied by a nice bottle of syrah with a total of about $100 for the two of us and it was a perfect night.
author: Emily L.

description: This place was yuuuuumy! I got the scrambled egg sandwich with bacon which was so good. I shared the yogurt with fresh fruit, honey, and granola with my boyfriend - scrumptious! ...and he got the pulled pork sandwich... also great. The fresh orange juice was delicious as well!
author: Caitlin B.

description:
we went for brunch and were lucky enough to snag the last free table AND get our order in before a large group that was seated before us (fistpump). 

everything we had was exceptional. i drool at the thought of their challah custard toast and coffee. between the four of us we shared 4 breakfast dishes and two desserts.  we rang up a $100 bill, but reasonable for the amount and quality of food we had. service was a tad slow but warm and helpful (ask them what their favorites are).  i've been hunting for a custard-toast recipe of my own, but i can't get it quite right. *shrug* it may be time to go back!
author: serbear n.

description: i came here with a friend one random thursday a while ago and the food was delicious! didn't have to wait for a table because my friend was already there so that worked out. i had the clams which were yummy and my friend had the cod which was also delicious. the service was great! our server was really friendly and attentive. in fact, he recommended that we come try brunch and that's just what we did! we came that saturday to try this amazing french toast everyone is talking about and that is exactly what it is -- amazing! and of course, the service was excellent yet again.
author: C. T.

description: This place is nice, but I think it might be a one time brunch place.  As I overheard the man next to me call it "cool," I knew this isn't a place I could go to on a regular basis.  The service was above and beyond friendly, the setting decent minus the rock music that came on blaring the calm of Sunday morning from my reach and smacking me with a wake-up call I won't forget.  Even sitting within distance of a neurotic sister my food was delicious.  The custard filled french toast sprinkled with cinnamon was nothing less than lovely, the texture, the scent, each bite lead to another.  The split peas, radish, and eggs cooked in the claypot were an ideal brunch item, lite and hearty.  The toast would have been more enjoyable if it were not for the jelly that came out of the store bought jar, still holding the shape of it's original container, and more like something from a science experiment than a breakfast spread.  However, the standing ovation is for the french pressed blue bottle coffee, simple, classic and flawless, three cheers and three stars..... :)
author: Steven K.

description: After a big walk up 37 flights Climbing for a Cure for Cystic Fibrosis (sorry for the shameless plug) my boyfriend and I worked up quite an appetite--the line at Dotties was too long, so we headed back to our hood but were in the mood for something new. Frankly, it feels like cheating to go to brunch a block away from Nob Hill Grille, seriously, cheating on someone. But the place looked cute and we'd been curious to try, and variety is the spice of life, right? We ordered mimosas which came in small flutes and took at really long time. BUT the good news is they have Blue Bottle coffee in a french press--it was great, even without the splenda--diabetics and weight watchers bring your own little fake sugar packets, they just have cubes of the real stuff. The menu is pretty limited and the one dish that really grabbed my attention-some baked egg dish with spicey tomato sauce and black beans, they said too a while--did I mention i was a hungry girl?  So my boyfriend and I both ordered the egg sandwich. It was good, but needed ketchup--since I was told there was no fake sugar I figured they wouldn't stoop so low as to have processed tomatoes, so I didn't ask. Overall the food was decent, it was nice to leave not feeling so full I couldn't move, but I wasn't totally impressed either.
author: Aly S.

description: This is becoming my favorite breakfast spot when I want more than just an omelet, and don't feel like waiting in line at Dottie's. Yes, the portions are smaller than a lot of other restaurants, but completely in line with what you would expect at a restaurant serving high quality food. I love the simple but unexpected flavors & combinations, and the staff has always been extremely friendly. The Blue Bottle coffee is a definite plus. The only reason I didn't give five stars is that I am slightly annoyed that they charge extra for toast ($2.50????). That's just stupid.
author: Eric S.

description: Love this place. Feels like I'm eating at grandma's house and the staff are very friendly.
author: Bay Area Truth Teller Z.

description: O! Olea!  This is the second time my wife and I ate at this lovely restaurant.  We are very satisfied.  We especially like the quality of the food--fresh, local, mostly organic, carefully selected, and masterfully prepared by the chef. Tonight we enjoyed a delectable dish of duck breast, its richness balanced by a pomegranate sauce. It was served with tasty sliced potatoes and turnips. We also had grilled hanger steak, cooked to tender perfection and served with a delicious cilantro sauce. Everything that the restaurant uses is of top quality, down to the salt! We ended our meal with a platter of Italian cheeses. Once again, thoughtfully selected. This is a place we will keep going back to.
author: N G.

description:
What is it about neighborhood restaurants that make you have simultaneously low and high expectations of them?   You're willing to put up with a lot with some places just for the sake of geographical convenience - sticky tables, creaky chairs, surly wait staff, and mediocre food.  But, when a new little spot opens up in your 'hood that seems like the restaurant manifestation of all you believe in regarding food (organic! seasonal! reasonably priced!), you just can't help thinking that it has the promise of being that perfect place around the corner that you've been longing for all this time.

Maybe it is unfair, but I was holding these lofty hopes up for Olea.  It had none of the aforementioned traits that I put up with in some restaurants I go to around the block.  In fact, it is undeniably a cute, warm nook of a restaurant, the kind that you can slip into and feel coddled in.  The waiters were charming and did a great job of putting diners at ease.  Also, the menu reads like a teaser - braised pork shoulder over all'uovo pasta and peas to me conjured up images of a luscious, darkly sauced hunk of tender meat over toothsome pasta, exactly the kind of dish you want on a fall evening when you've endured weather that dulls your senses.  Alas, out came five, bite-sized pieces of plain-ish pork on a nest of plain-ish ribbon-edged pasta.  Suddenly a dish that appeared like it could be a steal now seems like it's a little on the pricey side ($14.50).  Little gem lettuce salad ($7.50) reinforced that the kitchen has an overly restrained hand with flavor.  It was lightly dressed with a garlic vinaigrette and had no other accompaniments besides the leaves, though they were crisp and fresh.  I do like simple food, and appreciate Olea's concept.  However, I just wished that its "simple cooking" would carry a bit of punch as well.

I have faith in Olea.  I will probably try their brunch, which looks great on the menu, and perhaps give dinner another go-around, as it is so close to where I live.  But why settle for mediocrity like I do with those other places?  I'm rooting for it to be that perfect neighborhood spot that I'm still holding out for.
author: Rachel L.
